igbo: Anyi anaghi atu egwu Okorocha - ndị nkewa APC Imo

english: The APC in Imo State is famous as the so-called Restoration Group' said that they are not afraid of Rochas Okorocha.'
igbo: APC n'Imo steetị na-ekpo ọkụ ka ndị kpọrọ onwe ha 'Restoration Group' kwuru na Rochas Okorocha adịghị amapụ ha obi.

english: The controversy over who will succeed the APC Imo as governor in the 2019 general election still remains.
igbo: Esemokwu onye ga abụ onye ga-anọchịte anya ndị APC Imo dịka gọvanọ na ntụlịaka nke 2019 ka na-adakwa.

english: Remember that the issue was obvious this month, when they had 'Congress' to appoint a candidate from the party who will contest for governor.'
igbo: Cheta na esemokwu a pụtara ihe n'ọnwa a, mgbe ha mere nhazi akpọrọ 'Congress' a ga-eji họpụta onye ga-eji aha pati ahụ zọọ ọkwa gọvanọ.

english: Today, one of the separatists of APC called on journalists at the headquarters to express their views on the rivalry between APC members of the Imo state. According to APC spokesman, TOE Ekechi, they accuse Governor Okorocha of repeatedly violating them.
igbo: Taa, otu n'ime ndị kewapụtara n'otu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị APC kpọrọ ndị ntaakụkọ n'isi ụlọọrụ ha maka ị kọwa echiche ha n'esomokwu nke di n'etiti ndị APC nke Imo steeti.N'ọnụ okwu TOE Ekechi bụ onụ na-ekwuchitere otu a, ha na-ebo gọvanọ Okorocha ebubo na o nupuru iwu ji patu ha isi ọtụtụ oge.

english: Who will be the Governor of Imo Steet in 2019?
igbo: Onye ga-abụ Gọvanọ Imo Steet na 2019?

english: Can Okorocha afford his son-in-law to become the Governor of Imo State?
igbo: Okorocha ọ pụrụ imeli ọgọ ya Gọvanọ Imo steeti?

english: 'Four people have been arrested for stealing APC election votes. Ekechi said 'Okorocha has consumed all the funds in Imo state, and the Igbo and APC have rejected Okorocha in Imo State.' He went on to accuse Okorocha and Imo state legislature of not doing any work in the state.
igbo: A nwụchiela mmadụ anọ maka izu akwụkwọ ntuliaka APC Ekechi kwuru na 'Okorocha eriela ego niile dị n'Imo steeti, ndị Igbo na APC ajụla Okorocha n'Imo'Ọ gakwara n'ihu na-ebo Okorocha ndị omeiwu nke Imo steeti ebubo na ha anaghị arụ ọrụ ọbụla n'Imo steeti.

english: 'Ekechi said that they had about 40 videos which would serve as evidence in the election Congress made in Imo state.'
igbo: Ekechi kwuru na ha nwere ihe onyonyo ruru 40 ga-abụ ihe ga-akwụ dịka ihe akaebe ha na ntuliaka 'Congress' mere n'Imo steeti.

english: Restoration Group members said that they will return to Imo for election.
igbo: Ndị 'Restoration Group' si na ha ga alaghachị Imo maka ntụlịaka

english: They also said that Okorocha did not come back during the election because he was trying to ensure that his son-in-law takes over the governorship post in 2019.
igbo: Ha kwukwara na Okorocha a na-abataghị ntuliaka emere n'Imo steeti maka na ọ na-agba mbọ ihụ na ọgọ ya nwoke were ọchịchị gọvanọ n'afọ 2019.

english: The group also alleged that Okorocha was not honest when he mentioned that people were not part of the party.
igbo: Otu a na-ekwu kwa na Okorocha ekwughi eziokwu mgbe ọkpọro ndị mmadụ aha na ha esoghi na pati.

english: BBC Igbo asked Secretary to Governor Okorocha Governor Sam Onwuemeodo his view concerning everything the Restoration Group was saying but he told us nothing.
igbo: BBC Igbo jụrụ onye ode akwụkwọ Gọvanọ Okorocha bụ Sam Onwuemeodo ihe ochere banyere n'ihe niile ndị 'Restoration Group' na-ekwu mana ọ gwara anyị na-onweghị ihe ọ ga-ekwu banyere ha maka n'uche ya, ha emechala ihe ha nwereike ime.

english: They are exhausted, Onwuemeodo told us. Ekechi and his team said that they will come to Imo state for tomorrow's election being on May 18th.
igbo: Ike agwụla ha, Onwuemeodo gwara anyị.Ekechi na ndị otu ya kwuru na ha ga-abata Imo steeti maka ntụlịaka ga-eme echi bụ ụbọchi iri na asatọ nke ọnwa Mee.

igbo: Otu kwuburu ka ndị igbo bi n'ugwu hausa kwaralawa ekwuola na ha chọghị Buhari ma ọ bụ Atika dịka onyeisiala.

igbo: Otu kporo onweha 'The Coalition of Northern Groups' na bekee gwara onyeisiala Naịjirịa bụ Muhammadu Buhuri na onye chiburu dịka osote onyeisiala n'oge garaaga bụ Atiku Abubakar na ọ ga-adị mma maọbụrụ na ha abụọ wepuru aka n'ime ọsọ ị banye n'ọkwa ọchịchị dịka onyeisiala n'afọ 2019.

english: This group said that they were asserting that both Buhari and Atiku were more than 70 years old and that young people should be the ones who would rule the country now and in the future.
igbo: Otu a kwuru na ha na-ekwusi okwu ike makana ha abụọ bụ Buhari na Atiku karịrị afọ iri asaa na kwa na ndị ntorobia kwesiri ị bụ ndị ga-achị Naịjirịa ugbua na kwa n'iru.

english: They said that the former leaders who are now old are the most corrupt Nigerians, and it is time for the youths to take Nigerians to the promised land.
igbo: Ha kwukwara na ọ bụ ndị chiburu Naịjiria n'oge garaaga burukwa ndị ka goro nka bụ ndị mebiri Naịjirịa, na kwa oge eruola ndị ntorobia buru Naịjirịa gawa ala ekwere nkwa.

english: The group made this statement at the end of their meeting in Kaduna on Monday.
igbo: Otu ha kwuru okwu a n'ime akwụkwọ a dere na ngwụcha ọgbakọ ha na Kaduna n'ụbọchị Monde.

english: Atiku Abubakar has tried several times to become Nigerian president
igbo: Atiku Abubakar anwaala ugboro ole na ole ị bụ onyeisiala Naijiria

english: Recall that it was this group who asked the Igbo living in the northern part of Nigeria to go home
igbo: Cheta n'ọbụ ndị otu a sị ka ndị Igbo bị na mpaghara ugwu hausa kwara lawa.

igbo: Mana ọnụ na-ekwuchitere onyeisiala bụ Garba Shehu azaala otu a.

english: Shehu said that there is no law in Nigeria which said that someone who is more than 70 years of age cannot contest for the post of Nigerian president.
igbo: Shehu kwuru na onweghị iwu ọbụla na Naịjirịa kwuru na onye karịrị afọ iri asaa anaghị enwe ike ị so n'ọsọ ịzọ ọkwa ọchịchị dịka onyeisiala Naịjirịa.

english: Atiku Abubakar has not said anything yet concerning the matter.
igbo: Onweghị ihe Atiku Abubakar kwuru ugbua maka okwu a otu nke a na-ekwu.

igbo: Otu a kwukwara na ihe kachasị dị ha mkpa bụ ka gọọmentị leba anya na ntụlịaka maka ị nwere onwe nke a kpọrọ 'referendum' na bekee.

igbo: Bob manuel: A na-akpagbu ndị Igbo na Naịjirịa

english: A prominent Nigerian man in the film industry, Bobmanuel Odogwu has voiced his opinion on the situation of Igbo people in Nigeria.
igbo: Onye ama ama n'ihe nkiri na Naịjirịa bụ Bobmanuel Odogwu ekwuola uche ya gbasara ọnọdụ ndị Igbo n'ala Naịjirịa.

english: Nollywood actor, Bobmanuel Odogwu has said that the condition of the Igbo people in Nigeria is unfortunate.
igbo: Nwafọ Igbo ama ama n'ime ihe nkiri Nollywood bụ Bobmanuel Odogwu kwuru na ọnọdụ ndị Igbo na Naịjirịa bụ ihe nwute.

english: He said this when he had a conversation with BBC Igbo in Enugu.
igbo: O kwuru nke a mgbe ya na BBC Igbo nwere mkparịtaụka n'Enugwu.

english: Odogwu said that the Igbo were the first people in Nigeria, but they were persecuted and pushed to the side.
igbo: Odogwu kwuru na ndị Igbo bụ ndị mbụ na Naịjirịa, mana e bidoro na akpagbu ha ma kpagide ha n'akụkụ.

english: He said that after the Biafran war, the Igbo were deprived of their property.
igbo: O kwuru na mgbe a lụchara agha Biafra, na a naara ndị Igbo ihe niile ha nwere.

english: But within the 40 years, the Igbo started flourishing
igbo: Mana n'ime afọ iri anọ, ndị Igbo wee pultekwa dịka osiisi achara ma soro n'ihe niile a na-eme na Naịjirịa.

english: He went on to urge the Igbo to remain united and be part of the Nigerian politics with the right attitude.
igbo: Odogwu gara n'ihụ rịọ ndị Igbo ka ha nwee otu obi ma pụta n'okwu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị na Naịjirịa, i ji were ezi ọnọdụ ruru ha.

english: Here's what Nigerian kids need most now

english: On Children's Day, Nigerian children have said what they want the federal government to do for them.
igbo: Ụmụaka Naịjirịa ekwuola ihe ha chọrọ ka gọọmentị etiti mere ha dịka a na-eme emume ụbọchị ncheta ha.

english: Every May 27 of each year is a special day dedicated to commemorating all children in Nigeria.
igbo: Ọnwa Mee 27 n'afọ ọbụla bụ ụbọchị pụrụiche ekewapụtara maka ncheta ụmụaka niile nọ na Naịjirịa na ihe gbasara ha.

english: as they were celebrating Children's Day in 2018, Nigerian children have said what they want from the federal government.
igbo: Dika a na-eme emume ụbọchị ncheta ha nke afọ 2018, ụmụaka Naịjirịa ekwuola ihe ha chọrọ ka gọọmentị etiti mere ha.

english: The federal government as well as the international child protection agency, UNICEF have said that they will do everything in their power to stop child abuse.
igbo: Gọọmentị etiti nakwa ngalaba na-ahụ maka ụmụaka na mbaụwa niile akpọrọ UNICEF ekwuola na ha ga-eme ihe niile ike ha ruru iji wee kwụsị mwakpo ụmụaka .

english: See how people remember kids today
igbo: Lee etu ndị mmadụ si cheta ụmụaka taa

english: Today, many people remember children in different ways as the world commemorates children.
igbo: Ọtụtụ mmadụ chetara ụmụaka n'ụzọ dị iche iche taa ka ụwa niile na-eme mmemme ncheta ụmụaka.

english: A student
igbo: Nwaakwụkwọ

english: children are the future of Nigeria but people said that they are not getting the right kind of education in Nigeria.
igbo: Ụmụaka bụ ọdịnaihu Naịjirịa mana ndị mmadụ na-ekwu na ha anaghị enweta ezi nkuzi n'ụdị nkuzi dị na Naịjirịa ugbua

english: President Buhari started the program with a letter to the children where many prominent people joined in commemorating children, especially those in distress.
igbo: Onyeisiala BUhari ji akwụkwọ ozi o zigara ụmụaka taa wee bido ya bụ mmemme ebe ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ ọnụ na-eru n'okwu gakwara sonyere ụmụaka taa, tụmadị ụmụaka ndị nọ n'ahụhụ dị icheiche.

english: Some went to where the victims of Boko Haram camped while some went to other places.
igbo: Ụfọdụ gara ebe ndị agha Boko Haram chụsasịrị bi ebe ụfọdụ gara ebe ndị ọzọ dị icheiche.

english: Amalu Ngozi shows how the program took place in Enugu stadium today.
igbo: Amalu Ngozi gosiri etu ya bụ mmemme si gaa n'ọgbọ egwuregwu dị n'Enugwu taa.

english: what President Buhari has said about children today
igbo: Ihe 8 onyeisala Buhari kwuru maka ụmụaka taa

english: Buhari: Fight against child abuse
igbo: Buhari: Buo agha megide mwakpo ụmụaka

english: Here is a picture posted on Twitter from the office of the president showing how he remembers the kids;
igbo: Nke a bụ foto ụlọọrụ onyeisiala zipuru igosi etu o si echeta ụmụaka, ha zipuru n'igwe twitter;

english: On his part, the senate president, Bukola Saraki said that he went to where the victims live in Benue state,
igbo: N'akụkụ nke ya, onyeisi ndị ụlọomeiwu sineti bụ Bukola Saraki kwuru na ya gara ebe ogige ebe ndị oyiegwu chụsasịrị bi na Benue steeti,

english: He said that the children have no reason to be there but that they are future Nigerians.
igbo: O kwuru na ụmụaka enweghi ihe ha mere ha jiri nọrọ ebe ahụ mana ha bụ ọdịnaihu ala Naịjirịa.

english: On the other hand, former Vice president, Atiku Abubakar took to his twitter account that children should be remembered in order to make them happy.
igbo: N'aka nke ọzọ onye bụbu osote onyeisiala bụ Atiku Abubakar nọrọ n'akara twitter ya kwuo ka e cheta ụmụaka ma nọnyere ha, mee ka ha chịa ọchị.

english: The winner of the 2018 BBN movie, Miracle Ikechukwu did not hesitate to post his own message and was with some of the children. He said that our hopes will be fulfilled in the future if children are taken good care of.
igbo: Onye meriri ihe nkiri BBN nke afọ 2018 bụ Miracle Ikechukwu ekpeghikwa azụ ebe o dekwara ozi nke ya ma ga nọnyere ụfọdụ ụmụaka ma kwuo na olileanya anyị ga-abalị na mmezu ma e soo ha nke ọma.

english: Oluyemi Fasipe wrote his own message and said he reminds all Nigerians and foreigners about Leah Sharibu who was abducted by Boko Haram and has never returned.
igbo: Oluyemi Fasipe dere ozi nke ya ma kwuo na ya na-echetara ụmụ Naịjirịa niile na ndị mba ofesi maka Leah Sharibu bụ onye ndị Boko Haram kpọrọ ma na ha akpọghachitebeghi ya.

english: He said that other children are with their parents but this little girl is not with her parents, let not forget her.
igbo: O kwuru na ụmụaka ndị ọzọ na nne na nna ha nọ mana nwantakịrị nwaanyị a na ndị mụrụ ya anọghị, ka a ghara ichefu ya.

english: Deekachy wrote a heartbreaking story about a 9-year-old pregnant girl who he claimed to have seen during child birth.
igbo: Deekachy dere akụkọ na-agbawa obi gbasara nwantakịrị nwaanyị dị afọ 9 dị ime nke o kwuru na ya hụrụ ebe ọ chọrọ ịmụ nwa.

english: He explained that the little girl had been married at the age of eight years and he thanked such children.
igbo: Ọ kọwara na ọ lụrụ di n'afọ asatọ wee na-ekele ụmụaka niile ndị dị etu ahụ.

english: Osinachi is making fun as he thanks everyone who has reached the age of 20 but still in the care of his parents as a child.
igbo: Osinachi ji ọchị na-eme nke ya ebe ọ na-ekele onye ọbụla rugoro afọ 20 mana na-anata ndị mụrụ ya ego dịka nwantakịrị.

igbo: Onyeisiala Buhari kwuru na ego ahụ e bitere China bụ iji kwalite ngalaba teknụzụ Naịjirịa.

english: But Nigerians fear that if the money is not refunded, China will come and take much of Nigeria's wealth as they do in Zambia now.

igbo: Ọ kwuru na ihe gbasara ọkụ latrik ekwesighi ịbụ ihe eji achụnta vootu dịka gọọmentị nakwa ndị ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ji ya eme ugbua.

igbo: Ezeh gara n'ihu kwuo na gọọmentị anaghị emezu nkwa ha kwerela n'isi ọkụ latrik kamgbe ha bara ọchịchị.

igbo: Ngalaba nchọpụta nke ụlọọrụ akụkọ Economist a kpọrọ 'The Economist Intelligence Unit, ' na bekee, kwụrụ na APC agaghị emeri na ntuliaka 2019, ebe HSBC buru amụma na akụnaụba Naijiria ga-akụ afọ n'ala ma ọ bụrụ na onyeisiala Nigeria bụ Muhammadụ Buhari merie na ntuliaka 2019.

english: We should remember that Nigeria was predicted to separate in 2015, while all the ethnic groups would be independent.
igbo: Anyị ga-echeta na a maburu amụma na Naijiria ga-ekposa n'afọ 2015, ebe agburu dị iche iche ga agawara onwe ha.

igbo: Ha gara n'ihu kwuo na ọ na-agba pati ha gharịị ihe mere n'ụlọọrụ abụọ ahụ ahụghị ihe ọma niile ọchịchị APC merela na-ibua agha megide nrụrụaka, ọrụ mmepe na ibụ agha megide iyi-egwu.

english: APC pointed out that all EFCC funds received from those who stole from the Nigerian economy, the JAMB fund as well as the tax collection agency.
igbo: APC rụtụrụ aka na ego niile EFCC nwenitara n'aka ndị zuru ego Naijiria, mgbalite ego JAMB nakwa ụlọọrụ na-anata ụtụisi.

english: Clement Nze the representative of Ogunwale in that meeting, called upon Anambra state government and NEMA, to try and do what will reduce much flooding

english: Ogunwale said that much flooding is unstoppable in Nigeria, but early preparation will help reduce the damages it might cause

igbo: Ha na-eke ihe dị ka pe senti 50 nke mbido ịzụ ahịa ma anyị na-akpọ ha ndị nrụkọọrụọnụ.

english: What if I refer you and you now become a partner and you refer somebody else and that person becomes a partner, who also referred someone?
igbo: Kedụ maka ọ bụrụ na m ziga gị, I wee bụrụ onye nrụkọọrụọnụ, I ziga onye ọzọ, onye ahụ bụrụ onye nrụkọọrụọnụ, onye zigakwara onye ọzọ?

english: Shouldn't you be making money in referring somebody?
igbo: Ọ bụ n' ị gaghị na-enweta ego maka iziga mmadụ?

english: That is the new system that we have created, like higher level of stream of income for a partner, making it a multi-layer, instead of just a single layer system.
igbo: Nke ahụ bụ usoro ọhụrụ anyị meputarala, dị ka ogo dị elu nke ego si abatara onye nrụkọọrụọnụ, na-eme ya imerime okpukpu, kama nanị usoro otu okpukpu.

english: How reliable is the technology behind this business plan?.
igbo: Kedụ ụdị ntụkwasị obi teknọlọjị atụmatụ azụmahịa gbadoro ụkwụ dị?

english: Technology is not new.
igbo: Teknọlọjị abụghị ihe ọhụrụ.

english: At least, I have been in the business between seven and eight years and it has been around that same time.
igbo: Ọ pekata mpe, anọla m n' azụmahịa a agbata afọ asaa na asatọ mana ọ nọrọla ya oge ahụ.

english: I don't think there has ever been any day that the whole market is down and nothing is working.
igbo: Echeghi m na enwela ụbọchị ahịa niile mechiri ma onweghi ihe na-arụ ọrụ.

english: That has never happened.
igbo: Nke ahụ emenubeghi.

english: For example, about 60 per cent of the whole American economy is in New York Stock Exchange, which is why companies like Ali Baba in China can leave the country to raise money in America because there's no other place you can get that kind of money.
igbo: Ọmụma atụ, ihe dị ka pe senti 60 akụnụba Amerịka niile dị na 'New York Stock Exchange', nke mere n' ụlọ ọrụ dị ka Ali Baba na China nwere ike ịhapụ obodo ahụ ịnakọ ego n' Amerịka makana e nweghị ebe ọzọ I nwere ike inweta ụdị ego ahụ.

english: The whole American economy is built on the New York Stock Exchange, which is the same trading we are talking about.
igbo: A rụrụ akụnụba Amerịka niile na 'New York Stock Exchange,' nke bụ otu ụdị azụmahịa anyị na-ekwu maka ya.

english: If it is not reliable, they won't put all their lives in it.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ọ dịghị ntụkwasị obi, ha agaghị etinye ndụ ha niile na ya

english: When people tell me that the likes of 'Wonder Banks' and MMM had gone under, wondering if the forex market will not go like them, I only tell them that they are looking at it locally.
igbo: Mgbe ndị mmadụ gwara m na ihe dị ka 'Wonder Banks' na MMM anaala, na-eche ma ọ bụ na 'Forex market' ọ gaghị ala ka ha, ana m agwa ha nanị na ha na-ahụ ya ka ihe mpaghara ebe a.

english: Forex market is not a Nigerian thing, it's not an American thing, it is not a Japanese thing, it is the whole world and driven by a level of fundamentals.
igbo: Forex market abụghị ihe Naijiria, ọ bụghị ihe Amerịka, ọ bụghị Japan, ọ bụ ụwa niile ma nwe ogo ntọala na-achị ya.

english: So, it can go down unless human beings are all going down.
igbo: Ya bụ, ọ ga-ada beeresọ ma mmadụ niile a na-ada ada.

english: What competitive advantage is Rally Trade coming with?.
igbo: Kedụ uru asọmpi 'Rally Trade' ji abịa?

english: To be frank, all brokers offer the same thing.
igbo: N' ikwu eziokwu, ọre ahịa niile na-enye otu ụdị ihe.

english: It's like all Nigerian stockbrokers offer the same thing.
igbo: Ọ di ka ndị ọre ahịa Naijiria niile na-enye otu ụdị ihe.

english: You want to buy First Bank or GTBank shares, they are all offering the same thing.
igbo: Ị chọrọ igote òkè First Bank ma ọ bụ GTBank, ha niile na-enye otu ụdị ihe.

english: But the things that can make you different are in-depth customer service, things that sometimes, as a stockbroker, you take more time to research on.
igbo: Mana ihe ndị ga-eme gị ka ị dị iche bụ ọrụ onye ahịa miri emi, ihe ndị bụ mgbe ụfọdụ, dị ka ọre ahịa, i wepụta oge ịchọcha maka ya.

english: Of course, you can advise your clients on how to buy shares.
igbo: N' ezie, i nwere ike inye onye ahịa ndụmọdụ ka ọ ga-esi gote òkè.

english: But if people can see that your clients are making more money, it becomes extra advantage.
igbo: Mana ọ bụrụ na ndị mmadụ ahụ na ndị ahịa gị na-enweta ego karịa, ọ na-abụ uru.

english: In Rally Trade for instance, we have unusual customer support.
igbo: Na Rally Trade iji maa atụ, anyị nwere nkwado onye ahịa dị ukwuu.

english: Our staff call clients every day to know if there is any problem or challenge.
igbo: Ndị ọrụ anyị na-akpọ ndị ahịa kwa ụbọchị ịma ma enwere nsogbu ọ bụla ma ọ bụ ihe akamgba.

english: Every client has a dedicated staff that takes care of his or her business.
igbo: Onye ahịa ọ bụla nwere onye ọrụ wepụtara onwe ya maka ileta azụmahịa ya.

english: Then we have the best education system here.
igbo: Nke ọzọ anyị nwere usoro agụmakwụkwọ kasị mma ebe a.

english: There is no company that is educating Nigerians like Rally academy does.
igbo: Enweghi ụlọ ọrụ na-akụziri ndị Naịjirịa ka 'Rally academy' si eme.

english: In terms of our conferences, expos, seminars and the trainings we do in our office frequently.
igbo: Gbasara ọgbakọ, ngosi, nzukọ ọmụmụ na ọmụmụ anyị na-enwe n' ụlọ ọrụ anyị ugboro ugboro.

english: So, those are some of the two major advantages that we have- essential customer service and quality education system.
igbo: Ya bụ, ha bụ isi uru abụọ nke anyị nwere-----enyemaka onye ahịa dị oké mkpa na usoro agụmakwụkwọ dị mma.

english: There is this fear about Fintech, especially that of trust.
igbo: Enwere egwu dị banyere Fintech, ọ kasị nke ntụkwasị obi.

english: What is your take?.
igbo: Kedụ uche gị?

english: All a company can do is to make sure that it is dealing with a regulated institution, the same way we are sure that banks are regulated by Central Bank of Nigeria.
igbo: Ihe ụlọ ọrụ nwere ike ime bụ ihụ na ya na ewumewu nwere usoro na-emekọ, dị ka ọ si doo anyị anya na 'Central Bank of Nigeria' nyere ụlọ akụ usoro.

english: We are regulated in Europe by financial commission.
igbo: 'Financial Commission' nyere anyị usoro na Europe.

english: At the same time, when I talk to people about online business, if you decide to run away and hide yourself in the sand, saying you don't trust it, your money might disappear, you will never do anything.
igbo: N' otu aka ahụ, mgbe m na- agwa ndị mmadụ okwu banyere azụmahịa 'online', ọ bụrụ n' ịchọ ịgbapụ ma zoo onwe gị n' àjà, na-asị na ịtụkwasịghi ya obi, ego gị nwere ike ifu, ị gaghị eme ihe ọbụla.

english: You won't believe that some people don't use ATM till today, you know why, saying if they are being caught up in a corner, all their money will be collected.
igbo: Ị gaghị ekwe na ụfọdụ mmadụ ejighi ATM eme ihe taa, ị mara ihe kpatara ya, na-ekwu na ọ bụrụ n' e jide ha n' akụkụ, a ga-ewere ego ha niile.

english: Some people don't use Internet banking but that doesn't help you at all.
igbo: Ụfọdụ mmadụ enweghị 'Internet banking' mana nke ahụ anaghị enyere gị aka ma ncha.

english: You are losing more than you are gaining.
igbo: I na-etufu karịa ka ị na-erita.

english: That is the way it is.
igbo: Otu ahụ ka ọ dị.

english: With the current technology comes challenges and hacking of funds, but yet, there is nothing you can do about it other than find how to use them safely and make sure you do enough research.
igbo: Ihe iche aka mgba na mbanye anataghị ikike so teknọlọjị ugbua bịa, mana, enweghị ihe I ga-eme banyere ya karịa ịchọ ụzọ ị ga-eji were ha mee ihe n' enweghi nsogbu ma hụ na i mere nchọcha zuru okè.

english: Wherever you are putting your money, do extensive research.
igbo: Ebe ọbụla ị na-etinye ego gị, mee nchọcha miri emi.

english: For instance, in the last 10 years, Nigerians have gone through several scams.
igbo: Ọmụma atụ, n' ime afọ iri gara aga, ndị Naijiria agaferela ọtụtụ ojoro.

english: We had MMM, Wonder Banks, among others, but I have never lost one kobo to any of them because I learnt about 10 years ago that there are no free money and I had been a victim online, when I lost like $200 and had to withdraw.
igbo: Anyị nwere MMM, Wonder Banks, na ndị ọzọ, mana etufubeghi m otu kobo nyere nke ọbụla makana a mụtara ihe dị ka afọ iri gara aga na enweghi ego efu nakwa na abụrụla m onye o metụtara n' 'online', mgbe m tụfuru ihe dị ka $200 nke mere m jiri laa azụ.

english: So, when Wonder Bank and MMM came, I knew that it was just scam.
igbo: Ya bụ, mgbe Wonder Bank na MMM bịara, amara m na ọ bụ nanị ojoro.

english: People need to be educated, do research, then you really have very little issues when it comes to doing financial business online.
igbo: Ndị mmadụ kwesiri ịmụta ihe, mee nchọcha, n' ezie I ga-enwe obere nsogbu ebe ọ gbasara azụmahịa ego n' 'online'

english: What is the MT4 Platform all about?.
igbo: Kedụ ihe MT4 bụ maka ya?

english: Let me try to describe the MT4 in a simple way.
igbo: Ka gbalịa ịkọwa MT4 n' ụzọ dị mfe.

english: Let's use car, which is the best way.
igbo: Ka anyị were ụgbọ ala, nke bu ụzọ kasị mma.

english: A Toyota and a Honda, what is the difference? Nothing! They both are cars.
igbo: Otu Toyota na otu Honda, gịnị bụ ndị iche? Onweghi! Ha abụọ bụ ụgbọala.

english: But in Nigeria, we have more Toyota than Honda, why? People just love Toyota! Or maybe Toyota is easier to maintain or it has more second hand value or it is cheaper to buy.
igbo: Mana na Naijiria, anyị nwere Toyota karịa Honda, maka gịnị? Naanị na ndị mmadụ hụrụ Toyota n' anya! Ma ọ bụ onwere ike o bụrụ na Toyota ka mfe ilekwa anya ma ọbụ n' ọ ka nwee uru na ngokpo ma ọ bụ n' ọ dị ọnụ ala igote.

english: The same way we have different trading platforms.
igbo: Otu ahụ kwa ka anyị si nwe ụzọ izu ahịa dị iche iche.

english: For instance, there is a company called Tesla, which makes car in the U.S.
igbo: Ọmụma atụ, ọnwere ụlọ ọrụ a na-akpọ Tesla, nke na-arụpụta ụgbọ ala n' U. S.

english: He added that immense opportunities abound in the sector that had remained largely untapped. 'This is why most advanced economies of the world have highly developed their maritime industries'.
igbo: Ọ gbakwunyere na nnukwu ohere jupụtara na ngalaba a kpabeghi aka. 'Nke a mere mba ụwa akụnụba ha mepere emepe ji enwe ụlọ ọrụ mmiri mepere emepe nke ukwuu.'

english: They didn't exist before now.
igbo: Ha adịghị na mbụ.

english: The same way companies create trading platforms for themselves.
igbo: Otu ahụ ka ụlọ ọrụ si echeputara onwe ha ụzọ ịzụ ahịa.

english: So, I can start a brokerage company and decide that like the software banks use, I don't want to use a certain platform, but a fresh one people can trade on that can be better, but that doesn't mean people are going to love it.
igbo: Ya bụ, enwere m ike ibido ụlọ ọrụ ire ahịa ma kpebie na di ka 'software banks', agaghị m achọ iji ụfọdụ ụzọ, kama ụzọ ọhụrụ ndị mmadụ nwere ike ịzụ ahịa na ya ka mma, mana ọ pụtaghị na ọ ga-amasị ndị mmadụ.

english: Tesla is in America now but doesn't mean it is selling more than Toyota that has been selling for a while.
igbo: Tesla dị n' Amerịka ugbua mana ọ pụtaghị na ọ na-ere ahịa karịa Toyota no na-ere ahịa nwa oge.

english: MT4 is just a platform people trade on, just to buy and sell, that is what it is but it is the oldest, it has the highest adoption, it is what people love the most, so every broker has it.
igbo: MT4 bụ naanị ụzọ ndị mmadụ si ere ahịa, naanị ịzụ na ire, ya bụ ihe ọ bu mana ọ bụ ụzọ kasị ochie, ọ nwere nhọrọ kasị ukwuu, ọ bụ ihe masịrị ndị mmadụ, ya mere na ọre ahịa ọ bụla nwere ya.

english: Quran used for muslim prayer.
igbo: Quran e ji ekpe ekpere Muslim.

english: It does not bother me at all that you woke up today and you are bothered by matters bothering your brethren, male and female.
igbo: Ọ naghị emekpa m ahụ ma ncha na I biliri ọtọ taa ma nwee mmekpa ahụ maka ihe na-emekpa ụmụnne gị ahụ, nwoke na nwaanyị.

english: It does not bother me at all that you are there seated or standing running after the necessities of life.
igbo: Ọ naghị emekpa m ahụ ma ncha na ị nọ ala ebe ahụ ma ọ bụ kwụrụ ọtọ na-agbaso ihe ndị dị mkpa na ndụ.

english: It bothers me a trifle that you are buffeted by the vicissitudes of life, by the vagaries and uncertainties of living and by the pursuit of that which would not last.
igbo: Ọ na-emekpa ahụ ọbere na mgbanwe nke ndụ, ihe mfiahụ na ihe ejighi n' aka na ịchụ ihe agaghị adịgide na-atụgharị gị.

english: Quran used for muslim prayer.
igbo: Quran e ji ekpe ekpere Muslim.

english: Yes.
igbo: Ee.

english: It is the will of the Almighty in creation that all subjects born of the womb shall toil and labour in order to enjoy and suffer.
igbo: Ọ bụ ebumnuche onye pụrụ ime ihe niile n' okike na ihe niile afọ mụrụ ga-adọgbu onwe ya n' ọrụ iji nwe añụrị na ahụhụ.

english: The worshipper of the Merciful shall observe vigil at night in order to qualify for His favours.
igbo: Onye ofufe onye ebere ga-amụ anya abalị iji tozuo ịnata amara ya.

english: The armed robber shall forsake the pleasure of his bed at night in order to visit pain on the neighbourhood and thereby qualify for punishment and eternal damnation.
igbo: Oji egbe ezu ga-ajụ ihe ụtọ nke àkwà ya n' abalị iji mee agbataobi ya ihe mgbu wee sị n' ụzọ dị otú a nweta ntaramahụhụ na mbibi ebighiebi.

english: Yes.
igbo: Ee

english: Those who shall enter paradise have to work and sweat; those who shall enter hell would have to earn it through toil and labour! I am not bothered by all of these simply because this is the reality.
igbo: Ndị ga-aba alaeze eluigwe ga-arụ ọrụ ma gba ọsụsọ; ndị ga-aba ọkụ mmụọ ga-enweta ya site n' ịdọgbu onwe na ọrụ! Ihe ndị a niile anaghị ekpa m ahụ naanị makana ihe a bụ eziokwu.

english: I am concerned with one other thing, however.
igbo: Otu ọ dị, otú ihe ọzọ gbasara m.

english: I am concerned with the possibility that you are involved in the frenetic pursuit of this world on the assumption that you could indeed have it all.
igbo: Ọ gbasara m na i nwere ike iso na mgbagharị ịchụ ụwa n' enweghi isi bụrụ n' obi n' ị ga-enwetasị ihe niile.

english: No! You cannot have it all.
igbo: Mba! Ị gaghị enweta ihe niile.

english: Nobody has ever had it all.
igbo: Onwebeghi onye nwetarasịrị ihe niile.

english: Nobody will ever have it all.
igbo: Onweghi onye ga-enwetasị ihe niile.

english: Evidence in support of these claims and assertions are there in your wakeful moments, in your everyday life.
igbo: Ihe akaebe kwadoro mkwupụta nọ n' echiche gị, n' ụbọchị niile nke ndụ gị.

english: There she is seated.
igbo: Ebe ahụ ka ọ nọ ala.

english: The pepper grinder in the neighbourhood.
igbo: Ọkwọ ose nọ n' agbataobi.

english: Every time her husband copulates with her, pregnancy sets in.
igbo: Oge ọ bụla ya na di ya nwere mmekọ ọ dị ime.

english: Today, she is nursing two beautiful girls.
igbo: Taa, ọ na-azụlite obere ụmụ nwaanyị abụọ mara mma.

english: Only a year before, she gave birth to a boy.
igbo: Naanị otu afọ gara aga, ọ mụrụ nwa nwoke.

english: Her husband is the Chief Messenger in that office.
igbo: Di ya bụ onyeisi njeozi n' ụlọ ọrụ ahụ.

english: Yes.
igbo: Ee.

english: The Chief Messenger.
igbo: Onyeisi njeozi.

english: To every profession its chief.
igbo: N' aka ọrụ ọbụla ọ bụ isi.

english: There is the Chief Whip in the Parliament.
igbo: E nwere 'Chief whip' n' ụlọ mmepụta iwu.

english: There are chiefs in the palace.
igbo: E nwere ndị isi n' obi eze.

english: I wonder whether there are chiefs among thieves and kidnappers.
igbo: Ọ na-atụ m n' anya ma e nwere ndị isi n' etiti ndị ohi na ndị ntọ.

english: Yes.
igbo: Ee.

english: There are Chief Lecturers.
igbo: E nwere ndi isi nkụzi mahadum.

english: But there are no Chief Professors.
igbo: Mana enweghị ndị isi Ọkammụta.

english: Now the chief messenger of interest to me today is he whose spermatozoic prowess is reminiscent of the 'Danfo' driver in the other part of the town.
igbo: Ugbua onyeisi njeozi nke m nwere mmasị taa bụ nke nkà spam ya na-arụtụ aka n' ebe ọkwọ ụgbọala 'Danfo' nọ n' akụkụ obodo ọzọ nọ.

english: The latter is loved and abhorred by women in the bus station by equal measure.
igbo: Ụmụ nwaanyị nọ ọdụ ụgbọala hụrụ nke ikpeazụ n' anya ma kpọkwa ya asị n' otu aka ahụ

english: They know that whenever he 'touches' the opposite sex, often times illicitly, the latter would bear the 'burden' for the next nine months.
igbo: Ha ma na mgbe ọbụla ọ kpaturu okike nke ọzọ aka, mgbe ụfọdụ n' ụzọ iwu n' akwadoghi, onye nke ọzọ ga-ebu ibu ya ọnwa iteghete ọzọ.

english: This Chief Danfo driver owns no vehicle.
igbo: Onyeisi ọkwọ ụgbọala Danfo a enweghị ụgbọala.

english: He owns no properties.
igbo: O nweghi ihe onwunwe.

english: He has no investment in any blue-chip companies.
igbo: O nweghi ego n' ụlọ ọrụ 'blue-chip.'

english: He has no bank accounts.
igbo: O nweghi akaụntụ n' ụlọ akụ.

english: He knows that he is poor.
igbo: Ọ mara na ọ bụ ogbenye.

english: He desires to be rich.
igbo: Ọ chọrọ ịbụ ọgaranya.

english: But at least for now, he is contented in the knowledge that he does not have it all.
igbo: Mana ugbua, ọ nwere afọ ojuju n' ọmụma na ya enwghi ha ncha.

english: He is contented that at least he has his virility and masculinity.
igbo: O juru ya afọ na opekata mpe na ya dị ike ma bụrụ nwoke.

english: He is happy in the knowledge that he is an active partaker in the unceasing task of populating the world!.
igbo: Ọ na-enwe añụrị n' ịma na ya ketara oké ịrụsị ọrụ ike n' ịmụba ụwa akwusịghị akwụsị.

english: Across the town, in an area known as GRA, there lives the multi-millionaire.
igbo: N' ofe obodo, na mpaghara a mara ka GRA, ebe ka nnukwu ọgaranya bi.

english: He has almost everything money can buy- a posh house and state-of-the-art automobiles.
igbo: Ọ nwere ihe ọbụla ego nwere ike igote----ụlọ bụ oyoyo na ụgbọala ọgbara ọhụrụ.

english: His wife is that woman who is subject of the second gaze whenever she steps out of her home: beautiful, elegant and intelligent.
igbo: Nwunye ya bụ nwaanyị ahụ nke bụ ihe ile anya ugboro abụọ mgbe ọbụla o si be ya pụta: ọ mara mma, chapụ achapụ na nwe ọgụgụ isi.

english: However, despite these provisions and blessings, the woman is not happy.
igbo: Otu ọ dị, n' agbanyeghi ndokwa na ngọzi niile a, obi anaghị atọ nwaanyị ụtọ.

english: She cries every night because she has not been blessed with the fruit of the womb.
igbo: Ọ na-ebe ákwá abalị ọbụla makana e jibeghi mkpụrụ nke afọ wee gọzie ya.

english: Whenever she contemplates the plum and pleasure that surrounds her, she remembers what material comfort cannot provide.
igbo: Mgbe ọbụla ọ tụgharịrị uche ya banyere ezigbo ihe ndị a na ihe ụtọ gbara ya gburugburu, ọ cheta nkasi obi ihe onwunwe agaghị enyenwu.

english: She shed hot tears for being barren.
igbo: Ọ na-ebe ákwá n' anụ ọkụ maka ịbụ àgà.

english: She has it; but she cannot have it all.
igbo: Ọ nwere ya, mana ọ gaghị enwenwu ha niile.

english: Meanwhile, one of the children of the poor 'Danfo' driver is registered in one of the public schools in the neighbourhood.
igbo: Ugbua, otu n' ime ụmụnne aka ogbenye ọkwọ ụgbọala Danfo denyere aha n' ụlọakwụkwọ ọha dị n' agbataobi.

english: As fate would have it, he is a classmate to one of the children of the 'big men' in town.
igbo: Dị ka akara aka si dee ya, ọ bụ nwa klas otu nwa n' ime ụmụ ndị ọgaranya n' obodo.

english: While the child of the poor driver comes to school barefooted and in completely worn out school uniform, his classmate is brought to school every morning by a chauffeur-driven car.
igbo: Ka nwa ogbenye ọkwọ ụgbọala na-agba ụkwụ nkịtị mana na-eyi ákwà akwụkwọ ñachasịrị añacha abịa akwụkwọ, a na-eji ụgbọala ọkwọ ụgbọala na-anya ebute nwa klas ya akwụkwọ kwa ụtụtụ ọbụla.

english: The boy's food basket is usually the most sought after one during the break time.
igbo: Nkata nri nwata nwoke a ka a kasị achọ oge ezumike.

english: The irony however is this- each time the school closes for the session, the son of the poor driver always takes the first position while his classmate, the child of the rich man, takes the last position.
igbo: Mana ihe mgbagwoju anya dị na ya bụ nke-- mgbe ọbụla akwụkwọ mechiri, nwa nwoke ogbenye ọkwọ ụgbọala na-agba onye nke mbụ ebe nwa klas ya, nwa nwoke onye ọgaranya, na-agba onye nke ikpeazụ.

english: The rich man has it; but he cannot, by His design, have it all.
igbo: Nwoke ọgaranya nwere ya, mana ọ nweghi ike, n' ike nke ya, inwe ha niile.

english: Have you ever found yourself in situations where people demand favours from you, favours you cannot grant unto yourself?
igbo: Inwetala onwe gị n' ọnọdụ ebe ndị mmadụ na-achọ ihu ọma n' aka gị, ihu ọma inweghi ike inye onwe gị?

english: What about the Vice-Chancellor of that university whose children have continually failed the Unified Tertiary Matriculation Examination (UTME) organized by the Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB).
igbo: Kedụ maka 'Vice-chancellor' mahadum ahụ onye ụmụ ya na-ada 'Unified Tertiary Matriculation Examination (UTME)' nke 'Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB)' na-achikọba kwa mgbe.

english: He presides over life-long opportunities; opportunities none of his children can by law enjoy.
igbo: Ọ nọ n' isi ohere ogologo ndụ; ohere nke onweghi ụmụ ya nwere ike inwe site n' iwu.

english: He has this; he does not have that because he cannot have it all!.
igbo: Ọ nwere nke a; ọ nweghi nke ahụ makana ọ nweghi ike inwe ha ncha.

english: Oladosu is a Professor of Middle Eastern, North African and Cultural Studies. Dean, Faculty of Arts, University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria.
igbo: Oladosu bụ Ọkammụta nke 'Middle Eastern, North African and Cultural Studies.' Onyeisi, ngalaba nka, Mahadum nke Ibadan, Ibadan, Naijiria.

english: 'We shall develop and enhance safety enforcement, minimise environmental damage and provide clear framework to enable investors to participate in maritime projects to improve growth and competiveness within the subsector,' Moghalu said.
igbo: 'Anyị ga-emepe ma welie mmanye nchekwa, beleta mmebi gburugburu ebe obibi ma weta amụma doro anya ga-eme ka ndị ntinye ego sonye n' ọrụ ngo mmiri ga-abawanye otito na asọmpi na ngalaba ahụ, ' Mọghalụ kwuru.

english: He said that measures were installed to address challenges by ensuring efficiency and cost effectiveness in the industry, as well as the privatisation of the port.
igbo: Ọ sịrị na a tụpụtala atụmatụ ga-agbazi ịma aka site n' ịhụ maka arụmọrụ na inwe ọnụ ahịa dị írè n' ụlọ ọrụ, nakwa inyefe ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n' aka ndị nnọrọ onwe.

english: There's a lot of talk about toilets lately.
igbo: E nwere ọtụtụ okwu banyere ụlọ mposi n' ikpeazụ a.

english: After the Obama administration told US schools to let transgender pupils use toilets matching their gender identity, everyone has an opinion about who should use which toilet.
igbo: Ka ọchịchị Obama gwasịrị ụlọakwụkwọ US ka ha hapụ ụmụ akwụkwọ e megharịrị okike ha ije mposi n' ụlọ mposi gosiri okike ha, onyeisi ọbụla nwere echiche banyere ụlọ mposi nke onye ga-eje na ya.

english: Meanwhile in the interest of public service, I'd also like to encourage a debate about 'how' toilets are used.
igbo: Ugbua n' ihi ọdịmma nke ọrụ ọha, m ga-achọkwa ịkwado arụmụka maka ojiji ụlọ mposi.

english: I encourage male readers to pay particular attention because I'm asking you to stop peeing on rather than in the toilet.
igbo: Ana m agba ndị ụmụ nwoke na-agụ ihe ka tinye uche pụrụ iche makana ana m agwa ha ka ha kwụsị ịnyụ mamịrị n' elu kama n' ime ụlọ mposi.

english: Were an alien species to conduct an in-depth study of the human species, they would say of Nigerian men – a well-adapted group, intellectually vigorous, entrepreneurial and charming, but with disgraceful toilet manners.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ụmụ ndị ọbịa eme nchọcha miri emi banyere mmadụ, ha ga-ekwu banyere ụmụ nwoke Naijiria---Òtù, sịrị ike ọgụgụ isi,

english: Of course there would be exceptions and some women would be similarly judged.
igbo: N' ezie e nwere ndị iche mana a ga-ekpe ụfọdụ ụmụ nwaanyị ikpe.

english: But the good number of male 'splashers' amidst us would bring the score down.
igbo: Mana ọtụtụ ụmụ nwoke n' ime anyị g-ebutu ọnụ ọgụgụ ahụ.

english: Since aliens may not land on earth in my lifetime, I conducted my own in-depth study about this corrosive issue.
igbo: Kemgbe ndị ọbịa enweghi ike ịbịa n' ụwa na ndụ m, emere m nchọcha nke m banyere okwu a.

english: The study did not (thankfully) involve visits to the Gents.
igbo: Nchọcha a (n' inye ekele) agụnyeghi nleta ụlọ mposi.

english: Rather it was undertaken (reluctantly) in the one given place where all genders share toilets, namely on airplanes.
igbo: Kama e mere (n' ejighị obi) n' otu ebe okike niile na-ejekete mposi, ya bụ ụgbọelu.

english: The study confirmed that using the shared toilets on flights to and from Nigeria is an extraordinarily unpleasant experience.
igbo: Nchọcha a gosiri na ijeko mposi n' ụgbọelu site Naijiria nakwa ịlaghachi Naijiria bụ ahụmihe adịghị ụtọ dị egwu.

english: In fact, the situation is such that on my next Nigeria bound flight I will bring a raincoat, rubber gloves and Wellies.
igbo: N' ezie, ọnọdụ a bụ nke na n' oge ọzọ m ga-aba ụgbọelu ịga Naijiria m ga-eweta 'raincoat', 'rubber gloves' na 'wellies. '

english: Jokes aside, toilet use is in truth a political issue.
igbo: Egwuregwu laa azụ, ojiji ụlọ mposi bụ n' ezie okwu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị.

english: Fela Anikulapo-Kuti himself often connected the scatological with the political.
igbo: Fela Anikulapo-Kuti n' onwe ya mgbe ụfọdụ jikọrọ

english: Though judging by the lines, 'Long time ago African man no dey carry shit, we dey shit inside big big hole, na European man teach us to carry shit', Fela may have disagreed with me on toilet matters.
igbo: N' ezie e sowe ụgbara egwu ndị a: 'Ọtụtụ oge gara aga nwoke Afrịka anaghị ebu nsị, anyị na-anyụ nsị n' ime nnukwu ọhere, ọ bụ nwoke Europe kụziri anyị ibu nsị,' Fela nwere ike ghara ikwenyere m banyere okwu mposi.

english: Because in a sense, I am indeed advocating for western toilet habits.
igbo: Makana n' otu ụzọ, ana m akwado àgwà mposi ọdịda anyanwụ.

english: (By the way, I never imagined I would combine those last three words.).
igbo: (Ka o sila dị, echeghi m na m ga-agwọkọta okwu ikpeazụ atọ ahụ ọnụ.).

english: Moghalu, then, said that developing a policy framework to include strategic objectives, policy action and strategic plan for implementation to precede reforming the transport sector.
igbo: Mọghalụ, mgbe ahụ, kwuru na imeputa nlereanya iwu ga-agunye ebumnuche dị mkpa, ọrụ iwu, na atụmatụ dị mkpa na mmejuputa iwu ga-ebu mgbanwe ngalaba njem ụzọ.

english: To be clear, had we modernized the old African way of using the toilet to contemporary society it would be better suited both for the environment and for our bodies.
igbo: Ka ọ doo anya, ọ bụrụ n' anyị gbanwee ụzọ ojiji mposi Afrịka ochie ka ọ bụrụ ụzọ nke ugbua ọ ga-aka mma nyere gburugburu anyị na ahụ anyị.

english: But I'm thankful that at least airplanes don't use the hole system, or I would need to add a diving suit to my in-flight gear.
igbo: Mana ana m enye ekele na opekata mpe ụgbọelu enweghi usoro ọghere, ma ọ bụ agara m ekwesi ịgbakwunye uwe mmapụ na ngwa njem ụgbọelu m.

english: Toilet use is not only a political matter, but also a 'geopolitical' one.
igbo: Ojiji mposi abụghị nanị okwu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị, kama ọ bụkwa nke mpaghara.

english: I hate to admit it, but I find myself making toilet habit comparisons between countries.
igbo: Akpọrọ m ikweta na ya asị, mana enwetara m onwe m n' ime ntule àgwà mposi n' etiti mba na mba.

english: It turns out that flights to and from the US are a particularly 'dry' experience.
igbo: Ọ pụtara na njem ụgbọelu jee na site US bụ ahụmihe adịghị ụtọ.

english: When you enter a toilet cubicle that has just been used by an American man, nine out of ten times it will be pristine.
igbo: Ịbanye ụlọ mposi nke nwoke Amerịka jere mposi na nso, iteghete n' ime iri ga-adị ọcha.

english: Maybe American men go to a special toilet training school? Or maybe they are just particularly good at tactical target aiming.
igbo: Ọnwere ike o bụrụ na ụmụ nwoke Amerịka na-aga ọzụzụ mposi n' ụlọakwụkwọ pụrụ iche.

english: [Sarcasm].
igbo: [Sakazim]

english: Whatever the case may be, I see no reason why my countrymen can't show equal consideration to their fellow human beings.
igbo: Ihe ọ bụla ọ bụ, ahụghị m ihe ndị obodo m agaghị eji gosi ntule ha nhanya n' ebe mmadụ ibe ha nọ.

english: Tottenham Hotspur's South Korean striker Son Heung-Min (L) and Tottenham Hotspur's Belgian defender Toby Alderweireld (R) celebrate on the pitch after the English Premier League football match between Wolverhampton Wanderers and Tottenham Hotspur at the Molineux stadium in Wolverhampton, central England on December 15, 2019.
igbo: Ònyè goolu Tottenham Hotspur bụ onye South Korea, Son Heung-min (L) na onye nchekwa Tottenham Hotspur bụ onye Belgium, Toby Alderweireld (R) nwere añụrị na piichi na ngwụsị asọmpi bọọlụ 'English Premier League' dị n' etiti Wolverhampton Wanderers na Tottenham Hotspur n' ama egwuregwu Molineux, central England na Disemba 15, 2019.

english: Tottenham won the game 2-1. Paul ELLIS / AFP.
igbo: Tottenham meriri n' egwuregwu ahụ 2-1. Paul ELLIS/AFP.

english: 'It is on this basis that we have decided to engage the civil society and all other stakeholders in the maritime subsector in the South East Geopolitical Zone.
igbo: 'Ọ bụ na ndabere a ka anyị ji kpebie inweta ọha mmadụ na ndị ngalaba mmiri na ndịda ọwụwa anyanwụ gbasara.

english: Jan Vertonghen's stoppage time header continued Tottenham's turnaround under Jose Mourinho as Spurs moved up to fifth with a 2-1 win at Wolves.
igbo: Isi nkwụsị oge Jan Vertonghen mara tụgharịrị ọnọdụ Tottenham n' okpuru Jose Mourinho dịka Spurs gbagoro n' ọkwa nke ise na mmeri 2-1 ha mmeriri Wolves.

english: Mourinho's men were largely outplayed at Molineux, but were ruthless with their chances to inflict Wolves' first league defeat in 12 games.
igbo: E meriri ndi òtù Mourinho ọfụma na Molineux, mana obi tara ha mmiri n' ohere ha nwetara iji nye Wolves mmeri izizi liigi n' egwuregwu 12.

english: Adama Traore's spectacular strike had cancelled out Lucas Moura's early opener before Vertonghen stooped to guide home Christan Eriksen's corner.
igbo: Shọtụ pụrụ iche Adama Traore gbara hichapụrụ ụzọ mmepe Lucas Moura gbara tupu Vertonghen ehulata iduga kọna Christan Eriksen ụlọ.

english: Spurs can now move into the top four before Christmas if they beat Chelsea at home next weekend.
igbo: Spurs nwere ike iso n' òtù anọ nọ n' elu tupu Kristimas ma ha merie Chelsea n' be ha na ngwụsị izu ụka ọzọ.

english: That speaks volumes for the impact Mourinho has made in less than a month in charge as Tottenham trailed Chelsea and the top four by 12 points when he was appointed.
igbo: Nke ahụ na-ada ụda banyere mmetụta Mourinho merela n' oge n' erughi otu ọnwa ọ bụrụ isi dị ka Tottenham na-eso nzọ ukwu Chelsea na òtù anọ ji akara 12 nọrọ n' elu mgbe a họpụtara ya.

english: Wolves drop to eighth as their longest unbeaten run in the top flight since 1962 came to an end, but there was little more Nuno Espirito Santo's men could have done to at least avoid defeat.
igbo: Wolves gbadara n' ọnọdụ nke asatọ dị ka ọkasị ogologo emerighi emeri ha n' arị elu elu kemgbe afọ 1962 bịara na njedebe, mana ọnwere obere ihe ọzọkwa ndị òtù Nuno Espirito Santos kara ime opekata mpe ka ha wee gbanarị mmeri.

english: After an industrious start by Wolves, it was Spurs who scored after eight minutes.
igbo: Ka Wolves jisiri ịrụsị ọrụ ike bido, ọ bụ Spurs bụ ndị nyere goolu ka nkeji eight gasịrị.

english: Son Heung-min's drive was beaten away by Rui Patricio but the ball was worked to Moura, who glided into the area before rifling in high from an angle for his third goal in seven games under Mourinho.
igbo: Rui Patricio kụdara mkpalite Son Heung-min mana a gbagara Moura, onye kpụbara n' ime

english: Wolves remained undaunted though and after Paulo Gazzaniga gathered Traore's low effort they began to create openings.
igbo: Wolves ka nọ n' obi isi ike n' ezie mana ka Paulo Gazzaniga chịkọtasịrị mbọ dị ala Traore ha bidoro kepụtawa ọhere.

english: Diogo Jota was a menace and it was from his work Raul Jimenez nearly levelled after 26 minutes but his low effort flashed wide.
igbo: Diogo Jota bụ ihe egwu mana ọ bụ ọrụ ya ka ọ fọdụrụ obere ka Raul Jimenez bibiri ka nkeji 26 gasịrị mana mbọ ya dị ala pụtara ihe.

english: Soon after Jota was denied by the recovering Davinson Sanchez after the defender's initial mistake allowed the forward through.
igbo: Ozigbo David Sanchez na-agbake agbake gọnahara Jota ka onye mgbachite mesiri mmejọ na mbido nke mere ka onye nọ n' ihu gafere.

english: Wolves continued to dominate but should have been 2-0 down nine minutes before the break.
igbo: Wolves ka na-emeri mana ọ kara ịbụ 2-0 na nkeji iteghete tupu ezumike.

english: Referee Stuart Attwell played a good advantage after Moura was fouled to allow Eric Dier forward.
igbo: Refirii Stuart Attwell nyere ezigbo uru ka a kwaturu Moura iji mee ka Eric Dier gaa ihu.

english: He played a cute one-two with Dele Alli to leave the midfielder with just Patricio to beat but his low strike hit the post.
igbo: Ya na Dele Alli gbara ezigbo pam pam pam ịhapụrụ nanị Patricio ọ nọ n' etiti ka ọ gafee mana shọtụ ọ gbasighi ike kụrụ na postu.

english: It would have been harsh on Wolves and they continued to push after the break.
igbo: Ọ kara isiri Wolves ike ma ha nọ na-agbalị ka ezumike gasịrị.

english: Jota failed to turn in Traore's cross and Gazzaniga pushed away Jimenez's shot.
igbo: Jota enwetaghị bọọlụ Traore gbanyere ya ma Gazzaniga kwapụrụ shọtụ Jimenez.

english: Spurs' defence had lived dangerously, with Vertonghen in particular struggling against the pace of Traore.
igbo: Nchekwa Spur nọ n' ihe egwu, Vertonghen n' onwe ya na-agbalị ijide nzọụkwụ Traore.

english: Wolves finally got their reward on 67 minutes.
igbo: N' ikpeazụ Wolves nwetara ụgwọ ha na nkeji 67.

english: Traore had given the visitors problems all game and he made them pay, collecting Jimenez's pass and unleashing a rocket which flew past Gazzaniga from 20 yards.
igbo: Traore enyeela ndị ọbịa nsogbu n' egwuregwu ahụ niile ma ọ mere ka ha kwụọ ụgwọ, nara paasị Jimenez ma gbapụ rọketi nke fere gafee Gazzaniga site na 20 yaadị.

english: Tottenham then never looked like restoring their lead before the late drama.
igbo: Tottenham adịghị ka ha ana eweghachite mmeri ma ncha tupu ngwụcha ejije ahụ.

english: Wolves remained the aggressors and Romain Saiss' glancing header four minutes later forced Gazzaniga into a fine stop.
igbo: Wolves bụlịrị ndị mwakpo ma isi ntachara Romain Saiss na nkeji nke anọ ka e mesiri manyere ka ọ kwụsị.

english: But Spurs silenced the hosts in the first minute of injury time when Vertonghen nodded in Eriksen's corner.
igbo: Mana Spurs mechiri ndị nnabata ọnụ na nkeji nke mbụ nke oge a gbakwunyere agbakwunye mgbe Vertonghen tara isi n' akụkụ Eriksen.

english: Manish Rohtagi is the Business Head for Simba Group of Companies.
igbo: Manish Rohtagi bụ isi azụmahịa ụlọ ọrụ Simba Group.

english: Simba Group has reiterated its commitment to empowering more Nigerians through its products and services.
igbo: Simba Group ekwuputala ọzọ nkwa o kwere inyekwu ndị Naịjirịa ikike site na ngwaahịa ya na ọrụ ya.

english: Business Head of Simba TVS, Mr Manish Rohtagi, speaks on partnership with some Microfinance Banks, while banks should lend more to customers, the business environment, economy and challenges faced by businesses operating in the country.
igbo: Onyeisi azụmahịa nke Simba TVS, Mr Manish Rohtagi, kwuru banyere ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ nke ụfọdụ Ụlọ akụ 'Microfinance,' ka ụlọ akụ ji kwesi ibinye ọtụtụ ndị ahịa ego, gburugburu azụmahịa, akụnụba na ọtụtụ ihe ịma aka azụmahịa ndị dị n' ala a na-ezute.

english: What is Simba Group all about?.
igbo: Kedụ ihe bụ Simba Group?

english: Simba Group has been in this country for over 30 years.
igbo: Simba Group anọọla n' ala a ihe karịrị afọ 30.

english: We started our business with bicycles and bicycle parts way back in 1988.
igbo: Anyị ji anyịnya ìgwè na ngwa anyịnya ìgwè bido azụmahịa anyị oge gara aga na 1988.

english: We are present in several key sectors that are critical to the development of the Nigerian economy including transport, power, IT, agriculture etc.
igbo: Anyị nọ n' ọtụtụ ngalaba bụ isi nke dị mkpa mmepe akụnụba Naijiria nke gụnyere njem, ọkụ, IT, ọrụ ugbo wdg.

english: The office you are in is the headquarters of our transport business.
igbo: Ụlọ ọrụ ị nọ n' ime ya bụ isi ụlọ ọrụ azụmahịa njem anyị.

english: We in partnership with TVS Motors India are the largest manufacturers of kekes (tricycles) in Nigeria and our two wheelers, also known colloquially as okadas, continue to reshape the Nigerian two-wheeler market.
igbo: Anyị, n' ịrụkọ ọrụ nke TVS Motors India, bụ ndị kasị emeputa keke na Naijiria ma 'two wheelers' anyị, nke a makwara dị ka ọkada, nọgide na-akpụgharị ahịa 'two wheelers' na Naijiria.

english: How does the TVS brand help the Nigerian Economy?.
igbo: Kedụ ka ụdị TVS si enyere akụnụba Naijiria aka?

english: Transport is essential to the functioning of any economy and is one of the main drivers of it.
igbo: Njem dị nnukwu mkpa nye arụmọrụ nke akụnụba ọbụla ma ọ bụ isi sekpu ntị n' akụnụba.

english: Our products address the last mile transport needs of Nigerians.
igbo: Ihe anyị mepụtara na-edozi ihe siri ike na njem okporo ụzọ na Naijiria.

english: It has been shown each tricycle or motorcycle sold creates employment for around four people as these machines not only require riders, but also mechanics, dealers and spares distributors etc.
igbo: E gosila na keke na ọgbatumtum ọbụla e rere na-enye ìhè dị ka mmadụ anọ ọrụ dịka machiini anaghị achọ so ndị na-anya ha, mana ha na-achọkwa ndị mekaniik, ndị na-ere ahịa na ndị na-ekesa akụkụ mapụtara.

english: That's even without considering our own employees.
igbo: Nke ahụ ọbụnadị bụ ileghara ndị ọrụ anyị anya.

english: Hence this industry is one of the biggest employment generators in the country.
igbo: N' ihi ya ụlọ ọrụ a bụ otu n' ime ụlọ ọrụ kasị enye ọrụ n' ala anyị.

english: Along with that we have been running several programmes that empower the youth of the country.
igbo: Ka anyị na-eme nke ahụ anyị na-emekwa ọtụtụ atụmatụ nke na-enye ndị ntorobịa nke ala anyị ikike.

english: We have worked with several government agencies including National Automotive Design Development Council (NADDAC), National Directorate of Employment (NDE) among others and trained countless people into becoming keke riders or mechanics for free.
igbo: Anyị na ọtụtụ ụlọ ọrụ gọọmenti arụkọọla ọrụ nke gụnyere 'National Automotive Design Development Council (NADDAC),' 'National Directorate of Employment (NDE)' n' ime ndị ọzọ ma zụọ ndị mmadụ dị agụta agụta ịbụ ndị na-anya Keke ma ọ bụ mekaniik n' efu.

english: We also try to partner with the State and Federal Governments so that we empower more and more youths.
igbo: Anyị na-agbalịkwa ka anyị na gọọmenti etiti na nke steeti na-arụkọ ọrụ ka wee na-enye ndị ntorobịa ikike na-aga.

english: Could you tell us a bit about Simba Group's other companies?.
igbo: I nwere ike ịgwa anyị maka ụlọ ọrụ Simba Group ndị ọzọ?

english: As I mentioned earlier, along with transportation, Simba Group is into power backup.
igbo: Dị ka m kwuru na mbụ, Simba Group nọ na-eme ndabere ike (power back up)

english: Our Luminous Inverters are the most popular inverter brand in the country, we are also heavily investing in the development of solar energy.
igbo: Invata anyị a kpọrọ 'Luminous Inverters' bụ ụdị invata a kasị mara n' ala anyị, anyị nakwa etinye ego nke ukwuu na mmepụta 'solar energy. '

english: Other companies in the group include Simba Agric where we focus on mechanisation which includes tractors and irrigation systems – both responsible for increasing agricultural productivity.
igbo: Ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọzọ so n' òtù a gụnyere Simba Agric ebe anyị na-elekwasị anya n' ìgwè ọrụ nke gụnyere traktọ na usoro ịgba mmiri---- ha abụọ na-eme ka ihe akụkụ na-emepụta

english: Simba Cycles sells bicycles, SimbaNET provides business connectivity solutions to corporates and Simba Infrastructure offers Business Communication Solutions in partnership with Avaya.
igbo: Simba Cycles na-ere anyịnya ìgwè, SimbaNET na-enye ụlọ ọrụ ọsịsa njikọta azụmahịa ma Simba Infrastructure na-eweta ọsịsa nzikọrita ozi azụmahịa site na njiko aka Avaya.

english: But basically, the focus area for me is transportation.
igbo: Mana ka ọdịna mkpa, akụkụ nlekwasị anya ma a sị m kwuo bụ njem.

english: What have been the challenges so far?.
igbo: Gịnị bụ ihe ịmaka ruo ugbua?

english: We get lots of support from government institutions but there is still a huge opportunity for public and private sector financial institutions to increase the access to cheap and collateral-free borrowing, in order to provide a major boost to the industry, and the economy at large.
igbo: Anyị nwere ọtụtụ nkwado si ewumewu gọọmenti mana a ka nwere nnukwu ọhere maka ewumewu nke ego ọha na nke nnọrọ onwe ịbawanye ọhere ibiri ego n' ụzọ dị mfe na nke enweghị ihe nnọchianya.

english: How many financial institutions have helped?.
igbo: Ewumewu nke ego ole nyerela aka?

english: There has been much progress, and impetus from the Central Bank as well.
igbo: A na-enwe nnukwu ọganihu nakwazị nkwado si 'Central Bank'

english: But there's still a long way to go before we really begin to see efficient financial models coming into play.
igbo: Mana a ka nwere ọtụtụ ihe a ga-eme eme tupu anyị ebido ịhụ nlereanya nke ego dị írè ịpụta ihe n' ezie.

english: There are few microfinance banks who have partnered with us and things are getting better.
igbo: Enwere ụlọ akụ 'microfinance' ole na ole ndị anyị na ha rụkọwarala ọrụ ma ihe na-aka mma.

english: If many more banks can come and offer people loans to buys kekes and okadas at a subsidised rate or even collateral free, then things will move much faster.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ọtụtụ ụlọaku nwere ike ịbịa ma binye ọtụtụ mmadụ ego iji gote Keke na ọkada n' ọnụ ala ma ọ bụ n' enweghi ihe nnọchianya, ihe ga-aga ọsọ ọsọ.

english: What are your projections for the nearest future?.
igbo: Kedụ ihe bụgasị ntule gị n' ọdị nso ọdịnihu.

english: We see limitless growth potential in the country and the growth quantum can be much bigger than any other countries.
igbo: Anyị na-ahụ otito ike mmepụta enweghi nsọtụ n' ala anyị ma kwantum otiti nwere ike ika nke obodo ndị ọzọ nke ukwuu.

english: Nigeria can be among the top 10 economies in the world.
igbo: Naijiria nwere ike iso n' akụnụba iri kasị elu n' ụwa niile

english: I truly believe that, and our investments in the economy certainly reflect that.
igbo: Ekwere m n' ezie nke ahụ, ma ego anyị tinyere n' akụnụba na-egosi nke ahụ n' ezie.

english: Is your organisation into any Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) activities?.
igbo: Ewumewu gị ọ na-eme emume Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)?

english: CSR has always been integral to the Simba Group.
igbo: CSR bụ akụkụ ahụ Simba Group kemgbe.

english: As part of our group philosophy of empowerment, even our CSR programmes follow the same ideology.
igbo: Dị ka fịlọsọfị ikike òtù anyị, ọbụnadị amụma CSR anyị na-eso otu echiche.

english: At the heart of our offering is our emphasis on training- something that we provide free of charge to mechanics and engineers who aspire to be mini-entrepreneurs or gainfully employed in the industries we represent.
igbo: Isi onyinye anyị bụ nkwụsị ike anyị banyere ọzụzụ----- ihe na-enye ndị mekaniik na injinia ndị chọrọ ịbụ ọbere enteprịnịọ ma ọ bụ inwe ọrụ na-akwụ ezigbo ụgwọ n' ụlọ ọrụ anyị na-anọchi anya ya n' efu.

english: We have intervened in times of national disaster, such as our actions and contributions during the recent Kano floods, and have been praised for our contributions to the victims of that terrible atrocity.
igbo: Anyị etinyela aka n' oge ọdachi nke obodo, dị ka omume anyị na ụtụ anyị otuto mmiri nke Kano na nso a, ma e tokwala anyị maka ụtụ anyị nyere ndị mmekpa ahụ dị egwu metụtara.

english: We believe in wome empowerment very strongly, and our efforts to support the development of women, have taken two forms.
igbo: Anyị kwenyesiri ike n' ikike ụmụnwaanyị, ma mgbalị anyị ịkwado mmepe ụmụnwaanyị, enwerela ụdị abụọ.

english: Firstly, we have partnered with the National Centre for Women Development (NCWD) to distribute cycles to girl students to encourage them to attend school.
igbo: Nke mbụ, anyị na 'National Centre for Women Development (NCWD) na-arụkọ ọrụ ọnụ ikere ụmụ akwụkwọ ụmụnwaanyị ịnyịnya ígwè iji gba ume ka ha na-eje akwụkwọ.

english: And secondly, we run the Queen Riders programme – a programme in which we train and certify women from under-privileged backgrounds to become Keke riders and help them on the path to self-employment by harnessing the ecosystem of financiers that we have created.
igbo: Nke abụọ, anyị na-ahụ maka atụmatụ nke Queen Riders----- atụmatụ anyị ji azụ ma na-agba akaebe ka ụmụnwaanyị si ndabere enweghi ka ọ hà ha bụrụ ndị na-anya Keke ma na-enyere ha aka n' inye onwe ha ọrụ site n' ijikọta usoro akụnụba ndị na-eweta ego anyị bidorola.

english: Celebrating its 125 years of research and impacts, the Natural Resources Institute (NRI), University of Greenwich, has acknowledged the positive impacts of a homegrown technological device developed in Nigeria on value chain development of the root and tuber crops in Africa.
igbo: N' oriri afọ 125 nke nchọcha na mmetụta ya, 'Natural Resources Institute (NRI), mahadum nke Greenwich, ekwela na mmetụta dị mma nke ngwaọrụ teknọlọjị e mepụtara na Naijiria maka' value chain development ' nke akụkụ mgbọrọgwụ na mba n' Afrịka.

english: The institute admits that smallholder farmers have benefited and would continue to improve their means of livelihood with the use of value-adding devices in the post-harvest management of their roots and tubers.
igbo: Ụlọakwụkwọ kwetara na 'smallholder' ndị ọrụ ugbo eritela uru ma ga-anọgide n' ịkwalite obibi ndụ ha site n' ojiji ngwaọrụ n' agbakwunye uru na nlekọta n' oge e wesiri ihe ubi nke mgbọrọgwụ na mba ha.

english: The device, called flash dryer, dries agricultural products such as yam, cassava, potato and other granulated food commodities for elongated shelf life, higher profitability and food security.
igbo: Ngwaọrụ a, a kpọrọ 'flash dryer', na-akpọkọ ihe akụkụ dị ka ji, akpụ, nduku na ngwongwo nri ndị ọzọ dị aja aja maka ogologo ndụ, uru dị elu na nchekwa nri.

english: The project that propped up the improvement of the design by Nobex Technologies was an initiative of Cassava: Adding Value for Africa (CAVA), facilitated by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and executed through multiple partnership.
igbo: Ọrụ ngo malitere ọganihu nke mmewe si n' aka 'Nobex technologies' bụ atụmatụ nke 'Cassava Adding Value for Africa' (CAVA), nke 'Bill and Melinda Gates' kwadoro ma mezuo ya site n' ọtụtụ nrụkọọrụọnụ.

english: One of the ways CAVA2 supports smallholders is by offering farmers more 'avenues for sales' for their cassava roots.
igbo: Otu n' ime ụzọ CAVA2 si agba 'smallholders' bụ site n' inye ndị ọrụ ugbo ọtụtụ ụzọ maka ọnụahịa mgbọrọgwụ akpụ ha.

english: To ensure a smooth flow of roots from farm to product, CAVA2 works with SMEs to expand and develop processing capacity; a key issue is the availability of quality equipment and after sales service.
igbo: Iji hụ na e nwere ezigbo nsọpụta nke mgbọrọgwụ site n' ugbo ruo n' ngwaahịa, CAVA2 ji SMEs arụ ọrụ iji mụbaa ma mepee ikike mmeputa; isiokwu bụ nnweta nke ngwá dị mma na ọrụ nsote ọnụahịa.

english: The Nigerian who developed the device in working with the institute, Mr Idowu Adeoya, fabricates equipment for drying and roasting root and tuber crops.
igbo: Onye Naijiria nke mepụtara ngwaọrụ na nrụkọ ọrụ ụlọakwụkwọ a, Maazị Idowu Adeoya, cheputara ngwá ịkpọ nkụ na ịhụ ihe akụkụ mgbọrọgwụ na mba n' ọkụ.

english: The improvement to the flash dryer, which dries agricultural products almost instantaneously, was started in 2006 when the fabricator was first contacted by specialists from the Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta (FUNAAB), led by the Country Manager of CAVA Nigeria, Professor Lateef Sanni, and a food processing specialist from NRI, Dr Andrew Graffham, from the Natural Resources Institute (NRI), University of Greenwich, the United Kingdom.
igbo: Ọganihu nyere 'flash dryer', nke fọrọ obere ka ọ bụrụ na ọ na-akpọkọ ihe a kọtara n' ugbo ozugbo, ka e bidoro na 2006 mgbe a kpọtụrụ fabriketọ n' izizi bụ ndị ọkachamara si 'Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta (FUNAAB), nke onye duru ha bụ onyeisi ọrụ nke CAVA obodo Naijiria, ọkammụta Lateef Sanni, na ọkachamara na mmepụta nri si NRI, Dr. Andrew Graffham, sị 'Natural Resources Institute', Mahadum nke Greenwich, United Kingdom.

english: As part of a FUNAAB-NRI collaboration, they had encountered a Nobex flash dryer at a factory in Akure, 300km from Lagos.
igbo: Dị ka nkewa mmekọrịta FUNAAB-NRI, ha ezutela 'Nobex flash dryer' n' ụlọ ọrụ dị n' Akure, 300km site Legosi.

english: The team was interested in collecting some data about the dryer, in order to look into its efficiency.
igbo: Òtù ọrụ ahụ nwere mmasị n' ịchịkọba data maka 'dryer' ahụ, iji leba anya n' arụmọrụ ọrụ ya.

english: Mr Adeoya welcomed Dr Graffham's interest and some months later, he was visited by NRI agricultural engineering specialist, Dr Andrew Marchant.
igbo: Maazị Adeoya nabatara mmasị Dr Graffham ma ka ọtụtụ ọnwa gasịrị, ọkachamara injinia ọrụ ugbo NRI, Dr Andrew Marchant, letara ya.

english: Improvements included reduced fuel usage from 374 to 65 litres per tonne of dried product; increased output from approximately 100kg an hour to around 330kg an hour of dried product; and increased efficiency, from 11 to 55 percent.
igbo: Ịka mma gụnyere mbeleta ojiji mmanụ ụgbọala site 374 gba 65 lita kwa tọn ihe kpọrọ nkụ e mepụtara ọhụrụ; mgbago na mmepụta site n' ihe dịka 100kg n' ime otu awa gbagoo ihe dị ka 330kg ihe kpọrọ nke e mepụtara kwa awa; mgbago n' ịrụ ọrụ nke ọma site 11 ruo 55 pesent.

english: Building on CAVA2's experience and progress with the fabricator in Nigeria, a complementary initiative is taking shape in Ghana, with the development of a new, fuel-efficient flash dryer on a smaller scale.
igbo: N' ịgbakwunye n' ahumihe CAVA2 na iji fabriketọ nweta ọganihu na Naijiria, icheputa ihe ha abụọ ga-arụkọ ọrụ na-ewere ọnọdụ na Ghana, site n' imepute 'flash dryer' ọhụrụ ji mmanụ ụgbọala arụ ọrụ nke ọma n' ọbere ọnụ Ọgụgụ.

english: The University of Lagos, UNILAG Muslim Community, has commended President Muhammadu Buhari for the merit award conferred on dedicated Nigerians who have proved to be exceptional in public service.
igbo: Ndị òtù Muslim nọ na Mahadum nke Legosi, UNILAG, etole onyeisi ala Muhammadu Buhari maka ùgwù kwesiri ekwesi o tunyere ndị Naịjirịa dị uchu ndị gosipụtara ịpụ iche n' ọrụ ọha.

english: Chairman, UNILAG Muslim Community, Prof.
igbo: Onyeisi oche ndị Muslim na UNILAG, ọkammụta

english: Lai Olurode, in a commendation letter made available to The Guardian, applauded the recognition of the Comptroller-General of Nigeria Customs Service, Hameed Ali and that of Registrar, Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB), Prof.
igbo: Lai Olurode, na leta ịja mma ọ wetara 'The Guardian, ' toro ncheta nke 'Comptroller-General of the Nigeria Customs Service,' Hameed Ali na nke 'Registrar, Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB), ọkammụta

english: Ishaq Oloyede as deserving of productivity merit award.
igbo: Ishaq Oloyede dị ka ndị irite ùgwù ịrụpụta ihe kwesiri.

english: Olurode said: 'The two institutions are truly exceptional and had really shown that we need not be consistently skeptical about our own goodness.
igbo: Olurode kwuru: 'Ewumewu abụọ pụrụ iche n' ezie ma gosikwa n' ezie na anyị ekwesighi inwe obi abụọ kwa mgbe banyere ịdị mma anyị.

english: 'Perhaps, there are thousands outside of these two individuals who can perform far better.
igbo: 'Ikekwe, e nwere puku kwuru puku n' abụghị mmadụ abụọ a ndị nwere ike ime karịa.

english: The lesson in these exceptional case studies is for other public office holders to take note of factors that had assisted the rise of these organizations to pockets of effectiveness,' he stated.
igbo: Ihe mmụta dị na nchọcha pụrụ iche a bụ ka ndị ọrụ ọha ndị ọzọ mụta ihe ndị nyerela nzukọ ndị a aka weta ịdị irè.

english: Olurode however enjoined government to ensure that other moribund institutions rise to performance.
igbo: Olurode otu ọ dị gwara gọọmenti ka ha gba mbọ hụ na ewumewu ndị ọzọ n' anaghịzị arụ ọrụ bidoro rụwa ọrụ.

english: 'At the UNILAG Muslim Community, we congratulate them for their being specially recognised by the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.
igbo: Anyị kelere ndị Muslim nọ na UNILAG makana onyeisi ala nke obodo Naijiria chetara ha n' ụzọ pụrụ iche.

english: We urge them to keep up the good job and begin to mentor others for institutional effectiveness so that their exit would not usher a reversal of successes that had been attained.
igbo: Anyị na-agba ha ume ka ha jidesie ezi ọrụ ha ike ma bido ịzụlite ndị ọzọ maka arụmọrụ ewumewu nke ga-eme na ọpụpụ agaghị eweta ntụgharị ọganihu ha nweta

english: Individuals cannot travel far but institutions can,' he said.
igbo: 'Ndị mmadụ agaghị emeto njem aka mana ewumewu ga-emenwu ya,' o kwuru.

english: He said that measures were installed to address challenges by ensuring efficiency and cost effectiveness in the industry, as well as the privatisation of the port.
igbo: Ọ sịrị na a tụpụtala atụmatụ ga-agbazi ịma aka site n' ịhụ maka arụmọrụ na inwe ọnụ ahịa dị írè n' ụlọ ọrụ, nakwa inyefe ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n' aka ndị nnọrọ onwe.

english: Although it has been temporarily suspended by the Federal Government, there are, however, several underlining factors that still surround the operations of the Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD).
igbo: Ọ bụ ezie na gọọmenti etiti kwụsịrị ya nwa oge, e nwere, otu ọ di, ọtụtụ ihe na-egbochi arụmọrụ 'Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD).

english: 'We shall develop and enhance safety enforcement, minimise environmental damage and provide clear framework to enable investors to participate in maritime projects to improve growth and competiveness within the subsector,' Moghalu said.
igbo: 'Anyị ga-emepe ma welie mmanye nchekwa, beleta mmebi gburugburu ebe obibi ma weta amụma doro anya ga-eme ka ndị ntinye ego sonye n' ọrụ ngo mmiri ga-abawanye otito na asọmpi na ngalaba ahụ, ' Mọghalụ kwuru.'

english: Mr Ezenwa Nwagwu, Chairman , Partners for Electoral Reforms (PEF) says the jailing of former Gov. Orji Kalu of Abia was a proof that joining the ruling party with criminal case was not a guarantee against justice.
igbo: Maazị Ezenwa Nwagwụ, onyeisi, ndị otu nhazigharị ọnọdụ nhọpụta nke bekee kpọrọ 'Partners for Electoral Reforms' (PEF) kwuru na ịtụ nga onye chịburu Abia state, Gov. Ọjị Kalụ, gosiri na ibu ikpe a na-enyo enyo ohi banye otu pati ọchịchị dị n' aka agaghị eme ka e megide ike nkwụmọtọ.

english: Nwagwu in an interview with the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Thursday in Abuja said that the jailing has faulted the notion that once people with criminal record join the ruling party they were covered.
igbo: Nwagwụ kwuru n' ajụjụ ọnụ 'News Agency of Nigeria' gbara ya n' Abuja n' ụbọchị Tọzdee sị na ịtụ nga a emebiela nkwenye ahụ bụ na ngwa ngwa onye a na-enyo enyo banyere pati ọchịchị dị n' aka ná ha nwerela onwe ha.

english: NAN reports that Kalu was on Thursday convicted of corruption and sentenced to 12 years in prison by a Federal High Court in Lagos after he was found guilty of N7.2 billion fraud and money laundering.
igbo: 'NAN' kọwapụtara na ụlọikpeukwu dị na Legosi nọrọ n' ụbọchị Tọzdee maa Kalụ ikpe maka nrụrụaka ma tụọ ya nga afọ iri na abụọ ka ha chọpụtachara na o bu ijeri nara asaa na nde naịra abụọ (N7. 2 billion).

english: 'The judgment is a good boost for the anti-corruption fight, especially against the background of all the noise about once somebody is in the All Progressives Congress (APC) the person cannot be brought to justice.
igbo: Mkpebi a bụ ihe agbamume nyere agha megidere nrụrụaka, ọkachasị ebe o megidere mkpọtụ a na-eme na ngwa ngwa mmadụ banyere All Progressive Congress (APC) na agaghị amanwu ya ikpe.

english: READ ALSO: Orji Kalu's conviction shows Magu fears no one — Anti Corruption group
igbo: Gụ kwuo banyere: Amamikpe Ọjị Kalụ gosiri na Magu anaghị atụ egwu onye ọbụla - Anyị Corruption Group.

english: 'It is a good signal that even if you join the ruling party you will not clog the will of justice.
igbo: Ọ bụ ezigbo akara na obunagodu na l banyere pati na-achị ị gaghị emechu ikpe nkwụmọtọ ihu.

english: 'It also signals the fact that no matter how long it last, once there is the determination by the court to bring justice, justice would be done.
igbo: Ọ na-egosikwa na n' agbanyeghi oge ọ gburu, ikpe nkwụmọtọ ga-apụta ìhè ma ọ bụrụ na ụlọikpe ekpebie inye ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

english: 'We are excited about the judgment and we hope that it is also brought to bear on the Babachir Lawal's case and other cases of people with a criminal record who think that being in the ruling party is a guarantee against justice,' he said
igbo: 'Obi dị anyị ụtọ banyere mkpebi a ebe anyị na-atụ anya na ọ ga-apụtakwa ihe n' ikpe gbasara Babachir Lawal na ndị ọzọ a na-enyo enyo ohi nọ bụ ndị na-eche na ị nọ na pati nọ n' ọchịchị ga-eme ka ikpe nkwụmọtọ ghara ịpụta ihe, ' o kwuru.

english: Lassa fever kills two, infects 10 in five states
igbo: Ọrịa lassa gburu mmadụ abụọ, jide mmadụ iri na steeti ise.

english: Lassa fever has claimed two more lives in Abia and Edo states as the country approaches the peak season for outbreaks of the deadly disease.
igbo: Ọrịa lassa anapụla mmadụ abụọ ọzọ ndụ na steeti Abia na Edo dịka obodo anyị na-abanye oge nje a ji akpa ike.

english: According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June.
igbo: N' okwu 'World Health Organisation' (WHO), a mara ọrịa lassa ka ọrịa na-apụta ihe na Naijiria ọ kacha bido Disemba ruo Juun.

english: Latest figures from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), confirmed 10 new cases of the disease in five states: five in Ondo, two in Edo, one each in Ebonyi, Bauchi and Abia. In those new cases, one person each died in Edo and Abia states.
igbo: Ọnụ Ọgụgụ e nwetara na 'Nigeria Centre for Diseased Control (NCDC) na nso a gbara aka ebe na e nwere ndị butere ọrịa a ọhụrụ na steeti ise: ise n' Ondo, abụọ n' Edo, otu n' Ebonyi, Bauchi na kwa Abia. N' ime ihe a niile otu mmadụ otu mmadụ nwụrụ na steeti Edo na Abịa.

english: Man, 26, drowns at National Stadium, Surulere
igbo: Mmiri gbagburu otu nwoke, 26, n' ama egwuregwu 'National Stadium', Surulere.

english: One Sodiq Yusuf, 26, of No. 26, Horgan Bassey Street, Surulere, has said to have drowned at National Stadium, Surulere.
igbo: Otu onye a na-akpọ Sadiq Yusuf, 26, nke bi na 26, Horgan Bassey Street, Surulere, ka e kwurur na mmiri agbagbuola n' ama egwuregwu National Stadium, Surulere.

english: The police in Lagos on Sunday said that a 26-year-old man, Sodiq Yusuf, had drowned inside the National Stadium swimming pool, Surulere.
igbo: Ndi uweojii Legosi nọrọ n' ụbọchị ụka kwuo na otu nwoke gbara afọ iri abụọ na isii, Sadiq Yusuf, ka mmiri gbagburula n' ime ọdọ mmiri a na-egwu egwu 'National Stadium', Surulere.

english: Lagos Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), DSP Bala Elkana, said in a statement that a team of policemen was immediately mobilised to the scene.
igbo: Onye uwe ojii ntụsa ozi dị n' aka ná Legosi, DSP Bala Elkana, kwuru n' okwu ya na e zigara òtù ndị uwe ojii ebe ya bụ ihe mere n' egbughi oge ọbụla.

english: Man caught raping little girl inside bush in Abia (photos)
igbo: Nwoke e jidere ka ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị n' ike n' ime ọhịa n' Abịa steeti (ihe onyonyo)

english: A man was on Wednesday caught raping little girl in a bush in Abia state, around Hightaste Road by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road. According to a Facebook user, David Osinachi Nwankwo, who shared photos from the scene of the incident, the suspect lured the girl into a nearby bush and covered her mouth with his hand to stop her from shouting for help.
igbo: Otu nwoke ka e jidere ụbọchị Wenzidee ebe ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị n' ike n' ime ọhịa na mpaghara ụzọ si 'Hightaste Road' banye Ibere 'Street' nke Ngwa 'Road ' n' Abịa steeti. Dị ka otu onye ji 'Facebook' agbasa ozi, David Osinachi Nwankwo, onye tụsara foto ihe a merenụ siri kwuo, nwoke a a na-enyo enyo tụrụ nwata nwaanyị a banye n' ọhịa dị ya nso ma were aka ya mechie ya ọnụ ka ọ ghara iti mkpu enyemaka.

english: READ ALSO: Rape victim dies after being set alight on her way to court hearing
igbo: Gukwuazị: onye a wakporo n' ike nwụrụ ka a gbachara ọkụ n' ụzọ dị ka ọ na-aga ịnụ ikpe.

english: David wrote 'He was caught having carnal knowledge/raping the little girl on the picture after luring her into a nearby bush with his hand on her mouth to stop her from shouting somewhere around Hightaste Rd. by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road in Aba, Abia State today'.
igbo: David dere 'E jidere ya ka ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị nọ n' ihe onyonyo ahụ n' ike ka ọ tụbachara ya n' ime ọhịa dị ya ebe o ji aka ya kpuchie ya ọnụ ka ọ ghara iti mkpu na mpaghara ebe si 'Hightaste Road' banye Ibere Street nke ụzọ Ngwa n' Abịa steeti.'

english: Nasarawa Assembly to enact law to protect women, children against violence
igbo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu nke Nasarawa ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ihe mmekpa ahụ.

english: The Nasarawa State House of Assembly says it will enact a law that will protect women and children against violence in the interest of development of the state and the country.
igbo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu nke Nasarawa steeti sị na ya ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ihe mmekpa ahụ maka ọdịmma nke mmepe nke steeti ahụ nakwa nke obodo anyị.

english: Alhaji Ibrahim Balarabe-Abdullahi, the Speaker of the House, stated this on Tuesday when the state women led by the State Commissioner for Women Affairs, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, led the campaign rally on violence against women to the House.
igbo: Alhaji Balarabe-Abdullahi, okwuchite ọnụ ụlọ ọmebe iwu ahụ, kwuru nke a n' ụbọchị Tuzdee mgbe ụmụnwaanyị steeti ahụ nwere nnukwu ọgbakọ banyere mmekpa ahụ nye ụmụnwaanyị nke onye du ha gaa n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu bụ Cọmishọna na-ahụ maka ụmụnwaanyị na steeti ahụ, Hajiya Halima Jabiru.

english: He said that the law if enacted would protect, respect and promote the rights of women and children in order to improve their health and their standard of living.
igbo: O kwuru na ọ bụrụ na e mebe iwu ahụ na ọ ga-echekwa, sopụrụ ma kwalite ikike dịịrị ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka iji bulite ahụ ike ha nakwa obibi ndụ ha.

english: READ ALSO: Abia Assembly moves to pass law prohibiting violence against all Persons
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu Abịa na-eme ka ha hibe iwu megidere mmekpa ahụ nye onye ọbụla.

english: 'We will enact any relevant law that will put to end violence against women and children in the state.
igbo: 'Anyị ga-eme iwu ziri ezi nke ga-eweta mmekpa ahụ nye ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' isi njedebe na steeti a.'

english: 'We believe that the law if enacted will also protect the rights of women and children for the overall development of the state,' he said.
igbo: 'Anyị kwenyere na ọ bụrụ na e hibe iwu a na ọ gakwa echekwaba ikike nke ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka maka ezi mmepe nke steeti a,' o kwuru.

english: Abdullahi called on all Nigerians to protect women and children from all forms of violence for development to thrive in the state and the country.
igbo: Abdullahi kpọkuru ndị Naịjirịa ka ha chekwaa ikike ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ụdị mmekpa ahụ ọbụla iji mee ka mmepe nwere ọnọdụ na steeti ahụ nakwa obodo anyị.

english: 'Every Nigerian should ensure that women and children are protected and are not put under unnecessary violence,' he said.
igbo: 'Onye Naijiria ọbụla kwesiri ịhụ na e chekwabara ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka ma wezụga ha n' ihe mmekpa ahụ ọbụla n'ezighị ezi,' o kwuru.

english: Earlier, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, the state Commissioner for Women Affairs, said that they were in the assembly to seek for the legislature's support on crusade on violence against women.
igbo: Na mbụ, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, Cọmishọna na-ahụ maka ụmụnwaanyị nke steeti ahụ, sịrị na ha nọ n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu ahụ iji rịọ nkwado ndị ọmebe iwu n' ibu agha megide mmekpa ahụ nyere ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka.

english: 'As you can see that our women carried different placards with inscriptions such as say no to rape , no to violence against women.
igbo: 'Dịka ị ga-ahụ na ụmụnwaanyị anyị bu akwụkwọ ịkpọ ganigani e dere ihe dị iche iche dị ka jụ mwakpo n' ike, jụ mmekpa ahụ ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka.'

english: NASS inauguration: Dozie Nwankwo unifies citizens as he returns
igbo: Mwube nke NASS: Dozie Nwankwọ jikọtara ụmụ amaala ka ọ lọtara.
