english: Michael added that she had remained without a job since sustaining a career-threatening injury five years ago while playing for the club.
igbo: Michael gbakwunyere na ya nọrọ n' enweghị ọrụ kamgbe o nwetara mmeru ahụ a na-echere ọrụ ya aka mgba afọ ise gara aga ka ya na-agbara òtù egwuregwu a bọọlụ.

english: She disclosed that no form of help came from the management of the Ondo State Football Agency since that period.
igbo: O kwuputara na onweghi ụdị enyemaka ọbụla si n' aka ndị nlekọta egwuregwu bọọlụ Ondo Steeti kamgbe ahụ.

english: She said, 'For almost five years after I was injured and spent my entire earnings on treating myself, I have had no job.
igbo: O kwuru, 'N' ihe dịka afọ ise m meruchara ahụ ma mefusie ego niile m nwetara n' ịgwọ onwe m, enweghị m ọrụ.

english: 'We are therefore appealing to Ondo State Government to help us out.
igbo: 'Ya mere anyị na-arịọ gọọmenti Ondo Steeti ka ha nyere anyị aka.

english: 'I played almost five years for this team, the injury I had, government and management didn't help me. So, they should pay us our money.'
igbo: Agbara m òtù a bọọlụ ihe dịka afọ ise, mmeru ahụ m nwetara, gọọmenti na ndị nlekọta enyeghiri m aka. Ya bụ, ha kwụọ anyị ego anyị. '

english: Former Sunshine Stars player, James Moses, said government should honour the agreement it entered into with the players and pay them their sign-on fees.
igbo: Onye gbagburu 'Sunshine Stars' bọọlụ, James Moses, kwuru na gọọmenti kwesiri ịsọpụrụ nkwekọrịta ha na ndị ọgba bọọlụ nwere ma kwụọ ha ụgwọ nkwekọrịta ha.

english: Moses, fondly called 'Okomu' in his playing days by fans, said the love they had for the team had prevented them from taking legal action against the management.
igbo: Moses, onye ọ na-amasị ndị ofufe ya ịkpọ 'Okomu' mgbe ọ na-agba bọọlụ, kwuru na ịhụnanya ha nwere banyere òtù a egbochiela ha ibu amụma ikpe megide ndị nlekọta òtù a.

english: He said, 'The state has been owing us sign-on fees for long and we have been begging for them to pay us.
igbo: O kwuru, ' O teela aka Steeti jiwara anyị ụgwọ nkwekọrịta mana anyị na-arịọ ha ka ha kwụọ anyị ụgwọ.

english: 'Sunshine was my first club, I love Sunshine so much. I want them to pay us our money that is due to us.
igbo: 'Sunshine bụ òtù egwuregwu mbụ m, ahụrụ' Sunshine' ya n' anya nke ukwuu. Achọrọ m ka ha kwụọ anyị ego ruru anyị.

english: 'We are calling on the state governor to help us because some of us have families to take care of.'
igbo: Anyị na-akpọkwu gọvanọ steeti a ka ọ nyere anyị aka makana ụfọdụ n'ime anyị nwere ezinụlọ anyị ga-eleta anya.

english: In his reaction, Tajudeen Akinyemi, Chairman, Ondo State Football Agency, said the previous government agreed to pay the money in 15 instalments but was only able to offset eight.
igbo: N' okwu ya, Tajudeen Akinyemi, onyeisi, ụlọ ozi egwuregwu bọọlụ Steeti Ondo, kwuru na gọvanọ pụrụ apụ kwetara ịkwụ ego ahụ ịchafụ ịchafụ ụzọ 15 mana ọ bụ ụzọ asatọ ka o nwere ike kwụọ.

english: Akinyemi said the file for the remaining seven months had been sent to the Head of Service, who had raised the issue with the governor of the state.
igbo: Akinyemi kwuru na e zigarala onyeisi ọrụ, onye gwarala gọvanọ steeti maka okwu a, faịlị ọnwa asaa fọrọ afọ

english: He promised that government would accelerate action on the file to ensure that the former players were paid.
igbo: O kwere nkwa na gọọmenti ga-eme ngwa ngwa na faịlị ahụ iji hụ na a kwụrụ ndị a gbagburu bọọlụ ụgwọ.

english: Ex-Ondo Governor, Mimiko, Loses Mother
igbo: Nne onye jiburu ọkwa gọvanọ Ondo steeti, Mimiko, nwụrụ.

english: The 88-year-old woman, Muyinat Mimiko, died in Ondo following a brief illness on Friday.
igbo: Nwaanyị a dị iri afọ asatọ na asatọ, Muyinat Mimiko, nwụrụ n' Ondo ka ọ rịachara obere ọrịa na Fraịdee.

english: The mother of a former governor of Ondo State, Olusegun Mimiko, has died.
igbo: Nne onye jiburu ọkwa gọvanọ nke Ondo Steeti, Olusegun Mimiko, anwụọla.

english: The 88-year-old woman, Muyinat Mimiko, died in Ondo following a brief illness on Friday.
igbo: Nwaanyị a dị iri afọ asatọ na asatọ, Muyinat Mimiko, nwụrụ n' Ondo ka ọ rịachara obere ọrịa na Fraịdee.

english: An aide to the former governor, Paul Akinduro, confirmed the incident on Saturday.
igbo: Onye enyemaka aka chịburu Ondo Steeti, Paul Akinduro, kwuru ihe a merenụ na Satọdee.

english: He said, 'Mama Muinat Mosekola Mimiko fondly called 'Iye Ruka' has gone to rest. We will miss her dearly.'
igbo: O kwuru, 'Mama Muyinat Mosekola Mimiko onye a na-akpọ 'Iye Ruka' anaala na ndokwa. Anyị ga-akwa ngaramara ya nke ukwuu.'

english: Mimiko was a two-term governor of Ondo State.
igbo: Mimiko bụụrụ gọvanọ Ondo steeti ugboro abụọ.

english: EXCLUSIVE: Davido: 'No Money Osun State Can Make In 40 Years That My Dad Hasn't Made'
igbo: SỌỌSỌ: Davido: 'Onweghi ego Osun Steeti nwere ike inweta n' afọ iri anọ nke aka m enwetabeghi.'

english: *Why I stayed away from Nigeria for 8 months
igbo: 'Ihe mere n' anọghị m na Naijiria ọnwa asatọ.'

english: Nigerian singer David Adeleke, aka Davido, says there is no money Osun State can make in the next 40 years that his father, Adedeji Adeleke, has not already made as the 'omo baba olowo' crooner revealed why he stayed away from Nigeria for eight months.
igbo: Ọgwụ egwu onye Naijiria David Adeleke, onye a na-akpọ Davido, sị na onweghi ego Osun Steeti nwere ike inweta n' afọ iri anọ na-abịa abịa nke nna ya, Adedeji Adeleke, enwetabeghi dịka onye kụrụ 'ọmọ baba olowo' kpughere ihe mere na ya anọghị na Naijiria ọnwa asatọ.

english: A similar controversial statement regarding the paltry financial capacity of Osun was made by the national leader of the All Progressives Congress, Bola Tinubu.
igbo: Ụdị okwu mgbagha a banyere enweghị ego nke Osun Steeti bụ nke onye ndu otu pati 'All Progressives Congress' ala anyị gba gburugburu mere.

english: Contrary to beliefs that Davido was away from the country to promote his music on the international scene, the singer said he had to leave the country of some time due to the fillers he was getting that the government was after him.
igbo: Nkwenye nke nupụrụ isi na Davido pụrụ n' ala anyị ikwalite egwu ya na mba ụwa, ọgwụ egwu a sịrị na ya hapụrụ ala anyị nwa oge maka ihe ya na-anụ na gọọmenti na-achụ ya.

english: According to him, he needed to protect his family and associates which he was why he left the country.
igbo: Dịka ọ siri kwuo, ọ chọrọ ịchekwa ezinụlọ ya na ndị ha na ya na-akpakọrịta ya mere o jiri pụọ n' ala anyị.

english: The singer made this known at his album private listening event, Wednesday night, which held at Landmark Events, Victoria Island, where he disclosed that if he had chosen to stay things would not have gone smoothly for him as the government were beginning to track his activities.
igbo: Ọgwụ egwu a mere ka a mara nke a n' emume abọm ya, n' abalị Wenzidee, nke e mere na Landmark Events, Victoria Island, ebe o kwuru na ọ bụrụ na ya họọrọla ịnọ na ihe agaghị agara ya ọfụma dịka gọọmenti bidoro inyocha ihe niile ọ na-eme.

english: The singer whose album, 'A Good Time', will be released in October while fielding questions from MTV Base TV host, Ehiz, said, 'With the whole politics thing it was first about family.
igbo: Ọgwụ egwu a onye abọm ya, 'A Good Time', ga-apụta n' Ọktoba ka ọ na-aza ajụjụ si n' aka onye nọ isi emume 'MTV Base TV', Ehiz, sịrị, 'Ihe ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị niile bụ maka ezinụlọ na mbụ.

english: Honestly, it was first about family.
igbo: N' eziokwu, ọ bụ maka e, ezinụlọ na mbụ.

english: I was in Osun with my guys.
igbo: Mụ na ndị òtù m nọ n' Osun.

english: We saw everything in plain sight.
igbo: Anyị hụrụ ihe niile hoo haa.

english: Let me tell you a story about my uncle.
igbo: Ka m kọọrọ gị maka nwanne nna m nwoke.

english: My uncle is the last born of the family.
igbo: Nwanne nna m nwoke bụ nwa ịkpazụ ezinụlọ ha.

english: The original politician of the family is Serubawon, my father's elder brother.
igbo: Onye ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị nsinambụ nke ezinaụlọ ha bụ Serubawon, nwanne nna m nke okenye.

english: 'He was the first governor of Osun state; came back then went for senator you know when everybody for the state knows that this is the next governor and then we just woke up one day and they said he went to eat somewhere and he died.
igbo: Ya bụ Gọvanọ izizi nke Osun Steeti; nachiere azụ gawa sineti.

english: 'Yoruba culture when somebody holds an office and he passes on they either give the bride or the close relatives.
igbo: Ị ma mgbe onye ọbụla na Steeti mara na onye a bụ Gọvanọ na-abịa abịa mana anyị biliri ótù ụbọchị ha sị na o jere iri nri n' otu ebe wee nwụọ.

english: The next in line is B red's daddy and he is just a happy person.
igbo: 'N' omenaala Yoruba mmadụ jide ọchịchị wee nwụọ, ha na-enye nwunye ya ma ọ bụ ndị ikwu ya dị ya nso ọchịchị.

english: He doesn't like politics but when you lose your brother everybody knows what's up.
igbo: Osote bụ nna B Red, ọ bụ onye obi añurị.

english: With that, they wanted to give my uncle automatically.
igbo: Ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị anaghị amasị ya mana mgbe nwanne gị nwoke nwụnahụrụ gị onye ọbụla ma ihe merenụ. N' ihi nke a, ha chọrọ inye ya nwanne nna m n' akpaghị ya akpa.

english: 'A day to them swearing him in as senator they said no we want to do re-election another guy has come up and my father doesn't like wahala so he said let's go to the other party if we lose we pack our thing and go.
igbo: Ka otu ụbọchị fọrọ ka ha duo ya n' iyi ọrụ dị ka sinetọ ha sị mba anyị chọrọ imegharị nhọpụta onye ọzọ apụtala mana nna m achọghị nsogbu ọ wee sị ka anyị gaa na pati ọzọ anyị daa anyị kwara ngwongwo anyị pụọ.

english: The next day we did election my uncle cleared 16 out of 17 local government areas.
igbo: Ụbọchị na-esote anyị mere nhọpụta nwanne nna m meriri okpuru ọchịchị 16 n' ime okpuru ọchịchị 17.

english: 'He became a senator in just a week.
igbo: 'Ọ bụrụ sinetọ nanị n' ime otu izu ụka.

english: His own journey to winning that governorship primary election was out of sight that was how we knew this one nah God.
igbo: Njem ya imeri nhọpụta praịmarị ndọrọndọrọ gọvanọ miri emi nke anyị ji mara na ọ bụ uche Chukwu.

english: 'It was painful and will tell everybody here that was the real reason I was not even in the country because of the politics.
igbo: 'Ọ bụ ihe mgbu mana m ga-agwa onye ọ bụla ebe a na ọ bụ ihe a n' ezie mere na anọghị m n' obodo a maka ndọrọndọrọ.

english: I have to watch what I say.
igbo: Ekwesiri m ịkpachara anya n' ihe na-ekwu.

english: If I was around he no go dey OK for me and my people.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na m nọ ya ọ gaghị adịrị m na ndị be m mma.

english: So I had to be a man and say look let me stay away.
igbo: Ya mere m jiri mee ka nwoke wee sị ka m pụọ apụ.

english: 'We have Adeleke University all the roads that lead was done by my father.
igbo: 'Anyị nwere Adeleke University nna m lụrụ ụzọ niile gara ebe ahụ.

english: There's no money Osun wants to make in the next 30 to 40 years that my father has not made.
igbo: Enweghị ego ọbụla Osun chọrọ inweta n' afọ iri atọ ruo iri anọ nke nna m enwetabeghi.

english: The way things turned out was crazy.
igbo: Ka ihe siri gbata kwuru ezighi ezi.'

english: When asked if he got any backlash for doing what he did, he said no.
igbo: Mgbe a jụrụ ya ma ọ nwetara nkọcha maka n' ihe ọ mere, ọ sịrị mba.

english: According to him, he met an APC chieftain at a wedding in Paris wherethey both shared a joke.
igbo: Dị ka o kwuru, o zutere onyeisi APC n' agbamakwụkwọ na Paris ebe ha abụọ kparịtara amụ.

english: He said he 'felt shebi una don take am'.
igbo: Ọ sịrị' Ọ kwa unu enwerela ya.'

english: That's why I'm back, he explained.
igbo: Ya mere m jiri nachie azụ, ọ kọwara.

english: 'I'm praying every day for the country.
igbo: 'Ana m ekpere obodo anyị ekpere kwa ụbọchị.

english: Everybody is complaining why you talking about politics.
igbo: Onye ọbụla na-ekpesa na I na-ekwu maka ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị.

english: I have an American passport I could have chosen to stay there.
igbo: Enwere m akwụkwọ njem Amerịka enwere m ike ịhọrọ ịnọ ebe ahụ.

english: But this is home and I am comfortable here.'
igbo: Mana ebe a bụ ụlọ, obi ruru m ala ebe a.

english: EXCLUSIVE: EFCC Quizzes Ondo Poly Bursar, Registrar Over Funds Misappropriation
igbo: Sọọsọ: EFCC jụrụ onye ojide ego na onye ndeko aha Politeknik Ondo ajụjụ banyere iri ego.

english: SaharaReporters gathered on Wednesday that the two men were 'drilled' for authorising the sum of N68m from the treasury of the school without due process.
igbo: Sahara Reports' chịkọtara na Wenzidee na a tara ụmụ nwoke abụọ ahụhụ maka inye ikike ka e wepụ nde N68 n' akpa ụlọ akwụkwọ a n' esoghị ụzọ ziri ezi.

english: The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission has quizzed the Registrar of Rufus Giwa Polytechnic Owo, Ondo State, Mr Sule Atiku, and the Bursar of the institution, Mr Matthew Adejuwon, over alleged financial impropriety.
igbo: 'Economic and Financial Crimes Commission' ajụọla odeko aha nke Rufus Giwa Politeknik Owo, Ondo Steeti, Maazị Sule Atiku, na ojide ego ụlọakwụkwọ a, Maazị Matthew Adejuwon, ajụjụ maka ebubo e boro ha banyere imefu ego n' ụzọ ezighi ezi.

english: SaharaReporters gathered on Wednesday that the two men were 'drilled' for authorising the sum of N68m from the treasury of the school without due process.
igbo: 'Sahara Reports' chịkọtara na Wenzidee na a tara ụmụ nwoke abụọ ahụhụ maka inye ikike ka e wepụ nde N68 n' akpa ụlọ akwụkwọ a n' esoghị ụzọ ziri ezi.

english: A source, who confided in our correspondent, said that, 'The Registrar and Bursar of the institution were at the EFCC on Tuesday and they were quizzed over the role they played in allegedly misappropriating the funds of the institution.
igbo: Onye nyere anyị ozi, nke tụkwasịrị obi n' onye mmekọrịta anyị, kwuru 'Onye ndeko aha na onye njide ego ụlọakwụkwọ a nọ n' ụlọ ọrụ ndị EFCC n'ụbọchị Tuzdee, a jụrụ ha ajụjụ maka ebubo e boro ha banyere imefu ego ụlọakwụkwọ n' ụzọ n' ezighi ezi.

english: 'They were there with their lawyers and brought some documents to defend themselves.
igbo: 'Ha na ndị ọka ikpe ha nọ ebe ahụ, ha wetara akwụkwọ ụfọdụ iji gọrọ isi onwe ha.

english: 'Our investigations showed that the Bursar had his authorised signature on some of the documents which also implicated him as an accomplice.
igbo: Nyocha anyị gosiri na ojide ego binyere aka ikike ya na ụfọdụ akwụkwọ nke gosiri ya ka onye aka ya adịghị ọcha.

english: Two of them (Bursar and the Registrar) were accomplices in the ongoing corruption and fraud perpetrated at the polytechnic.
igbo: Ha abụọ (ọnakọ ego na odeko aha) so n' ihe nrụrụaka na igwu wayo a na-aga n' ihu e mere na Politeknik a.

english: A senior management officer of the school also confirmed the questioning of the two men during a chat SaharaReporters.
igbo: Otú onye nlekọta ọkwa ya gbalitere n' ụlọakwụkwọ a kwetara na a jụrụ mmadụ abụọ ajụjụ ka ya ndị' Sahara Reports ' na-akọrị.

english: He said, 'Yes, it is true that the two men have honoured the invite of the EFCC and they have been quizzed but I don't know if they were detained.
igbo: Ọ sịrị,' Ee, ọ bụ eziokwu na ụmụ nwoke abụọ zara òkù EFCC kpọrọ ha na a jukwara ha ajụjụ mana amaghị m e jidere ha.

english: I noticed I did not see them in school today (Wednesday).
igbo: Achọpụtara m na ahụghị m ha n' ụlọakwụkwọ taa (Wenezdee).'

english: When contacted on Wednesday evening over the matter, spokesperson for the institution, Mr Ojo Samuel, could not be reached as his telephone line was switched off.
igbo: Ka a kpọtụrụ n' ụbọchị Wenzidee banyere okwu a, okwuchite ọnụ ụlọ akwụkwọ, Maazị Ojo Samuel, e nwetaghị ya dị ka ekwentị ya gbanyụrụ agbanyụ.

english: Recall that the EFCC had last month invited and quizzed both the Chairman, Governing Board of the school, Mr Banji Alabi; the Rector, Gani Ogundahunsi; Deputy Rector (Academics), and Mr Olorunwa Lawson after a petition was received by the agency.
igbo: Cheta na ndị EFCC n' ime ọnwa gara aga kpọrọ ma jụọ ma onyeisi ọche otu na-achị ụlọakwụkwọ, Maazị Banji Alabi, onyeisi ụlọakwụkwọ a, Ganị Ogundahunsi; osote onyeisi ụlọakwụkwọ (n' agụmakwụkwọ), na Maazị Olorunwa Lawson ka ndị ụlọ ọrụ a nata character akwụkwọ mkpesa.

english: Some aggrieved lecturers of the school had accused the management of the institution of allegedly diverting and using some illegal means to misappropriate the school's fund into private purse.
igbo: Ụfọdụ ndị nkụzi ụlọakwụkwọ a ọ na-ewute ebola nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ ahụ ebubo na ha na-ewegharị ma jiri ụzọ n' ezighi ezi na-etinye ego ụlọakwụkwọ a n' akpa nke onwe.

english: Sources at the EFCC had earlier told SaharaReporters that there are documents linking the principal officers of the polytechnic to the financial misappropriation.
igbo: Ndị si EFCC eweta ozi gwara 'Sahara Reports' na mbụ na e nwere ụfọdụ akwụkwọ na-ejiko ndị isi ọrụ Politeknik a na ihe mmefu ego n' ụzọ n' ezighi ezi a.

english: EXCLUSIVE: Real Reason I was Assaulted –FUTA Student Brutalised By Colleagues.
igbo: SỌỌSỌ: Ihe kpatara e jiri manye m ọgụ mberede n' ezie - - nwata akwụkwọ FUTA ụmụ akwụkwọ ibe ya meruru ahụ.

english: She was attacked by her colleagues for revealing how one of their boyfriends forcefully tried to have an affair with her.
igbo: Ndị òtù ya wakporo ya maka ikpughe ka ótù enyi ha nwoke si chọọ ka ha nwee mmekọahụ n' ike.

english: Boluwatife Adekunle, the female undergraduate of the Federal University of Technology Akure, Ondo State, who was physically assaulted by two ladies and a guy all said to be student of the institution, has given more insight into why she was attacked.
igbo: Boluwatife Adekunle, nwaanyị na-agwụ na 'Federal University of Technology' Akure, Ondo Steeti, onye ụmụ nwaanyị abụọ na ótù nwoke e kwuru na ha ncha bụ ụmụ akwụkwọ ụlọakwụkwọ a, enyewanyela nghọta banyere ihe e ji wakpo ya.

english: The young lady, who says she wants justice served, told SaharaReporters on Tuesday in Akure, the state capital, that she was attacked by her colleagues for revealing how one of their boyfriends forcefully tried to have an affair with her.
igbo: Nwata nwaanyị a, onye kwuru na ya chọrọ ikpe nkwụmọtọ, gwara 'Sahara Reporters' ụbọchị Tuzdee n'Akure, isi ọnọdụ steeti a, na ndị òtù ya wakporo ya mana ikpughe ka ótù enyi ha nwoke si chọọ ka ha nwee mmekọahụ n' ike.

english: Adekunle revealed that she was assaulted in one of the private hostels outside the school campus by the group in a bid to be disgraced among fellow students.
igbo: Adekunle kpughere na ndị òtù a masoro ya ọgụ mberede n' ótù ụlọ onwe n' adịghị n' okirikiri ụlọakwụkwọ iji mee ihe ihere n' etiti ụmụ akwụkwọ ibe ya.

english: She said, 'The whole issue started few weeks ago.
igbo: O kwuru, 'Ihe a niile bidoro izu ụka ole na ole gara aga.

english: I and one of the ladies in the video called 'Faith' were roommates in a hostel outside campus.
igbo: Mụ na ótù n' ime ụmụ nwaanyị nọ n' ihe onyonyo a a na-akpọ Faith bikoburu ọnụ n' òtù ụlọ na-adịghị n' okirikiri ụlọakwụkwọ.

english: 'Her boyfriend began asking me out but I felt it was not proper for me to date him.
igbo: Enyi ya nwoke bidoro rịọwa m enyi mana e chere m na ọ zighi ezi mụ ịyịwa ya.

english: I rejected his advances.
igbo: Ajụrụ m mbọ ya niile.

english: 'But instead of him to leave me alone, the guy kept disturbing me, so I had to report him to Faith because I don't want trouble.
igbo: 'Mana kama ọ ga-ahapụ m aka, ọ kachiri ntị na-enye m nsogbu, m wee kpee ya n' aka Faith makana achọghị m nsogbu.

english: FUTA Female Student Brutalised For Calling Colleagues 'Runs Girls'
igbo: E meruru nwa akwụkwọ nwaanyị FUTA ahụ maka ịkpọ ndị òtù ya ndị achawo.

english: 'Before then, I had been having some issues with Faith as she had been living a wayward life on campus which I didn't like.
igbo: Tupu oge ahụ, mụ na Faith enwela ụfọdụ nsogbu dịka ọ na-ebi ndụ na-adabaghị nke mụ achọghị n' ụlọakwụkwọ.

english: 'From that point, she started seeing me as talking bad about her to people around our area.
igbo: 'Bido oge ahụ, o bidoro na-ahụ m ka m na-akọrọ ndị mmadụ nọ mpaghara anyị ihe ọjọọ banyere ya.

english: 'During this period, her boyfriend kept pestering me to date him but I refused.
igbo: 'N' oge a, enyi ya nwoke kachiri ntị na-enye m nsogbu ka m yịwa ya mana ajụrụ m ajụ.'

english: 'Instead of Faith to caution her boyfriend, she accused me of planning to sleep with her man.
igbo: Kama Faith ga-adọ enyi ya nwoke aka na ntị, o bo m ebubo na m na-akpa nkata ka mụ na ya nwee mmekọahụ.

english: 'On the day that I was assaulted, she invited me to a room in one of the hostels and boyfriend and other ladies were inside the place already.
igbo: 'N' ụbọchị a masoro m ọgụ mberede, ọ kpọrọ m oku n' ótù ọnụ ụlọ ebe enyi ya nwoke na ụmụ nwaanyị ndị ọzọ nọrọla tupu m bịa.

english: 'Immediately I entered the place, they locked the door and asked me to kneel down while the guy was asking if he ever asked me for a date.
igbo: 'Ozugbo m batara ebe ahụ, ha akpọchie ụzọ wee sị m sekpuruala ebe nke nwoke na-ajụ ma ya arịọnugo m enyi.

english: 'Since I refused to kneel down, they began to beat me and also tried to strip me naked.
igbo: 'Ebe m jụrụ isekpuala, ha bidoro tiwe m ihe ma chọkwa ịgba m ọtọ.

english: 'They used a stick to hit me on my head and punched me on my face.
igbo: 'Ha jiri osisi na-akụ m n' isi ma na-akụ m ọkpọ n' ihu.

english: The guy used horse whip to flog me several times.
igbo: Nke nwoke pịara m koboko ugboro ugboro.

english: 'They said they would make sure they disgraced me on campus, I pleaded with them but they refused and I was about to faint when they stopped beating me.
igbo: 'Ha sịrị na ha ga-ahụ na ha mere ihe ihere n' ụlọakwụkwọ, arịrịọ m ha mana ha jụrụ, ana m achọ ikubi ume mgbe ha kwụsịrị iti mkpu ihe.

english: 'As I speak, I feel pains all over my body due to the beatings.
igbo: Dịka m na-ekwu ana m enwe mmetụta ihe mgbu n' ahụ m niile n' ihi ihe ha kụrụ m.

english: Their plan was to kill me.
igbo: Atụmatụ ha bụ ka ha gbuo m.

english: I want them arrested and face the consequences of their action.'
igbo: Achọrọ m ka e jidere ha ka ha nara ntaramahụhụ dịrị akparamagwa ha.'

english: While condemning the attack on her daughter, the victim's mother, Mrs Florence Adekunle, said they wanted justice over the matter.
igbo: Ka ọ na-akọcha mwakpo a wakporo nwa ya nwaanyị, nne onye ihe a metụtara, Florence Adekunle, sịrị na ya chọrọ ikpe nkwụmọtọ n' okwu ahụ.

english: Former lawmaker, Shehu Sani, and rights activist, Segun Awosanya popularly known as Segalink, have condemned the expulsion of a student of Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta, over a Facebook post, an open letter to the Inspector-General of Police and his alliance with pro-democracy and human rights activist, Omoyele Sowore.
igbo: Onye bụbu ọmebe iwu, Shehu Sani, na 'obuagha' ikike dịrị mmadụ, Segun Awosanya nke ọha ji Segalink wee mara, akatọọla ọchụchụ a chụrụ nwata akwụkwọ Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta, maka ihe o tinyere na 'Facebook,' akwụkwọ ozi e zoghi ezo nyere onyeisi uweojii ala anyị na ndọnye ukwu ọ dọnyere obuagha ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na nke ikike dịrị mmadụ, Omoyele Sowore.

english: Shehu Sani, who took to his Twitter handle to express his grievance, said, 'Expelling students and sacking workers over Facebook or Twitter postings is likely to intensify in view of the growing culture of intolerance to criticisms and the establishment discomfort with the social media.'
igbo: Shehu Sani, onye jiri ebe nzisa ozi 'Twitter' ya kwupụta ka obi dị ya, sịrị, 'Ịchụ nwata akwụkwọ n' ụlọakwụkwọ na ịchụ ndị ọrụ n' ọrụ maka ihe ha tinyere na' Facebook' na' Twitter' nwere ike isiwanye ike n' ụdị mmụọ enwe nnabata nyere nkọcha na iguzogide mgbakasị ahụ nyere ntụsa ozi soshịa midia.'

english: Also reacting to the issue, Segalink wrote, 'By the grace of God, we shall be taking up this case.
igbo: N' itinye kwa ọnụ n' okwu a, Segalink dere,' Site n' amara Chukwu, anyị ga-ewere okwu.

english: The level of impunity in our citadel of knowledge is astronomical.
igbo: Ogo enwetaghị ntaramahụhụ n' ajọ ihe n' ebe mmụta anyị dị ukwuu.

english: An example will be made of this abuse of power by people who should know better.
igbo: A ga-eji mmetọ ike nke ndị kwesịrị ịma nke ka mma a wee mere ọmụma atụ.

english: Kindly advise Ifemosu Michael to reach out, so we can be properly briefed and take up the matter for justice to be served.
igbo: Nye Ifemosu Michael ka ọ kpọtụrụ anyị, ka anyị nwe ike mata ihe na-eme ọfụma ma were okwu a iji hụ na o nwetara ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

english: He is no longer alone.
igbo: Ọ bụghị sọ ya so.

english: However, despite the outcry the expulsion of Ifemosu by on the orders of the Vice Chancellor, Prof Felix Salako, the university's management are yet to give any statement on the issue.
igbo: Ka o sina dị, n' agbanyeghi oku na-aga maka ọchụchụ Ifemosu site n' ihe onyeisi ụlọakwụkwọ ahụ, Ọkammụta Felix Salado, kwuru, nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ ekwubeghi ihe ọbụla banyere okwu a.

english: Expose Prostitutes In Your Locality, Hisbah Tells Kano Residents
igbo: Gbakpo ndị akwụna nọ n' gburugburu gị, Hisbah gwara ndị bi na Kano.

english: Commander-General of the Board, Sheikh Harun Ibn-Sina, was said to have made the call while addressing women apprehended for roaming the city at night.
igbo: Ọchịagha nke òtù a, Sheik Harun Ibn-Sina, ka e kwuru kpọrọ oku a ka ō na-agwa ụmụ nwaanyị e jidere maka ikwụgharị n' obodo n' abalị.

english: Kano Hisbah corps
igbo: Ndị agha Hisbah nke Kano.

english: Residents of Kano have been urged to expose prostitutes in their localities so that immoral activities can be curbed.
igbo: A gbaara ndị bi na Kano ume ka ha gbakpo ndị akụna bi na gburugburu ha ka e wee belata omume rụrụ arụ.

english: In a statement on Wednesday by its Public Relations Officer, Alhaji Lawan Ibrahim, the Kano State Hisbah Board said that the move would lead to speedy development of the state.
igbo: N' okwu ya n' ụbọchị Wenezdee site n' ọnụ onye mmekọrịta ọha na eze ya, Alhaji Lawan Ibrahim, òtù Hisbah nke Kano steeti sịrị na nzọ ụkwụ a ga-eweta mmepe ngwa ngwa na Steeti ahụ.

english: Commander-General of the Board, Sheikh Harun Ibn-Sina, was said to have made the call while addressing women apprehended for roaming the city at night.
igbo: Ọchịagha nke òtù a, Sheik Harun Ibn-Sina, ka e kwuru kpọrọ oku a ka ō na-agwa ụmụ nwaanyị e jidere maka ikwụgharị n' obodo n' abalị.

english: He said, 'Those apprehended during the Hisbah corps patrol were young girls.
igbo: O kwuru, 'Ndị ahụ e jidere n' oge ngagharị ndị agha Hisbah bụ obere ụmụ nwaanyị.

english: 'The raids were carried out at Church Road Sabon Gari, Railway quarters, Tukur Road in Nassarawa GRA and Sarkin Yaki Road in Kano.
igbo: 'Mbuso agha a were ọnọdụ na' Church Road Sabon Gari', 'Railway quarters', Tukur Road na Nasarawa Grant na Sarkin Yakima Road, Kano.

english: 'To achieve optimum result in its set programmes and policies, the board had set up 24-hour desk officers to handle any form of security report from the general public.
igbo: 'Iji nweta ezigbo mpụtara atụmatụ na amụma ha, òtù a ahọpụtala ndị ọrụ ga-anọ ọrụ awa 24 iji leba anya ụdị mkpesa nchekwa ọbụla ndị mmadụ wetara.

english: 'All reports will be treated with utmost confidence and urged people in the state to always be law abiding citizens.'
igbo: 'A ga-eji okwukwe gbasiri ike wee so mkpesa ọbụla ma na-agba ndị mmadụ nọ na steeti a ume ka bụrụ ndị na-erubere iwu isi.

english: Ibn-Sina however, said that the arrested women would be counselled before being handed them over to their parents.
igbo: Ibn-Sina ka o sina dị, sịrị na a ga-adụ ụmụ nwaanyị ndị e jidere ọdụ tupu e nyefee ha n' aka nne na nna ha.

english: FC Ifeanyi Uba Players Attacked By Armed Robbers Along Kabba Road
igbo: Ndị ohi wakporo ndị òtù bọọlụ Ifeanyị Ụba n' ogologo ụzọ Kabba.

english: Driver of the bus conveying the team was said to have been shot while some members of the coaching crew and players were critically injured.
igbo: Ọkwọ ụgbọala ụgbọala bụ ndị òtù a ka a sịrị na a gbara egbe ebe ụfọdụ na ndị ọrụ nchịkwa na ndị ọgba bọọlụ meruru nnukwu ahụ.

english: Players of FC Ifeanyi Uba have been attacked by armed robbers operating along Kabba Road near Lokoja in Kogi State.
igbo: Ndị oji egbe ezu nọ n' ogologo ụzọ Kabba dịdebere Lokoja na Kogi steeti awakpoola ndị ọgba bọọlụ nke òtù egwuregwu Ifeanyị Ụba.

english: A statement by the management of the club on Friday said that the players were travelling to Kano for their scheduled NPFL matchday 6 fixture against Jigawa Golden Stars when they ran into a group of armed robbers dressed in NYSC uniforms.
igbo: Okwu a kwuru, ' Nke a bụ iji mee ka ọha na eze mara na n' ihe dịka 1:30pm taa, ndị bọọlụ òtù egwuregwu Ifeanyị Ụba na-aga Kano maka asọmpi NPFL nke 6 e yiwere ha na Jigawa Golden Stars ka zutere òtù oji egbe ezu yi uwe ndị NYSC n' akụkụ Lokoja na Kogi steeti.

english: Driver of the bus conveying the team was said to have been shot while some members of the coaching crew and players were critically injured.
igbo: Ọkwọ ụgbọala ụgbọala bụ ndị òtù a ka a sịrị na a gbara egbe ebe ụfọdụ na ndị ọrụ nchịkwa na ndị ọgba bọọlụ meruru nnukwu ahụ.

english: Some of the victims were said to be receiving treatment at an undisclosed hospital in the state.
igbo: Ụfọdụ ndị ọ metụtara ka a sị na-ara ọgwụgwọ n' ụlọ ọgwụ a kpọghị aha ya na steeti ahụ.

english: The statement reads, 'This is to inform the general public that at about 1:30pm today, players of FC Ifeanyi Ubah travelling to Kano for their scheduled NPFL matchday 6 fixture against Jigawa Golden Stars ran into a group of armed robbers dressed in NYSC uniforms near Lokoja in Kogi State.'
igbo: Okwu onye nlekọta òtù egwuregwu a n' ụbọchị Fraịdee kwuru na ndị ọgba bọọlụ ahụ na-aga Kano maka asọmpi NPFL nke 6 e yiwere ha na Jigawa Golden Stars ka zutere òtù oji egbe ezu yi uwe ndị NYSC.

english: The club called on the government as well as football regulatory bodies including the Nigerian Football Federation and League Management Company to intensify security on roads across the country.
igbo: Òtù egwuregwu a kpọkuru gọọmenti nakwa òtù dị iche iche nchịkwa egwuregwu bọọlụ dị n' aka nke gụnyere 'Nigerian Football Federation' na 'League Management Company' ka kwalite ọnọdụ nchekwa n' okporo ụzọ na Naijiria gburugburu.

english: Federal Polytechnic Ado Ekiti Bans Students Unionism Over Protest
igbo: 'Federal Polytechnic' Ado Ekiti machiri òtù ọchịchị ụmụ akwụkwọ maka ịkpọ ganigani.

english: The students' body had accused the school's management of plotting to install a stooge, who would do the management's bidding as their leader.
igbo: Òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ a ebola ndị nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ ebubo na ha chọrọ itinye onye ga-eme ebumnuche ndị nlekọta ka onye ndu ha.

english: The management of the Federal Polytechnic, Ado Ekiti, Ekiti State, has shut down the school following students' protest over the interference of the school's authorities in the running of the Students Union Government.
igbo: Ndị nlekọta 'Federal Polytechnic' , Ado Ekiti, Ekiti steeti, emechiela ụlọakwụkwọ maka ịkpọ ganigani ụmụ akwụkwọ n' ihi itinye aka ndị na-achị ụlọakwụkwọ na ọchịchị gọọmenti òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ.

english: Consequently, the management also banned all SUG activities in school until further notice.
igbo: N' ihi nke a, ndị nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ machikwara mmemme gọọmenti òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ niile ganye n' ọdịnihu

english: The students' body had accused the school's management of plotting to install a stooge, who would do the management's bidding as their leader.
igbo: Òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ a ebola ndị nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ ebubo na ha chọrọ itinye onye ga-eme ebumnuche ndị nlekọta ka onye ndu ha.

english: According to the News Agency of Nigeria, the protest by the students disrupted normal academic activities and vehicular movement in and out of the school.
igbo: Dị ka 'News Agency of Nigeria' sịrị kwuo, ịkpọ ganigani ụmụ akwụkwọ a gbochiri agụmakwụkwọ na ọpụpụ na mbata ụgbọala n' ụlọakwụkwọ a.

english: Some valuable facilities in the institution's School of Engineering were also destroyed.
igbo: E mebiri ụfọdụ ngwa bara uru na ngalaba ọmụmụ nkanụzụ ụlọakwụkwọ a.

english: The institution's Director of Protocol, Information and Public Relations, Adeyemi Adejolu, in a statement issued in Ado Ekiti on Sunday, denied the students' claims that authorities were interfering with the union's affairs.
igbo: Onye nhazi ihe omume, nzisa ozi na mmekọrịta ọhaneze nke ụlọakwụkwọ a, Adeyemi Adejolu, n' okwu o kwuru n' Ado Ekiti ụbọchị Ụka, gọrọ ihe ụmụ akwụkwọ kwuru na ndị na-achị ụlọakwụkwọ na-etinye anya n' ihe òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ na-eme.

english: He also described as needless and unwarranted the violent protest by the students, saying their action was based on mere rumour from unreliable sources, adding that the school's management had nothing to gain from imposing candidates in students' union election.
igbo: Ọ kọwakwara ganigani ike ụmụ akwụkwọ mere dị ka ihe na-enweghị isi na ihe na-ezighị ezi, na-ekwu na omume ha gbadoro ụkwụ n' akụkọ asịrị si ebe adịghị ntụkwasị obi, na-agbakwunye na onweghi ihe ndị nlekọta ụlọakwụkwọ ga-erite n' iweta mmadụ na ntụli aka òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ.

english: According to him, the decision to shut the polytechnic was arrived at during an emergency joint meeting of the Academic Board and Management Committee held on Saturday.
igbo: Dị ka o kwuru, mkpebi imechi Politeknik pụtara na ọgbakọ mberede bọọdụ ọmụmụ na Kọmitii nlekọta nwekọrọ ọnụ na Satọdee.

english: For Femi Falana and Kunle Ajibade: Sixty Hurrahs to Courage and Conviction By Ogaga Ifowodo
igbo: N' ebe Femi Falana na Kunle Ajibade nọ: Huree iri isii maka obi ike na nkwenyesi ike nke si n' aka Ogaga Ifowodo.

english: These two tribunes of truth and justice recently marked their sixtieth anniversary in a beautiful land made almost unliveable on any proper index of healthy living, where the average life expectancy is a bleak fifty-four years, placing us behind 215 other countries in the world and 15 in Africa.
igbo: Ndị ọchịagha nke eziokwu na ikpe nkwụmọtọ abụọ a mere emume ncheta iri isii ha na nso a n' ọmarịcha ahụ ike zuru oke nke sịrị nnukwu ike nweta n' ịgụkọ ndụ ahụ ike, ebe ihe a tụrụanya ibi bụ afọ iri anọ na ise edochaghị anya, nke mere ka anyị na-agba ndị nke 215 n,' ụwa niile na ndị nke 15 na mba Afrịka.

english: They can't hear me, but I am shouting sixty hurrays in the first instance, and sixty more (for I wish them a very long life), in tribute to their extraordinary courage.
igbo: Ha enweghị ike ịnụ ihe m na-ekwu, mana ana m eti huree iri isii na mbido, na iri isii ọzọ (makana achọrọ m ka ha nọọ nnọọ ogologo ndụ), ụtụ nyere obi isi ike pụrụ iche.

english: Dr. Ogaga Ifowodo
igbo: Dr. Ogaga Ifowodo

english: I was twenty-three and in the first semester of my final year as a law student at the University of Benin.
igbo: 'Adị m afọ iri abụọ na atọ ma nọrọ na simesta nke mbụ nke afọ ikpe azụ m dịka nwata akwụkwọ na-agụ maka iwu na Mahadum nke Benin.

english: He was thirty and already a rising star in the legal profession, though still under the wing of the urbane but ever battle-ready Alao Aka-Bashorun.
igbo: Ọ dị afọ iri atọ ma bụrụ onye chapụrụ achapụ na-awalite n' ọrụ iwu, ọ bụ ezie na ọ bụ ọkaibe mana Alao Aka-Bashorun dị njikere mgbe ọbụla.

english: I had recently ceased to be Secretary-General of the Students Union and Opeyemi Bamidele (now literally taking the bullets of enemies of democracy in our land) newly sworn in as the Chairman of the Caretaker Committee, pending the election to constitute a new executive.
igbo: Akwụsịcharala m ịbụ odeakwụkwọ ukwu nke òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ ma Opeyemi Bamidele (ugbua na-aghọ mgbọ ndị iro ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya n' ala anyị) ka e duru n' iyi ọrụ ọhụrụ dị ka onyeisi Kọmitii nlekọta, ruo mgbe e mere ntụli aka iguzobe ndị ezekutivu ọhụrụ.

english: And it was the matter of the election that led to my 'indefinite suspension' — along with Bamidele and two others, in the first instance (eight more followed suit, besides the president of the union) — thereby almost confirming my father's fear the day I informed him of my intention to run for a Students Union office: that I did not intend to graduate!
igbo: Ma ọ bụ ihe gbasara ntụli aka a kpatara nkwụsị akwụkwọ enweghị mgbe o jedebere m'--tinyere Bamidele na mmadụ abụọ ndị ọzọ, n' izizi (mmadụ asatọ ọzọ sochikwara, ma e wezụga onyeisi nke òtù) - - n' otu a ọ fọdụrụ obere ịmezu egwu nna m tụrụ ụbọchị m gwara ebumnuche m ịzọpụta ọkwa òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ: na ebughi m n' uche ịgụsị akwụkwọ!

english: Still smarting from our victory in the fight for the restoration of the union at Uniben — following the unconstitutional ban on student union activities in the wake of the nationwide protests sparked by the murder of four Ahmadu Bello University students by anti-riot policemen precipitately called to quell a peaceful protest (Professor Ango Abdullahi, the vice chancellor, would further outrage the nation by announcing that 'only four students died' as if one were not too many) — Professor Grace Alele-Williams sought to pacify her campus for General Babangida, the reigning military dictator, by issuing intolerable election guidelines.
igbo: Ka ọ ka na-eri ahụ ụfụ mmeri anyị meriri n' agha inweghachi òtù ụmụ akwụkwọs n' Uniben-- ka a machiri emume òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ n' ụzọ n' adanyeghi n' iwu ka e mechara ngagharị iwe n' ala anyị gburugburu nke ogbugbu ndị uweojii mgbochi ngagharị iwe a kpọrọ ka kwụsị ngagharị iwe udo gburu ụmụ akwụkwọ anọ nke Mahadum Ahmadu Bello (Ọkammụta Ango Abdullahi, vaịs chanselọ, gara n' ihu kpalite iwe ndị mmadụ site n' ikwuputa na 'sọọsọ ụmụ akwụkwọ anọ nwụrụ' ka a ga-asị n' ótù abaghị nnukwu ụba)--- Ọkammụta Grace Alele-Williams chọrọ imedara Onyeisi agha Babangida, onye agha na-achị ọchịchị aka ike, obi ụlọakwụkwọ ya, site n' inye usoro ntụli aka adịghị nnagide.

english: Candidates were to submit their manifestoes for vetting; were not to use university policy as a campaign issue;
igbo: Ndị na-azọ ọchịchị gara iweta ihe ga-eme maka nnyocha; agaghị eji amụma mahadum mee ihe ịchụ nta votu;

english: must not belong to campus associations (this aimed at disqualifying members of the 'banned' League of Patriotic Students, resurrected as the Cultural Awareness Club, our group);
igbo: agaghị esonye n' òtù ọbụla n' ụlọakwụkwọ (ebumnuche nke a bụ iwezuga ndị so n' òtù 'League of Patriotic Students,' a machiri amachi e mechara tute dịka 'the Cultural Awareness Club,' òtù anyị);

english: possession of a minimum Grade Point Average of 2.75; and disqualification without reason.
igbo: inwe opekata mpe akara gredi 2.75; na mwezuga n' enweghi ihe e ji aka.

english: Why call it an election, you might ask, but we were then in the early years of Babangida's political witchcraft, hence his dying need to pacify the campuses by emasculating the National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS), as well as the Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU), arguably the only organised opposition at the time to the burgeoning military terror. Our suspension was punishment for rallying the students against the obnoxious guidelines, for calling 'on students to boycott' the elections and — of course, they had to add this — 'incit[ing] them to violence and demonstration.'
igbo: Gịnị mere e ji kpọọ ntụli aka, i nwere ike ịjụ, mana mgbe ahụ anyị nọ mbido ọtụtụ afọ ọchịchị nchigbu Babangida n' ihi ya ọnwụ ya medara ụlọakwụkwọ dị iche iche obi site n' ịnapụ 'National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS), nakwa' Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU) ihe ha ji dị ebube, nke dị mgbagha bụ sọ òtù a haziri ahazi maka mbusoagha nyere mmenye ụjọ ndị agha na-etolite etolite. Nkwụsị akwụkwọ anyị bụ ntaramahụhụ maka ịkpọkọta ụmụ akwụkwọ megide usoro jọgburu onwe ya, maka ịkpọ 'ụmụ akwụkwọ ka ha jụ' ntụli aka ná ----eleghị anya, ha gbakwunyere nke a, 'ịkpali ha imesi ike na ngosiputa.

english: But that was hardly our only crime.
igbo: Mana nke ahụ abụghị sọ ihe ọjọọ anyị mere ma ncha.

english: At the time of the second petrol price increase by Babangida from 39.5 kobo to 42 kobo per litre — yes, the national currency did have value once upon a time! — the union had barely been inaugurated and so we lacked the platform for an effective protest, with the University of Jos, I believe, leading the way then.
igbo: N' oge nke ugboro abụọ Babangida bugoro ọnụ mmanụ ụgbọala site na 39.5 kobo ruo 42 kobo maka otu lita----ee, ego ala anyị bara uru n' ótù oge!--- a ka guzobesiri òtù ọhụrụ nke mere na anyị enweghi ohere ime ngagharị iwe dị írè, Mahadum nke Jos, ekwere m, bu ụzọ mgbe ahụ.

english: Then Babangida gave us a chance to salve our festering wound of non-participation: the students unions of the universities that shunned 'violence' by not protesting would each be given an eighteen-seater bus to commend their 'maturity.'
igbo: Mgbe ahụ Babangida nyere anyị ọhere ịnapụta onwe anyị na nsogbu nke esonyeghi: òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ nke mahadum dị iche iche ga-ajụ 'imesi ike' Site n' emeghi ngagharị iwe ka a ga-enye bọsụ na-ebu mmadụ iri na asatọ iji ja ha maka 'ntozu ọkè.'

english: Promptly, we made clear what kind of praise or gifts the University of Benin union would accept by holding a rally and rejecting the bribe outright.
igbo: N' egbughi oge, anyị mere ka o doo anya ụdị otito na onyinye òtù mahadum nke Benin ga-anata site inwe nnukwu ọgbakọ na ịjụ ngarị a ozugbo.

english: But the true test of the union's character followed quickly when the university decided to cancel resit examinations.
igbo: Mana ezi nnwale agwa òtù a sochiri anya ozugbo ka mahadum kpebiri ịkagbu nlegharị ule.

english: Resits gave a second chance, a lifeline even, to struggling students, many of whom were indigent, some constrained to do menial work in town to see themselves through school, and who still had to cope with poor living conditions, and non-existent or inadequate learning materials as libraries and laboratories were sapped to 'death' by the IMF/World Bank's Structural Adjustment Programme, imposed by Babangida on the nation despite its total rejection by the people.
igbo: Nlegharị ule nyere ọhere nke ugboro abụọ, ọbụna ihe dị nnukwu mkpa, nyere ụmụ akwụkwọ ndị nọ na mgbalị, nke ụfọdụ n'ime ha bụ ndị enweghị ka ọha ha, ụfọdụ n' ime ha ka a manyere ịrụ kirikiri ọrụ dị iche iche n' obodo iji zụọ onwe ha n' akwụkwọ, na ndị na-agide obibi ndụ erughi eru na ngwa ọmụmụ n' adịghị adị ma ọ bụ n' ezughi oké dịka ọba akwụkwọ na ụlọ nyocha nwụgoro site n' atụmatụ 'Structural Adjustment Programme' nke 'IMF/World Bank' Babangida kwanyere ala anyị ịnabata n' agbanyeghi na ndị mmadụ jụrụ ya kpamkpam.

english: Whatever the merits of the decision, the students would accept it only if living and learning conditions were improved, even if by a mere fifty percent.
igbo: Ihe ọ bụla uru mkpebi a nwere ike ịbụ, ụmụ akwụkwọ gaara anabata ya sọsọ ma ọ bụrụ na ọ ga-akwalite ọnọdụ obibi na ọmụmụ, ọbụna n' ọ bụ pesent iri ise nkịtị.

english: The vice-chancellor would not budge and challenged me, as the perceived recalcitrant mouthpiece of the students, to a debate.
igbo: Vaịs chanselọ agbanweghi echiche ya mana ọ mara m aka, dị ka onye a hụtara ka ọnụ na-ekwuru ụmụ akwụkwọ n' adịghị nkwadebe irubere iwu isi, ka anyị rụrịta ụka.

english: The entire university trooped to the quadrangle of the Faculty of Social Sciences to be schooled on how misguided the new students union was.
igbo: Ụmụ akwụkwọ pụtara n' ìgwè n' ámá nke ngalaba 'Social sciences' ka a gwa ha ka òtù siri gahie ụzọ.

english: As it happened, she lost the argument and was constrained to restore resit exams for the time being.
igbo: Dị ka o mere, e meriri ya n' arụmụka ahụ nke mere ka ọ nweghachi nlegharị ule n' oge a.

english: That was the last straw.
igbo: Nke a bụ ihe ọjọọ ikpeazụ.

english: Something had to be done.
igbo: O kwesiri ka enwe ihe e mere.

english: And so disregarding our request to examine the evidence and witnesses against us, and for adequate time to prepare our response to the charges of holding a rally, and incitement to demonstration and violence, the university proceeded at break-neck speed to hand us what, in effect, were expulsion letters.
igbo: Mana n' elenyeghi anya n' arịrịọ anyị ka e nyochaa mgba àmà na ndị akaebe megide anyị, na inye anyị oge zuru ezu iji kwado nzaghachi nye ebubo niile e boro anyị maka inwe nnukwu ọgbakọ, na mkpalite ngosiputa na ọgbaghara, mahadum gara n' ihu n' egbughi oge inye anyị ihe, na mpụtara, bụ akwụkwọ ozi ọchụchụ.

english: I took the query, our responses, and the suspension letters to Femi Falana in Lagos, meeting him at home in Ketu where he lived at the time.
igbo: Ewere m mgba njụ, nzaghachi anyị na akwụkwọ ozi ọchụchụ nye Femi Falana na Legosi, ka m zutere ya n' ụlọ ya dị na Ketu ebe o bi oge ahụ.

english: On the principle of fair hearing alone, our suspension would be annulled by the court, but what to do about the ubiquitous cast-iron ouster clauses in the Constitution (Suspension and Modification) Decree, the Federal Military Government (Supremacy and Enforcement of Powers) Decree, recently reiterated in the Students Union Activities (Control and Regulation) Decree 47?
igbo: Sọ n' usoro iwu inye ohere maka ikpe ọnụ, ụlọ ikpe ga-akagbu nkwusị akwụkwọ anyị, mana ihe a ga-eme banyere ihe siri oké ike maka ịchụpụ mmadụ n' ọchịchị onye ọ bụla mara dị n' akwụkwọ iwu (Iwu nkwụsị ọrụ na mmebilata), gọọmenti etiti nke ndị agha (Iwu ọnọdụnkacha na mmanye ikike), ihe e kwuputara ọzọ na nso nso a n' emume òtù ụmụ akwụkwọ (nchịkọta na usoroiwu) iwu 47?

english: Falana saw a way out.
igbo: Falana hụrụ ụzọ a ga-esi pụta na ya.

english: He would bring to aid the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights, already ratified and domesticated, which, as an international treaty, Nigeria was obligated to enforce in her courts.
igbo: Ọ ga-eweta enyemaka iwu Afrịka maka dịrị mmadụ na ndị mmadụ, nke e tinyegoro aka ma tinye n' ọrụ, nke, dị ka nkwekọrịta mba ụwa, iwu ji Naijiria itinye ya n' ọrụ n' ụlọ ikpe ya.

english: By sheer coincidence, the late Justice James Omo-Agege of the former Bendel State High Court was assigned the case, Bamidele & Ors v The University of Benin.
igbo: Site n' ọdakọ nkịtị, Jọstis James Omo-Agege nwụrụ anwụ nke 'High Court' Bendel Steeti mbụ ka e nyere ikpe a, ikpe dị n' etiti Bamidele & Ors na Mahadum nke Benin.

english: He had been one of the resource persons who helped birth the Charter during his time as an expatriate jurist in The Gambia.
igbo: Ọ bụ otu onye na ndị a mara aha ha nyere aka mebe iwu a mgbe ọ na Gambia ka ọkaikpe.

english: He was more than happy to give it life, though the university's failure to adhere to its enabling Act had already simplified the task for him.
igbo: O nwere ihe karịrị ọñụ ịhụ na ọ rụrụ ọrụ, n' agbanyeghi na mahadum agbasoghi usoro iwu n' ime ihe emeela ka ọrụ ya dị mfe.

english: He voided our suspension/expulsion.
igbo: Ọ kagburu ọchụchụ achụrụ anyị

english: I lost a semester but returned to complete my LL.B with honours.
igbo: Agụghị m otu simesta mana alọghitere m mechaa nzere LL.B m.

english: Though Professor Alele-Williams would withhold my faculty reference form and prevent my admission into the Nigeria Law School until a month before the bar exam, the battle for my admission waged administratively this time by Mr Aka-Bashorun himself.
igbo: N' agbanyeghi na Ọkammụta Alele-Williams gaara ijide akwụkwọ nrutuaka ngalaba m ma gbochie nnabata m n' ụlọ akwụkwọ iwu nke Naijiria ganye ka ule ọrụ iwu fọdụrụ otu ọnwa, onye buru agha nnabata n' oge bụ Maazị Aka-Bashorun n' onwe ya.

english: He was thirty and I was twenty-three when we first met.
igbo: Ọ di afọ iri atọ ebe m dị afọ iri abụọ na atọ mgbe izizi anyị zutere.

english: I, a law student with his head in law and his heart in poetry and literature, and he a copy writer with the defunct Grant Advertising at an indifferent address on Bode Thomas Street, Surulere, Lagos.
igbo: Mụ, nwata akwụkwọ iwu obi ya dị n' iwu mana uche ya dị n' abụ na agụmagụ, ma ya bụ ode okwu mgbasa ozi ahịa na 'Grant Advertising' kwụsịrịla ọrụ nke dị n' ebe amachaghị mma na Bode Thomas Street, Surulere, Legosi.

english: Kunle Ajibade, would soon after wend his way to the newsrooms of The Guardian, The African Concord, and TheNEWS magazine and Tempo newspaper, the last two as co-founder and editor.
igbo: Kunle Ajibade, ka e mechara n' oge n' adịghị anya jiri nwayọọ gaa n' ime ụlọ nnara akụkọ nke 'The Guardian', 'The African Concord', na 'The News Magazine' na 'Tempo newspaper' abụọ nke ikpeazụ dị ka onye so chọpụta ha na onye ndezi.

english: I don't recall precisely the occasion of our first meeting — whether the 1988 Association of Nigerian Authors annual conference at the National Theatre or on one of my many truant jaunts to Lagos to attend this or that reading — but whichever it was, I suspect that I was introduced by the late poet Idzia Ahmad, Ajibade's colleague at Grant.
igbo: Echetaghị kpọmkwem oge izizi anyị zutere---ma ọ bụ na 1988 'Association of Nigerian Authors annual Conference' na 'National Theatre' ma ọ bụ n' otu n' ime njem mmụta m mere gaa Legosi ịga gụọ nke a ma ọ bụ nke ahụ n' anataghị ikike---mana nke ọbụla ọ bụ, ana m eche na onye kọwara m bụ ode abụ nwụrụ anwụ, Idzia Ahmad, onye ọrụ Ajibade na 'Grant.'

english: It was in his days at The African Concord, however, that I really got to know Ajibade.
igbo: Mana ọ bụ n' oge ọ nọ na 'The African Concord' ka m jiri mara nnọọ Ajibade.

english: With the encouragement of Lewis Obi, its editor, and Ohi Alegbe, copy editor, I had begun contributing articles to its pages.
igbo: Site n' agbamume Lewis Obi, onye ndezi ya, na Ohi Alegbe, onye ndezi mbipụta, ebidola m ide ihe odide n' ihu akwụkwọ ya.

english: And then in 1993 I won the Association of Nigerian Authors poetry prize with an unpublished manuscript, what became Homeland and Other Poems.
igbo: N' afọ 1993 eji m akwụkwọ e biputaghị ebipụta rite ' Association of Nigerian Authors poetry prize,' ihe mechara bụrụ Homeland and other poems.

english: Ajibade who had begun a series of long interviews of established authors for Weekend Concord, was, it seemed, almost as delighted as my euphoric self and interviewed me for his report as if I were already a bona fide poet, thereby doing wonders for my budding writer's ego!
igbo: Ajibade onye bidorola ogologo nso nso ajụjụ ọnụ nke ndị ode akwụkwọ a mara ama na 'Weekend Concord,' nwere, dị ka ọ yiri, nnukwu obi ụtọ dị ka mu onwe m ọñụ na-egbu ka mmanya ma ọ jụrụ ajụjụ ọnụ maka akụkọ ya ka a ga asị n' abụrụla m ezigbo ode abụ, si otú a na-emeere odide ihe m na-eto eto ihe ịtụnanya.

english: But literature is one thing and real life another.
igbo: Mana agụmagụ bụ otu ihe ma ndụ a na-anya bụ ihe ọzọ.

english: And so it was that soon after that we would both be in the trenches during the vicious days of the Babangida/Abacha tyranny that culminated in the cruellest evil perpetrated against democracy and our sovereign right to self-determination: the annulment of the June 12, 1993, presidential election.
igbo: Ya mere na o bụ ozugbo nke a mechara ka anyị abụọ ga-anọ na trenchi n' oge ajọ ọchịchị aka ike Babangida /Abacha nke mechara bụrụ ihe ọjọọ kasị ihe ọjọọ e mere megide ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na ikike dịrị anyị inwere onwe anyị: nkagbu ntụli aka onyeisi ala nke Juun 12, 1993.

english: Jailed for life, he was, by a military tribunal set up to confirm verdicts already reached before the charges were framed.
igbo: A tụrụ ya mkpọrọ ndụ ya niile site n' òtù ikpe ndị agha e guzobere ikwuputa mkpebi e nyegoro tupu e chepụta ịgba akwụkwọ.

english: Ajibade's offence had been no more than publishing General Obasanjo's statement in denial of the ridiculous charge of accessory before the fact of treason, making Ajibade's offence purportedly that of being an accessory after the fact of treason!
igbo: Iwu Ajibade dara ebughi ibu karịa ibiputa okwu Jenerali Obasanjo kwuru iji gọọ n' aka ya adịghị n' igba gọọmenti mgba tupu a gbaa akwụkwọ, na-eme ka asị na iwu Ajibade dara bụ na o so gba gọọmenti mgba n' ikpeazụ!

english: Whenever anyone quite solicitously wondered how I coped with six months of preventive detention, I always said that I got away lightly and would cite Ajibade among other human rights and democracy activists given life imprisonment sentences, or who had spent well over a year in the Babangida/Abacha gulag, Ajibade having done three-and-a-half years before freedom came in the wake of his jailer's death.
igbo: Ọ ga-atụ onye ọbụla ihe m masịrị nke ukwuu n' anya mgbe ọbụla ka m si nagide mgbochi ntukpu ọnwa isii, ekwuru m mgbe ọbụla na obere ihe ka m ji pụta mana na-arụ Ajibade aka n' ime ndị na-ekwuchitere ndị na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya a na-emegbu emegbu ọnụ ha a mara ikpe itụ mkpọrọ ogologo ndụ ha, ma ọ bụ ndị nọgọrọ karịa otu afọ na mkpọrọ Babangida/Abacha, Ajibade mere afọ atọ na ọkara tupu nnwere onwe abịa ka onye tụrụ ya mkpọrọ nwụchara.

english: I was amused when Ngugi wa Thiong'o conceded to Ajibade the status of 'older jailbird' during a conversation with him at the 2016 Ake Arts and Book festival in Abeokuta because he had himself spent only one year in Arap Moi's prison.
igbo: Ọchị tọrọ m ka mgbe Ngugi wa Thing's kpọrọ Ajibade onye nọgọrọ na mkpọrọ ogologo oge nke okenye ka m na ya na-akparịta ụka na '2016 Ake Arts and Book festival' na Abeokuta maka ya onwe ya anọọla otu afọ na mkpọrọ Arap MOI.

english: Jailed for life, but the people on whose side he fought, as the rest of the world, hailed him for a life courageously lived.
igbo: A tụrụ ya mkpọrọ ndụ ya niile, mana ndị mmadụ ndị ọ na-anụchitere ọgwụ, dị ka mba ụwa ndị ọzọ, toro ya maka ndụ obi isi ike o biri.

english: As they hail Falana who in those days walked through revolving doors to prison cells and SSS dungeons.
igbo: Dị ka na-eto Falana onye n' ụbọchị ndị ahụ gafere ọtụtụ ụzọ mgbanwe, ulọ mkpọrọ na ụlọ mkpọrọ ndị SSS.

english: Among his peers and even succeeding generations, Falana stands tall as a people's solicitor and advocate, insisting on seeing law as a tool of social engineering rather than merely as a genteel profession of self-satisfied practitioners, best served without a conscience, by keeping silent in the face of tyranny or, even better, taking the side of diabolical governments.
igbo: N' ime ndị ọgbọ ya na kwa ndị na-esote, Falana kwụpụtara ka ọka iwu na okwuchite ọnụ ndị mmadụ, kwụsie ike n' ịhụ iwu ngwa ọrụ ilekọta ọha kama ọrụ nwere ugwu nkịtị nke ndị na-achọ afọ ojuju nke onwe, nke mma ime n' ejighị akọ na uche, site n' ịgbachi nkịtị n' ihu ọchịchị aka ike ma ọ bụ, kwanu ọ ka mma, isonyere gọọmenti ndị mmụọ ọjọọ.

english: For his part, Ajibade was editor of Tempo, the underground newspaper set up by TheNEWS crew after their magazine had been proscribed.
igbo: N' akụkụ nke ya, Ajibade bụ onye nde ziri nke ' Tempo,' akwụkwọ akụkọ okpuru ala nke 'The News Crew' bidoro ka iwu machibidoro magaziini ha.

english: These two tribunes of truth and justice recently marked their sixtieth anniversary in a beautiful land made almost unliveable on any proper index of healthy living, where the average life expectancy is a bleak fifty-four years, placing us behind 215 other countries in the world and 15 in Africa.
igbo: Ọchịagha nke eziokwu na ikpe nkwụmọtọ abụọ a mere emume ncheta iri isii ha na nso a n' ala mara mma nke n' ọ fọrọ obere ka ọ bụrụ na okweghi obibi na ngwukọ ibi ndụ ezi ahụ ike, ebe ndụ a tụrụanya ya bụ opekata mpe afọ 54, mere ka anyị nọdụ azụ 215 obodo ndị ọzọ na mba ụwa na ndị nke 15 na mba Afrịka.

english: They can't hear me, but I am shouting sixty hurrays in the first instance, and sixty more (for I wish them a very long life), in tribute to their extraordinary courage.
igbo: Ha enweghị ike ịnụ ihe m na-ekwu, mana ana m eti huree iri isii n' izizi, na kwa iri isi ọzọ (makana achọrọ m ka ha dị nnukwu ogologo ndụ), na tributi nyere obi isi ike ha pụrụ iche.

english: Ifowodo, poet, lawyer and activist, represents Delta State on the Governing Board of the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC).
igbo: Ifowodo, ode abụ, ọkaiwu na ọnụ na-ekwuru ndị a na-emegbu emegbu, nọchitere anya Delta Steeti n' ọgbakọ ndị isi ọchịchị nke 'Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC).

english: A Good Mourning, his latest book of poems, includes his reflections on the June 12, 1993 catastrophe.
igbo: A Good Mourning,' akwụkwọ abụ ọhụrụ ikpeazụ ya, gụnyere echiche nke ọdachi Juun 12, 1993.

english: FG Should Stop Subjecting Sowore To Media Trial By Femi Falana
igbo: FG ga-akwụsị ikpe Sowore ikpe n' ụzọ midia nke si n' aka Femi Falana.

english: The SSS also claimed in a sworn affidavit that Sowore had travelled to Dubai to collect millions of dollars to overthrow the President Muhammadu Buhari administration.
igbo: Ndị SSS na-ekwukwa n' iyi afidaviti ha ñụrụ na Sowore mere njem gaa Dubai ịnara ọtụtụ nde dọla iji kwatu ọchịchị onyeisi ala Muhammadu Buhari.

english: But when the SSS later found that Sowore had never travelled to Dubai or any part of the United Arab Emirates, the monstrous allegation was jettisoned.
igbo: Mana mgbe SSS mechara chọpụta na Sowore ejighị Dubai ma ọ bụ mpaghara ọbụla dị n' 'United Arab Emirates,' ha wepụrụ ebubo arụrụ ala a.

english: When Mr Omoyele Sowore was arrested on August 3 , 2019, the State Security Service accused him of engaging in terrorist activities.
igbo: Mgbe e jidere Maazị Omoyele Sowore n' Ọgọstụ 3, 2019, 'State Security Service' boro ebubo itinye aka n' omume iyi ọha egwu.

english: On the basis of the allegation, the SSS obtained an order from the Honourable Justice Taiwo Taiwo of the Federal High Court in Abuja to detain Sowore for 45 days in order to investigate his alleged terrorist activities.
igbo: Na ndabere ebubo a, SSS nwetara ikike n' aka Okwesiri nsọpụrụ Jọstis Taiwo Taiwo nke 'Federal High Court,' Abuja ijide Sowore mkpụrụ ụbọchị 45 iji nyochaa ebubo e boro ya banyere omume iyi ọha egwu.

english: But at the end of the investigation, he was not linked to terrorism in any way.
igbo: Mana na ngwụcha nyocha a, e jikọ ya na iyi ọha egwu n' ụdị ọbụla.

english: Hence, he was not charged with any offence under the Terrorism Prevention Act, 2011 as amended.
igbo: N' ihi ya, a gbaghị ya akwụkwọ banyere ihe ọbụla dị na 'Terrorism Prevention Act, dị ka e megharịrị ya na 2011.

english: The SSS also claimed in a sworn affidavit that Sowore had travelled to Dubai to collect millions of dollars to overthrow the President Muhammadu Buhari administration.
igbo: SSS na-ekwukwa n' iyi afidaviti ha ñụrụ na Sowore mere njem gaa Dubai ịnara ọtụtụ nde dọla iji kwatu ọchịchị onyeisi ala Muhammadu Buhari.

english: But when the SSS later found that Sowore had never travelled to Dubai or any part of the United Arab Emirates, the monstrous allegation was jettisoned.
igbo: Mana mgbe SSS mechara chọpụta na Sowore ejighị Dubai ma ọ bụ mpaghara ọbụla dị na 'United Arab Emirates,' ha wepụrụ ebubo arụrụ ala a.

english: Even though the allegations of terrorism and treasonable felony against Sowore had collapsed like a pack of cards, the Attorney-General of the Federation, Mr Abubakar Malami (SAN), engaged in a face-saving measure by charging him and Olawale Bakare with treasonable felony for planning to organise public protests against the Buhari administration.
igbo: N' agbanyeghi na ebubo iyi ọha egwu na ịgba gọọmenti mgba e boro Sowore amaala afọ n' ala ka kadị e kpokoro ọnụ, Ọka iwu izugbe ala anyị, Maazị Abubakar Malami (SAN), chọrọ imechapụ onwe ya ihere n' ihu site n' ịgba Sowore na Olawale Bakare akwụkwọ ịgba gọọmenti mgba maka ime atụmatụ ịchịkọba mkpesa ọha megide ọchịchị Buhari.

english: Not sure that the charge of treasonable felony would succeed in the court, the AGF proceeded to charge Sowore with cyberstalking for allegedly insulting President Buhari in a television interview and money laundering.
igbo: Makana odochaghị anya na akwụkwọ a gbara maka ịgba gọọmenti mgba ga-enwe isi n' ụlọ ikpe, AGF gara n' ihu ịgba Sowore akwụkwọ ichuzo Buhari na nzuzo na saịba maka ebubo ịkparị Onyeisi ala Buhari n' ajụjụ ọnụ a gbara na televishọn na ibupu ego.

english: Meanwhile, the organisers of the public protests, which were held in Lagos, Ogun, Ondo, Cross River and Osun states were charged with unlawful assembly.
igbo: Ugbua, ndị chịkọbara mkpesa nke ọha, nke e mere na steeti ndị a Legosi, Ogun, Ondo, Cross River na Osun ka a gbara akwụkwọ maka inwe ọgbakọ iwu akwadoghi.

english: The case filed in Ogun State has been dismissed while the defendants have been discharged following the no case submission of the defence counsel, Mr. Effiong Inibehe.
igbo: A kagbuola akwụkwọ a a gbara n' Ogun steeti ebe ahapụrụla ndị na-azara ọnụ site na mkpebi onye na-ekpere ha ọnụ ha, Maazị Effiong Inibehe, na ha enweghị okwu.

english: The defendants in the other cases have been granted bail pending trial by the various magistrate courts.
igbo: E nyere ndị na-azara ọnụ ha n' ikpe ndị ọzọ mgbapụta ha na-eche mgbe ụlọ ikpe Majie dị iche iche ga-ekpe ha ikpe.

english: Having met the bail conditions they have regained their freedom.
igbo: Ka ha mezuru ọnọdụ mgbapụta ha ha nwetaghachiri nnwere onwe.

english: But the orders of Justice Taiwo and Justice Ijeoma Ojukwu for the release of Sowore and Bakare were ignored with impunity by the SSS.
igbo: Mana iwu Jọstis Taiwo na Jọstis Ijeoma Ojukwu nyere maka nhapụ Sowore na Bakare ka ndị SSS leghara anya n' enweghị ntaramahụhụ ọbụla.

english: Although the SSS complied with the court order for the release of Sowore and Bakare within 24 hours' ultimatum, its operatives turned round to manhandle Sowore in the well of the court and later rearested him without any warrant of arrest.
igbo: N' agbanyeghi na SSS rubere isi n' iwu ụlọikpe nyere ịhapụ Sowore na Bakare n' awa 24, ndị ọrụ ya tụgharịrị ịkpụtọ Sowore n' ụlọ ikpe ma mecha jidekwa ya ọzọ n' enweghị ihe nyere ha ikike ijide ya.

english: However, because of the gravity of the charge pending at the Federal High Court, the presiding Judge, Justice Ijeoma Ojukwu had ordered the prosecutor to make available to the defendants the statements of all prosecution witnesses while the case was fixed for definite hearing on the 5th and 6th, December, 2019.
igbo: Otu ọ dị, n' ihi ịdị ukwuu ikpe a dị na 'Federal High Court,' ọkaikpe nọ n' isi ikpe a Jọstis Ijeoma Ojukwu enyela onye gbara akwụkwọ iwu ka ọ wetara ndị na-azara ọnụ ha nkwuputa ndị niile gbara akaebe akwụkwọ ọ gbara ebe e tinyere ọnụnụ ikpe a na 5th and 6th Disemba, 2019.

english: But on account of the refusal of the SSS to comply with the order of Justice Ojukwu for the release of Sowore and Bakare on bail, the defendants were unable to prepare their case.
igbo: Mana n' ihi ọjụjụ ndị SSS jụrụ ime ihe Jọstis Ojukwu nyere n' iwu maka mgbapụta Sowore na Bakare, ndị na-azara ọnụ ha enweghị ike ịkwado ikpe ha.

english: As the SSS refused to comply with the order of court to produce the statements of the prosecution witnesses the case has been further adjourned to February 20, 2020 at the instance of the prosecution counsel.
igbo: Dị ka SSS jụrụ ime ihe ụlọ ikpe nyere n' iwu inweta nkwupụta ndị akaebe akwụkwọ a gbara e yighariala ikpe ọzọ na Febrụwarị 20, 2020 n' ihi onye na-ekpere ndị gbara akwụkwọ ikpe.

english: For wasting the precious time of the trial court, the prosecutor was ordered to pay N100,000 to the defendants in accordance with section 296 of the Administration of Criminal Justice Act, 2015.
igbo: Maka igbu oge ụlọ ikpe a nọ na ya ekpe ikpe, e nyere onye gbara akwụkwọ iwu ka ọ kwụọ ndị na-azara ọnụ ha narị puku naịra dị ka nkeji 296 nke 'administration of Criminal Justice Act, 2015' siri kwu.

english: The prosecutor has since paid the said cost.
igbo: Onye gbara akwụkwọ akwụọla ego a kamgbe.

english: It is therefore embarrassing that the Federal Government which has found it difficult to prove its case in a competent court of law has resorted to the media trial of Sowore.
igbo: Ya mere na ọ bụ ihe ihere na gọọmenti etiti nke o siri ike iziputa ikpe ya n' ụlọ ikpe ruru eru nke iwu amalitela ikpe Sowere ikpe na midia.

english: Thus, in a press statement on Sunday, December 8, 2019, a presidential spokesperson, Mr Garba Shehu claimed that 'Sowore called for a revolution to overthrow the democratically elected government of Nigeria.'
igbo: Otu a, n' okwu edere ede ụbọchị ụka, Disemba 8, 2019, onye okwuchite okwu onyeisi ala, Maazị Garba Shehu kwuru 'Sowore kpọrọ maka mgbanwe ịkwatu gọọmenti nkịtị a họpụtara na Naijiria.'

english: In comparing Sowore with the Boko Haram sect, the Presidency said, 'Nigeria is already dealing with an insurgency that has left millions of people displaced and desperate in the North-East region of country.
igbo: N' iji Sowere tụnyere ndị òtù Boko Haram, ụlọ ọrụ onyeisi ala kwuru 'Naijiria na-ebu agha megide ndị agha isiaba okpu ugbua nke chụpụrụ nde mmadụ n' ebe obibi ha n' mgbago-ọwụwa anyanwụ nke obodo a.

english: The Boko Haram militants, who are behind the violence, also fancy themselves to be fighting for some sort of revolution.
igbo: Ndị agha Boko Haram, ndị na-ebute ọgba aghara, na-ahụkwa onwe ha ka ndị nwere ụdị mgbanwe ha na-achọ.

english: The link is a justification for the planned arraignment of Sowore for terrorism.
igbo: Njikọ a bụ ihe kpatara e ji kpụpụta Sowore maka iyi ọha egwu.

english: Since it is common knowledge that Sowore and Bakare are not among the well known merchants of violence and coup plotters that had successfully but illegally removed democratically elected governments in Nigeria, we are not going to join issues with Mr Shehu over the highly contemptuous statements credited to him.
igbo: Kamgbe ọ bụ ihe onye ọbụla mara na Sowere na Bakare esoghị na ndị mgbere ọgba aghara a ma ama na ndị mkwatu ọchịchị wepụrụla n' ụzọ n' akwụghị ọtọ gọọmenti ndị nkịtị a họpụtara na Naijiria, anyị na Shehu agaghị ese ọnụ banyere okwu nnukwu mkparị a sị na o kwuru.

english: But as a senior journalist, Mr Shehu ought to have known that it is highly unprofessional to subject a man held incommunicado to scurrilous attacks in the media.
igbo: Mana dị ka nnukwu onye nta akụkọ, Maazị Shehu kwesiri ịma na ọ dịghị ka ihe ọkachamara ikwanye onye e ji amaghị ebe ọ nọ na mkparị na midia.

english: We are however, convinced that Sowore will have a right of reply once the fundamental rights of the Nigerian people are restored.
igbo: Otu ọ dị, o doro anyị anya na Sowere ga-enwe ikike izaghachi ozugbo e weghachiri. ikike dịrị onye nke ndị Naịjirịa.

english: Even though the Federal Government has failed to engage in the diligent prosecution of the serious case, the Presidency has resorted to media trial while the charge of treasonable felony is allowed to hang menacingly on the heads of our clients.
igbo: N' agbanyeghi na Gọọmenti etiti enweghị ike ịkpachara anya n' ikpe ikpe ndị siri ike, ụlọ ọrụ onyeisi ala amalitela ikpe ikpe banyere midia ebe ịgba akwụkwọ ịgba gọọmenti mgba nọ ndị anyị na-ekpere ikpe n' isi n' ụdị na-eyi egwu.

english: We are however, not going to be tempted to join issues with the Presidency over a case that is pending before a properly constituted court of law.
igbo: Mana otu ọ dị, anyị ọnwụnwa isi gọọmenti ngọ agaghị anwa anyị banyere ikpe dị na-eche n' ihu ụlọ ikpe e hibere n' ụzọ kwesiri ekwesi.

english: If the Presidency is so sure that our clients committed treasonable felony or any other offence whatsoever, it should keep its powder dry and advise the prosecution to commence the trial without any further delay.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na o doro ụlọ ọrụ onyeisi ala anya ọfụma na ndị anyị na-ekpere ikpe gbara gọọmenti mgba ma ọ bụ daa iwu ọzọ ' ụdị ọbụla, ya kee nkwụcha ma gwa ndị ikpe ka ha bido ikpe n' egbughi oge ọbụla.

english: Fire Burns 12 Corpses Inside Obafemi Awolowo University Morgue
igbo: Ọkụ gbara ozu 12 n' ime ebe ndebe ozu Obafemi Awolowo University

english: She said no life was lost to the incident but about 12 corpses kept in the cabin inside the morgue were affected.
igbo: Ọ sịrị na onweghi ndụ a tụnyere ihe a merenụ mana ihe dịka ozu 12 e debere na kabin ebe ndebe ozu ka ọ metụtara.

english: About 12 corpses were on Tuesday burnt in an early morning fire that razed the morgue of Anatomy Department of Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile Ife, Osun State, according to a report by PUNCH.
igbo: Ihe dịka ozu 12 ka ọkụ gbara n' ụbọchị Tuzdee n' ọkụ ọnụ ụtụtụ gbapiara ebe ndebe ozu nke ngalaba Anatọmị nke Mahadum Obafemi Awolowo, Ile Ife, Osun Steeti, dị ka 'Punch' si kọwapụta.

english: Spokesperson for the Osun Police Command, Folasade Odoro, confirmed the incident.
igbo: Okwuchite ọnụ Osun Polis Kọmandị, Folasade Odoro, kwetara n' ihe merenụ.

english: She said no life was lost to the incident but about 12 corpses kept in the cabin inside the morgue were affected.
igbo: Ọ sịrị na onweghi ndụ a tụnyere ihe a merenụ mana ihe dịka ozu 12 e debere na kabin ebe ndebe ozu ka ọ metụtara.

english: Odoro added that the detectives from the command were already investigating the cause of the incident.
igbo: Odoro gbakwunyere na ndị nchọpụta si kọmandị a ebidola nnyocha ihe butere ihe a merenụ.

english: Public Relations Officer of the university, Abiodun Olanrewaju, in a statement said about 102 bodies were kept in the morgue when the fire caused by power surge started around 3:00am on Tuesday.
igbo: Onye mgbasa ọhaneze nke mahadum, Abiodun Olanrewaju, n' okwu ya kwuru na ihe dịka ozu 102 ka e debere n' ebe ndebe ozu mgbe ọkụ a nke mgbago n' ike ọkụ latriik butere bidoro n' ihe dịka 3:00am ụbọchị Tuzdee.

english: He said, 'The fire, which broke out at 3:00am today (Tuesday, November 19, 2019) was caused by electricity surge which affected a section of the morgue where corpses are kept.
igbo: O kwuru, 'Ọkụ a, nke bidoro na 3:00am taa (Tuesday, November 19, 2019) bụ mgbago ọkụ latriik n' ike butere ya nke metụtara otu mpaghara ebe ndebe ozu e debere ozu.

english: 'Out of about 102 bodies kept in the morgue, 12 were affected by the fire outbreak.
igbo: 'N' ime ihe dị ka ozu 102 e debere n' ebe ndebe ozu, ọkụ ọgbụgba metụtara 12.

english: 'The department has made detailed arrangements to duly and adequately inform those who have kept bodies (corpses) in the morgue.'
igbo: 'Ngalaba a emela nhazi zuru okè iji zie ndị debere ozu n' ebe ndebe ozu ozi.'

english: Five Lessons Learnt From Anthony Joshua's Comeback Victory By Samuel Osho
igbo: Ihe mmụta ise e nwetara na mmeri nlọghachi Anthony Joshua.

english: Our fears are as strong as the belief we put in them.
igbo: Egwu na-atụ anyị dị ike ka nkwenye anyị tinyere n' ime ha.

english: Joshua stepped into the ring and used his fears to his advantage;
igbo: Joshua zọnyere ụkwụ n' ogige ịkụ ọkpọ ma were egwu ya mee ihe bara ya uru;

english: he faced his demons and punched them until they got exhausted.
igbo: ọ chere ajọ mmụọ ya ihu ma kụwa ha ọkpọ ganye n' ike agwụla ha.

english: The suspense in the misty air of Diriyah Arena turned to an atmosphere of celebration as Nigerian-born British heavyweight boxer, Anthony Joshua, reclaims his titles.
igbo: Obi iko n'elu dị n' edonghi anya nke 'Diriyah Arena' tụgharịrị bụrụ ihe ọñụ ka ọkụ ọkpọ 'heavyweight' onye Britain a mụrụ na Naijiria, Anthony Joshua, bughachitere ihe nrite ya.

english: Joshua's tense rematch with Andy Ruiz remains one of the most significant moments in 2019 for the world of boxing.
igbo: Nnwegharị machị Joshua na Ruiz kpọtụrụ akpọtụ ka bụ otu n' ime oge kasị dị mkpa na 2019 n' ụwa ịkụ ọkpọ.

english: Andy Ruiz stunned the world six months ago at the Madison Square Garden in New York after a big upset that ended in a technical knockout.
igbo: Andy Ruiz gbagwojuru ụwa anya n' ọnwa isi gara aga n' ogige Madison Square na Nu Yok na nnukwu mkpasuiwe biri na nkutu akpachapụrụ anya.

english: Ruiz, an underdog, knocked Joshua to the canvass four times before the referee stopped the fight in the seventh round after a flurry of punches.
igbo: Ruiz, onweghi onye mara ya, kuturu Joshua na kanvasị ugboro anọ tupu referii akwụsị ha ọgwụ na ugboro nke asaa ka ọ kụrụ ya ọkpọ dara ụda.

english: On that night, Ruiz made history as the first boxer of Mexican descent to become a heavyweight title winner.
igbo: N' abalị ahụ Ruiz mere ihe banyere n' akụkọ mere eme dị ka ọkụ ọkpọ mbụ si Mexico ritere ihe nrite 'heavyweight.'

english: In Saturday night's rematch, the world saw a different Anthony Joshua with rare mettle and prowess required for success in the boxing ring.
igbo: N' nnwegharị machị abalị Satọdee, ụwa niile hụrụ Anthony Joshua dị iche nwere mkpebi dị ụkọ na nkà pụrụ iche a chọrọ maka ọganihu n' ogige ịkụ ọkpọ.

english: His athleticism, technicalities, and sportsmanship were on display as the world stood still to watch a resilient fighter reclaim his lost titles.
igbo: O gosiri ike ya, ụdị o ji akụ ọkpọ na mmụọ egwuregwu ya dị ka mba ụwa niile kwụrụ ikiri onye ọgụ nwere obi isi ike ka ọ na-nara ihe nrite ya fuburu efu.

english: It was an emotional moment for Joshua, who had a sweet return to the number one spot in the heavyweight boxing division.
igbo: Ọ bụ oge mmetụta obi nyere Joshua, onye nwere nlọghachi dị ụtọ n' ihe egwuregwu nke mbụ na nkewa ịkụ ọkpọ 'heavyweight.'

english: He won in style and became a two-time world heavyweight champion with a unanimous victory over Andy Ruiz.
igbo: O meriri n' ụzọ dị egwu ma bụrụ onye mmeri 'heavyweight' ụwa niile nke ugboro abụọ na mmeri onye ọbụla kwenyere na ya o meriri Andy Ruiz.

english: During the build-up to the match, there were fears if Joshua had the mental fortitude to fight his demons and go for a win.
igbo: N' oge nkwado machị a, enwere egwu ma Joshua onwere obi isi ike iji buso ihe ndị na-esogbu ya agha ma merie.

english: On Saturday, he reassured his teeming fans and answered lots of questions.
igbo: N' ụbọchị Satọdee, ọ kwekwara ndị ihe ya na-amasị nkwa ọzọ ma zaa ọtụtụ ajụjụ.

english: Those answers came with quick jabs, timely hooks, and calculated movements, all delivered in a 36 minutes show of clinical finish.
igbo: Azịza ndị ahụ bụ banyere ịkụ ọkpọ ngwa ngwa, ịkpọ nku aka n' oge okwesiri na ije a gbakọrọ agbakọ, inye ha ncha n' ime ngosi nkeji 36 klinikal finishi.

english: With the comeback victory, Joshua joined Muhammad Ali, Lennox Lewis, Evander Holyfield, Floyd Patterson and Mike Tyson in the league of men to have reclaimed the world heavyweight title.
igbo: Maka mmeri nlọghachite azụ a, Joshua sonyeere Muhammad Ali, Lennox Lewis, Evander Holyfield, Floyd Patterson na Mike Tyson n' òtù ụmụ nwoke ndị bughachiterela ihe nrite 'heavyweight' ụwa niile.

english: In this historical moment, there are lessons to learn from a man that came back from the dead to knock out the same person that gifted him his first career defeat.
igbo: N' ime oge a dị nnukwu mkpa n' akụkọ ihe mere eme, onwere ọtụtụ ihe mmụta n' aka nwoke a si n' ike ọgwụgwụ nachie azụ ịkụpụ otu onye ahụ nyere ya mmeri izizi n' ọrụ ya.

english: Fela Kuti lives on
igbo: Fela Kuti ka dị ndụ.

english: Ahead of his much-anticipated fight with Ruiz in Saudi Arabia, Joshua paid homage to his Nigerian roots.
igbo: Tupu ọgwụ a tụrụanya ya nke ukwuu dị n' etiti ya Ruiz na Saudi Arabia, Joshua zọrọ ụkwụ na Naijiria ebe o si.

english: The British boxer with Nigerian parents chose a tune by Nigerian multi-talented musician, Fela Kuti, as his entrance song.
igbo: Ọkụ ọkpọ Britain a nne na nna bụ ndị Naịjirịa họrọ egwu nke si n' aka ọkụ egwu Naijiria nwere onyinye dị iche iche, Fela Kuti, ka egwu mbata ya.

english: The song, Water No Get Enemy by Fela, a trailblazer of Afrobeat music and a fearless human rights activist, was perfect for the occasion and a precursor for a historic night.
igbo: Egwu a, 'Water No Get Enemy' nke si n' aka Fela, ọsụ ụzọ egwu 'Afrobeat' obuagha ikike dịrị mmadụ na-anaghị atụ egwu, kwesiri ọnọdụ a nke ọma mana na-arutu aka n' abalị dị mkpa n' akụkọ ihe mere eme.

english: During Joshua's visit to Nigeria in July, he stopped by at Fela's shrine in Lagos, where Femi Kuti showed him around.
igbo: Oge Joshua bịara Naijiria na Julaị, ọ kwụsịrị n' òkwú Fela na Legosi, ebe Femi Kuti gbọgharịrị ya.

english: This victorious match reminded everyone of Fela's undying legacy.
igbo: Machị mmeri a chetara onye ọbụla ihe nlereanya Fela dị anwụ anwụ.

english: Stay hungry for a win
igbo: Nọdụ n' agụụ mmeri

english: There are no friends in the ring, and the best way to come out of the ring victorious is by inflicting damage on the opponent.
igbo: Enweghi enyi n' ogige ịkụ ọkpọ, ma ụzọ kasị mma iji jiri mmeri si n' ogige ịkụ ọkpọ pụta bụ site n' imerụ onye iro gị ahụ.

english: In the first match in New York, it was apparent that Joshua lacked the hunger needed for victory.
igbo: Na machị nke izizi na Nu Yọk, o woro anya na Joshua enweghi agụụ a chọrọ maka mmeri.

english: After hitting the canvas in the third round, Joshua appeared lost and uncoordinated; he struggled through the remaining rounds before the referee waved the fight off.
igbo: Ka ọ kụsiri kanvasi na ugboro nke atọ, ọ dịka Joshua enwetaghị onwe ya ma ọ chịkọtaghị onwe ya, ọ gbalịrị n' ugboro ndị fọrọ afọ tupu referii egbubie ọgwụ ahụ.

english: In the rematch, it was evident that Joshua was hungry for a victory.
igbo: Na nnwegharị machị, o doro anya na agụụ mmeri na-agụ Joshua.

english: He was there to prove a point and retrieve his lost belts that were on exile in California.
igbo: Ọ nọ ebe ahụ igosi ebumnuche ya ma weghachite beltu ya o tụfuru nọ n' ala Kalifonịa.

english: The hunger reflected in the superb head and body movement aimed at dodging Ruiz's punches.
igbo: Agụụ a gosiri ọmarịcha ụzọ o si emegharị isi na ahụ iji zere ọkpọ Ruiz.

english: If there were anything Joshua learned after his defeat, it would be to stay hungry in the face of any opposition.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na onwere ihe Joshua mụtara ka e merisiri ya, ọ ga-abụ ịnọ n' agụụ n' ihu ihe chere ya aka mgba.

english: Stick to the game plan
igbo: Jidesie atụmatụ egwuregwu ike.

english: Before his first match with Ruiz, everyone was used to Joshua decapitating his opponents before the final round with an exception for the bout with Joseph Parker.
igbo: Tupu Maachị izizi ya na Ruiz, ọ marala onye ọbụla na Joshua na-emeri onye ha abụọ na-agba mgba tupu ugboro nke ikpe azụ beeresọ ọkpọ ya na Joseph Parker kụrụ.

english: For many of the fans, they wanted to see an angry Joshua in the ring with a shower of punches to revenge his humiliating loss in June.
igbo: N' ọtụtụ ndị faan nọ, ha chọrọ ịhụ Joshua iwe juru obi n' ogige mgba ga-eji ọtụtụ ọkpọ bọọ ọbọ nfulahu mmebọ ọ nwere na Juun.

english: It was not a big ask from a man that has 21 knockouts out of 22 professional wins.
igbo: O bughi ibu ịtụnanya ihe dị otú a n' aka nwoke nwere nkutu 21 n' ime mmeri 22 o meriri n' ọrụ ya.

english: Let the 'champ' do the magic again.
igbo: Ka onye mmeri a mee anwansi a ọzọ.

english: While that seems like a brilliant plan that could drive the fans wild, it would have placed Joshua in a vulnerable position resulting in a second defeat.
igbo: Ka nke ahụ dị ka atụmatụ amamihe ga-enye ndị faan nnukwu obi añurị, ọ gaara etinye Joshua n' Ọnọdụ ọjọọ ga-ebutere ya mmeri nke ugboro abụọ.

english: It would have been a blatant display power without tactfulness.
igbo: Ọ gaara abụ igosi ike ghe anya oghe n' enweghị akọ.

english: It is quite understandable if the critics wanted a spectacular match, but often, the key to victory is taking calculated risks and not doing what everyone expects.
igbo: Ọ kwere nghọta n' ezie ma ọ bụrụ na ndị nkatọ chọrọ machị pụrụ iche, mana mgbe ụfọdụ, isi mmeri bụ ịgbakọọ ihe ize ndụ ị na-ara na ọbụghị ihe onye ọbụla chere.

english: Joshua understood the difference between showmanship and professionalism.
igbo: Joshua ghọtara ihe dị iche n' etiti oké ihe ngosi na igosi nkà n' ọrụ.

english: He took the stance of a professional pugilist and displayed a tactical understanding of the sport to wear out his opponent.
igbo: Ọ were ọnọdụ ọkachamara n' ịkụ ọkpọ ma gosi nghọta usoro pụrụ iche nke egwuregwu iji mee ka ike gwụ onye ha abụọ na-akụ ọkpọ.
