igbo: E wezụga ihe akaebe doro anya nke ego e nwetara n' ahụ ndị ohi nke isi ụlọ ọrụ DNC na-arụgara ndị ọrụ Nixon aka, nchọpụta gosiri na onyeisi ala Nixon nwere ihe usoro ndekọ okwu nke teepu n' ụlọ ọrụ ya ebe ọ dekọrọ mkparịta ụka abughi nke ọha.

english: After grueling court battles, the Supreme Court ruled that the President was obligated to release the infamous tapes to government investigators.
igbo: Ka agha ụlọ ikpe na-agwụ ike gachara, ụlọ ikpe ukwu kpebiri na iwu ji onyeisi ala iweputara ndị nchọcha gọọmenti teepu ọjọọ ahụ niile.

english: The tapes bore damning evidence that President Nixon was irrefutably involved in the break-in of the DNC office and abuse of power to cover up the investigation.
igbo: Teepu ahụ gbara akaebe adịghị mgbagha na aka onyeisi ala dị na mgbaka nke ụlọ ọrụ DNC na mmetọ ike ọchịchị iji kpuchie nchọpụta ya.

english: In light of a predictable impeachment, on 9 August 1974, Nixon resigned his turbulent presidency.
igbo: N' itule nchụtu nwere ike ịpụta, n' Ọgọstụ 9 1974, Nixon pụrụ n' ọkwa onyeisi ala ya jupụtara n' ọgba aghara.

english: 'Watergate' the name became synonymous with political or public scandal not just in the United States but globally as well.
igbo: 'Watergate' aha ahụ bụrụ ihe e ji mara nkwụtọ ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị ma ọ bụ nke ọha ọ bụghị sọ n' Amerịka kama ụwa niile gbaa gburugburu.

english: On October 8, 1998, the United States House of Representatives commenced impeachment proceedings against President Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the U.S. under the accusation of 'high crimes and misdemeanors'.
igbo: N' Ọktoba 8,1998, ụlọ nnọchiteanya nke Amerịka bidoro usoro nchụtu megide onyeisi ala Bill Clinton, onyeisi ala U.S. nke 42, maka ebubo 'mpụ dị elu na ịda iwu'.

english: The reasons were for lying under oath and obstruction of justice tied to the sexual harassment lawsuit filed against Clinton by a woman named Paula Jones.
igbo: Ihe ndị kpatara ya bụ maka ịtụ asị n' iyi ọ ñụrụ na igbochi ikpe mkwụmọtọ nke gbadoro ụkwụ na akwụkwọ mmanye mmekọahụ nwaanyị a na-akpọ Paula Jones gbara megide Clinton.

english: This would be the second time an American president would be impeached where the House formally adopted the articles of impeachment and forwarded them to the Senate for adjudication.
igbo: Nke a ga-abụ nke ugboro abụọ a ga-achụtu onyeisi ala mba Amerịka n' ọchịchị ebe ụlọ nnọchiteanya nabatara edide nchụtu n' ụdị ma zigara ya sineti maka mkpebi.

english: I remember vividly the frenzy by paparazzi when the proceedings of impeachment began in January 1999 with the Chief Justice William Rehnquist presiding.
igbo: Echetara m nke ọma ime ara ara nke onye oze foto mgbe usoro nchụtu bidoro na Jenụwarị 1999 nke Chiifu Jọstis William Rehnquist nọ n' isi ya.

english: After sensational interviews and depositions, President Bill Clinton was acquitted on February 12, 1999, on both counts of high crimes and misdemeanors as neither charges received the necessary two- thirds majority vote of the Senators present for conviction and removal from office.
igbo: Ka a gbasiri ya ajụjụ ọnụ n' akpali akpali ma wega azịza ya n' ụlọ ikpe, a hapụrụ onyeisi ala Bill Clinton na Febrụwarị 12, 1999, n' ikpe abụọ nke mpụ dị elu na ịda iwu ka onweghi nke nwetara ọnụ ọgụgụ votu ka ụba nke abụọ n' ụzọ atọ ndị Sineti nọ ya maka amamikpe na mwepụ n' ụlọ ọrụ.

english: President Bill Clinton remained in office for the rest of his second term.
igbo: Onyeisi ala Bill Clinton nọrọ ọchịchị ganye na ngwụcha agba abụọ nke ọchịchị ya.

english: Donald J. Trump won the Electoral College with 304 votes compared to 227 votes for Hillary Clinton despite pre-election nationwide polls that predicted she would win.
igbo: Donald J. Trump ji votu 304 merie ndi nnọchiteanya ntụli aka n' ịtụnyere votu 227 Hillary Clinton n' agbanyeghi nhọpụta mba dum tupu ntụli aka buru amụma na ọ ga-eme win.

english: Globally women had been excited as her victory would have been a symbol of gender equality with a female being the leader of the free world, the great United States of America, land of dreams.
igbo: N' ụwa niile ụmụ nwaanyị enweela obi ụtọ na mmeri ya gaara abụ akara nhatanha okike maka nwaanyị ịbụ onye ndu nke ụwa kenwere onwe, steeti kenjikọta nke Amerịka, ala nrọ.

english: It was a bitter defeat for billions all over the world.
igbo: Ọ bụ mmeri mwute nyere ijeri n' ụwa dum.

english: Almost immediately, President Trump's presidency was riddled in controversies, accusations, and scandals amidst a chaotic White House.
igbo: Ọ fọrọ ntakịrị ka ọ bụrụ ozugbo ka ịbụ onyeisi ala onyeisi ala Trump jupụtara na mgbagha, ebubo, na nkwụtọ n' etiti ọgbaghara dị na 'White House.'

english: One could say that ultimately Hillary Clinton may have had the last laugh after all.
igbo: Mmadụ nwere ike ikwu na n' ikpeazụ nwere ike bụrụ onye nwere agamniihu n' agbanyeghi ihe niile.

english: The White House Staff were either dismissed or they quit by themselves and replaced on a regular basis, even the press struggled to keep up with the changes.
igbo: Ndị ọrụ 'White House' ka a chụrụ n' ọrụ ma ọ bụ ha jiri aka ha kwụsị ọrụ a na-edochi ha kwa ụbọchị, ọbụnadị ndị nta akụkọ gbalịrị ịnagide mgbanwe a.

english: A massive scandal subsequently broke out alleging that Russia had meddled in the 2016 presidential election and the President took great pains to undermine the investigation.
igbo: Nnukwu nkwụtọ mesiri dapụta nke na-ekwu na Russia tinyere aka ná ntụli aka onyeisi ala nke 2016 nakwa na onyeisi ala gbara nnukwu mbọ igbochi nchọpụta a.

english: It posed a threat to national security and made a mockery of the American voting system.
igbo: Ọ bụ ihe egwu nyere nchekwa obodo ma mee usoro atụm votu nke Amerịka ihe ọchị.

english: The Russia scandal, the firing of James Comey (former FBI Director), resignation of Michael Flynn (former national adviser) and many more obstacles in his administration proved this to be the most troubled presidency in modern history.
igbo: Nkwụtọ nke Russia, ọchụchụ James Comey (Daịretọ FBI na mbụ), arụkwaghịm nke Michael Flynn (onye ndụmọdụ nke obodo na mbụ) na ọtụtụ ọgbatụhie ndị ọzọ n' ọchịchị ya gosiri na nke a kacha bụrụ onyeisi ala kacha nwe nsogbu n' akụkọ ihe mere eme ọgbara ọhụrụ.

english: All this was happening amidst a barrage of regular tweets from the President on his official account on social media, which most see as unbecoming and entirely inappropriate for a President in office.
igbo: Ihe a niile na-eme n' etiti ọtụtụ twiit nke si n' aka onyeisi ala kwa ụbọchị n' akaụntụ soshịa midia ya, nke ọtụtụ mmadụ na-ekwesịghị ekwesị n' ọ bụla n' onyeisi ala no.

english: The latest Ukraine scandal was triggered by President Trump's alleged efforts to coerce Ukraine and other countries to provide damaging information about the 2020 Democratic Party candidate Joe Biden.
igbo: 'Nkwụtọ Ukraine nke ikpeazụ a ka e kwuru na ọ bụ mgbali nke onyeisi ala Trump ịmanye Ukraine na mba ndị ọzọ iweta ọmụma jọgburu onwe ya banyere onye ji 'Democratic Party' azọ ọkwa na 2020, Joe Biden kpalitere ya.

english: President Trump was said to have pressured his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, Attorney General, Bill Barr and other parties outside his administration to influence politics in Washington.
igbo: Onyeisi ala Trump ka e kwuru na ọ manyela ọkaiwu nke aka ya, Rudy Giuliani, Ọkaiwu izugbe, Bill Barr, and ndị ọzọ n' anọghị n' ọchịchị ya ka ha nwe mmetụta nye ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị na Washington.

english: The 2016 Presidential election scandal also has not disappeared.
igbo: Nkwụtọ ntụli aka onyeisi ala nke 2016 apụbeghi.'

english: In the middle of September 2019, Trump's misuse of power to solicit foreign electoral intervention in the 2020 U.S. presidential campaign came into the full glare of the public because of a whistleblower statement made in August 2019.
igbo: N' etiti Septemba 2019, ejizighi ike ọchịchị nke Trump n' ịrịọ enyemaka mba ọzọ na achụmnta votu maka okwa onyeisi ala U.S. n' afo 2020 putara ihe n' ihi okwu o kwuru n' Ogostu 2019.

english: Then on 24 September 2019, the House of Representatives initiated a formal impeachment inquiry led by six House Committees and the House voted to approve guidelines for the next phase of the impeachment inquiry on 31 October 2019.
igbo: Mgbe ahụ na Septemba 2019, ụlọ nnọchiteanya bidoro amụma njupụta nchụtu nke ndị Kọmitii isi ụlọ nnọchiteanya nọ n' isi ya ebe ndị ụlọ nnọchiteanya tụrụ votu iji nabata ụkpụrụ ndụzi maka ogo njupụta nchụtu ọzọ n' Ọktoba 31, 2019.

english: To impeach President Trump, a majority is required in the House and for conviction or removal from office a two- thirds 'super majority' is required in the senate.
igbo: Iji chụtu onyeisi ala Trump, a chọrọ ọtụtụ n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu mana maka ịma ikpe ma ọ bụ mwepụ n' ọchịchị a chọrọ abụọ n' ụzọ atọ nke ọnụ ọgụgụ dị ukwuu n' ụlọ sineti.

english: The whole world waits and watches the outcome of the impeachment as they also wonder whether President Trump who could so aptly be described as the cat with nine lives (having emerged seemingly unscathed by each scandal) would survive the latest misconduct.
igbo: Ụwa niile na-eche ma na-ekiri ihe ga-abụ mpụtara nchụtụ a dị ka ha na-atụ anya ma onyeisi ala Trump onye a kọwara dịka onye nwere chi ọma doro anya (n' ihi enweghi ihe mmekpa ahụ na nkwụtọ ọ bụla) ga-enwere onwe ya n' agwa ọjọọ nke ikpeazụ a.

english: The question remains: Will this be Trump's triumph or trial? We only have a short while left to see as the political games in the United States continue to unravel.
igbo: Ajụjụ ka bụ: Ihe a ọ ga-abụ mmeri ma ọ bụ ekpem ikpe Trump? Anyị nwere nanị obere oge ịhụ ka ịgụ okwe ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị na Yụnaịted Steeti na-ekpughe.

igbo: Hannatu Musawa

english: Turkish Airlines Denies Suspension Of Operations In Nigeria
igbo: Ụgbọ elu Turkey gọnarịrị ịkwụsị ọrụ na Naijiria.

english: In reaction to the news circulating about the suspension of operations of Turkish Airlines in Nigeria by the Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority, the airline has denied the report, branding it as false and misleading.
igbo: 'N' ịzaghachi akụkọ na-efegharị banyere 'Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority' ịkwụsị ụgbọ elu Turkey ọrụ na Naijiria, ọdụ ụgbọ elu a agọrịla akụkọ a ma kpọọ ya ihe asị na ihe nduhie ụzọ.'

english: In reaction to the news circulating about the suspension of operations of Turkish Airlines in Nigeria by the Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority, the airline has denied the report, branding it as false and misleading.
igbo: 'N' ịzaghachi akụkọ na-efegharị banyere 'Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority' ịkwụsị ụgbọ elu Turkey ọrụ na Naijiria, ọdụ ụgbọ elu a agọrịla akụkọ a ma kpọọ ya ihe asị na ihe nduhie ụzọ.'

english: Turkish Airlines in a statement sent to SaharaReporters, said it continues to operate in all of its destinations in Nigeria, adding that the news was far from reality.
igbo: Ọdụ ụgbọ elu Turkey n' okwu ha zitere 'Sahara Reporters,' kwuru na ọ ka na-arụ ọrụ n' ọnọdụ ya niile dị na Naijiria, na-agbakwunye na akụkọ ahụ abụghị eziokwu ma ncha.

english: The airline said, 'There are reports circulating in several news websites that claim Turkish Airlines operations in Nigeria are suspended or to be suspended by Nigeria Civil Aviation
igbo: Ọdụ ụgbọ elu a kwuru, 'Onwere ụfọdụ akụkọ na-efegharị n' ọtụtụ websaịt akụkọ na-ekwu ịrụ ọrụ ụgbọ elu Turkey na Naijiria kwụsịla ma ọ bụ na' Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority ' ga-akwụsị ya

english: Authority.
igbo: 'Authority'

english: 'We would like to announce that our operations continue in all of our destinations
igbo: 'Anyị chọrọ ikwu na ọrụ anyị na -aga n' ihu n' ọnọdụ anyị ọbụla

english: in Nigeria.
igbo: na Naijiria

english: The news reports on the subject do not reflect the reality.'
igbo: Akụkọ banyere isiokwu a egosighi ihe na-eme eme.'

english: Turkish Airlines Deploys Bigger Aircraft To Nigerian Route After Passengers' Protest NCAA had threatened to sack the airline from Nigeria if it continued to delay passengers' check-in luggage on arrival at Lagos and Abuja airports.
igbo: ọdụ ụgbọ elu Turkey butere nnukwu ụgbọ elu n' ụzọ Naijiria ka ndị njem kpọrọ ganigani na NCAA yiri egwu ịchụ ụgbọ elu na Naijiria ma ọ gaa n'ihu na-egbu ndị njem oge n' ebe iburu ibu ma ha bata n' ọdụ ụgbọ elu Legosi na Abuja.

english: Turkish Airlines has succumbed to threats by the Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority of being kicked out of the country by deploying bigger aircraft to Lagos and Abuja.
igbo: Ụgbọ elu Turkey adaalara iyi egwu nke 'Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority' ịchụpụ ya na Nigeria site ibute nnukwu ụgbọ elu na Legosi na Abuja.

english: NCAA had threatened to sack the airline from Nigeria if it continued to delay passengers' check-in luggage on arrival at Lagos and Abuja airports.
igbo: NCAA eyieela egwu ịchụpụ ụgbọ elu na Naijiria ma ọ gaa n'ihu igbu ndị njem oge iburu ibu ha ma rute ọdụ ụgbọ elu Legosi na Abuja.

english: The airline has deployed a bigger aircraft, an Airbus 330 to the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, Abuja, rather than the previous Boeing 737 it used for the route.
igbo: Ọdụ ụgbọ elu a ebuputeela nnukwu ụgbọ elu, nnukwu ụgbọ elu A330 na 'Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, Abuja, kama obere ụgbọ elu B737 ọ tinye n' ụzọ na mbụ.

english: The use of the B737, which is a smaller aircraft with a maximum capacity of 150 passengers, caused hardship to passengers whose luggage were consistently left behind in Istanbul, Turkey by the airline.
igbo: Ụgbọ elu B737, nke bụ obere ụgbọ elu nke nwere ike ịbụ nanị ndị njem 150, butere ihe isi ike nyere ndị njem ndị ụgbọelu a na-hapụ ibu ha kwa mgbe na Istanbul.

english: This forced some passengers to protest the non-arrival of their check-in luggage.
igbo: Nke a manyere ụfọdụ ndị njem ime ngagharị iwe maka na akpa ha tinyere n'ugbo abataghi.

english: Minister of Aviation, Hadi Sirika, confirmed the news on his official Twitter page.
igbo: Minista ụgbọelu, Hadi Sirinka, kwuputara nke a na Twiita peeji ya.

english: He said, 'Turkish Air operated A330 to Abuja today as against the small B737 in apparent response to our suspension order.
igbo: O kwuru, 'Ụgbọelu Turkey butere A330 na Abuja kama obere B737 na nzaghachi doro anya nye iwu ịkwụsị ọrụ anyị nyere. Anyị ekwesịghị iru ebe a.'

english: We needed not to get to this,' Turkish Airlines is allegedly notorious for its poor treatment of Nigerian travellers especially when they have to arrive their destinations without their checked-in luggage.
igbo: A mara ụgbọelu Turkey nke ọma maka eleghị ndị njem ndị Naịjirịa anya ọfụma ọ kasị mgbe kwesiri ibu ibu ha rute ebe ha na-aga.

english: Two Dead In Lagos Building Collapse The building, located at Number 9, Amosun Street, Ijora Badia, was said to have been an uncompleted building with nobody residing in it.
igbo: Mmadụ abụọ nwụrụ n' ụlọ dara na Legosi.

english: Two people have been confirmed dead in a three-storey building that collapsed in Lagos on Saturday.
igbo: Ụlọ a, dị na nọmba 9, Amosun Striii, Ijobara Bịda, bụ ne e kwuru na ọ bụ bụ ụlọ arụsịghị asụ enweghị onye bi n' ime ya.

english: The building, located at Number 9, Amosun Street, Ijora Badia, was said to have been an uncompleted building with nobody residing in it.
igbo: Mmadụ abụọ ka e kwuru na ha anwụọla n' ime ụlọ elu nkwo atọ dara na Legosi na Satọdee.

english: Confirming the accident, Adesina Tiamiyu, General Manager of Lagos State Emergency Management Agency (LASEMA), stated that those who died were illegal residents, as they were in the building when it partially collapsed from the back.
igbo: N' ikwuputa ihe mberede a, Adesina Tiamiyu, onyeisi ụlọ ọrụ nlekọta nke Lagos State Emergency Management Agency (LASEMA), kwuru na ndị ahụ nwụrụ anwụ bi ebe ahụ n' ụzọ iwu n' akwadoghi n' ihi na ha nọ ebe ahụ mgbe azụ ụlọ ahụ dara.

english: He added that two of the residents were brought out dead from the debris, while the third person sustained some injuries.
igbo: Ọ gbakwunyere na mmadụ abụọ na ndị bi ebe ahụ nwụrụ anwụ ka e si na mpekere okwute bụpụta ha ebe onye nke atọ nwetara ọtụtụ ihe mmeru ahụ.

english: LASEMA and other rescue agencies in Lagos were on ground to contain the situation.
igbo: LASEMA na ndị otu nzọpụta ndị ọzọ na Legosi nọ anọ ebe ahụ ibuso ọnọdụ ahụ agha.

english: Uduaghan, Ogboru Challenge Manager, Okowa As Delta Election Tribunal Receives 51 Petitions
igbo: Uduaghan, Ogboru mara onyeisi nlekọta, Okowa, aka dị ka ụlọ ikpe ntụli aka natara mkpesa 51.

english: Great Ogboru, the 2019 governorship candidate of the All Progressives Congress (APC), Delta State, has also filed a petition challenging INEC's declaration of Ifeanyi Okowa, Governor of Delta State, as the winner of the March 9 governorship election.
igbo: Great Ogboru, onye Ji otu 'All Progressives Congress' zọọ ọkwa gọvanọ na ntụli aka 2019, Delta Steeti, gbakwuaziri akwụkwọ na-ama INEC aka make ịkpọpụta Ifeanyị Okowa, Gọvanọ Delta Steeti, dị ka onye meriri na ntụli aka gọvanọ e mere na March 9.

english: Emmanuel Uduaghan, immediate past Governor of Delta State and Delta South senatorial candidate of the All Progressives Congres, (APC), has filed a petition at the Delta State Election Petitions Tribunal against his opponent, James Manager of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), challenging his declaration by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), as winner of the just concluded February, 23, 2019 National Assembly election.
igbo: Emmanuel Uduaghan, Gọvanọ Delta Steeti pụrụ na nso a na onye ji 'All Progressives Congress' zọ ọkwa sineti nke Delta Saụt, agbaala James Manager nke 'Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) ' ha abụọ zọrọ ọkwa akwụkwọ na 'Delta State Election Petitions Tribunal, ' na-ama mkpọpụta ndị 'Independent Electoral Commission (INEC) kpọpụtara ya dị ka onye meriri na ntụli aka' National Assembly' e mepuru na Febrụwarị 23 aka.

english: In the same vein, Great Ogboru, the 2019 governorship candidate of the APC in the state, has also filed a petition challenging INEC's declaration of Ifeanyi Okowa, Governor of Delta State, as the winner of the March 9 governorship election.
igbo: N' otu aka ahụ, Great Ogboru, ji APC zoo ọkwa Gọvanọ na steetỌzọkwa, Joel-Onowakpo Thomas, onye ji otu APC zọọ ọkwa ụlọ nnọchiteanya Isoko 'Federal Constituency'

english: The United States Government has announced a partnership with the Tony Elumelu Foundation to promote entrepreneurship initiatives in Nigeria as a way to create job growth, economic prosperity and political stability in the country.
igbo: Gọọmenti 'United States' amaala ọkwa ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ ya na 'Tony Elumelu Foundation' iji kwalite atụmatụ ọrụ aka na Naijiria dị ka ụzọ a ga-esi weta mbawanye ọrụ, ọganihu akụnụba na nkwudosi ike ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị n' obodo a.

english: Making the announcement in Lagos on Thursday, U.S Consul General, Claire Pierangelo, said that through a public diplomacy grant of $105, 000, the U.S. Consulate was supporting the training of a cohort of entrepreneurs from Southern Nigeria under the 2019 Tony Elumelu Entrepreneurship Program.
igbo: N' ịma ọkwa a na Legosi n' ụbọchị Tọzdee, onye nnọchianya ukwu U. S., Claire Pierangelo, kwuru na site ego enyemaka mmekọrịta ọhaneze dị $105,000, ụlọ ọrụ nnọchianya kwadoro ọzụzụ ìgwè ndị ọrụ aka si ọwụwa anyanwụ Naijiria n' okpuru atụmatụ 'Tony Elumelu Foundation' nke 2019.

english: She said, 'Under this partnership, we selected 20 U.S. Consulate/TEF Fellows to receive additional entrepreneurship training through a day-long program at the U.S. Consulate General that utilise some of the resources of the Young African Leaders Initiative including alumni of the Mandela Washington Fellowship.
igbo: O kwuru, 'N' ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ a, anyị họpụtara ndị ụlọ ọrụ nnọchianya U. S./ndị mkpakọrịta TEF 20 ịnatawanye ọzụzụ n' ọrụ aka site atụmatụ ogologo otu ụbọchị n' ụlọ ọrụ nnọchianya ukwu U. S. nke ga-eji ọtụtụ ngwa nke' Young African Leaders Initiative ' tinyere ndị gụchara na 'Mandela Washington Fellowship'mere ihe.

english: 'The 20 Fellows were selected from the Consular District with a priority being placed on five key sectors: energy, technology, transportation, agriculture, and health.
igbo: 'Ndị mkpakọrịta 20 ka a họpụtara site mpaghara ụlọ ọrụ nnọchianya ukwu site n' ilekwasị anya na ngalaba ise gacha dị mkpa: ọkụ, nkanụzụ, njem, ọrụ ugbo, na ahụ ike.

english: 'This program is intended to give these Fellows insight to innovative U.S business models that will help them manage their businesses, market their products or services, seek capital, and develop partnerships.
igbo: 'E bu n' uche na atụmatụ a ga-enye ndị mkpakọrịta a nghọta banyere ụdị azụmahịa ọgbara ọhụrụ U. S. ga-enyere ha aka jikwa azụmahịa ha, ree ngwa ahịa ma ọ bụ ọrụ ha, chọọ ego, zụlite ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ.

english: 'One of U.S Mission's primary goals is to support Nigeria's economic development, and entrepreneurship is a key driver of economic growth and success.
igbo: 'Otu ihe gacha dị mkpa n' ihe U. S. bu n' uche bụ ịkwado nzụlite akụnụba Naijiria, mana ọrụ aka bụ isi sekpu ntị n' otito akụnụba na ọganihu.

english: 'That is why the U.S Department of State supports entrepreneurs all over the world by working with host nation governments and non-government organisations such as the Tony Elumelu Foundation.
igbo: 'Nke ahụ kpatara Ngalaba Steeti U. S. ji akwado ọrụ aka n' ụwa niile dum site n' isonyere gọọmenti obodo nnabata ma ọ bụ òtù abụghị nke gọọmenti dị ka' Tony Elumelu Foundation.

english: 'Our partnership with the Tony Elumelu Foundation promotes our ongoing efforts to advance entrepreneurship in Nigeria and is yet another example of our long-standing commitment to supporting Nigeria as it strives to diversify its economy.
igbo: 'Ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ anyị na Tony Elumelu Foundation ga-akwalite mgbali anyị na-aga n'ihu ugbua ime ka ọrụ aka gaa n'ihu na Naijiria ma bụrụkwa ụzọ ọmụma atụ ọzọ nke mkpebi anyị nwegoro ịkwado Naijiria dị ka ọ na-agbalị imuba akụnụba ya.

english: 'I applaud the leadership of the Tony Elumelu Foundation for their dedication to empowering budding African entrepreneurs as catalyst for the social and economic development of the continent.'
igbo: 'Ana m akụrụ ndị ndu nke Tony Elumelu Foundation aka maka ịrara onwe ha nye n' inyere ndị ọrụ aka na-etolite etolite n' Afrịka aka dị ka ihe mkpali ga-akwalite mmepe mmekọrịta ọha na akụnụba nke kọntinent a.

english: University Student Killed By Hoodlums In Kogi
igbo: Ndị ekperima gburu Nwata akwụkwọ mahadum na Kogi

english: According to the police, the deceased was a 400-level student of English Education and an alleged member of a cult gang.
igbo: Dị ka ndị uwe ojii siri kwu, onye nwụrụ anwụ bụ nwata akwụkwọ 'English Education' nọ n' ogo nke 400 ma bụrụkwa onye a na-enyo enyo na o so n' òtù nzuzo.

english: A 400-level student of Kogi State University, Apeh Joseph, has been killed by two gunmen on the institution's campus
igbo: Nwata akwụkwọ nọ ogo 400 n' English Education, Ape Joseph, ka ndị oji egbe abụọ gburu na kampos ụlọ akwụkwọ ahụ.

english: This was confirmed by the Kogi State Command of the Nigeria Police, a report by PUNCH said.
igbo: Kogi Steeti Kọmandị nke uweojii Naijiria kwuputara nke a, akụkọ si PUNCH sịrị

english: According to the police, the deceased was a 400-level student of English Education and an alleged member of a cult gang.
igbo: 'Dị ka ndị uwe ojii siri kwu, onye nwụrụ anwụ bụ nwata akwụkwọ 'English Education' nọ n' ogo nke 400 ma bụrụkwa onye a na-enyo enyo na o so n' òtù nzuzo.'

english: A statement by the Police Public Relations Officer, DSP William Aya, claimed that the deceased was behind the cult killing that occurred in the university last month.
igbo: Okwu onye mmekọrịta ọhaneze ndị uwe ojii, DSP William Aya, kwuru na onye a nwụrụ anwụ sonyere n' ogbugbu mmadụ ndị òtù nzuzo gburu na mahadum ahụ n' ọnwa gara aga.

english: Aya stated that one Onuche Jibrin of the Security Unit of the Kogi State University filed a complaint at a police station that 'one Joseph Apeh, a 400-level student of English Education Department of the university, was shot inside the campus by two unknown men on a motorcycle'.
igbo: Aya kwuru n' otu Onuche Jibrin nke ngalaba nchekwa na Mahadum Kogi Steeti nyere mkpesa n' ọdụ ndị uwe ojii na 'Joseph Apeh, nwata akwụkwọ ogo 400 na ngalaba English Education nke mahadum ahụ, ka mmadụ abụọ a maghị ndị ha nọ n' ogbatutum gbara egbe n' ime kampos.

english: He said the victim was rushed to the university's teaching hospital where he was confirmed dead by medical doctors.
igbo: O kwuru na e buru ya bụ onye ihe metụtara gbaga na 'teaching hospital' mahadum ahụ ebe ndị dibịa bekee kwuputara na ọ nwụọla.

english: The remains of the deceased, the statement added, had been deposited in the morgue of the health facility for autopsy.
igbo: Ọzụ onye nwụrụ anwụ, okwu ahụ gbakwunyere, ka e dọnyerela n' ebe nchekwa ozu nke ahụ ike maka nnyocha

english: Victor Uwaifo: Why I Sued Simi For N50 Million Damages
igbo: Victor Uwaifo: Ihe m ji gbaa Simi akwụkwọ nde N50.

english: Uwaifo accused the songstress of 'stealing' his intellectual property, 'Joromi'.
igbo: Uwaifo boro ọgwụ egwu nwaanyị a ebubo izuru ọrụ ọgwụgwụ isi ya, 'Joromi'

english: Victor Uwaifo and Simi
igbo: Victor Uwaifo na Simi

english: Legendary Nigerian singer and guitarist, Sir Victor Uwaifo, has revealed why he sued Nigerian singer, Simisola Bolatito Ogunleye, aka Simi, for N50 million.
igbo: Ọgwụ egwu na ọkpọ ụbọ onye Naijiria a ma ama, Sa Victor Uwaifo, ekpughela ihe mere o jiri gbaa ọgwụ onye Naijiria, Simisola Bolatito Ogunleye, aka Simi, akwụkwọ nde N50.

english: Uwaifo accused the songstress of 'stealing' his intellectual property, 'Joromi'.
igbo: 'Uwaifo boro ọgwụ egwu nwaanyị a ebubo izuru ọrụ ọgwụgwụ isi ya, 'Joromi'

english: In an exclusive interview with SaharaReporters shortly after his performance at the just concluded National Festival of Arts and Culture in Edo State, he said: 'We're in court already.
igbo: N' ajụjụ ọnụ Sahara Reporters gbara Uwaifo ka ọ mere obere oge ọ kụsiri egwu na 'National Festival of Arts and Culture' e mere n' Edo Steeti na nso a, o kwuru: 'Anyị anọrọla n' ụlọ ikpe.

english: I sued her at the federal high court for N50 million.
igbo: Agbara m ya akwụkwọ nde N50 na 'Federal High Court'.

english: They will be coming to court.'
igbo: Ha ga-abịawa n' ụlọ ikpe.'

english: When Sahara Reporters asked if Simi had reached out to him privately, he answered: 'No, only through her lawyers.
igbo: Ka Sahara Reporters jụrụ ya ma Simi ọbịakwutela ya n' onwe ya, ọ zara: 'Mba, nanị site n' ndị ọka ikpe ya.

english: We will meet in court.'
igbo: Anyị ga-ezute n' ụlọ ikpe.'

english: Over a year ago, Uwaifo had told SaharaReporters that Simi was in trouble for failing credit for the song, Joromi, which she remixed.
igbo: N' otu afọ gara aga, Uwaifo gwara Sahara Reporters na Simi nọ na nsogbu maka ekwupughiri egwu a, 'Joromi, ' nke ọ kụgharịrị.

english: He had said, when asked if he was going to take any legal action against Simi, 'One after the other.
igbo: O kwuola, ka a jụrụ ya ma ọ ga-eme ihe ọ bụla gbadoro ụkwụ n' iwu megide Simi, 'N' otu n' otu.

english: I cannot just take everybody to court at the same time.
igbo: Agaghị m akpụga onye ọbụla ụlọ ikpe n' otu oge.

english: I don't know whether he or she; I know she is but I know somebody is behind it.
igbo: Amaghị m ma ọ bụ nwoke ma ọ bụ nwaanyị; amara m na ọ bụ mana ama m na mmadụ kwụ ya n' azụ.

english: An LP was sent as a compliment; I'm still looking at it but they were planning to come to Benin to see me.
igbo: E zitere LP dịka ihe ekele; aka m na-ele ya anya mana ha na-akwado ịbịa Benin ịhụ m.

english: Up till now, they haven't come.
igbo: Ruo ugbua, ha abịabeghi.

english: So I'm just putting that one on hold.
igbo: Ya bụ, m ga-akwụsị nke ahụ.

english: 'Joromi' is a franchise.
igbo: 'Joromi, bụ aha.

english: The name never existed before.
igbo: Aha ahụ adịghị na mbụ.

english: Benin don't have 'J' in their language.
igbo: Benin enweghị 'J' n' asụsụ ha.

english: If any started with 'J' in Benin then it is fake.
igbo: Onwe nke bidoro na 'J' na Benin ọ bụ adịgboroja.

english: All consonant words start with vowel sounds.
igbo: Okwu mgbochiume ọbụla na-eji mkpụrụ ụdaume ebido.

english: For example, if I use the trademark of one of these soft drinks, it is wrong.
igbo: Ọmụma atụ, ọ bụrụ na m jiri njirimara nke òtù n' ime mmanya ọtọ bịrịbịrị ndị a, ọ dịghị mma.

english: So Simi is in trouble.'
igbo: Ya bụ Simi nọ na nsogbu.'

english: Walter's Wake-keep By Rudolf Ogoo Okonkwo
igbo: Nlafo chi Walter nke si n' aka Rudolph Ogoo Okonkwọ

english: Wakes of Nigerian-Americans who died in America is a different ball game.
igbo: Nlafo chi ndị Naịjirịa-Amerika nwụrụ n' Amerịka bụ ihe ọzọ.

english: Some consider that the more legitimate kind of wake.
igbo: Ụfọdụ were ya ka nọ for chi kwesiri ekwesi.

english: Friends and associates sympathize more and understand the need to raise money to support the family and in some cases, to transport the body back to Nigeria.
igbo: Ndị enyi na ndị mmekọrịta na-emekarị ebere ma ghọta mkpa ọdị ịnakọ ego iji kwado ezinaụlọ nakwa oge ụfọdụ, iji bunata ozu ahụ Naijiria.

english: In the Boston metropolitan area is a Liberian who loved to attend Nigerian parties.
igbo: N' okirikiri Boston mepere emepe e nwere onye Liberia nke hụrụ ịbịa pati ndị Naịjirịa n' anya.

english: (Let us call him Walter, because we have no permission to use his real name.)
igbo: (ka anyị kpọọ ya Walter, makana enwetabeghi ikike ịkpọ ezigbo aha ya.)

english: He loved Nigerian music, jollof rice, pepper soup, Shoki dance and watching Nigerians spray dollar bills like snow flakes at these parties.
igbo: Ọ hụrụ egwu Naijiria n' anya, osikapa jọlọf, pepe supu, egwu shoki na ikiri ndị Naịjirịa ka ha na-efe dọla ka mmiri na pati ndị a.

english: Trust Nigerians in America, they come up with every reason to throw a party - child dedication, wedding anniversary, birthday, graduation, send-off, wake-keep, etc.
igbo: Tụkwasị ndị Naịjirịa nọ n' Amerịka obi, ha na-enwe ihe ọ bụla ka ibe iji kpọọ pati - nkupụta nwa, ncheta agbamakwụkwọ, ncheta ọmụmụ, mpụta n' ụlọ akwụkwọ, isi mmadụ laa n' udo, nlafo chi, wee dịrị gawa.

english: Every party is special but none is as special as a wake-keep.
igbo: Particularly ọ bụla bụ ọpụrụ iche mana ọnweghi nke bụ ọpụrụ ka nlafo chi.

english: If you rent a hall to celebrate your 50th birthday or 25th wedding anniversary, or even your child's 5th birthday, or your child's dedication in church, the general feeling is that you have the money to spare.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na igbazite nnukwu ụlọ iji rie oriri ncheta afọ ọmụmụ nke 50 ma ọ bụ ncheta agbamakwụkwọ nke 25, ma ọ bụ ọbụna ncheta ọmụmụ nke afọ 5 nwa gị, ma ọ bụ nkuputa nwa gị n' ụlọ ụka, mmetụta nke ọha bụ na i nwere ego ị ga-emefu.

english: People will still come, enjoy, and may even give you gifts, but it is mostly not seen as obligatory.
igbo: Ndị mmadụ ka ga-abịa, ñụrịa, ma ọbụna nwe ike inye gị onyinye, mana anaghị ahụ ya na ka iwu.

english: But when it is a wake-keep, the party from conception to execution is aimed at raising money to assist the bereaved to go home and attend the funeral of the dead.
igbo: Mana mgbe ọ bụ nlafo chi ọnwụ mmadụ, ebumnuche pati ahụ site na ncheta ruo omume ya bụ ịtụkọta ego iji nyere onye nwụrụ anwụ aka ka o ruo ụlọ na ịga akwamozu onye nwụrụ anwụ.

english: The MC makes that clear every ten minutes of the event.
igbo: MC na-eme ka nke a doo anya kwa nkeji iri ọbụla nke mmeme ahụ.

english: And since people are expected to drop something,' organizers make sure that there are a lot of food and drinks to justify the things people will 'drop'.
igbo: Ka ọ bụ na a tụrụ anya na ndị ga-eweta ihe ' ndị nchịkọta na-ahụ na enwere ọtụtụ ihe oriri na ihe ọñụñụ kwesiri ihe ndị mmadụ ga-eweta.

english: Another feature of these wake-keep, other than the fact that most of those for whom the events are held had never been to America, is that there is an unwritten understanding between the organizers and the attendees that whatever the attendee gives is documented, noted and permanently preserved for the time when it would be necessary to return the favor.
igbo: Ihe ọzọ e ji mara nlafo chi, n' abụghị na ọtụtụ n' ime ndị e ji maka ha eme mmemme abịanubeghi Amerịka, bụ na enwere nghọta e deghị ede dị n' etiti ndị nchikọba na ndị na-abịa mmemme na e dere ihe ọ bụla onye bịara mmemme nyere n' akwụkwọ, hụwa ya ama ma chekwaba ya ebighị ebi maka mgbe ọ ga-adị mkpa ịkwụghachi ụgwọ amara a.

english: In Igbo community, they even have a proverb that backs it up.
igbo: N' ala Igbo, ha nwere ọbụna ilu ọ dabere na ya.

english: It says: whatever a man gives to another man is a loan waiting to be repaid.
igbo: Ọ na-asị: ihe nwoke nyere ibe ya bụ ego ọ ga-akwụ akwụ ka o binyere ya.

english: This last part accounts for the proliferation of wake-keep.
igbo: Akụkụ ikpeazụ a kọwara ihe kpatara mbawanye na nlafo chi.

english: It is like a form of isusu.
igbo: Ọ dị ka ịtụ akawo.

english: You wait for your turn to collect return on your investments.
igbo: Ihe inwere ime bụ ichere oge gị ịnara ego ị tinyere.

english: Those who had lost their parents before coming to America waste no time in holding wakes for their uncles and aunts, not minding whether they were close or not.
igbo: Ndị nne na nna ha nwụrụla tupu ha abiawa Amerịka anaghị egbu oge ọ bụla imere nwanne nna/nne ha nwoke ma ọ bụ nwaanyị nlafo chi, n' agbanyeghi ma ha adị nso ma ọ bụ na ha adịghị.

english: Some will roll out the wake-keep red carpet for their step-mothers and step-fathers, even if they never saw eye-to-eye in life.
igbo: Ụfọdụ ga-eme mmemme nlafo chi nwunye nna ha na di nne ha, ọbụnadị na ha adịghị n' udo mgbe ha nọ ndụ.

english: All that they needed to say was that their parents died when they were young and it was this uncle, this aunt, this step-father, this step-mother, even step-sister and step-brother that stepped in and raised them.
igbo: Ihe ha nwedebere ikwu bụ na ndị mụrụ ha nwụrụ ka ha pere mpe ma ọ bụ nwanne nne/nna nwoke a ma ọbụ nwaanyị a, dị nne a, nwunye nna a na nwanne nwoke a batara wee zụọ ha.

english: Who are you to argue with a grieving fellow?
igbo: Onye ka I bụ gị na onye mmadụ ya nwụrụ anwụ ịrụ ụka?

english: After all, the ever-increasing cost of burial at home means that no matter who dies, once the 3 am call comes, the demand for money follows.
igbo: E kwuwe ekwuwe, mmụba ọnụ akwamozu n' ụlọ pụtara na n' agbanyeghi onye nwụrụnụ, ozugbo ọkpụkpọ òkù elekere atọ nke ụtụtụ batara, ịna ego ga-esochi ya.

english: And having someone abroad means pressure to go for 'a befitting' oversea-higher-standard burial.
igbo: Inwe onye nọ obodo oyibo pụtara ịgbalị maka akwamozu bụ eji ama atụ n' obodo oyibo.

english: Wake-keep is so ubiquitous that people now simplify it by saying Peter's wake or Angela's wake, instead of properly labeling it as the wake of Peter's father or Angela's mother.
igbo: Nlafo chi dị ebe niile nke ndị mmadụ na-emezi ya ka ọ dị mfe site n' ikwu ihe dị ka nlafo chi Peter ma ọbụ nlafo chi Angela, kama inye aha kwesiri ya dị ka nlafo chi nna Peter ma ọ bụ nne Angela.

english: It saves everyone the headache of figuring out the real relationship.
igbo: Ọ na-ebelatara onye ọbụla isi ọwụwa ịchọpụta ihe jikọrọ onye na onye.

english: Once you are part of the wake-keep-going circus, it is expected that, sooner or later, you will get your own wake.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na i so n' òtù ndị na-eje nlafo chi, a tụrụ anya n' aka gị na, na nso nso ma ọ bụ e mechaa, na ị ga-enwe nlafo chi nke gị.

english: One guy having difficulty completing his house in the village manufactured his own wake out of the death of his maternal grandmother.
igbo: Otu onye nwere ihe isi ike ịrụsị ụlọ ya n' ime obodo bọlitere nlafo chi nke ya site ọnwụ nne nne ya.

english: Recently, the expectation of going home for the funeral has been waived.
igbo: Na nso nso a, e wepula ibu n' obi ịna ụlọ maka akwamozu.

english: It is now acceptable that the person who collected all those money at the wake did not even go home for the funeral.
igbo: A na-anabatazị na onye ahụ nke nakọrọ ego niile a na nlafo chi ejeghi ụlọ ma ọlị maka ya bụ akwamozu.

english: That he or she presumably sent the money home is satisfactory.
igbo: Na ọ zigara ego ahụ n' ụlọ ka ha si eche juru afọ.

english: Wakes of Nigerian-Americans who died in America is a different ball game.
igbo: Nlafo chi ndị Naịjirịa-Amerịka nwụrụ na Amerịka bụ ihe dịrị onwe ya iche.

english: Some consider that the more legitimate kind of wake.
igbo: Ụfọdụ enwe ya ka nlafo chi ka dị nkwesi.

english: Friends and associates sympathize more and understand the need to raise money to support the family and in some cases, to transport the body back to Nigeria.
igbo: Ndị enyi na ndị mkpakọrịta na-emekarị ebere ma ghọta mkpa ọ dị ịtụkọ ego kwado ezinaụlọ nakwa oge ụfọdụ, ibuna ahụ onye ahụ Naịjirịa.

english: Though recently there has been the increasing grumble for Nigerian-Americans to obtain life insurance to cover transportation of their body home, if they so wish, and still leave something for those they left behind.
igbo: N' ezie na nso a e nwere mbawanye na ntamu banyere ndị Naịjirịa-Amerịka inweta inshọọransị maka ndụ ga-ahụ maka ibunata ahụ ụlọ, ha ọ masikarịa ha, ma hapụrụ ndị ha hapụrụ ihe.

english: Walter is a permanent fixture at these wakes.
igbo: Walter na-abịa nlafo chi ọbụla.

english: He drinks to his heart's desire, dances until his waist aches.
igbo: Ọ a-añụ mmanya ka ọchịchọ obi ya sịrị dị, gbagide egwu ganye n' ukwu afụwa ya ụfụ.

english: He once inquired about joining People's Club after he watched the display of the club members at some of these wakes, but he pulled back when told how much it costs to join the club.
igbo: N' otu oge ọ jụrụ maka ịbanye 'People's Club' ka o kirisiri ihe ngosi ụfọdụ n' ime ndi òtù a na nlafo chi ụfọdụ, mana ọ lara azụ ka a gwasịrị ya ego ole ọ na-eri iji wee sonye.

english: Then, one day, Walter's mother died.
igbo: Otu ụbọchị, nne Walter nwụrụ.

english: And Walter had his wake.
igbo: Walter wee nwe nlafo chi nke ya.

english: He contacted his Nigerian friends who told him how to plan a wake.
igbo: Ọ kpọrọ ndị enyi ndị Naịjirịa ndị gwara ya ka e si akwado nlafo chi.

english: He did not have close friends to constitute his Committee of Friends so he became his own one-man Committee of Friends.
igbo: O nweghi ndị enyi ha na ya dị na mma ga-abụ Kọmitii ndị enyi ọ wee bụrụ Kọmitii otu nwoke nke onwe ya.

english: He did all the running-around and spent all the money needed for drinks, hall, DJ, photographer and food.
igbo: Ọ mere mgbagharị niile ma weta ego niile a chọrọ maka mmanya, nnukwu ụlọ, DJ, onye ose foto na nri.

english: On the day of the wake, Nigerians came in large numbers.
igbo: N' ụbọchị nlafo chi, ndị Naịjirịa bịara n' ìgwè.

english: They ate, drank, danced, and, went home.
igbo: Ha riri, ñụọ, gbaa egwu, ma laa ụlọ.

english: The morning after Walter's wake, he went to the office of a friend of mine who had given him $50.
igbo: N' ụtụ ka Walter mesiri nlafo chi, o jere n' ụlọ ọrụ otu eyi m onye nyere ya $50.

english: The average money given at these wakes is $100.
igbo: Ego a na-enyekarị na nlafo chi bụ $100.

english: Walter thanked my friend so profusely that my friend found it odd.
igbo: Walter kelere enyi m nwoke nke ọfụma nke enyi m nwoke hụrụ ya ka ihe ezighi ezi.

english: Something a phone call would have taken care of, Walter came in person.
igbo: Ihe ọkpụkpọ òkù ekwenti kaara ime, Walter bịara n' onwe ya.

english: When Walter left, my friend called around to find out why Walter was super appreciative.
igbo: Ka Walter pụrụ, enyi m bịara ka ọ mara ihe mere Walter ji nwe nnukwu afọ ojuju.

english: Could it be because someone who didn't know him very well gave him $50?
igbo: Ọ ga-abụ makana onye amaghị ya ọfụma nyere ya $50?

english: What my friend found out was that all those Nigerians who came, ate, drank, danced, and then went home, none gave Walter any money because he never gave any money at all those wakes he had attended over the years.
igbo: Ihe enyi m chọpụtara bụ na ndị Naịjirịa niile ahụ bịaranụ, riri, ñụọ, ma laa, onweghi onye nyere Walter ego ọbụla makana onweghi onye ọ nyere ego ma ncha na nlafo chi ahụ ọ jere afọ niile gara aga.

english: Rudolf Ogoo Okonkwo is the author of 'This American Life Sef.
igbo: Rudolf Ogoo Okonkwọ bụ odee nke 'This American Life Sef.

english: His latest book is 'The Secret Letters of President Donald J. Trump age 72 1/6.
igbo: 'Akwụkwọ ọhụrụ ikpeazụ ya bụ 'The Secret Letter of President Donald Trump age 72 1/6.

english: This piece was first published in the Catalyst International magazine.
igbo: E bu ụzọ biputa akwụkwọ a na 'Catalyst International Magazine.

english: We Have Always Maintained Our Innocence, Says NFF President, Pinnick
igbo: Anyị anọgidela n' aka idi ọcha anyị mgbe niile, onyeisi NFF, Pinnick, kwuru

english: On the recent court victory, Pinnick said, 'This is not a personal victory for me and my other board members.
igbo: N' imeri n' ụlọ ikpe na nso a, Pinnick, kwuru, 'Nke a abụghị mmeri nke onwe nyere m na ndị òtù bọọdụ ndị ọzọ.

english: It is victory for all of Nigerian football.'
igbo: Ọ bụ mmeri nyere òtù egwuregwu bọọlụ Naijiria.'

english: President of the Nigeria Football Federation, Amaju Pinnick, has said that his team had always maintained their innocence at the organisation.
igbo: Onyeisi òtù egwuregwu bọọlụ Naijiria, Amaju Pinnick, ekwuola na ndị òtù ọrụ ya anọgidela aka idi ọcha ha n' òtù a.

english: Pinnick made the disclosure on Monday while appearing as guest on Channels Television's Sunrise Daily.
igbo: Pinnick kwuputara na Mọndee ka ọ bịara dị ka onye ọbịa na 'Channels Television's Sunrise Daily.'

english: The NFF President said his team had also always laid its books bare for everyone to see.
igbo: Onyeisi NFF a kwuru na ndị òtù ọrụ ya ekpughela ihe niile ka onye ọbụla hụ.

english: His statement comes few days after a Federal High Court sitting in Abuja discharged and acquitted him of charges bordering on fraud to the tune of $8.4m and N4bn.
igbo: Okwu ya bịara ka ụbọchị ole na ole gasịrị 'Federal High Court' dị n' Abuja hapụrụ ikpe ya ma kwuo na aka ya dị ọcha banyere ebubo igwu wayo ruru nde $8.4 na ijeri N4.

english: Pinnick and other executives of the NFF were charged on 16 counts of corruption and misappropriation of the said sums from the 2014 FIFA Grant, as well as for conflict of interest and non-declaration of assets by the defunct Special Presidential Investigation Panel headed by Okon Obono-Obla.
igbo: Pinnick na ndị nchịkwa NFF ndị ọzọ ka e boro ebubo 16 nke mpụ na iri ego ndị a kpọrọ aha site ego enyemaka FIFA 2014, nakwa maka esomokwu mmasị na ekwuputaghị akụ bụ 'Special Presidential Investigation Panel' kwụsịrịla ọrụ nke onye ya bụ Okon Obono-Obla.

english: He said that Gov. Willie Obiano was interested in Agriculture, especially livestock production, calling on such farmers to utilise the opportunity made available in the state.
igbo: O kwuru na Gọv. Willie Obiano nwere mmasị n' ọrụ ụgbọ, ọkasị ịzụpụta anụ ụlọ, na-akpọzị ndị ọrụ ugbo ka ha nwere ohere e mebere na steeti a mere ihe.

english: The officer urged farmers to work closely with Agric Ministry to benefit from governor's incentive packages aimed at boosting animal production.'
igbo: Onye ọrụ a gbara ndị ọrụ ugbo ume ka ha kpaa ministri ọrụ ugbo nso ka ha wee rite uru dị n' ihe mkpali gọvanọ wepụtara maka ịkwalite ịzụpụta anụ ụlọ.

english: Mr Okeke gave tips on how pig farm could be constructed as well as promised to produce manuals for achieving odourless pig farming.
igbo: Maazị Okeke nyere ntụziaka ka e nwere ike isi rụ ubi ezi ma kwekwa nkwa ịmepụta akwụkwọ ntụziaka maka inwe ubi ezi anaghị esi isi.

english: He enjoined pig farmers to go to the grassroots to convince other farmers to join them to access government facilities in order to develop their farms.
igbo: Ọ dụrụ ndị na-azụ ezi ọdụ ka ha ga n' ime obodo mee ka ndị ọrụ ugbo ndị sonyere ha n' inweta akarangwa gọọmenti iji zụlite ubi ha.

english: Ace broadcaster Emmanuel Ugolee authors first book.
igbo: Onye mgbasa ozi a ma ama Emmanuel Ugolee ede elaborate akwụkwọ mbụ ya.

english: Broadcaster and voice actor Emmanuel Ugolee has added yet another giant stride to his list of known accomplishments as he turns author with the release of his book titled 'A Hundred Random Light Bulbs'.
igbo: Onye mgbasa ozi na onye ejije olu Emmanuel Ugolee agbakwunyela nnukwu nzọ ukwu ọzọ na ngụkọ ihe nweta ya dị ka ọ bụrụ odee akwụkwọ site iweputa akwụkwọ ya ọ kpọrọ 'A Hundred Random Light Bulbs. '

english: Born in Jos Plateau State, Emmanuel Ugolee who hails from Abia state started broadcasting in 1999 with Minaj Broadcast Television as a talk show host.
igbo: A mụrụ ya na Jọs, Plateau State, Emmanuel Ugolee onye si Abịa State bidoro ịgbasa ozi na 1999 na 'Minaj Broadcast Television' dị ka onye na-anọ n' isi emume mkparịta ụka.

english: He went on to create the 1st all Nigerian music video countdown show on TV – The MBI Top 10 Countdown.
igbo: O bidoro ngosi onyonyo ngụda egwu ndị Naịjirịa niile mbụ na TV-- 'The MBI Top 10 Countdown'

english: The show became a launchpad for a lot of iconic music stars including Ruggedman, Plantation Boiz, Sound Sultan, Mode 9 and a host of other musicians and music video directors.
igbo: Ihe ngosi a bụụrụ ihe mgbakwasa ụkwụ nyere ọtụtụ ndị egwu a mara aha ha na Naijiria nke gụnyere Ruggedman, Plantation Boiz, Sound Sultan, Mode 9 na ọtụtụ ndị egwu ndị na-agbazi onyonyo egwu.

english: Acrobat falls 30ft to floor while performing in London.
igbo: Omee ihe ịtụnanya si ebe dị 30fit daa n' ala ka ọ na-eme ngosi na London.

english: An acrobat has been injured in front of hundreds of people at the Winter Wonderland event in Hyde Park.
igbo: Omee ihe ịtụnanya emeruọla ahụ n' ihu narị mmadụ na ebe emume Winter Wonderland dị na Hyde Park.

english: Jackie Armstrong's foot is believed to have slipped from her harness causing her to crash to the floor at the Zippos Christmas Circus Show.
igbo: Ụkwụ Jackie Armstrong ka e kwuru n' ọ michapụrụ n' ihe o ji jide ya wee mee ka ọ daa n' ala n' ebe a na-eme ihe ngosi a kpọrọ 'Zippos Christmas Circus Show.'

english: Witnesses said she did not get back up and staff rushed over to her after the 30ft fall during the Cirque Berserk performance.
igbo: Ndị akaebe kwuru na o kwunyighi ọtọ mana ndị ọrụ gbakwuru ya ka ọ dasịrị ọdịda 30ft na ngosi ihe 'Cirque Berserk'

english: An audience member said:.
igbo: Onye so ná ndị na-ege ntị kwuru:

english: The lady had one foot in the loop with no actual harness and her foot slipped out and she fell to the floor diagonally.
igbo: Otu ụkwụ nwaanyị ahụ dị n' eriri n' enweghi ihe ji jide ya doro anya ụkwụ ya wee mịchapụ ọ wee daa.

english: Kids were on the front row and there were people screaming.
igbo: Ụmụaka nọ n' ụgbara ihu ma o nwere ndị na-eti mkpu.

english: READ ALSO: Lampard: Mourinho not right to say I turned my back on Chelsea to join Man City.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Lampard: Mourinho ekwughi eziokwu n' ikwu na m nyere Chelsea oche azụ ma sonyere Man City.

english: She was yelping in agony, it was traumatic as she bounced as she hit the floor.
igbo: Ọ na-ebe akwa na nnukwu ahụ ụfụ, ọ bụ ihe ahụ ụfụ ka o si bịaghachi ka ọ kụrụ n' ala.

english: There was an announcement after a min or two to all leave.
igbo: E nwere ọmụma ọkwa ka onye ọ bụla lawa ka otu nkeji ma ọ bụ abụọ gasịrị.

english: The circus was evacuated as paramedics went to her aid following the 6pm performance.
igbo: A pụrụ na 'circus' dị ka ndị enyemaka ọrụ ahụ ike gbagara ya ọsọ enyemaka nke na-esote ihe ngosi 6pm.

english: A spokesman for Zippos said: 'The female British artist, Jackie Armstrong, performs an aerial act and is a highly experienced circus artist with 10 years in the ring.
igbo: Ọnụ na-ekwuru Zippos kwuru: 'ome ihe ngosi nwanyị onye Britain, Jackie Armstrong, na-eme ihe ngosi ife n' elu ma bụrụkwa ome ihe nkiri mara ihe ọ na-eme megoro afọ iri n' ọgbọ egwuregwu.

english: 'Jackie was immediately attended to on the scene by first aiders and an ambulance called.
igbo: Ndị enyemaka ahụ ike letara Jackie ozugbo n' ebe ahụ ihe mere ma kpọkwa ụgbọ ihe mberede.

english: She was taken to hospital by ambulance and further information on the nature of her injuries is awaited.
igbo: Ụgbọ mberede bugara ya ụlọ ọgwụ ebe a nọ na-eche ọmụma banyere mmeru ahụ ya.

english: 'Immediately following the incident, audience members were asked to leave the Big Top and offered tickets for the next performance that evening.
igbo: Ozugbo ihe a mere, a gwara ndị nkiri ka ha pụọ ebe a (Big Top) ma nye ha tiketi maka ihe ngosi ọzọ na mgbede ahụ.

english: READ ALSO: Abia Warriors claim slim win to bring MFM's fine start to a halt.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: 'Abịa Warriors' ji obere ohere merie wee nweta ọmarịcha mbido MFM na njedebe.

english: Circus Founder and Director Martin Burton told MailOnline: 'Jackie is a very experienced artist whom we value dearly as part of our circus family.
igbo: Onye bidoro ma bụrụkwa onye mgbazi 'circus' Martin Burton gwara 'MailOnline': 'Jackie bụ Ome ihe nkiri mara ihe ọ na-eme nke anyị hụrụ n'anya nke ọma dị ka onye ezinaụlọ 'circus' anyị.

english: 'Clearly we are concerned and offering her and her family our full support and sympathy at this time.
igbo: Odoro anya na ọ gbasara anyị, anyị na-enye ya na ezinaụlọ ya nkwado anyị n' ozuzu oké ma na-emere ya ebere n' oge a.

english: 'At this stage we cannot comment further as we have no information on any injuries she may have sustained.
igbo: Ka ọ dị ugbua anyị agaghị ekwuru okwu gaa n' ihu dị ka anyị enweghi ọmụma banyere ụdị mmeru ahụ ọ nwere ike inweta

english: Experts want critical thinkers to lead, transform Nigeria.
igbo: Ndị ọkachamara chọrọ ka ndị nwere echiche nnyocha chịwa, gbanwee Naijiria.

english: Stakeholders who converged on the Nnamdi Azikiwe University (NAU) Awka, Anambra State have canvassed the emergence of critical thinkers in leadership positions with a view to transforming Nigeria.
igbo: Ndị eji okwu ha agba izu gbakọrọ na Mahadum Nnamdi Azikiwe (NAU) Awka, Anambra Steeti yọrọ nkwado inwe ndị nwere echiche nnyocha n' ọkwa ọchịchị buru n' uche ịgbanwe Naijiria.

english: They stated this during the Ninth World Philosophy Day of the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) at the Department of Philosophy, Faculty of Arts, with the theme, 'Critical Thinking, Leadership and Social Transformation.
igbo: Ha kwuru nke a n' emume 'Ninth World Philosophy Day' nke 'United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) na ngalaba Philosophy nke ngalaba 'Arts, ' nke isiokwu ya bụ 'Critical Thinking, Leadership and Social Transformation'.

english: A former Dean of the Faculty of Arts, Rev. Fr. Professor Obi Oguejiofor noted that leaders are drawn to the led if they possess critical thinking, analytical, communicative, creative, open-minded and problem solving to lead and transform organisations or institutions socially and economically.
igbo: Onye bụbu onyeisi ngalaba nke Arts, Rev. Fr. Ọkammụta Obi Ọgụejiofor kwuru na ọ na-adọta ndị ndu nye ndị ha na-achị ma ha nwere echiche nnyocha, echiche miri emi, nkwurịta okwu, ekelere uche, obi ghe oghe na mmụọ ndozi na-edu ma na-agbanwe nzukọ ma ọ bụ ewumewu nke mmadụ na akụnụba.

english: He lamented that the problems dogging Nigeria and Africa's developmental path stem from absence of leaders who could think critically from time to time, likening the failure of Nigerians to think critically in the clamour for power shift, which he said, does not produce the best leader who could give justice.
igbo: Ọ kwara arịrị na nsogbu na-esogbu mmepe Naijiria na Afrịka si n' enweghi ndị ndu ndị nwere ike iche echiche miri emi n' otu oge ma ọ bụ nke ọzọ, were ọdịda Naijiria na-atụnyere enweghị ike iche echiche miri emi n' iti mkpu ka e bugharịa ike ọchịchị, nke o kwuru, na ọ naghị eweta onye kasị mma nwere inye ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

english: Also, former Chair, Department of English and Speech, A & T State University, North Carolina, United States of America, Professor Chimalu Nwankwo lamented that Africans do not think critically hence their inability to think on their own, but rely on dictates of foreigners.
igbo: Ọzọkwa, onyeisi oche na mbụ, Ngalaba nke Bekee na Okwu, Steeti Mahadum A na T, Mgbago ugwu California, 'United States of America' Ọkammụta Chimalu Nwankwọ kwara arịrị na ndị Afrịka anaghị eche echiche miri emi nke butere na ha enweghi ike iche echiche n' onwe ha, kama dabere n' ihe ndị ọbịa kwuru.

english: Another stakeholder, Professor A. U. Igwe wondered if Nigerians apply critical thinking in whatever they do just as he condemned leaders who choose to become egocentric rather than critical thinkers when occupy leadership positions.
igbo: Onye ọzọ ọ metụtara, Ọkammụta A. U. Igwe jụrụ ma ndị Naịjirịa ha na-etinye echiche miri emi n' ihe niile ha na-eme dị ka ọ katọrọ ndị ọchịchị ndị họrọ ịma sọ onwe ha kama ibu ndị na-eche echiche miri emi ma ha nwere ọnọdụ ọchịchị.

english: Igwe, who is a Professor of History, at NAU, said there were few African leaders who were guided by critical thinking, particularly the former President of Burkina Faso, Thomas Sankara who he described as an ideal leader who employed critical thinking and rational application of force during his regime.
igbo: Igwe, onye bụ Ọkammụta nke Akụkọ ihe mere eme, na NAU, kwuru na e nwere ole na ole ndị ndu Afrịka ndị echiche miri emi duru, ọkasị onyeisi ala Burkina Faso na mbụ, Thomas Sankara onye ọ kọwara dị ka ezigbo onye ndu nke webatara echiche miri emi na itinye ikike n' ezi ọrụ mgbe ọ chịrị.

english: He observed that the UNESCO knows the important role philosophy plays in leadership; hence the declaration of November 21 every year as World Philosophy Day, stressing that critical thinking propels leaders to better the lot of their people.
igbo: Ọ kwuru na UNESCO mara ọrụ dị oké mkpa nkà ọmụma (philosophy) na-arụ n' ọchịchị; ya mere ha ji kwupụta na Nọvemba 21 kwa afọ ọbụla Ụbọchị nkà Ọmụma Ụwa niile, na-ekwusi ike na echiche miri emi na-akpali tell ndị ndu ime ka ihe dịrị ndị nke ha mma.

english: On his part, Dr. Emmanuel Umezinwa of the Department of Music and the first Master Degree Graduate of Philosophy Department, said Western system of thinking has inadvertently made Africans to sharpen their intellect and give too much thought to thinking, adding that there is an 'overblown idea of thought.
igbo: N' akụkụ nke ya, Dr. Emmanuel Umezinwa nke Ngalaba Egwu ma bụrụkwa onye mbụ ji nzere Masta nke ngalaba nkà Ọmụma, kwuru na usoro iche echiche ndị ọcha emela n' amaghị ama ka ndị Afrịka mụọ ọgụgụ isi ha ma tinye nnukwu echiche n' iche echiche, na-gbakwunye na e nwere nnukwu nghọtahie ihe bụ echiche.

english: Government should enforce ban on religious activities in stadia ― Rojenny Proprietor.
igbo: Gọọmenti kwesiri inye iwu machiri mmemme okpukperechi n' ama egwuregwu - onye nwe Rojenny.

english: Rommy Ezeonwuka, Proprietor of Rojenny Stadium and Tourists Village, has called on government at all levels to ban religious and other non-sporting activities in all spots sports stadia in the country.
igbo: Rommy Ezeọnwụka, onye nwe ama egwuregwu Rojenny na 'Tourist village, ' akpọkuola gọọmenti n' ogo dị iche iche ka ha machie okpukperechi na mmemme ndị ọzọ n' abụghị egwuregwu n' ama egwuregwu ọ bụla dị n' ala anyị.

english: Ezeonwuka made the call when he received members of Sports Writers Association of Nigeria (SWAN), Anambra chapter, who were on tour of sports facilities in the state.
igbo: Ezeọnwụka kpọrọ òkù a mgbe ọ nabatara ndị òtù 'Sports Writers Association of Nigeria (SWAN), ngalaba Anambra, ndị na-eme njem nleta maka ngwa egwuregwu na steeti ahụ.

english: The tour of sports was part of the three day SWAN Week activities in the state.
igbo: Njem nleta egwuregwu a bụ so n' otu ihe mejupụtara ụbọchị nke atọ na mmemme otu izu ụka SWAN na steeti ahụ.

english: The facility investor blamed the collapse of most Nigerian stadia on their use for non-sporting activities like religious crusades and political rallies.
igbo: Otinye ego na ngwa egwuregwu a tara iji ama egwuregwu mee ihe n' abụghị ihe egwuregwu dị ka ọgbakọ okpukperechi na ọgbakọ ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị ụta maka ọdịda ama egwuregwu dara.

english: He berated successive sports administrators in the country for misuse of the multi-billion Naira facilities for momentary gain.
igbo: Ọ kpọrọ ndị nchịkwa egwuregwu ala anyị gara aga maka ejizighi ngwa ọtụtụ ijeri naịra n' ihi uru oge nta.

english: READ ALSO: Women groups want FG to declare state-of-emergency on GBV.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Ọtụtụ òtù ụmụ nwaanyị chọrọ ka FG nye GBV 'state-of-emergency'.

english: Ezeonwuka said Rojenny was still relevant more than three decades because he refused to allow such distractions in his facility.
igbo: Ezeọnwụka kwuru Rojenny ka dị mkpa ihe karịrị afọ iri atọ makana ọ jụrụ ịnabata ụdị ihe ndọpụ uche ndị a na ngwa ya.

english: 'One major factor that is killing our sports facility is the permission to use them for activities that are not sports related, it is sad that government allows crusade, political rallies, burials in our stadia.
igbo: 'Otu ihe kasị egbu ngwa egwuregwu anyị bụ inye ikike ka e jiri ha mee mmemme n' eyighi egwuregwu, ọ bụ ihe mwute na gọọmenti na-enye ọhere maka ntụte, ọgbakọ ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị, akwamozu n' ama egwuregwu anyị.

english: 'Look at the National Stadium in Surulere, National Stadium Abuja and other facilities that should be used for training our youths for world championships collapsing because our administrators rent them out for money.
igbo: 'Lee ama egwuregwu ala anyị dị na Surulere, ama egwuregwu ala anyị Abuja na ngwa egwuregwu ndị ọzọ e kwesiri iji na-enye ndị ntorobịa anyị ọzụzụ egwuregwu maka egwuregwu mba ụwa na-ada makana ndị nchịkwa anyị na-ara ụgwọ ha.

english: 'Even here in Anambra, Achebe Stadium, Fegge and Ikpeazu Stadium have collapsed because of these things, it should be stopped and government should outlaw it.
igbo: 'Ọbụnadị n' Anambra ebe a, ama egwuregwu Achebe, Fegge na ama egwuregwu Ikpeazụ adala maka ihe ndị a, ọ kwesiri ka a kwụsị ya nakwa gọọmenti kwesi ịmachibidokwa ya.

english: 'Sports has a spirit and you must respect the spirit of sports, that is why I have refused to allow anybody to use here for any other thing other than sports, that is the secret of Rojenny survival after 35 years.
igbo: 'Egwuregwu nwere mmụọ mana ị ga-asọpụrịrị mmụọ egwuregwu, ya mere m jiri jụ inye onye ọbụla ọhere iji ebe a mee ihe ndị ọzọ n' abụghị egwuregwu, ya mere Rojenny dị ndụ ka afọ 35 gasịrị.

english: 'This is the only individually-owned Olympic size Stadium where you can hold most major games without leaving the stadium complex,' he said.
igbo: Nke a bụ sọ ama egwuregwu nke onwe nwere zuru olimpiks ebe i nwere ike inwe nnukwu egwuregwu ụfọdụ mana ị gaghị apụ n' ime ama egwuregwu, o kwuru.

english: Ezeonwuka said Nigeria had all it takes to dominate sports at the world stage but regretted that administrators have reduced the country to mere training ground where other countries come to adopt talented athletes.
igbo: Ezeọnwụka kwuru na Naijiria nwere ihe niile o ga-ewe ịkpakọrọ egwuregwu n' ogo mba ụwa mana ọ kwara ngaramara na ndị nchịkwa budara ala anyị ịbụ ala ọzụzụ egwuregwu nkịtị ebe mba ndị ọzọ na-abịa ịkpọrọ ndị na-eme egwuregwu nkà.

english: He said Nigeria must try to retain their best so that the country could enjoy the benefits of sporting economy like Europe, America and now, Asia.
igbo: O kwuru na Naijiria ga-agbalịrịrị idowe ọkachamma ha ka wee nwe ike irite uru akụ na ụba egwuregwu dịka Yurop, Amerịka na Ashia nke ugbua.

english: On the coming Nigeria Police Games scheduled to hold at Rojenny next year, Ezeonwuka described Rojenny as the proverbial parish waiting for the priest to come and conduct the Holy Mass.
igbo: Banyere Egwuregwu ndị uweojii Naijiria na-abịa abịa e dowere ka e mee na Rojenny afọ ọzọ, Ezeọnwụka kọwara Rojenny dịka pariishi a tụrụ n' ilu na-eche ụkọchukwu ka ọ bịa chụọ àjà maasị dị asọ.

english: 'Bahrain adopted about 10 Nigerians athletes, the young girls that recently won the world championship for them trained here, we must stop the West from poaching on us by placing value on what we have.
igbo: 'Bahrain kpọrọ ihe dị ka ndị Naịjirịa 10 na-eme egwuregwu, ụmụ nwaanyị na-eto eto ndị meriri ha egwuregwu mba ụwa na nso a nwere ọzụzụ ebe a, anyị ga-akwụsịrịrị ndị ọdịda anyanwụ ịnọchi anyị site n' ịkpọ ihe anyị nwere ihe.

english: 'Rojenny is like a parish waiting for the priest, the priest is the government who is supposed to create programmes so that athletes can make use of what we have here.
igbo: 'Rojenny dị ka pariishi na-eche ụkọchukwu, ụkọchukwu a bụ gọọmenti nke kwesiri ikeputa usoro emume ka ndị na-eme egwuregwu wee nwe ike iji ihe anyị nwere ebe a mee ihe.

english: 'It is not easy to run a stadium, even the government is finding it difficult, so those of us in the private sector need encouragement.
igbo: 'Ọdịghị mfe ilekọta ama egwuregwu, o siri ọbụnadị gọọmenti ike, ya bụ ụfọdụ n' ime anyị bụ ndị nnọrọ onwe kwesiri agbamume.

english: 'I want to thank the Nigerian Police for finding here worthy and we promise that the 2020 Games will be the best for them,' he said.
igbo: 'Achọrọ m ikele ndị uwe ojii Naijiria maka ịhụta ebe a ka ebe kwesiri ekwesi ma anyị na-ekwe nkwa na egwuregwu 2020 ga-abụrụ ha ọkachamma,' o kwuru.

english: In his remark, Philip Balepo, a veteran journalist, said Rojenny deserved a golden place in the history of Nigerian sports because of what he had done for the Nigerian youth.
igbo: N' okwu ya, Philip Balepo, onye ọrụ nta akụkọ pụrụ iche, kwuru na Rojenny kwesiri inye ọnọdụ pụrụ iche n' akụkọ ihe mere eme n' egwuregwu Naijiria n' ihi ihe ọ merela ndị ntoroọbịa.

english: Balepo, who expressed satisfaction with the ambience of Rojenny environment, called on Nigerian sports administrators to visit the place and see how best it could be optimised for sports growth.
igbo: Balepo, onye gosipụtara afọ ojuju n' ikuku gburugburu Rojenny, kpọkuru ndị nchịkwa egwuregwu Naijiria ịga leta ebe ahụ ma hụ ụzọ kasị mma a ga-eji ya kwalite otuto egwuregwu.

english: The SWAN team was led by its chairman Anthony Oji.
igbo: Ọ bụ onyeisi otu SWAN, Anthony Oji, duru ya.

english: Reactions.
igbo: Nzaghachi

english: Group sets agenda for next Anambra governor.
igbo: Òtù yiwere ajenda maka gọvanọ Anambra ọzọ.

english: As the countdown to the search for the successor to the incumbent governor of Anambra state, Willie Obiano, kicks off, a non-governmental organidation (NGO) has set out qualities and agenda for the next governor of the state.
igbo: Dịka ngụda ịchọ onye ga-anọchi anya gọvanọ Anambra nọ ugbua, Willie Obiano, bidoro, òtù abụghị gọọmenti (a non-governmental organization) eyiwela eyiwela àgwà na ajenda maka gọvanọ ọzọ na steeti ahụ.

english: The group under the aegis of Dikeorah Mandate Group said their emergence was propelled by the need to ensure that only the best and committed choice would be picked.
igbo: Òtù nke a na-akpọ Dikeorah Mandate Group sịrị na ihe kpalitere mpụta ha mkpa ọ dị ihu na ọ bụ sọ nhọrọ kasị mma ma nwe mmasị ka a họrọ.

english: Addressing journalists in Awka shortly after their inauguration, the chairman of the group's Board of Trustees (BoT), Chief Morris Ebo said they are non-political group committed to a sustained mass sensitisation of Anambra citizens towards choosing a performer as the next governor of the state.
igbo: N' ịgwa ndị ọrụ nta akụkọ okwu n' Awka obere oge ka e guzosiri ha, onyeisi ngalaba ndị isi (Board of Trustees, BoT) òtù a, Ichie Morris Ebo kwuru na ha abụghị òtù ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị ma ha kwudosiri ike ime ka ndị Anambra mkpa ọ dị ịhọpụta onye ngosi dị ka Gọvanọ ọzọ na steeti ahụ.

english: Israel pledges to strengthen bilateral relations with Nigeria.
igbo: Israel kwere nkwa ime ka mmekọrịta ha Naijiria siwanye ike.

english: Israeli Ambassador to Nigeria, Mr Shimon Ben-Shoshan.
igbo: Onye nnọchiteanya Israel na Naijiria, Maazị Shimon Ben-Shoshan.

english: The Israeli Ambassador to Nigeria, Mr Shimon Ben-Shoshan, has pledged to strengthen bilateral relations between Israel and Nigeria in terms of moral education.
igbo: Onye nnọchiteanya Israel na Naijiria, Maazị Shimon Ben-Shoshan, ekwela nkwa ime ka mmekọrịta dị n' etiti Naijiria na Israel n' ụdị ọmụmụ ịkpa àgwà siwanye ike

english: Ben-Shoshan said this on Thursday in Abuja at the grand finale of the 2019 edition National Bible Quiz competition.
igbo: Ben-Shoshan kwuru nke a na Tọzdee na Abuja n' agbasịa ekuru nwa n' Asọmpi Ajụaza Baịbụl Ala anyị gburugburu nke agba 2019.

english: The event was organised by the Embassy of Israel in Nigeria, in collaboration with Christians United for Israel (CUFI) Nigeria, CAN and Nigeria Pilgrims Board.
igbo: Ụlọ ọrụ nnọchiteanya Israel chịkọbara emume, site na njikọ aka 'Christian United for Israel (CUFI) Nigeria', 'CAN' na 'Nigeria Pilgrim Board.'

english: According to him, the relationship between Israel and Nigeria in every field had been very good and both would always do things diplomatically from one level to a higher level.
igbo: Dị ka o si kwuo, mmekọrịta dị n' etiti Israel na Naijiria na mpaghara ọbụla dịrịị mma ma ha abụọ ga na-emekọrịta ihe site otu ogo ruo ogo buru ibu.

english: Ben-Shoshan said, 'We are very happy to celebrate this year's contest, we had marvelous contest with participants from across the country.
igbo: Ben-Shoshan said, 'Anyị nwere nnukwu añụrị ime mmemme asọmpi nke afọ a, anyị nwere asọmpi dị ebube si n'aka ndị so sọ mpi ndị si akụkụ dị iche iche n' ala a.

english: 'Coincidentally, we had people of diverse Nigerian cultures among the participants.
igbo: 'Na ntụmadị, anyị nwere ndị mmadụ nwere omenala Naijiria dị iche iche na ndị so sọ mpi a.

english: 'I was also happy to see a lady among the participants like last year's, by next year we hope to have more women among the participants make it to the final stage.
igbo: 'Enwekwara m añụrị ihu nwaanyị na ndị so sọ mpi a dịka nke afọ gara aga, n' afọ ozo anyị na-atụ anya ịhụ ọtụtụ ụmụnwaanyị na ndị so asọmpi a ruo na agba ikpeazụ.

english: READ > Israel: Thousands of Netanyahu supporters set to rally in Tel Aviv.
igbo: Gụọ > Israel: Puku kwuru puku ndị kwado Netanyahu dị mkwadobe ịgbakọ a Tel Aviv.

english: 'I hope in 2020 we shall have more than 1900 participants; this is the second edition and it has been a long process from the beginning of this year,.
igbo: 'Ana m atụ anya na 2020 anyị ga-enwe ihe karịrị 1900 so asọmpi; nke a bụ agba nke abụọ mana ọ bụrịị ogologo usoro site a mbido afọ a.

english: In separate interviews, the winners of the competition commended the programme as rewarding and promised to live up to moral expectations.
igbo: N' ajụjụ ọnụ dị iche iche, ndị mmeri nke asọmpi a toro emume a dịka ịkwụ ụgwọ ọrụ ma kwee nkwa ibi ndụ a tụrụ anya ya.

english: Mr Chukwuowo Jerry, 18 years, representing Enugu in the Bible contest emerged first and thanked God for the grace to have emerged as winner.
igbo: Maazị Chukwuowo Jerry, afọ 18, na-anọchiteanya Enugu na asọmpi Baịbụl a gbara onye nke mbụ ma kele Chukwu maka amara ibu onye mmeri.

english: Jerry, who was the youngest participant in the competition with required age limit pegged at 18, said the process was free and fair.
igbo: Jerry, bụ onye dịkarịsịrị nta so ná asọmpi a nke afọ ọpekata mpe ya bụ 18, kwuru na usoro ghe anya ọghe.

english: 'I took it as an ordinary contest and I thank God for how it ended in praise, when we get to Israel I will see things that I have never seen.
igbo: 'Enwere m ya ka asọmpi nkịtị mana ekelere m Chukwu maka otu o si jedebe n' otito, mgbe anyị ga-eru Israel m ga-ahụ ihe ndị mụ ahụbeghi.

english: 'I will see things about the Bible I have been reading and to understand the aspects of it in real life, so I thank God,' Jerry said.
igbo: 'M ga-ahụ ọtụtụ ihe banyere Baịbụl m na-agụ maka ya ma ghọta akụkụ ya ụfọdụ n' ụdị anya fụrụ, ya bụ ekelere m Chukwu, Jerry kwuru.

english: Mr Oyare Ayegba, who took second position, also thanked God for placing him as first runner-up of the keenly contested National Bible Quiz.
igbo: Maazị Oyare Ayegba, onye gbara onye nke abụọ, kelekwuazịrị Chukwu maka idowe ya n' ọnọdu osote onye nke mbụ na Ajụaza Baịbụl nke Ala a zọrọ nke ọma.

english: Ayegba, who represented Akwa Ibom State said, 'I thank God for what he has done for me to emerge the second national champion in the bible competition.
igbo: Ayegba, onye nọchitere anya Akwa Ibom Steeti kwuru, 'Ekelere m Chukwu maka ihe O merele m ịbụ onye nke abụọ na asọmpi ala anyị n' ịsọ mpi baịbụl.

english: 'Being first runner up is a good thing and I am grateful to God, I contested last year, but I was not among finalists, I was not among the first three.
igbo: 'Ịbụ osote onye nke mbụ bụ ihe dị mma, ana m ekele Chukwu, azọrọ m n' afọ gara aga mana esoghi m na ndị ruru n' isi, esoghi na mmadụ atọ bụ ụzọ.

english: In another interview, Mr Akonde Josiah, who emerged third winner, representing Borno, said confidence reposed in him by his parent and friends was an inspiration for him in the contest.
igbo: N' ajụjụ ọzọ, Maazị Akonde Josiah, onye gbara onye nke atọ, na-anọchiteanya Borno, kwuru na obi isi ike nke onye mụrụ ya na ndị enyi tinyere n' ime ya bụ mkpalite mmụọ ya n' asọmpi ahụ.

english: According to him, I am grateful to God and I appreciate everyone who believed in me beyond myself, which is very important.
igbo: Dị ka o si kwuo, ekelere m Chukwu ma kelee onye ọbụla kwenyere na m karịa mụ onwe m, nke dị ọke mkpa.

english: 'It is not really about knowledge but the grace of God.
igbo: 'Ọ bụghị n' ezie maka ọmụma kama amara Chukwu.

english: Since March when we started it has been grace.
igbo: Kamgbe March mgbe anyị bidoro ọ bụrịị amara.

english: 'Last year I was here and made part of the 12 finalists and still kept close relationship with those who emerged as winners,' Josiah said.
igbo: 'Afọ gara aga anọ m ebe a ma ma soro ná mmadụ 12 ruru agba ikpeazụ ma mụ na ndị meriri ka na-enwe ezi mmekọrịta,' Josiah kwuru.

english: News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reports that the winners were rewarded with chance to be guests of honour at the International Bible Contest on Dec. 24, in Jerusalem, Israel.
igbo: 'News Agency of Nigeria (NAN )' kọrọ na a kwụrụ ndị mmeri a ụgwọ ọrụ site n' inye ha ohere ịbụ ndị ọbịa nwere ùgwù na Asọmpi Baịbụl Mba Ụwa na Disemba 24, na Jeruselem, Israel.

english: Mrs Nkechinyere Chidi-Mbah, 39, who hails from Abia, was winner of the maiden National Old Testament Competition in Nigeria, with 1,800 participants in 2018.
igbo: Odoziakụ Nkechinyere-Mbah, 39, bụ onye Abịa, bụ onye mmeri nke Asọmpi Agba Ochie nke Ala anyị Izizi, nke 1,800 so sọ mpi na 2018.

english: Kalu's conviction: Joining ruling party not guarantee against criminal justice ― Nwagwu.
igbo: Ọmụma ikpe Kalụ: Isonyere pati na-achị abụghị nkwa megide ikpe nkwụmọtọ banyere mpụ--- Nwagwụ.

english: Orji Kalu.
igbo: Orji Kalụ

english: Mr Ezenwa Nwagwu, Chairman , Partners for Electoral Reforms (PEF) says the jailing of former Gov. Orji Kalu of Abia was a proof that joining the ruling party with criminal case was not a guarantee against justice.
igbo: Maazị Ezenwa Nwagwụ, onyeisi, 'Partners for Electoral Reforms (PEF )' kwuru na ịtụ mkpọrọ nke onye ji ọkwa gọvanọ na mbụ Gov. Orji Kalụ nke Abịa bụ ihe àmà na ibu ikpe mpụ sonyere pati na-achị achị abụghị nkwa megide ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

english: Nwagwu in an interview with the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Thursday in Abuja said that the jailing has faulted the notion that once people with criminal record join the ruling party they were covered.
igbo: Nwagwụ n' ajụjụ ọnụ ndị News Agency of Nigeria (NAN ) gbara n' ụbọchị Tọzdee n' Abuja kwuru na ịtụ mkpọrọ a egosila na ọ bụghị eziokwu bụ echiche na ozugbo ndị mmadụ ndekọ mpụ banyere pati na-achị achị ha nwere onwe ha.

english: NAN reports that Kalu was on Thursday convicted of corruption and sentenced to 12 years in prison by a Federal High Court in Lagos after he was found guilty of N7.2 billion fraud and money laundering.
igbo: NAN kọrọ na Kalụ nọ na Tọzdee bụrụ onye a mara ikpe mpụ ma tụọ nga afọ 12 site n' aka Federal High Court na Legosi ka a masịrị ya ikpe ijeri N7.2 igwu wayo na ibu ego

english: The judgment is a good boost for the anti-corruption fight, especially against the background of all the noise about once somebody is in the All Progressives Congress (APC) the person cannot be brought to justice.
igbo: Ikpe a bụ agbam ume nyere ibu agha megide mpụ, ọkasị megide mgbakwasa ụkwụ nke mkpọtụ niile banyere na ozugbo mmadụ nọ n' 'All Progressives Congress' (APC) n' onye ahụ anara ikpe mkwụmọtọ.

english: READ ALSO: Orji Kalu's conviction shows Magu fears no one — Anti Corruption group.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Ọmụma ikpe Orji Kalụ gosiri na Magu anaghị atụrụ onye ọbụla egwu----- Òtù ibu agha megide mpụ.

english: 'It is a good signal that even if you join the ruling party you will not clog the will of justice.
igbo: 'Ọ bụ ezigbo mgba àmà na ọbụnadị na ị banyere pati na-achị ị gaghị emechu ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

english: 'It also signals the fact that no matter how long it last, once there is the determination by the court to bring justice, justice would be done.
igbo: Ọ na-agbakwa àmà na n' ezie n' agbanyeghi oge ọ nọrọ, ozugbo ụlọ ikpe kpebiri inye ikpe mkwụmọtọ, a ga-enwe ikpe mkwụmọtọ.

english: ' We are excited about the judgment and we hope that it is also brought to bear on the Babachir Lawal's case and other cases of people with a criminal record who think that being in the ruling party is a guarantee against justice,' he said.
igbo: 'Anyị nwere obi añụrị banyere ikpe ma anyị na-atụkwasị anya na a ga-ewetakwazị ya na mmezu n' ikpe Babachir Lawal na ikpe ndị ọzọ nke ndị mmadụ nwere ndekọ mpụ ndị chere na ịnọ na pati na-achị achị bụ nkwa megide ikpe nkwụmọtọ' o kwuru.

english: Lassa fever kills two, infects 10 in five states.
igbo: Ọrịa 'lassa fever' gburu mmadụ abụọ, fere 10 na steeti ise.

english: Lassa fever has claimed two more lives in Abia and Edo states as the country approaches the peak season for outbreaks of the deadly disease.
igbo: 'Lassa fever' enwerela ndụ abụọ ọzọ na steeti Abịa na Edo dị ka ala anyị na-erute oge dị elu na ndapụta ọrịa na-egbu egbu.

english: According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June.
igbo: Dị ka World Health Organisation (WHO) si kwuo, a mara 'lassa fever' ka ihe jupụtara Naịjirịa nke a na-atụ anya nnukwu oge ya site Disemba ruo Juun.

english: Latest figures from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), confirmed 10 new cases of the disease in five states: five in Ondo, two in Edo, one each in Ebonyi, Bauchi and Abia.
igbo: Ọnụ Ọgụgụ ikpeazụ nke si 'Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC)', kwuru na e nwetara mmetụta ọrịa iri ọhụrụ na steeti ise: ise n' Ondo, abụọ n' Edo, otu n' ime Ebonyi, Bauchi na Abịa.

english: In those new cases, one person each died in Edo and Abia states.
igbo: Na mmetụta ọhụrụ ndị a, otu mmadụ nwụrụ n' Edo na Abịa steeti.

english: Man, 26, drowns at National Stadium, Surulere.
igbo: Nwoke, 26, ka mmiri riri n' ama egwuregwu nke ala anyị (National Stadium ).

english: One Sodiq Yusuf, 26, of No. 26, Horgan Bassey Street, Surulere, has said to have drowned at National Stadium, Surulere.
igbo: Otu Sodiq Yusuf, 26, nke No 26, Horgan Bassey Striit, Surulere, ka e kwuru na ọ mmiri riri n' ámá egwuregwu nke ala anyị, Surulere.

english: The police in Lagos on Sunday said that a 26-year-old man, Sodiq Yusuf, had drowned inside the National Stadium swimming pool, Surulere.
igbo: Ndị uwe ojii na Legosi n' ụbọchị Ụka kwuru na otu nwoke dị afọ 26, Sodiq Yusuf, anwụọla n' ime mmiri ebe igwu mmiri nke ámá egwuregwu ala anyị dị na Surulere.

english: Lagos Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), DSP Bala Elkana, said in a statement that a team of policemen was immediately mobilised to the scene.
igbo: Onye mmekọrịta ọhaneze ndị uwe ojii Legosi, DSP Bala Elkana, kwuru n' okwu ya na e zigara òtù ndị uwe ojii ebe ihe mere ozugbo.

english: Man caught raping little girl inside bush in Abia (photos).
igbo: Nwoke e jidere na-edina obere nwa nwaanyị n' ike (foto).

english: A man was on Wednesday caught raping little girl in a bush in Abia state, around Hightaste Road by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road.
igbo: E jidere otu nwoke n' ụbọchị Wenzidee ka ọ na-edina obere nwa nwaanyị n' ike n' ime ọhịa n' Abịa steeti, na gburugburu ụzọ si 'Hightaste' banye Ibere Striit nke ụzọ Ngwa.

english: According to a Facebook user, David Osinachi Nwankwo, who shared photos from the scene of the incident, the suspect lured the girl into a nearby bush and covered her mouth with his hand to stop her from shouting for help.
igbo: Dị ka onye nwe ihu akwụkwọ, David Osinachi, onye tụsara foto si ebe ihe ahụ mere, si kwuo, onye a na-enyo enyo tụrụ nwata nwaanyị a banye n' ime ọhịa ma were aka ya kpuchie ya ọnụ iji gbochie ya iti mkpu enyemaka.

english: READ ALSO: Rape victim dies after being set alight on her way to court hearing.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Onye e dinara n' ike nwụrụ ka e duturu n' ụzọ ụlọ ikpe ka a - aga ikpe ikpe

english: David wrote 'He was caught having carnal knowledge/raping the little girl on the picture after luring her into a nearby bush with his hand on her mouth to stop her from shouting somewhere around Hightaste road by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road in Aba, Abia State today'.
igbo: David dere: 'E jidere ya ka ọ na-enwe mmekọahụ/na-edina nwata nwaanyị nọ foto a n' ike ka ọ labatara ya n' ọhịa dị nso ebe aka ya kpuchiri ya ọnụ ka ọ ghara iti mkpu n' otu ebe si Ụzọ Hightaste banye Ibere Striit nke Ụzọ Ngwa n' Aba, Abịa Steeti taa'.

english: Nasarawa Assembly to enact law to protect women, children against violence.
igbo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu Nasarawa steeti ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka mmesike.

english: The Nasarawa State House of Assembly says it will enact a law that will protect women and children against violence in the interest of development of the state and the country.
igbo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu Nasarawa steeti sị na ya ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka na mmesike maka mmepe nke steeti ahụ nakwa ala anyị.

english: Alhaji Ibrahim Balarabe-Abdullahi, the Speaker of the House, stated this on Tuesday when the state women led by the State Commissioner for Women Affairs, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, led the campaign rally on violence against women to the House.
igbo: Alhaji Ibrahim Balarabe-Abdullahi, okwuchite ọnụ ụlọ ọmebe iwu, kwuru nke a ụbọchị Tuzdee mgbe ụmụnwaanyị steeti nke Komishọna steeti maka Ụmụnwaanyị, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, nọ n' isi ọgbakọ kampeenu megide mmesike ụmụnwaanyị n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu steeti.

english: He said that the law if enacted would protect, respect and promote the rights of women and children in order to improve their health and their standard of living.
igbo: O kwuru na iwu a na-ewube ya ga-echekwaba, sọpụrụ ma kwalite ikike ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka iji kwalite ahụ ike ha na obibi ndụ ha

english: READ ALSO: Abia Assembly moves to pass law prohibiting violence against all Persons.
igbo: Gụkwuazị: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu Abịa chọrọ imebe iwu machiri mmesike nye onye ọbụla.

english: We will enact any relevant law that will put to end violence against women and children in the state.
igbo: Anyị ga-eweputa iwu ọbụla dabara adaba ga-akwụsị mmesike megide ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka na steeti a.

english: We believe that the law if enacted will also protect the rights of women and children for the overall development of the state,' he said.
igbo: Anyị kwenyere na iwu a na ewepụta ya gakwa echekwaba ikike ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka maka mmepe zuru ezu nke steeti a,' o kwuru.

english: Abdullahi called on all Nigerians to protect women and children from all forms of violence for development to thrive in the state and the country.
