english: One: the politics of the First Republic (1960-1965) was heavily characterized by ethnicity, especially towards the end of that tragic period .
igbo: Otu: ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke Republik nke mbụ (1960 - 1965) eji agbụrụ mara ya nke ukwuu, ọkachasị njedebe nke oge ọdachị.

english: Two: Of the five army majors that are more frequently mentioned as leading the coup attempt, only one, Major Adewale Ademoyega, was non-Igbo by ethnic origin .
igbo: Abụọ: n'ime ndị agha ise akpụ n'ọnụ na-edu nwapụ ndị agha, naanị otu onye agha bụ Adewale Ademoyega bụ onye na-abụghị onye si n'agbụrụ Igbo pụta.

english: Three: No Igbo political leader died and the only Igbo military casualty occurred not because he was a target but because he was considered a 'nuisance' .
igbo: Nke atọ: onweghi onye ndu ọchịchị ala Igbo nwụrụ na nanị ihe kpatara ogbugbu ndị agha Igbo abụghị n'ihi na ọ bụ onye Igbo, kama, ọ bụ n'ihi na e lere ya anya dịka nsogbu.

english: Four: The attempted coup was the culmination of a long period of political crisis in Nigeria .
igbo: Anọ: Mgbagha ahụ bụ njedebe nke ogologo oge ọgbahara ndọrọ ndọrọ na Naịjirịa.

english: A crisis whose centre of gravity was Western Region where, before the military intervention, the crisis had become an armed popular uprising .
igbo: Nsogbu nke ike ya si na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu tupu ntinye aka ndị agha, nsogbu ahụ bụ ọgbaghara amaama eji alụ agha.

english: On July 29, 1966, there was another military coup led by officers from Northern Nigeria and Lt. Col Yakubu Gowon became head of state.
igbo: Na Julai 29, 1966, enwere mbuso agha ọzọ nke ndị agha si n'mpaghara ugwu nke Naịjirịa duuru na Lt. Col. Yakubu Gowon bụ onye isi ala.

english: According to Madunagu, the coupists 'first made a move to pull the Northern Region out Nigeria, but when they were advised that they were now in a military situation to rule the whole country, instead of a part of it, they dropped the idea of secession and became champions of 'One Nigeria'.
igbo: Site n'akụkọ Magunagu, ndị a kpara ike a na mbu chọbuuru ikewa mpaghara ugwu na Naịjirịa, mana mgbe a duru ha ọdụ na ha bụzi ndị agha na achị mba niile kama ịchị so akụkụ nke ha, ha tufuru echiche ikewa obodo wee bụrụzie ndị agbachitere Otu Naịjirịa.

english: Lt. Col Ojukwu refused to recognize Lt. Col Gowon as head of state.'
igbo: Lt. Col. Ojukwu juru ịnabata Lt. Col. Gowon dịka onye isi ala.

english: The second coup led to the assassination, among other high-profile casualties, of the country's first military head of state, Gen. Aguiyi Ironsi, an Igbo, as well as the military governor of the Western Region, Lt. Col. Adekunle Fajuyi.
igbo: Nchịkwa nke abụọ butere ogbugbu ahụ, na ndị ọzọ nwụrụ bụ onye isi agha ala mbu, Gen. Aguiyi Ironsi, onye Igbo, yana onye ndu ndị agha mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu, Lt. Col. Adekunle Fajuyi.

english: This was followed by, as Madunagu notes, 'mass killings not only in the North but all over the country, except the Eastern Region.
igbo: Nke a sochiri ka Madunagu kwuru, ' ogbugbu mmadụ abụghị naani na mpaghara ugwu kamakwa na mba niile, sọsọ mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu.

english: Now, multiply the May 1966 tragedy by a factor of 50, add to it the fact that the killings were now led by armed soldiers whose commanders were now in power and add to this the fact that the killings did not abate for at least five months and you begin to have an idea of what happened.'
igbo: Ugbua, jiri ọnụọgụ iri ise gbakọ ihe mgberede Mee 1966, tinye ya na ogbugbu ahụ bụ ndị agha na-eduga n'ike nke ndị ọchịagha ha nọ ugbu a ma gbakwunye na nke a na ogbugbu ahụ akwụsịghị, tụpụ ọnwa ise, ị malite ịghọta ihe mere

english: The criminal indifference of the Nigerian state to the manifest pogrom against people from Eastern Nigeria, particularly Igbos, the repudiation by the Nigerian contingent (and the 'unilateral implementation' by the Eastern regional government) of the agreement on decentralization of power reached at a meeting in Aburi, Ghana, involving the main protagonists, Yakubu Gowon and Emeka Ojukwu, at the instance of Gen. Ankrah of Ghana, finally paved the road to Biafra.
igbo: Eleghị anya na mpụ nke steeti Naịjirịa na ihe pụtara ìhè megide ndị si ọwụwa anyanwu Naịjirịa, ọkachasị ndị Igbo, ndị nnọchị anya ndị Naịjirịa (na idi n'otu gọọmentị nke ndị mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu mejupụtara) nke nkwekọrịta maka ikewa ike ọchịchị ekwekọrịta na nzukọ e enwere na Aburi, Ghana, nke gụnyere ndị isi, Yakubu Gowon na Emeka Ojukwu, na onye aka ebe Gen. Ankrah nke Ghana, mechara wara Biafra ụzọ.

english: The accounts of what took place in those turbulent days are as varied as there are ethnic groups in Nigeria.
igbo: Ihe ndekọ ndị mere n'ụbọchị ọgbaghara ahụ dịgasị iche iche dịka esi nwee agbụrụ dị iche iche na Naịjirịa.

english: But one thing is certain:
igbo: Mana otu ihe doro anya:

english: The effects of those events, particularly the actions of May 27 and 30, 1967, are still being felt today .
igbo: Nsonaazụ nke ihe omume ndị ahụ, ọkachasị na ihe omume Mee 27 na 30,1967 ka ana-ahụ ruo taa.

english: In one fell swoop, the military unilaterally restructured Nigeria according to its dictates.
igbo: N'otu ọsụsọ, ndị agha rụzigharịrị Naịjirịa dịka iwu ya siri dị.

english: While Ojukwu drafted 'unwilling' minorities in the Eastern Region to create a Biafran state where Igbos were in the majority, the Nigerian military which was nothing but the armed wing of a reactionary feudal class that had power thrust on it at independence began the implementation of an agenda of conquest.
igbo: Mgbe Ojukwu wepụtara ndị 'achọghị' obere agburu na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ iji mepụta ala Biafra ebe ndị Igbo ka n'ọnụ ọgụgụ, ndị agha Naịjirịa nke abụghị ihe ọbụla karịa ogwe aka nke ndị agha na-akpata esemokwu nke ndị enyere ike ọchịchị nnwere onwe malitere mmejupụta atụmatụ nke mmeri.

english: Interestingly, barely a year earlier, the section of the military that seized power after the January 15, 1966 coup had attempted to reconstruct Nigeria as a unitary state with the promulgation of the unification decree 34 of 1966.
igbo: N'ụzọ na-akpali mmasị, na-erughị otu afọ tupu mgbe ahụ, ngalaba nke ndị agha weghara ike mgbagha ahụ mere na Jenuwarị 15, 1966 nwughari iweghachi Naịjirịa dị ka ala jikọrọ ọnụ nke iwu nke njikọta 34 nke 1966 jikọrọ.

english: That attempt was opposed fiercely by those (including a section of the military) who felt they had lost out in the power equation. The rest is history.
igbo: Ndị gbahara atụmatụ ahụ bụ ndị (nke gunyere ngalaba ndị agha) chere na ha afụọla n'ike ọchịchị. Nke fọdụrụ ziri bụ akụkọ.

english: When history repeats itself
igbo: Mgbe akụkọ mere ọzọ

english: Unfortunately, Nigeria is on the cusp of that tragic history repeating itself.
igbo: Ọ bụ ihe nwute na Naịjirịa nọ na njedebe nke akụkọ ihe mere eme ahụ na-emegharị onwe ya.

english: Regrettably, 50 years after the declaration of Biafra many young Nigerians of Igbo descent are trying to recreate Biafra.
igbo: Ọ dị nwute na afọ iri ise gasịrị mgbe e kwupụtachara Biafra, ọtụtụ ndị ntorobịa ndị Naịjirịa sitere n'agburu Igbo na-anwa ime ka Biafra dịghachị mma.

english: In a few days, there will be events in Nigeria and around the world to mark the 50th anniversary of the declaration of Biafra on May 30, 1967.
igbo: N'ụbọchị ole na ole, a ga-enwe ihe omume na Naịjirịa na ụwa niile iji mee ncheta afọ iri ise e kwupụtara Biafra na Mee 30, 1967.

english: Forty-seven years after the end of the Nigeria-Biafra War, Biafra still resonates with individuals and groups within and outside the country; perhaps, a testament to the fact that the war hasn't ended in the minds of the protagonists and victims .
igbo: Afọ iri anọ na asaa ka agha obodo Naịjirịa-Biafra gwụsịrị, Biafra ka na-emegharị n'etiti ndị mmadu n'otu n'otu na ndị nọ ná mpụga; ikekwa, ọgbụgba akaebe nke eziokwu ahụ akwụsịbeghị n'uche ndị meriri na ndị emeriri.

english: The reality is that many of the issues that propelled the civil war are still with us today.
igbo: N'eziokwu, ọtụtụ ihe kpatara agha obodo ahụ ka dị ugbu a.

english: So, how do we deal with this conundrum ?
igbo: Yabụ kedu out anyị ga-esi mee ihe nnọkọ ọnụ a ?

english: Is Biafra the solution ?
igbo: Biafra ọ bụ ọsịsa ya ?

english: In other words, can we solve the problems of 2017 Nigeria using the tragic solution of 50 years ago ?
igbo: N'aka nke ọzọ, anyị ga-edozinwu nsogbu nke 2017 Naịjirịa site na iji oke nsogbu nke afọ iri ise gara aga ?

english: As S.M. Sigerson noted in The Assassination of Michael Collins:
igbo: Dị ka S. M. Sigerson kwuru na ogbugbu nke Michael Collins:

english: What Happened at Béal na mBláth ?
igbo: Gịnị mere na Beal na mBlath ?

english: A nation which fails to adequately remember salient points of its own history is like a person with Alzheimer's.
igbo: Mba nke daramba na-icheta nke ọma banyere akụkọ dị oke mkpa na ihe mere eme na ụbọchị ya ndị gara aga dị ka onye nwere ọrịa Alzheimer.

english: And that can be a social disease of a most destructive nature .
igbo: Nke nwere ike ịbụ ọrịa nwere ike imebi ihe.

english: Seventeen years ago, Edwin Madunagu, in the piece referenced above, admonished
igbo: Afọ iri na asaa gara aga, Edwin Madunagu na mpempe a kpọtụrụ aha n'ele dụrụ ọdụ

english: The young Nigerians now threatening to actualize Biafra (to) forget or shelve the plan.
igbo: Ụmụ Naịjirịa na-eyi egwu ugbu a na ha ga-eme ka Biafra bịa (na ha) chefuo ma ọ bụ kpachie atụmatụ ahụ.

english: In place of 'actualisation', they should, through research and study, reconstruct the Biafran story in its fullness and complexity and try to answer the unanswered questions and supply the missing links in the story.
igbo: Ha kwesiri iji ụzọ nchọpụta na agụmakwụkwọ degharịa akụkọ banyere Biafra n'uju ya na ihe dịkwa mgbagwoju anya ma gbalịa zaa ajụjụ a na-edeghị ma chọtakwa ihe na-apụtaghị n'akụkọ a .

english: This is a primary responsibility you owe yourselves:
igbo: Nke a bụ ibu ọrụ dịịrị ụnụ:

english: You should at least understand what you want to actualise .
igbo: ịkwesiri ịghọta opekata mpe mata ihe ịchọrọ ime.

english: If 30 years after Biafra, you want to produce its second edition, you need to benefit from the criticism of the first.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ n'afọ iri atọ gafere, ịchọọ iwepụta mbịpụta ya nke abụọ, ịkwesiri irite uru site na nkatọ nke mbụ.

english: History teaches that a second edition of a tragic event could easily become a farce—in spite of the heroism of its human agencies .
igbo: Akụkọ ihe mere eme na-akụzị na mbipụta nke abụọ nke ihe ọdachị nwere ike ịghọ ihe dị njọ - n'agbanyeghị ike ọrụ nke ndị mmadụ na-achọ ya.

english: On the other hand, those who enjoy ridiculing Biafra—instead of studying it—are politically shortsighted.
igbo: N'aka nke ọzọ, ndị na-enwe mmasị ịkwa Biafra emo - kama ịmụ ya - anaghị elezi anya na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị.

english: My own attitude to Biafra is neither 'actualisation' nor ridicule .
igbo: Omume m maka Biafra abụghị imepụta ya ma ọ bụ ịkwa ya emo.

english: I propose that accounts should be settled with Biafra .
igbo: M na-atụ alo na ekwesiri idozi akaụntụ dị na Biafra.

english: Madunagu's admonition needs no elaboration .
igbo: Ndụmọdụ Madunagu enweghị nkọwa.

english: It is clear enough for the young people pushing for the actualization of Biafra, many of whom were born after the end of the Biafra war 47 years ago .
igbo: O doro anya nyere ndị na-eto eto n-akwado ikewapụta Biafra, nke ọtụtụ n'ime ha bụ ndị amụrụ mgbe agha Biafra biara na njedebe afọ iri anọ na asaa gara aga.

english: The aspect of his position on Biafra that I want to focus on is the aspect that warns of the 'political shortsightedness of ridiculing Biafra' .
igbo: Akụkọ nke ọnọdụ ya na Biafra nke m chọrọ ilekwasị anya bụ akụkọ nke na-adọ aka na ntị banyere elerughi anya ala nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke ịkwa Biafra emo

english: Balkanizing the nation
igbo: imebe isi ala nke mba

english: When the military regime headed by Gowon divided Nigeria into 12 states, it sought to weaken the prospect of the different groups in the Eastern Region uniting against the Nigerian state .
igbo: Mgbe ndị agha nke Gowon na-achị kewara Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri abụọ, ọ chọrọ imebi atụmatụ nke ndị otu dị iche iche na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ ijikọ aka megide Naịjirịa .

english: Of course, that action was music to the ears of minority groups, particularly those in the Eastern Region, who had long demanded their own state .
igbo: N'ezie, ihe ahụ emere dịka egwu na ntị ndị otu pere mpe, ọkachasị ndị nọ n'ọwụwa anyanwụ, ndị chọgoro steeti nke ha ogologo oge .

english: With the creation of states, however, the military not only unilaterally abrogated the geo-political structure that existed then, it went a step further to destroy the principle of federalism on which Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and which had sustained and kept the country together.
igbo: Site na okike nke steeti, ọbụghị naanị na ndị agha kagburu usoro ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke dị n'oge ahụ, ọ gara n'ihu mebie ụkpụrụ nke gọọmentị etiti nke Naịjirịa nke eji nwete nwere onwe na 1960 nke jigidere ma gbazie mba ọnụ .

english: We need to understand that this principle was adopted not only to assuage the fear of domination by a single group in the country but as recognition of the differences (multi-ethnic and multi-lingual) of the various 'ethnic nationalities' that were brought together to create Nigeria.
igbo: Anyị kwesịrị ịghọta na nnabata ụkpụrụ a abụghị naanị maka ụjọ otu òtù ịkagide ndị ọzọ na mba ahụ, kamakwa, dị ka mmata ndịiche (agbụrụ dị iche iche na ọtụtụ asụsụ) nke 'agbụrụ dị iche iche' a kpọkọtara ọnụ iji mebe Naịjirịa.

english: Part of Gowon's broadcast on May 27, 1967, signaling the breakup of Nigeria into 12 states is pertinent here:
igbo: Ihe so n'akụkọ nke mgbasa ozi Gowon na Mee 27, 1967, na-egosi nkewa Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri na abụọ bụ ihe dị oke mkpa ebe a:

english: The main obstacle to future stability in this country is the present structural imbalance in the Nigerian Federation .
igbo: Ihe mgbochi kacha njọ maka nkwụsị ike ọdịnihu na mba a bụ enweghị nhazi nke ugbu a na njịkọ mba.

english: Even Decree No.8 or Confederation or 'loose association' will never survive if any one section of the country is in a position to hold the others to ransom.
igbo: Ọbụla iwu nke asatọ ma ọ bụ njịkọ ma ọ bụ 'mkpakọrịta na-adịghị ọcha' agaghị adị ndụ ma ọ bụrụ na mpaghara ọ bụla nke mba ahụ nwere ike ijide ndị ọzọ n'nkwe.

english: This is why the first item in the political and administrative program adopted by the Supreme Military Council last month is the creation of states for stability .
igbo: Ọ bụ ya mere ihe mbu dị na mmemme ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na nhazi nke ọchịchị ndị agha nabatara n'ọnwa gara aga bụ ịmepụta steeti maka nkwụsị ike .

english: This must be done first so as to remove the fear of domination.
igbo: A ga-ebu ụzọ mee nke a iji wepu egwu nke nnara ike .

english: Representatives drawn from the new states will be more able to work out the future constitution for this country which can contain provisions to protect the powers of the states to the fullest extent desired by the Nigerian people.
igbo: Ndị nnọchị anya sitere na steeti ndị ọhụrụ ga-enwe ike hazie iwu obodo maka ọdịnihu a nke nwere ike ịnwe atụmatụ ichebe ike nke steeti ruo n'ọsọ ndị Naịjirịa chọrọ.

english: As soon as these are established, a new revenue allocation commission consisting of international experts will be appointed to recommend an equitable formula for revenue allocation taking into account the desires of the states .
igbo: Ozugbo emepụtara ihe ndị a, a ga-ahọpụta kọmitii ọhụrụ na-enweta ego nke mejupụtara ndị ọkachamara nke mba ụwa ịkwado usoro ziri ezi maka ịke oke ego ma buru n'uche ọchịchọ nke steeti.

english: I propose to act faithfully within the political and administrative program adopted by the Supreme Military Council and published last month.
igbo: A na m atụ alo ijiri ntụkwasị obi rụọ ọrụ na ihe omume ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na nchịkwa nke nzụkọ ọchịchị ndị agha nabatara ma bipụta n'ọnwa gara aga.

english: The world will recognize in these proposals our desire for justice and fair play for all sections of this country and to accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country.
igbo: Ụwa ga-amata site n'usoro ndị a chọrọ ka anyị jiri ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu dị mma nabata mpaghara niile nke mba a ma nabata ezi ebumnuche nke ndị dị iche iche nke mba a.

english: I have ordered the re-imposition of the economic measures designed to safeguard federal interests until such time as the Eastern Military Governor abrogates his illegal edicts on revenue collection and the administration of the federal statutory corporations based in the East.
igbo: Enyela m iwu iwezighachị usoro akụ na ụba emebere iji chekwaa ọdịmma onye niile ruo oge dị ka Gọvanọ ndị agha nke ọwụwa anyanwụ na-ekpochapụ iwu na-akwadoghị ya na nnakọta ego yana nchịkwa nke ụlọ ọrụ gọọmentị etiti na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ.

english: The country has a long history of well-articulated demands for states .
igbo: Mba a nwere ogologo akụkọ ihe mere eme maka ndị chọrọ steeti .

english: The fears of minorities were explained in great detail and set out in the report of the Willink Commission appointed by the British in 1958 .
igbo: A kọwara nke ọma ihe ịtụ egwu nke ndị mpaghara pere mpe ma wepụta na akụkọ nke akwụkwọ akụkọ Willink nke ndị Britain họpụtara n'afọ 1958 .

english: More recently, there have been extensive discussions in Regional Consultative Committees and leaders-of-thought conferences .
igbo: N'adịbeghị anya, enwere mkparịta ụka miri emi na kọmitii na-ahụ maka mpaghara na nnọkọ ndị isi-echiche .

english: Resolutions have been adopted demanding the creation of states in the North and in Lagos .
igbo: Emeela mkpebi maka ịmepụta steeti na mpaghara Ugwu na Legos.

english: Petitions from minority areas in the East which have been subjected to violent intimidation by the Eastern Military Government have been publicized .
igbo: A kọsara arịrịọ ndị mpaghara pere mpe na ọwụwa anyanwụ maka ịmepụta steeti nke gọọmentị ndị agha ọwụwa anyanwụ na-eyi egwu .

english: While the present circumstances regrettably do not allow for consultations through plebiscites, I am satisfied that the creation of new states as the only possible basis for stability and equality is the overwhelming desire of the vast majority of Nigerians .
igbo: N'agbanyeghị ọnọdụ ndị dị ugbu a na-akwa ụta na ha ekweghị ka a jụọ ajụjụ site na arịrịọ, enwere m afọ ojuju na ịmepụta steeti ọhụrụ dịka naanị ihe ndabere maka nkwụsị ike na nhatanha bụ nnukwu ọchịchọ nke ọtụtụ ndị Naịjirịa .

english: To ensure justice, these states are being created simultaneously .
igbo: Iji hụ n'ikpe ziri ezi, a na-ekepụta steeti ndị a n'otu oge .

english: To this end, therefore, I am promulgating a decree which will divide the Federal Republic into 12 states .
igbo: N'ihi nke a, ana m ekwupụta iwu ga-ekewa obodo niile na steeti iri abụọ .

english: The 12 states will be six in the present Northern Region, three in the present Eastern Region, the Mid-Western will remain as it is, the Colony Province of the Western Region and Lagos will form a new Lagos State and the Western Region will otherwise remain as it is .
igbo: Steeti iri na abụọ ahụ ga-adị isii na mpaghara Ugwu nke ugbu a, atọ dị na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ ugbu a, mpaghara nke etiti ga-adị ka ọ dị ugbu a, mpaghara ogbè ndị ọdịda anyanwụ na Legos ga-emepụta steeti Legos ọhụrụ na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwụ ga-anọrọ otu ọ dị.

english: What the military regime of Gowon gave with one hand it took with the other .
igbo: Ihe ndị agha ọchịchị Gowon nyere n'otu aka, o were ya n'aka nke ọzọ .

english: And that would become the hallmark of subsequent military regimes in Nigeria .
igbo: Nke ahụ ga-abụkwa ihe eji amara ọchịchị ndị agha na-achị na Naịjirịa .

english: Gowon failed to realize, or deliberately ignored the reality that the issue wasn't the division of the country but the reluctance or inability of the military to keep its promise
igbo: Gowon amataghị, ma ọ bụ ọ kpachara anya leghaara eziokwu ahụ anya na okwu ahụ abụghị nkewa nke obodo mana enweghị mmasị ma ọ bụ enweghị ike nke ndị agha iji mezuo nkwa ya

english: This must be done first so as to remove the fear of domination .
igbo: A ga-ebu ụzọ mee nke a iji wepu egwu nke mkpagbu .

english: Representatives drawn from the new states will be more able to work out the future constitution for this country which can contain provisions to protect the powers of the states to the fullest extent desired by the Nigerian people .
igbo: Ndị nnọchị anya si na steeti ndị ọhụrụ ga-enwe ike ịmebe iwu obodo n'ọdịnihu nke nwere ike ịnwe ihe iji chebe ikike nke steeti ruo n'okè ndị Naịjirịa chọrọ .

english: Unfortunately, that never happened .
igbo: Ọ dị nwute, nke ahụ emeghị .

english: It couldn't have, considering the rapacious and parasitic nature of the Nigerian military so-called and the interest it represented and still represents .
igbo: O nweghị ike ịme, na-atule ụdị mmadụ ndị agha Naịjirịa bụ na mmasị ọ nọchịrị anya ma ka na-anọchị anya ya .

english: Once the military couldn't deliver on that promise, it also meant that the second part of its declaration that:
igbo: Ozugbo ndị agha enweghị ike imejupụta nkwa ahụ, ọ pụtakwara na akụkụ nke abụọ nke nkwupụta ya na:

english: 'The world will recognise in these proposals our desire for justice and fair play for all sections of this country' and
igbo: 'Ụwa ga-amata site n'usoro ndị a na ọchịchọ anyị bụ maka ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi maka ngalaba niile nke mba a' na

english: 'To accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country,' was nothing but meaningless soundbite by a rampaging military sub-class in desperate search for legitimacy.
igbo: 'Ịnabata ebumnuche dị mma niile nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu obodo a' abụghị ihe efu ma oli nke na-enweghị isi site na ndị agha na-ebuso agha n'ịchọsị i ike iwu.

english: Since then, there has neither been 'justice nor fair play for all sections' of Nigeria.
igbo: Kemgbe ahụ, enwebeghị 'ikpe ziri ezi ma ọ bụ egwuregwu ziri ezi nyere mpaghara niile' nke Naịjirịa.

english: There hasn't been any serious attempt to 'accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country .
igbo: Enwebeghị mgbalị siri ike iji 'nabata ebumnuche niile dị mma nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu mba a' .

english: The sham of a federation that the military created has evolved into a Frankenstein's monster. Fast forward 50 years.
igbo: Ihe ihere nyere mba nke otu ndị agha mebere abanyela na nnukwu anụ Frankenstein. Ngwa ngwa n'ihu afọ iri ise .

english: Cleary, it is the nebulous federal government that is holding the country to ransom. The moment the military government took economic powers from the states, there was no way we could ensure justice and fair play.
igbo: N'ụzọ doro anya, ọ bụ gọọmentị etiti na-ejide mba a n'mgbapụta .

english: And once you can't ensure justice and fair play, there is no way you can stop the concomitant disquiet.
igbo: Ozugbo oge ndị ọchịchị weghara ikike akụ na ụba nke steeti, ọ nweghị ụzọ anyị ga-esi hụ na ekpere ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi, ọ nweghị ụzọ ị ga-esi kwụsị ọgbahara .

english: The politics of state creation
igbo: Ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke okike steeti

english: When Gen Murtala Muhammed created additional seven states—three in the 'South' and four in the 'North'—bringing the total to 19 states, and a new federal capital territory, Abuja, on February 3, 1976, ten days before his assassination on February 13, he left no one in doubt that the conquest was real.
igbo: Mgbe Gen. Muhammed mepụtara steeti asaa ọzọ - atọ na mpaghara ọdịda na anọ na mpaghara Ugwu- na-enweta mkpọkọta nke steeti ruo iri na itoolu, yana ogbè ọhụrụ gọọmentị etiti, Abuja na Febuwarị 3, 1976, ụbọchị iri tupu egbuo ya na Febuwarị 13, enyeghị onye ọbụla obi abụọ na mmeri a dị.

english: While Gowon showed an inclination to balance Nigeria geo-politically, Muhammed ensured that the 'North' had ten states while the 'South' had nine .
igbo: Oge Gowon gosipụtara na ọ nwere ike imezu nhazi usoro ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị Naịjirịa, Muhammed gbara mbọ hu na mpaghara Ugwu nwere steeti iri ebe mpaghara ọdịda nwere itoolu.

english: It has been alleged that the decision was to create four new states in the 'North' and four new states in the 'South', but when Muhammed announced the creation of states, instead of creating two states (Cross River and Akwa Ibom States) out of the old South-Eastern State, he simply announced the transformation of South-Eastern State into Cross River State.
igbo: Ekwuru na mkpebi ahụ bụ ịmepụta steeti ọhụrụ anọ na mpaghara Ugwu na steeti ọhụrụ anọ na ọdịda, mana mgbe Muhammed kwupụtara okike steeti, kama ịmepụta steeti abụọ, (steeti Cross River na Akwa Ibom) site na nke ochie ọdịda anyanwụ nke steeti ọwụwa anyanwụ, ọ kpọrọ mgbanwe nke ọdịda anyanwụ nke steeti ọwụwa anyanwụ gaa steeti Cross River.

english: Subsequent military regimes continued the conquest, not just on the political front, but on the economic front as well .
igbo: Usọrọ ọchịchị ndị sochirinu gara n'ihu na-emeri, ọ bụghị naanị n'ihu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, kamakwa n'ihu akụ na ụba.

english: Ten years later, in 1986, when the self-professed evil genius, Gen Ibrahim Babangida, set up a Political Bureau to review the country's political and democratic system, one of its recommendations was the creation of an additional state (Akwa Ibom State) in 'South' to create a geo-political balance of ten states each between the 'North' and 'South' .
igbo: Afọ iri ka nke ahụ gasịrị,na 1986, mgbe onye kwupụtara onwe ya ka ọkachamara maka ajọ ihe, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, guzobere ụlọ ọrụ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị iji nyochaa ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche nke obodo, otu n'ime ndụmọdụ ya bụ ịmepụta steeti ọzọ (Akwa Ibom) na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwụ iji mepụta ndozi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke steeti iri ọbụla n'etiti mpaghara Ugwu na ndida .

english: Babangida spurned that recommendation .
igbo: Babangida jụrụ ịkwado ndụmọdụ ahụ .

english: He did create Akwa Ibom State, but he added another state (Katsina State) in the 'North' to maintain the imbalance .
igbo: O mepụtara steeti Akwa Ibom mana o mepụtarakwara steeti ọzọ (Katsina steeti) na Ugwu iji nọgịde na-adighị n'otu .

english: It was the same pattern that was adopted in subsequent state creation in 1991 (under Gen Babangida) and 1996 (under Gen Sani Abacha) .
igbo: Ọ bụ otu ukporo ahụ ka atọrọ na mmepụta steeti na-esote na 1991 (n'okpuru Gen. Babangida) na 1996 (n'okpuru Gen. Sani Abacha).

english: Geo-politically, today, Nigeria is composed of 36 states: 19 states in the 'North' and 17 states in the 'South' .
igbo: Na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, taa, Naịjirịa nwere steeti iri atọ na isii: Steeti iri na itoolu si na mpaghara Ugwu ebe steeti iri na asaa si na mpaghara ndida .

english: Ordinarily, this should not matter .
igbo: N'ihe ịga n'anya ya, nke a ekwesịghị ịdị mkpa .

english: After all, in a federation, the federating units (states) are supposed to manage their affairs substantially and contribute to the sustenance of the Federation.
igbo: N'ihe niile, na ngalaba, gọọmentị etiti, ngalaba ndị a na-achị (steeti) kwesịrị ijikwa ihe omume ha nke ọma ma na-enye aka na nkwalite nke gọọmentị .

english: Therefore, only those who feel their states can sustain themselves would clamor for the creation of such states .
igbo: Ya mere, ọ bụ naanị ndị chere na steeti ha nwere ike ịkwagide onwe ha ga-ekwupụta maka ịmepụta steeti ndị a .

english: Of course, more self-sustaining states would mean more opportunities for the national government to benefit from the exploration and exploitation of resources in every state.
igbo: N'ezie, steeti ndị ga-ejigidenwu onwe ha ga-enwekwu ohere maka gọọmentị mba iji rite uru na nrigbu na nrigbu akụrụngwa na steeti ọ bụla .

english: Unfortunately, that is not the case with Nigeria.
igbo: Ọ bụ ihe nwute na osighị otua dịrị na Naịjirịa .

english: In a country where the military had hijacked and centralized the control of economic resources and political power by, for example, arrogating to itself the authority to create local governments as well as placing itself in the position of chief dispenser of funds based on its own criteria, including population, land mass, number of local governments, derivation principle, etc.
igbo: N'obodo ebe ndị agha weghaara ma tinye isi na ikike nchịkwa akụ na ụba na ike ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị site, n'ọmụmatụ, inye onwe ya ikike imepụta ọchịchị gọọmentị ime obodo yana itinye onwe ya n'ọnọdụ onye isi na-ekesa ego site na njirisi nke ya, gụnyere ọnụ ọgụgụ nke gọọmentị mpaghara inweta ụkpụrụ, ọnụ ọgụgụ nke ọchịchị ime obodo dgz.

english: The dog eat dog demand for states was inevitable.
igbo: A kwusinwughị usoro nkịta riri nkịta chọrọ steeti.

english: Thanks to the military—the armed wing of Nigeria's dominant power bloc—Nigeria has a weird federation where states can't create their own local governments; where local governments are listed in constitutions that have been nothing but military decrees writ large.
igbo: Ekele dịrị ndị agha- ogwe aka ike nke Naịjirịa- Naịjirịa nwere ọgbakọ ọchịchị dị egwu ebe steeti enweghị ike ịmepụta gọọmentị ime obodo; ebe edepụtara ọchịchị ime obodo na usoro iwu ndị agha na enweghị ihe ọzọ na-abụghị iwu ndị agha.

english: Thanks to the military, Nigeria has spurned justice and fair play and disregarded the genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country.
igbo: Ekele dịrị ndị agha, Naịjirịa emebiela ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi ma leghaara ezi ebumnuche nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu obodo a anya.

english: It is not for nothing that Nigeria is described as a federal republic.
igbo: Ọ bụghị n'efu ka a kọwara Naịjirịa dịka otu obodo .

english: It was a choice made by the three regions in Nigeria preceding independence.
igbo: Ọ bụ mmasị nke mpaghara atọ ndị dị na Naịjirịa mere tupu nnwere onwe .

english: Both the Eastern and Western regions obtained internal self-government (independence) in 1957, while the North got same in 1959.
igbo: Mpaghara ọwụwa na ọdịda anyanwụ nwetara ọchịchị nke ịchị onwe ha (nnwere onwe) na 1957, ebe mpaghara Ugwu nwetara na 1959 .

english: Each region could have opted to go its own way in 1960.
igbo: Mpaghara ọbụla gaara ahọrọ ịga n'ụzọ nke aka ha na 1960 .

english: We could have had three countries as opposed to one at independence.
igbo: Anyị kaara inwe mba atọ na-abụghị otu na mgbe nnwere onwe .

english: The decision by the regions to be part of a shared territory called Nigeria came with some obligation and expectation.
igbo: Mkpebi mpaghara ịbụ akụkụ nke ala a na-akpọ Naịjirịa biara na ụfọdụ oke na ọrụ .

english: There is little to suggest that the federating region were willing to jettison the greater part of their economic and political independence for the sake of 'one Nigeria' .
igbo: E nweghị ihe na-atụ alo na mpaghara ndị a na-achị dị njikere iwere akụkụ ka ukwuu nke akụ na ụba na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ha maka 'otu Nịjirịa' .

english: In 1963, the regions (the precursor of our current states) controlled 50 percent of the revenues accruing from their region
igbo: N'afọ 1963, (ihe anyị na-elebara anya na steeti anyị ugbu a) na-achịkwa pesent iri ise nke ego ha na-enweta site n'obodo ha

english: Today we are quibbling whether the states have right to as little as 13 percent.
igbo: Taa anyị na-ajụ ma steeti o nwere ikike ọbụladị pesent iri na atọ .

english: In a sense, this manifest heist by the federal government has perpetuated injustice in some sections of the country while condoning indolence in others .
igbo: N'otu echiche, gọọmentị etiti enwebatala ikpe ikpe a, na-ezighị ezi na mpaghara ụfọdụ ma na-anabata ndị ọzọ .

english: It is this quest for control or lack of, that is at the heart of the Nigerian crisis .
igbo: Ọ bụ n'ọchịchọ nchịkwaa ma ọ bụ enweghị, bụ isi nsogbu nke Naịjirịa.

english: Biafra of the mind vs Biafra of the field
igbo: Biafra nke uche na Biafra nke ubi

english: What is Biafra ?
igbo: Gịnị bụ Biafra ?

english: If that question was tough to answer in 1967, it is even more difficult today, fifty years after .
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ajụjụ a siri ike ịza na 1967, ọ ka sie ike taa, afọ iri ise ka nke ahụ gasịrị .

english: As a nation, Biafra was going to be difficult to sustain even if it had been actualized .
igbo: Dị ka otu mba, Biafra ga-esi ike ịnagide ọ bụrụgodị na e keputara ya .

english: Was Biafra a nation made up of ethnic nationalities ?
igbo: Ndị Biafra ha buru mba mejupụtara agbụrụ ha?

english: In other words, was Biafra a microcosm of Nigeria ?
igbo: N'aka nke ọzọ, Biafra ọ bụ obere Naịjirịa ?

english: One of the things those who are agitating for Biafra have not been able to define or communicate effectively is an answer to the question: What is Biafra ?
igbo: Otu n'ime ihe ndị ahụ na achọ Biafra enwebeghị ike ịkọwa ma ọ bụ ikwukọrịta okwu nke ọma bụ azịza nye ajụjụ a : Gịnị bụ Biafra ?

english: The answers to this question are as varied as there are agitators .
igbo: Azịza ajụjụ a dị iche iche dị ka ndị na-achọ ya.

english: There are those who will tell you that Biafra encompasses the area that used to be the Eastern Region of Nigeria and beyond, including parts of Southern Cameroon and stretching to Equatorial Guinea and Gabon.
igbo: Enwere ndị ga-agwa gị na Biafra gụnyere mpaghara ahụ bụbu mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu nke Naịjirịa na gafere, gụnyere akụkụ ụfọdụ nke Saut Cameroon wee ruo Equatorial Guinea na Gabon .

english: Some define Biafra as simply the former Eastern Region of Nigeria that was given the name Biafra on May 30, 1967.
igbo: Ụfọdụ kọwara Biafra dịka nanị mpaghara izizi nke ọdịda anyanwu nke Naịjirịa nke enyere aha ya bụ Biafra na Mee 30, 1967.

english: Some say it is the five states (Abia, Anambra, Ebonyi, Enugu and Imo) in south-east Nigeria where the Igbos are the major ethnic group .
igbo: Ụfọdụ kwuru na ọ bụ steeti ise ( Abia, Anambra, Ebonyi, Enugu na Imo) na south-east nke Naịjirịa ebe ndị Igbo bụ ndị kacha na agbụrụ.

english: Yet, others define Biafra as encompassing all the Igbo-speaking areas of southern Nigeria, including parts of present-day Rivers, Bayelsa, Delta, Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Benue States.
igbo: Agbanyeghị, ndị ọzọ kọwara na Biafra gụnyere mpaghara niile na-asụ asụsụ Igbo mpaghara ndịda nke Naịjirịa, gụnyere Rivers, Bayelsa, Delta, Akea Ibom, gafere osimiri na steeti Benue.

english: The issue of definition is important because the lack of understanding and agreement can pose great problems .
igbo: Okwu banyere nkọwa dị mkpa n'ihi enweghị nghọta na nkwekọrịta nwere ike ibute nnukwu nsogbu.

english: Of course, up until May 30, 1967, there was nothing like Biafra as nation or political territory.
igbo: Dịka ruo ọnwa Mee 30, 1967, o nweghi ihe dịka Biafra dịka obodo ma ọ bụ mpaghara ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị .

english: The only thing that bore the tag Biafra was a bight off the West African coast, in the easternmost part of the Gulf of Guinea, stretching to Cape Lopez in Gabon, over which Britain established a colonial protectorate in 1849.
igbo: Naanị ihe gosipụtara Biafra bụ ebe mpụtara dị n'akụkụ ọdịda anyanwụ nke Africa, n'akụkụ ebe ọwụwa anyanwụ nke Guinea, na-eru Cape Lopez dị na Gabon, ebe ndị bekee guzobere ikike nchịkwa na 1849.

english: Biafra as a nation was a child of circumstance that would become a child of necessity.
igbo: Biafra dịka mba bụ nwa amụrụ ka ihe si dị nke ga-abụzị nwa dị mkpa e kwesiri ịmụ.

english: What if the bloody January 15, 1966, coup and the attendant assassinations didn't happen ?
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ọgbaghara ọbara nnatụ ọchịchị nke ọnwa Jenụwarị 15, 1966 emeghi .

english: If Igbo political leaders had been killed alongside their counterparts from the 'North' and 'West';
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na e gbụrụ ndị isi ọchịchị si n'ala Igbo na ibe ha ndị si na ndịda na ọwụwa anyanwụ .

english: If the 'revenge coup' of July 29, 1966, and the attendant murders didn't occur;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na o gbụgbụ nke Julai 29,1966 na o gbụgbụ ndị bịara emeghi .

english: If the Nigerian state had reined in the murderous groups (military and civilian) that had targeted Igbos after the July 29 coup;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na steeti ndị Naijiria nọ na ọchịchị ndị na-akwafụ ọbara (ndị agha na ndị nkiti) nke lekwasara anya na ndị Igbo mgbe ọgbahara nke Julai, 29 ghara .

english: If Gen Aguiyi Ironsi—the first indigenous general and leader of the Nigerian Army—an Igbo who was not part of the January 15 abortive coup, had not been a major beneficiary by seizing power and becoming head of state;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na onye isi agha bụ Ironsi - nwa afọ izizi bụ Onyeisi agha na onyeisi ndi agha Naiijiria - onye Igbo esonyeghị na nnatụ Jenuwarị 15 ahụ - abughi one rikarisiri uru ya site n'iweghara ọchịchị ma bụrụ onyeisi obodo .

english: If Gen Ironsi had executed the coup plotters of January 15 as military tradition dictates;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na onye isi agha bụ Ironsi gburu ndị na-akpa nkata i were ọchịchị na Jenụwarị 15 dịka iwu ndị agha siri kwuo.

english: If the regime of Gen Ironsi did not promulgate Decree No. 34 — which abrogated the country's federal structure in exchange for a unitary one;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ọchịchị onye isi agha bụ Ironsi emebeghi iwu 34 nke wepụrụ udi ọchịchị nke federal ji ọchịchị nke inwe otu onye isi ji gbanwee ya.

english: If the 'January 15 boys' had completed their 'project' either by one of them becoming head of state or as some have alluded, released the imprisoned leader of the national opposition, Chief Obafemi Awolowo, and installed him as prime minister;
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ụmụ nwoke nke ọnwa Janụwarị 15, rụchara ọrụ ha site na otu onye ibu onye ndu ma ọ bụ dịka ụfọdụ si chee, ị kpọpụta onye isi ndị otu na emegide ndị ọchịchị bụ Obafemi Awolowo na ngha ka ọ bụrụ onye isi,

english: If the Nigerian government led by Gowon had implemented the agreement reached at Aburi ?
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị nke Naijiria n'okpuru Gowon mejuputara nkwekọrịta ha n'Aburi ?

english: The secret police had stormed the place to effect the rearrest of pro-democracy campaigner and journalist, Omoyele Sowore, who was standing trial in a case brought against him by the Nigerian Government.
igbo: Ndị uwe ojii nzuzo wakporo ebe ahụ iji wee ruo ọrụ azụ nye onye nta akụkọ na-ekwu maka ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na onye nta akụkọ, Omoyele Sowore, onye na-ekpe ikpe n'okwu gọọmentị Naịjirịa wetara ya.

english: Sowore was first arrested on August 3, 2019 by the DSS for calling on Nigerians to take to the streets in peaceful demonstrations to demand a better country from the administration of President Muhammadu Buhari.
igbo: Ndị uwe ojii DSS jidere Sowore na ọgọst 3, 2019 maka ịkpọ ndị Naịjirịa ka ha gaa n'okporo ụzọ ngosipụta udo iji chọọ obodo ka mma site na ọchịchị Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari.

english: The government is accusing him of insulting President Buhari and planning to bring down his regime.
igbo: Gọọmentị na-ebo ya ebubo na ọ na-akparị onye isi ala Buhari na-eme atụmatụ iweda ọchịchị ya.

english: He was rearrested by the DSS on Friday less than 24 hours after being released on bail after 125 days in detention.
igbo: Ndị DSS kpọgharịrị ya na Fraịde erughị elekere iri abụọ na anọ ka a gbapụtachara ya n'nga nọrọ ụbọchị iri abụọ na ụma.

english: Chairman of Senate Committee on Judiciary, Human Rights and Legal Matters, Opeyemi Bamidele, moved the motion for the probe of the court invasion by the DSS.
igbo: Onye isi oche Kọmitii na-ahụ maka ọkaikpe, ihe ndị ruuru mmadụ na okwu gbasara iwu, Opeyemi Bamidele kpaliri ngagharị maka nyocha nke mwakpo ụlọ ọrụ ndị DSS.

english: Senate President, Ahmed Lawan, instructed the committee to begin legislative procedure on the matter and report next week.
igbo: Onye isi oche Sinet, Ahmed Lawan, nyere kọmitii ahụ iwu ịmalite usoro iwu gbasara okwu ahụ ma kọọ akụkọ na-abịa n'izu .

english: Public Bus (BRT) Currently Burning On Third Mainland Bridge In Lagos
igbo: Ụgbọ ala na-akwọ ọha na eze (BRT) Ugbu a na-agba Ọkụ n'akwa mmiri III Mainland na Legos

english: According to an eyewitness, the blue bus, which was heading towards Iyana-Oworo, caught fire just after Adeniji Adele axis of the bridge with the disaster resulting in chaos and heavy traffic gridlock
igbo: Dị ka onye hụrụ ya hụrụ, ụgbọ ala ahụ na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, nke na-aga Iyana-Oworo, gbara ọkụ mgbe Adeniji Adele gbariri àkwà mmiri nke kpatara ọdachi kpatara ọgbaghara na nnukwu okporo ụzọ.

english: There is chaos on the third mainland bridge right now as one of the buses used for the bus rapid transit (BRT) in Lagos is currently burning on the bridge.
igbo: Enwere ọgbaghara na akwa mmiri nke ala ugbu a dịka otu n'ime ụgbọ ala ndị e ji mee njem ngwa ngwa (BRT) na Legos na-agba ọkụ ugbu a na akwa mmiri.

english: According to an eyewitness, the blue bus, which was heading towards Iyana-Oworo, caught fire just after Adeniji Adele axis of the bridge with the disaster resulting in chaos and heavy traffic gridlock.
igbo: Dabere na onye hụrụ ya anya, ụgbọ ala na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, nke na-aga Iyana-Oworo, gbara ọkụ mgbe Adeniji Adele gbariri àkwà mmiri nke kpatara ọdachi ọgbaghara na nnukwu okporo ụzọ.

english: It is unclear if there have been any casualties from the incident.
igbo: Amabeghị ma onwere onye meruru ahu na ihe ndachị ahụ

english: The officials of Lagos fire service and LASTMA are desperately trying to put out the fire and ensure order in the area.
igbo: Ndị ọrụ nchekwa ọkụ na Legos na LASTMA na-achọsi ike ịmenyu ọkụ ma hụ na enwere nhazị dị na mpaghara ahụ.

english: Queen's College Student To Face Disciplinary Panel Over Artificial Eyelashes
igbo: Nwa akwụkwọ nke Queen's College ga-aza ndị na-agbazị mmadụ maka nku anya ọkwunyere.

english: The college's Parents-Teachers Association have condemned the girl's mother seen in a viral video harassing a security guard of the school because her daughter was punished, according to The Nation.
igbo: Ndị otu nne na nna ndị nkuzi kọleji ahụ katọrọ nne nwa nwanyị ahụ a hụrụ na ihe nkiri na-enye ndị nche ụlọ akwụkwọ ahụhụ n'ihi ntaramahụhụ nwa ya nwanyị, ka 'Nation' kwuru.

english: Queen's College was founded as a girls' school in 1927 during the colonial era
igbo: E guzobere Queen's College dị ka ụlọ akwụkwọ ụmụ nwanyị na 1927 n'oge ọchịchị ndị ọcha

english: More details have emerged about what transpired in the viral video of a Queen's College pupil harassed out of the college for wearing artificial eyelashes and painting her nails.
igbo: Nkọwa ndị ọzọ apụtaala gbasara ihe mere na ihe nkiri nke nwa akwụkwọ Queen's College agbara akwụkwọ na kọleji maka ịkwụnye nku anya ma tee kwa mbọ aka.

english: The college's Parents-Teachers Association have condemned the girl's mother seen in a viral video harassing a security guard of the school because her daughter was punished, according to The Nation.
igbo: Ndị otu nne na nna ndị nkuzi kọleji ahụ katọrọ nne nwa nwanyị ahụ a hụrụ na ihe nkiri na-enye ndị nche ụlọ akwụkwọ ahụhụ n'ihi ntaramahụhụ nwa ya nwanyị, ka The Nation kwuru.

english: The girl had resumed two weeks late after midterm on Monday and was being punished for wearing artificial eyelashes and painted nails.
igbo: Nwatakịrị nwanyị ahụ lọghachitere izu abụọ ka ọ gafesịrị ezumike ha na Mọnde, enye ya ntaramahụhụ maka iyi nku anya ma tee mbọ aka.

english: However, unknown to her teachers, her mother was watching but did not identify herself.
igbo: Agbanyeghị, ndị nkuzi amaghị na nne ya na-ele ma onweghị onye ọ kọwara onwe ya.

english: Trouble started when she attempted to drag the girl out of the school and the security man (not knowing she was the mother) challenged her.
igbo: Nsogbu malitere mgbe ọ nwara ịchụpụ nwa agbọghọ ahụ n'ụlọ akwụkwọ na nwoke nchekwa (n'amaghị na ọ bụ nne ya) mara ya aka.

english: The mother reacted by attacking the security guard.
igbo: Nne ya mere ihe site na ịwakpo onye nche.

english: A source said, 'The girl was returning to school two weeks after the mid-term had ended.
igbo: akụkọ kọrọ, sị, 'Nwata nwanyị ahụ loghachitere ụlọ akwụkwọ izu abụọ ka izu ezumike gwuru.

english: When the teachers saw her with eyelashes and painted nails, they asked her to kneel down.
igbo: Mgbe ndị nkuzi hụrụ nku anya ya na mbọ aka ya, ha gwara ya gbuo ikpere n'ala.

english: Her mother came in with her, sat down and listened but did not say anything.
igbo: Mama ya batara, soro ya nọdụ ala ma gee ntị ma ọ nweghị ihe ọ bụla o kwuru.

english: Someone heard her telling her daughter in Igbo that she should run away.
igbo: Otu onye nụrụ mgbe ọ na-agwa nwa ya nwanyị na olu Igbo na ya gbaa ọsọ.

english: But the girl refused.
igbo: Ma nwa agbọghọ ahụ jụrụ.

english: After the third time, the mother grabbed the girl's bag and made to leave.
igbo: Mgbe oge nke atọ gasịrị, nne ya jidere akpa nwa agbọghọ ahụ wee chọọ ịpụ.

english: When people realised that she was the girl's mother, she quickly dragged the girl out. The security man did not did not know it was the girl's mother dragging her out.
igbo: Mgbe ndị mmadụ matara na ọ bụ nne nwatakịrị nwanyị ahụ, ọ kpọpụtara nwa agbọghọ ahụ ngwa ngwa. Onye nchekwa amabeghị na ọ bụ nne nwa agbọghọ ahụ na-akpọpụta ya.

english: In an attempt to ask why she was taking one of our students out, that was when she attacked the security man.
igbo: Mgbe ọ si ka ọjụọ ihe mere o ji na-akpọpụ otu n'ime ụmụ akwụkwọ anyị, ọ bụ mgbe ahụ ka ọ wakporo nwoke ahụ na-eche nche.

english: The girl was even remorseful .
igbo: Nwa agbọghọ ahụ chegharịrị .

english: She was asking the mother why she was disgracing her .
igbo: Ọ nọ na-ajụ nne ya ihe mere o ji na-emenyere ya ihere .

english: The source said the girl was returned to school by her mother on Tuesday and would face disciplinary measures.
igbo: Isi akụkọ ahụ kwuru na nne ya kpọghachiri ya n'ụlọ akwụkwọ na Tuzde ebe ọ ga-anara usoro ọzụzụ.

english: The source added, the woman came to drop the girl around 5:00am in the morning urging her to sneak into her class.
igbo: Isi akụkọ ahụ gbakwụnyere, nwanyị ahụ zụbara nwa agbọghọ ahụ n'ihe dị ka elekere 5 nke ụtụtụ wee gbaa ya ume ịbanye na klasi ya.

english: But the girl did not sneak .
igbo: Ma nwa agbọghọ ahụ agaghị.

english: She stood by the security gate till morning and presented herself to the school management.
igbo: O guzo n'akuku uzo nche rue ututu wee gosi onwe ya onye isi ụlọ akwụkwọ.

english: A man who claimed to be her father came to the school to apologise on her behalf but we found out that he is not her father .
igbo: Otu nwoke nke kwuru na ya bụ nna ya bịara ụlọ akwụkwọ ịrịọ mgbaghara mana anyị chọpụtara na ọ bụghị nna ya.

english: She will face the disciplinary committee .
igbo: Ọ ga-eche kọmitii ọzụzụ .

english: Many people – including the state, are now interested in the case .
igbo: Ọtụtụ ndị mmadụ - gụnyere steeti, nwere mmasị ugbu a n'okwu ikpe.

english: So we are investigating .
igbo: Ya mere anyị na-eme nchọpụta .

english: In a statement, the Caretaker Committee of the College's PTA noted that the association was in support of the school management's position on discipline .
igbo: Na nkwupụta, Kọmịshọna na-ahụ maka PTA kọleji ahụ kwuru na ndị otu ahụ nọ na-akwado ọnọdụ nchịkwa ụlọ akwụkwọ na ịdọ aka na ntị .

english: The statement reads: We condemn in totality the action of the parent .
igbo: Nkwupụta ahụ kwuru, sị: 'Anyị na-akatọ akparamagwa dum nne na nna ya.

english: We stand by the management in enforcing discipline in the school .
igbo: Anyị na-eguzo n'akụkụ ndị nlekọta ụlọ akwụkwọ na ịmanye ịkpa ezi agwa n'ụlọ akwụkwọ.

english: However, the Committee will invite both the parent and the student with a view to ameliorating the situation and preventing a repeat of similar occurrence .
igbo: Otuodi, Kọmitii ahụ ga-akpọ ma nne ma nna ma nwa akwụkwọ ahụ ka ha chebara ọnọdụ ahụ echiche wee gbochie imeghachi ụdị ihe ahụ.

english: The lesson we need to take home on this is simply that Queen's College will not tolerate violation of its well settled rules and regulations.'
igbo: Ihe nkuzi anyị kwesịrị ịmụta na nke a bụ naanị na ụlọ akwụkwọ Queen agaghị anabata iwu megidere ya na ụkpụrụ ya .

english: Questions Amaechi Should Answer On Transportation University By Olabisi Deji-Folutile
igbo: Ajụjụ Amaechi Kwesịrị ịza gbasara ụgbọ njem mahadum Site na Olabisi Deji-Folutile

english: Honestly, Nigeria should concentrate on building its research capacity and developing innovative curricula that will help its students develop the crucial skills of creativity and critical thinking.
igbo: N'ezie, Naịjirịa kwesiri itinye uche na iwulite ikike nyocha ya na iwulite usoro mmụta ga-enyere ụmụ akwụkwọ ya aka ịzụlite ikike dị mkpa nke okike na echiche siri ike.

english: These are some of the things that can make Nigeria relevant in the development space.
igbo: Ihe ndị a bụ ụfọdụ n'ime ihe nwere ike ime ka Naịjirịa nwee ohere na mmepe obodo.

english: I never believed Nigeria was serious about starting a Transportation University until Monday when President Muhammadu Buhari and other government officials commissioned the project in Daura, the President's home town.
igbo: Ekweteghị m na Naịjirịa kpọrọ ịmalite Mahadum ụgbọ njem ihe ruo ụbọchị Mọnde mgbe Onye isi ala bụ Muhammadu Buhari na ndị ọrụ gọọmentị ndị ọzọ mepere ọrụ ahụ na Daura, obodo nke Onye isi ala.

english: The university, according to Transportation Minister, Mr Rotimi Amaechi, is a response to the question of how Nigeria would maintain and manage its railway infrastructure.
igbo: Mahadum ahụ, ka mịnịsta ụgbọ njem, Mazị Rotimi Amaechi si kwuo, bụ azịza nye ajụjụ ahụ banyere etu Naịjirịa ga-esi lekọta ma jikwaa akụrụngwa okporo ụzọ ya.

english: The reason given notwithstanding, the whole gamut of excitement that characterized the groundbreaking ceremony, suggests something else.
igbo: N'agbanyeghị ihe kpatara ya, obi ụtọ niile nke emume a, na-egosi ihe ozo.

english: Going by the way the minister resorted to insults and vituperation on Nigerians that dared to query the rationale for establishing the university in the President's home town;
igbo: Otu mịnịsta ahụ jiri mkparịa ndị Naịjirịa juru maka ebumnuche iguzo mahadum n'obodo nke Onye isi ala;

english: It appears the project was borne out of political contingency than any other reason.
igbo: Ọ dị ka ebumnuche nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị karịrị ihe ọzọ ọ bụla .

english: Besides, Amaechi stole the show at the ceremony that ordinarily should have been organised by the ministry of education and the National Universities Commission in conjunction with the Transportation ministry
igbo: Agbanyeghị, Amaechi weere ụbọchị ahụ nke kwesịrị isite na ngalaba agụmakwụkwọ na ụlọ ọrụ n'ahụ maka ọchịchị Mahadum ma gbaziri ụlọ ọrụ na ahụ maka ụgbọ njem .

english: From the minister's excitement, it is as if the transportation university is the best thing that has ever happened to Nigeria in recent times.
igbo: Site na mkparịta ụka obi ụtọ nke onye ozi, ọ dị ka a ga - asị na mahadum njem ahụ bụ ihe kachasị mma nke emetụla na Naịjirịa n'oge ndị na - adịbeghị anya .

english: He boasted about how he forced the China Civil Engineering Construction Company to undertake the project by refusing to sign the contract for Lagos-Ibadan Rail project and how he also forced the company to take some Nigerians to China for training in railway technology .
igbo: O turu ọnụ banyere etu o siri mee ka ụlọ ọrụ na akụ igwè nke China wee rụọ ọrụ a site na ịhapụ ịbịanye aka na nkwekọrịta maka iwu ụzọ tren Legos / Ibadan na otu o si manye ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ịkpọrọ ụfọdụ ndị Naịjirịa gaa mba China maka ọzụzụ gbasara iwu okporo ụzọ .

english: The Director of Rail Services of the Federal Ministry of Transportation, Mohammed Babakobi, didn't help matter, as he too, was more concerned about why the university must be in the President's town.
igbo: Onye isi n'ahụ maka okporo tren na Naịjirịa bụ Mohammed Babakobi, enyereghị aka n'okwu a, ihe kachasị dị ya mkpa bụ ihe kpatara eji hibe mahadum a n'obodo onye isi ala.

english: Amaechi's action, reminds me of the popular Yoruba adage that says forcing a man to get married is not a big deal, but making him to make provision for the family is the real work .
igbo: Ihe Amaechi mere, na-echetara m usoro ilu ndị ofe mmanụ a ma ama na-ekwu na ịmanye nwoke ịlụ nwaanyị abụghị mkpa, mana ime ka ọ zụọ ezinaụlọ ya nri bụ ọrụ .

english: Beyond constructing a university structure, there are numerous questions that Amaechi must answer to convince Nigerians that he understands what he is doing .
igbo: N'agbanyeghị iwu mahadum a, enwere ọtụtụ ajụjụ Amaechi ga-azariri iji mee ka ndị Naịjirịa kwenye na ọ ghọtara ihe ọ na-eme .

english: For example, he needs to come clear on who owns the university and the institution that is funding it .
igbo: Dịka ọmụmaatụ, ọ kwesiri ịpụta kwuo onye nwe mahadum ahụ na ụlọ ọrụ na-akwado ya .

english: Is it to be fully funded by the Chinese government or partly funded by the Federal Government ?
igbo: Ọ bụ ndị gọọmentị China ga-enweta ego nkwado ya ka ọ bụ gọọmentị etiti na-akwado ?

english: The only reason why anybody should be excited about a transportation university in Nigeria at a time like this as far as I am concerned is if the CCECC is fully running it as a gift to Nigeria .
igbo: Naanị otu ihe mere mmadụ ọ bụla kwesịrị iji nwee obi ụtọ banyere mahadum njem na Naịjirịa n'oge dị ka nke a bụ na ọ bụrụ na ọ bụ CCECC na-arụ ya nke ọma dịka onyinye nye Naịjirịa .

english: But, if all that CCECC is doing is to construct a university as part of its corporate social responsibility, then Amaechi's display of a sense of achievement is totally misplaced .
igbo: Mana, ọ bụrụ na ihe niile CCECC na-eme bụ ibulite mahadum dị ka akụkụ nke ọrụ mmekọrịta ya na ụlọ ọrụ, mgbe ahụ, ngosipụta Amaechi gosipụtara na ọ ga-eme ka a mata nke ọma ma inwe mahadum njem ọ bụ ihe kachasị mkpa na Naịjirịa .

english: If government wants to develop transportation, what stops it from expanding transport departments in existing universities ?
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị chọrọ imepụta ngalaba njem, gịnị na-egbochi ya ịgbasa ngalaba njem na mahadum ndị dị ugbu a ?

english: The Institute of Transportation in Zaria is there as well as many others .
igbo: Ụlọ akwụkwọ nke ụgbọ njem dị na Zaria na ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ .

english: The Federal Government could have simply increased the capacity of existing institutions to provide better manpower and training in the sector.
igbo: Gọọmentị etiti gaara enyekwu ikike nye ụlọ ọrụ ndị dị ugbu a iji nye ndị mmadụ ọzụzụ kachasị mma na mpaghara ahụ .

english: For me, it doesn't make any difference where the university is sited.
igbo: Maka m, ọ nweghị ọdịiche ọ bụla ebe edoziri mahadum ahụ .

english: I believe the current administration has proved beyond any reasonable doubt that it does not have any iota of regard for federal character.
igbo: Ekwenyere m na nchịkwa gọọmentị ugbu a gosipụtara n'enweghị obi abụọ ọ bụla enweghị ezi uche ọbụla maka nchịkọta gọọmentị .

english: President Buhari showed the direction his administration would follow with his very first set of appointments and he has continued on that path ever since.
igbo: Onye isi ala bụ Buhari gosipụtara ụzọ ọchịchị ya ga - agbaso na nhọpụta ndị ọrụ ya, ọ na - aga n'ihu n'ụzọ ahụ kemgbe .

english: So, there is no point dissipating energy on something that is not likely to change.
igbo: Yabụ, enweghị isi na-agbasapụrụ ike na ihe n'agaghị enwe ike mgbanwe.

english: The reason given by President Buhari for establishing the Transportation University is even more interesting.
igbo: Ebumnuche nke Onye isi ala Buhari nyere maka iguzobe Mahadum ugbọ njem na-adọrọ mmasị karị .

english: According to him, the university will bring rapid development to the nation's transport sector and generate both academic and non-academic employment opportunities to Nigerians.
igbo: Dị ka ya si kwuo, mahadum ahụ ga-eweta mmepe ngwa ngwa na ngalaba njem ụgbọ ala nke mba ma mepụta ohere ọrụ na agụmakwụkwọ nyere ndị Naịjirịa .

english: How can a Federal Government struggling to fund its 43 universities be on an adventure of establishing more ?
igbo: Kedụ ka gọọmentị si na-adọga ịkwado mahadum iri anọ na atọ ya ga-enwe obi ụtọ maka ịmalite ọzọ ?#

english: A lot of people, including our leaders, know that Nigeria's federal universities are nothing to write home about.
igbo: Ọtụtụ ndị mmadụ, gụnyere ndị isi anyị, maara na mahadum gọọmentị etiti Naịjirịa abụghị ihe edere banyere ya .

english: This is one of the reasons why you are not likely to find children of the President, governors and other political leaders in these universities.
igbo: Nke a bụ otu n'ime ihe kpatara na ọ rara ahu ka ịhụ ụmụ nke Onye isi ala, ndị gọvanọ na ndị isi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ndị ọzọ na mahadum ndị a .

english: Many of the university administrators are struggling to cope.
igbo: Ọtụtụ n'ime ndị na-elekọta mahadum na-agbasi mbọ ike ịnagide .

english: Recently, the Vice Chancellor of the University of Ibadan, Prof. Idowu Olayinka, revealed that what the university was getting as overhead was less than N100m, whereas it needs a minimum of N800m for overhead.
igbo: N'oge na-adịbeghị anya, osote onye isi mahadum nke Ibadan, ọkammụta Idowu Olayinka kpughere na ihe mahadum ahụ na-enweta bụ nde narị naịra, ebe ọ chọrọ opekata mpe nde narị naịra asatọ .

english: The VC wondered where universities were expected to get money from when reacting to lawmakers' call for cancellation of admission fees in Nigeria's tertiary institutions .
igbo: VC na-eche ebe elere anya na mahadum ga-enweta ego site na mgbe ha na-aza oku ndị omebe iwu maka ịkagbu ụgwọ nnabata na ụlọ akwụkwọ mahadum nke Naịjirịa .

english: The VC said what the university gets from the Federal Government in one year is not enough to fund it in a month .
igbo: VC kwuru na ihe mahadum ahụ na-enweta n'aka gọọmentị etiti ala n'otu afọ ezughi iji kwado ya na otu ọnwa.

english: How soon can this Transportation University catch up with the rest of the world on rail technology ?
igbo: Ogologo oge ole ka Mahadum ụgbọ njem a ga - ejide ụwa ndị ọzọ na ogo teknọlọji ụgbọ oloko ?

english: When several countries are operating driverless trains and efficient underground rail system, Nigeria is still struggling to construct surface rail systems .
igbo: Mgbe ọtụtụ mba na-arụ ọrụ n'ụgbọ okporo ígwè na-enweghị ọkwọ ụgbọ ala ma na-arụ ọrụ nke ọma n'ime ala, Nigeria na-agbasi mbọ ike iji rụọ usoro okporo ụzọ .

english: The coaches here still run on the oldest technology and unfortunately for the country, its President thinks the aim of creating a university is to get people to be employed .
igbo: Ndị nkuzi ebe a ka na-agba ọsọ na teknọlọji kacha ochie ma ọ dị mwute na maka mba a, Onye isi ala ya na-eche na ebumnuche nke ịmepụta mahadum bụ iji mee ka ndị mmadụ were ọrụ .

english: The Texas Central train will soon be transporting riders on the 240-mile trip from Dallas-Fort Worth to Houston in less than 90 minutes, making it the fastest train in North America .
igbo: Okporo ígwè Texas ga-ebugharị ndị na-anya ụgbọ elu na njem 240 site na Dallas / Fort Worth na Houston erughị nkeji 90, na-eme ka ọ bụrụ ụgbọ oloko kachasị ọsọ na mpaghara ugwu nke mba America .

english: Going by the way we develop in Nigeria, it could take forever for the university to be relevant to the rail business .
igbo: Site na ụzọ anyị si zụlite na Naịjirịa, o nweghị ike iwere mahadum a ka ọ dị mkpa maka azụmahịa okporo ígwè. Teknọlọji ga-aga n'ihu na-aga n'ihu .

english: Technology will definitely keep evolving and it is almost certain that our leaders won't do what it takes to make the university relevant .
igbo: Ọ dịkwa ihere na ndị isi anyị agaghị eme ihe iji mee ka mahadum ahụ nwee ùgwù.

english: Engaging in high research and experimentation is one of the hallmarks of universities all over the world.
igbo: Itinye aka na nyocha dị elu na nnwale bụ otu n'ime ihe e ji mara mahadum n'ụwa niile .

english: How much budget does Nigeria devote to research in its universities ?
igbo: Ego ole ka Naịjirịa na-etinye na nyocha na mahadum ya?

english: As of today, Africa, as a continent, produces one per cent of research technologies in the world.
igbo: Ruo taa, Afrịka, dịka kọntinenti, na -emepụta otu pasenti nke nyocha n'ime ụwa.

english: Tackling this problem should be of more importance to the giant of Africa than turning universities to a constituency project.
igbo: Ijikwa nsogbu a kwesịrị ịbụ ihe kachasị mkpa nye ndị Africa karịa ịtụgharị mahadum ka ọ bụrụ ọrụ mpaghara.

english: As rightly noted by the African Research Universities Alliance, Africa can't speak about development until it has the capacity to generate its own knowledge.
igbo: Dika ekwupụtara nke oma site na otu jịkọrọ mahadum nke Afrika, Afrika apụghị ikwu okwu banyere mmepe rue mgbe o nwere ikike imeputa ihe omuma ya .

english: The rest of the world is concerned about how African universities are preparing students for the 4th Industrial Revolution (4IR) calling for more doctoral training.
igbo: Ndị ụwa ọzọ n'enwe mgbasa banyere otu ndị mahadum n'Afrika siri na-akwado ụmụ akwụkwọ maka agha mmekorita nke ano (4IR) na- achọ ka ha nwekwuo ọzụzụ ịbụ ọkammụta .

english: The challenge is lack of innovation and technologies that can solve the continent's problems.
igbo: Ihe ịma aka a bụ enweghị azịza na teknọlọji nwere ike idozi nsogbu kọntinent ahụ .

english: For those who will argue that this is the essence of establishing Transportation University, I challenge them to tell Nigerians where they hope to get the academic staff that will run the university from.
igbo: Maka ndị ga-ekwu na nke a bụ nhiwe maka ịmalite Mahadum ụgbọ njem, m na-ama ha aka ka m gwa ndị Naịjirịa ebe ha nwere olileanya inweta ndị ọrụ agụmakwụkwọ ga-esi na mahadum ahụ pụọ .

english: Are they going to be sourced from this current university system that is suffering from dearth of academic staff ?
igbo: Ha ga-enweta usoro mahadum a dị ugbu a na-arịa ụkọ nke ndị ọrụ agụmakwụkwọ ?

english: There are reports of universities renting staff to get their courses accredited by the National Universities Commission .
igbo: Enwere akụkọ nke mahadum na-akwụ ụgwọ ndị ọrụ mahadum iji nweta Mahadum nke Mahadum Mba.

english: The NUC cannot claim to be ignorant of this phenomenon.
igbo: Ndị NUC enweghị ike ikwu na ha amaghị maka ihe a.

english: A lot of lecturers in public universities work in private universities and vice versa .
igbo: Ọtụtụ ndị nkuzi na mahadum ọha na-arụ ọrụ na mahadum nkeonwe na nke ọzọ.

english: The NUC, for instance, has a template for the minimum number of PhDs that universities should have in each department, how many Nigerian universities meet this requirement ?
igbo: Dịka ọmụmaatụ, NUC nwere ndebiri maka ntakịrị ọnụọgụgụ PhD nke mahadum kwesịrị inwe na ngalaba ọ bụla, kedu mahadum Naịjirịa ruru ihe achọrọ.

english: How many universities in Nigeria are producing PhDs on annual basis ?
igbo: ụlọ akwụkwọ ole na Naịjirịa na emeputa ndị PhD kwa ubochi?

english: I know UI produces the highest number of PhDs annually but I doubt if it could produce up to 500 per annum.
igbo: Amaara m na UI na-emepụta ọnụ ọgụgụ kachasị elu nke PhD kwa afọ mana enwere m obi abụọ ma ọ nwere ike iwepụta ihe ruru 500 kwa afọ.

english: The last figure I knew was around 250 per annum.
igbo: Onu ogugu ikpeazụ m maara gbara 250 kwa afọ.

english: Honestly, Nigeria should concentrate on building its research capacity and developing innovative curricula that will help its students develop the crucial skills of creativity and critical thinking.
igbo: N'ezie, Naịjirịa kwesiri itinye uche na iwulite ikike nyocha ya na iwulite usoro mmụta ga - enyere ụmụ akwụkwọ ya aka ịzụlite ikike dị mkpa nke okike na echiche siri ike.

english: These are some of the things that can make Nigeria relevant in the development space.
igbo: Ihe ndị a bụ ụfọdụ n'ime ihe nwere ike ime ka Naịjirịa nwee ohere na mmepe.

english: China is one of the few countries in the world controlling over 80% of research innovations.
igbo: China bụ otu n'ime mba ole na ole n'ụwa na-achịkwa ihe karịrị pesent 80 nke nyocha.

english: The Federal Government should commit more resources into funding research activities and capacity building.
igbo: Gọọmentị ala kwesịrị itinyekwu akụ na ụba n'ime mmemme nyocha ego na ike ikike.

english: Universities are not secondary schools.
igbo: Mahadum abụghị ụlọ akwụkwọ sekọndrị.

english: We don't need this proliferation!
igbo: Anyị achọghị mmụba a!

english: Olabisi Deji-Folutile is a member of the Nigerian Guild of Editors.
igbo: Olabisi Deji-Folutile bụ onye otu ndị odeakwụkwọ nke Naịjirịa .

english: My most recent published article, 'Recalling Tai Solarin's prediction', which appeared in the first week of this month, ended with a series of questions .
igbo: Edemede m bipụtara n'oge na-adịbeghị anya, 'Icheta amụma Tai Solarin', nke pụtara n'izu mbụ nke ọnwa a, ji ọtụtụ ajụjụ jedebe.

english: I reproduce four of them that are most relevant to this sequel: 'Why is it that despite the Nigerian Left's insistence, at least since 1979, on the inevitability and irreducibility of a Revolutionary Party, the party has not emerged?
igbo: M mepụtara anọ n'ime ha nke dabara adaba na usoro a: 'Gịnị kpatara na n'agbanyeghị ntuli aka nke ndị Naịjirịa, ka ọ dịkarịa ala site na afọ 1979, maka mbuso agha na enweghị ike ọfụma nke otu mgbanwe, otu ahụ apụtabeghị ?

english: Why should we find ourselves repeating the same theses and propositions after every bloody and farcical display called 'election'?
igbo: Kedu ihe kpatara anyị ga - eji hụ na anyị na - emegharị otu echiche na atụmatụ a mgbe ngosipụta ọbara niile ana - akpọ 'ntuli aka' ?

english: How has Nigeria's ruling class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule ?
igbo: Kedụ ka ndị ọchịchị Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịhazị onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, were usoro nhazi ọhụrụ wee gaa n'ihu na-achị ya ?

english: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force ?
igbo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka klaasị, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dị ka ike ọchịchị kacha ike ?

english: The day after the article appeared, a comrade, Wumi Raji, who is a Leftist academic at the Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, called me on phone .
igbo: Otu ụbọchị ka edemede ahụ pụtachara, otu komred bụ Wumi Raji, onye bụ onye agụmakwụkwọ akaịpa na Mahadum Obafemi Awolowo, Ile-Ife kpọrọ m na ekwentị.

english: After the usual pleasantries, he respectfully 'complained' that my article ended abruptly, that he had expected me to answer or begin to answer the questions I posed .
igbo: Mgbe ọ masịrị ya, ọ jiri nkwanye ugwu 'kọchaa' na edemede m gwụrụ na-akụghị ekwe, na ọ tụrụ anya na m ga-aza ma ọ bụ malite ịza ajụjụ ndị m jụrụ.

english: As I was about to suggest a time for us to discuss the answers on phone, he expressed preference for a written response – perhaps a sequel to the previous article .
igbo: Ka m na-achọ ịtụwa oge ka anyị kpaa mkparịta ụka n'ekwentị, o kwupụtara mmasị maka nzaghachi edereede m - ikekwe ide asịsam ede.

english: Finally, he 'requested' that the sequel should not take too long in coming .
igbo: N'ikpeazụ, ọ 'rịọrọ' ka usoro ahụ ghara iwe ogologo oge.

english: When he asked what I thought of his 'request' I told him bluntly that I did not understand what he asked me to do as a request, that I understood it as a comradely order which, coming, in particular, from his generation, I could not turn down.
igbo: Mgbe ọ jụrụ m ihe m chere banyere 'arịrịọ' a, agwara m ya n'ezoghị ọnụ na aghọtaghị m ihe ọ gwara m ka m mee dị ka arịrịọ, na m ghọtara ya dị ka iwu nke, na-abịa, ọkachasị, n'ọgbọ ya, m enweghị ike ịgbatu.

english: Wumi Raji did not give me any space in our brief telephone conversation to say something that I would have liked to say, namely, that my questions were drafted as open questions to the Nigerian Left.
igbo: Wumi Raji enyeghị m ohere ọ bụla na mkparịta ụka ekwentị dị mkpirikpi iji kwuo ihe m ga-enwe mmasị ikwu, ya bụ, na edepụtara ajụjụ m dị ka ajụjụ azịza nye n'aka ekpe ndị Nigeria.

english: They were not drafted as an introduction to a 'lecture' which, perhaps, I was preparing to deliver; nor were they rhetorical questions (which demand no answers) nor exam-type questions (which demand answers from entities that exclude the examiner).
igbo: E deghị ha ka okwu mmeghe nke 'nkuzi', ikekwe, m na-akwado ikwu; ha abụghịkwa ajụjụ ajụrụ (na achoghi azịza ha) ma ọ bụ ajụjụ (nke chọrọ azịza site n'aka ndi mmadụ ewezuga onye nlere).

english: In any case, what, practically, should I or could I do now, I asked myself at the end of my discussion with Raji.
igbo: N'ọnọdụ ọ bụla, kedu, ihe m ga - eme ma ọ bụ mee m ugbu a, ajụrụ m onwe m na njedebe nke mkparịta ụka mụ na Raji.

english: The answer, which came a day later, was that I could expand the questions and supply explanatory notes to some of them.
igbo: Azịza ya, nke bịara otu ụbọchị mgbe nke ahụ gasịrị, bụ na m nwere ike ịgbatị ajụjụ na ọkọnọ nkọwa ụfọdụ nye ha.

english: If I perform these minimum tasks well, I would have begun to contribute to discussions leading to answers.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ n'ọrụ ndị a pere mpe ọfụma, aga m amalite itinye aka na mkparịta ụka na-eduga azịza.

english: If the four questions I have reproduced here are combined, they translate to a loud and angry regret that since the end of Nigeria's Civil War in 1970 and particularly since the 1979 general elections with which the Second Republic (1979-1983) was inaugurated, a sufficiently strong Leftist Revolutionary Party has not emerged in the country to frontally and seriously challenge the ruling capitalist class.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na ejikọta ajụjụ anọ ndị m depụtara ebe a, ha tụgharịrị gaa n'oké iwe na ebe ọ bụ na kemgbe njedebe nke agha Naịjirịa na 1970 na karịsịa kemgbe e guzobere ntuli aka 1979 nke bụ repọblik nke abụọ (1979-1983), ndị otu mgbanwe akaịpa nke nwere ike zuru oke apụtabeghị na mba ahụ n'ihu na ịma ndị isi ọchịchị aka ike ọchịchị.

english: This serious and frontal challenge would have been either for power or for the dominant political position in the country or, minimally, for a significant shift in the balance of socio-political forces in favour of the working and toiling masses of Nigeria.
igbo: Ihe ịma aka a dị mkpa ga-abụ maka ike ma ọ bụ n'ọkwá ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị kachasị na mba ahụ ma ọ bụ obere, maka mgbanwe dị ukwuu na nguzosi ike nke ndị ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na-akwado ọrụ na ike Naịjirịa.

english: This regret about what could have happened—but did not, or had not happened—now translates back to a single question, Why?
igbo: Ta ụta a banyere ihe gaara eme — ma ọ meghị, ma ọ bụ emeghị — ugbu a sụgharịrị n'otu ajụjụ, N'ihi gịnị?

english: In my view, a view shared by many Leftists, the major reasons for the non-emergence of a Revolutionary Party, sufficiently strong to frontally and seriously challenge Nigeria's ruling capitalist class may be broadly separated into two segments: the objective and the subjective.
igbo: N'echiche m, echiche nke ọtụtụ ndị akaịpa, bụ isi ihe kpatara na enweghị mmalite nke otu mgbanwe, nke nwere ike zuru oke iji chee ihu na ịma ndị isi ọchịchị Naịjirịa aka nwere ike ikewapụ onwe ha ụzọ abụọ: ebumnuche na isiokwu ahụ.

english: We may defer the objective reasons.
igbo: Anyị nwere ike wepụ ebumnuche.

english: But of the subjective reasons, the most prominent is what I had described as 'differences within the Nigerian Left' (The Guardian, October 4, 2018).
igbo: Mana nke ndị metụtara ya, nke akachasị mara bụ nke m kọwara dị ka ndịrịta iche dị n'etiti ndị hapụrụ ala Naịjirịa . (Guardian, Ọktọba 4, 2018).

english: This important factor will be our focus in the rest of this piece.
igbo: Ihe a dị mkpa ga-abụ ihe anyị ga-elebara anya na ibe ya.

english: It is on account of the differences within the Left that I have insisted, in the last two years, on the production and dissemination of a People's Manifesto.
igbo: Ọ bụ n'ihi ọdịiche dị na ekpe a ka m siri ọnwụ na, n'ime afọ abụọ gara aga, na nrụpụta na mgbasa nke Manifesto nke Ndị mmadụ.

english: My reasoning is that in the process of producing and disseminating the People's Manifesto (The Left platform) the differences that many Leftists presume do not exist, or are not serious, will emerge and be engaged.
igbo: Echiche m bụ na n'ịmepụta ma na-agbasa echiche nke Manifesto (nke nyiwe akaịpa) ọdịiche ọtụtụ ndị akaịpa chere na-adị, ma ọ bụ na-adịghị njọ, ga-apụta ma tinye aka .

english: It is, of course, expected that the Manifesto—which in the process of production and dissemination will begin to resolve our internal differences—will first appear as a robust draft document that attempts to take precise positions on some critical questions before the masses and the nation.
igbo: N'ezie, a tụrụ anya na Manifesto — nke ga - emeputa ma kesaa ga - ebido idozi esemokwu dị n'ime anyị - ga - ebu ụzọ gosipụta akwụkwọ siri ike nke na - anwa iweghara ọnọdụ ụfọdụ dị mkpa n'ihu nnukwu mba .

english: The draft may begin with a Preamble or Introduction: Who we are, what we propose to do, the agency of the revolutionary transformation and the social forces of the transformation.
igbo: Mpempe akwụkwọ ahụ nwere ike ịmalite ma ọ bụ Okwu Mmalite: wenye anyị bụ, ihe anyị na-atụ alo ime, ụlọ ọrụ nke mgbanwe na ndị otu ndị na - eme mgbanwe .

english: It may then go on to Popular-Democratic Ideas (constitutional and republican democracy, the rule of law, the state and the people, socioeconomic rights, political rights and civil rights).
igbo: Ọ nwere ike ịga n'ihu na echiche ndị ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya (usoro iwu ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na usoro iwu, steeti na ndị mmadụ, ikike mmekọrịta ọha na eze, ikike ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na ikike obodo).

english: It may then proceed to Strategy of the Revolutionary Transformation; Democratic Governance; Philosophy of Governance and Principles of State Policy; SocioEconomic Restructuring; The National Question, National Unity and Geo-political Restructuring; National Independence and Foreign Policy.
igbo: Ọ nwere ike ịga n'ihu na Usoro nke Mgbanwe; Ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya; Nkà ihe ọmụma banyere ọchịchị na ụkpụrụ nke iwu Ọchịchị; Idozi akụ na ụba ndị mmadụ; Ajụjụ Mba ahụ, ịdị n'otu mba na idozigharị ihe ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị; Nnwereonwe nke mba na iwu Ofesi.

english: The document should, of course, end with a Transitional Programme (immediate agenda).
igbo: Akwụkwọ ahụ kwesịrị, n'ezie, ijedebe na Usoro Mgbanwe (usoro a na-eme ozugbo).

english: My current position on each of these proposed elements of a Peoples Manifesto has been explicit in my published articles of the past two years.
igbo: Ekwupụtalam ọnọdụ m na nke ọ bụla ugbu a n'ime akwụkwọ m bipụtara n'afọ abụọ gara aga.

english: But a particular sensitive subject—the National Question—requires further explanatory notes here.
igbo: Ma otu isiokwu dị ire - ajụjụ nke mba - chọrọ nkọwa ndị ọzọ.

english: Nigerian Leftists, especially Marxists, know or should know that neither theory nor history has resolved what Marxism knows as the National Question—from the standpoint of Marxism.
igbo: Ndị akaịpa nke Naịjirịa, ọkachasị ndị otu Marx ma ọ bụ na edemede ma akụkọ ntolite emebeghị mkpebi nke Marxism, dị ka ajụjụ nke mba - site n'echiche nke Marxism.

english: Had it been resolved—even if badly—we could have been more confident to take positions on the tragic things that happened within the leaderships of the ruling communist parties of the former Soviet Union, former Yugoslavia and former Czechoslovakia and to the countries and peoples over whom they ruled for decades.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na e kpebiri ya, ọbụlagodi ma ọ dị njọ - anyị nwere ike inwe ntụkwasị obi karịa ịnwe ọnọdụ n'ihe ọjọọ ndị mere n'etiti ndị isi nke ndị otu ọchịchị Kọmunist n'oge mbụ otu Soviet, Yugoslavia na mbụ. Czechoslovakia na mba ndị dị n'ofe ndi ha chiri arọ iri.

english: If there were a near-settled Marxist position on the National Question the enduring ethnic question in China (since the 1949 Revolution) would not have remained an embarrassing issue for Marxists and socialists everywhere.
igbo: Oburu na ndopụta ndị Marxist dị nso n'ajụjụ nke mba China n'abia (kemgbe Mgbanwe nke 1949 ) agaraghị adị ihe idochu ndị Marxist na ndị ọkacha amara n'ebe niile.

english: If the history of Marxism had handed us a resolution of the National Question, we would have been bolder in taking positions on what happened between Ethiopian and Eritrean Marxists and Leftists in the last quarter of last century.
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na akụkọ banyere Marxism wetara anyị mkpebi nke Ajụjụ mba, anyị gaara enwe obi ike were ọnọdụ maka ihe mere n'etiti ndị Etiopia na ndị Eritrea na ndị akaịkpa na nkeji iri na ise gara aga.

english: And coming home, if we had a near-settled theory or if Marxism had substantially advanced the debate on the National Question since the Russian Revolution and the Third International, Nigerian Marxists would today be bolder to take positions on what happened to the Nigerian Marxist Left during the Nigerian Civil War and on the status of current pro-Biafra Nigerian Marxists.
igbo: Ma na abia n'ulo, oburu na anyị nwere echiche dị nso ma ọ bụ nweko nke Marxism mere nke oma na nkparịta ụka nke ala, ajụjụ nke ndị Russia kemgbe ndị Ju nke Russia na ndị nke atọ, ndị ala Marxist ga enwe obi ike iguzosi ike n'ihe mere ndị ọchịchị nke ndị Marxist n'oge agha obodo Naịjirịa na ọkwa ndị ugbu a. Ndị ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị ndị Naịjirịa tupu Biafra abịa.

english: I do not know how many living Nigerian Marxists followed and still remember the public 'national question' debate between two leading Nigerian Leftist intellectuals: Comrade GG Darah and the late Comrade Yusufu Bala Usman about a decade ago.
igbo: Amaghị m mmadụ ole ndị ndọrọndọrọ ala Naịjirịa sochiri ma na-echeta arụmụka a na-ajụ ajụjụ gbasara 'ajụjụ mba' n'etiti ndị isi ọgụgụ isi nke ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa: Comrade GG Darah na onye nke nwuru anwụ Comrade Yusufu Bala Usman ihe dị ka afọ iri gara aga.

english: Let me end the present piece with the following poser: Before, during and after the Russian Revolution, a Marxist tendency closely connected with Lenin introduced 'national oppression' as a 'Marxist category, related to class oppression but not identical with or subordinate to it'
igbo: Ka m kwubie okwu a ugbua site n'ihe ndịa: Tupu, n'oge na mgbe mbugharị Russia gasịrị, echiche Marxist nwere njịkọ chiri anya na Lenin gosipụtara 'mmegbu nke mba' dị ka otu 'ụdị Marxist, metụtara mmegbu otu mana ọ bụghị otu ihe ma ọ bụ nọ n'okpuru ya. ',

english: Whereas in that period, Rosa Luxembourg, who requires no introduction, stood (and still stands) 'at the apex of the attempt to make operational the Marxist concept of class as the primary social referent, and to break once and for all the old alternative stranglehold of nation'.
igbo: Ebe oge ahụ, Rosa Luxembourg, onye na-achọghị iwebata, guzo (ma kwụrụ ọtọ)' na njịkọ nke nnwale iji mee ka echiche nke Marxist nke otu bụrụ ntụle maka mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya, yana imebi ozugbo oge niile. uzọ ochie ọzọ nke mba '.

english: From this poser I propose that Nigerian Leftists, especially those of Marxist orientation, should advance the debate on the National Question and Geopolitical Restructuring in Nigeria with the twin-objective of arriving at a common position in Nigeria and simultaneously contributing to the further development of Marxism on this question.
igbo: Site n'okwu a, m na-ekwupụta na ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa, ọkachasị nke mgbakwasị ụkwụ Marxist, kwesịrị ịkwalite arụmụka ahụ na Ajụjụ mba na idozi gburugburu ọchịchị Naịjirịa nwere ebumnuche ibilite n'otu ọnọdụ na Naịjirịa ma n'otu oge na-enye aka maka mmepe nke Marxism n'ajụjụ a.
