english: This effort will also, simultaneously, advance the process of founding a nationwide Revolutionary Party that is substantial, authoritative and respected.
igbo: Mgbalị a ga-emekwa n'otu oge ahụ ga - eme ka usoro ịchọpụta otu Ntugharị Mba nke dị ukwuu, nke nwere ikike na nkwanye ùgwù.

english: Torrential rain has destroyed makeshift tents and caused severeflooding to temporary displacement camps in northeast Nigeria, leaving vulnerable families homeless.
igbo: Oke mmiri ozuzo ebibiela ụlọ ntu nke mere obere oge ma mekwaa ka idei mmiri jupụta n'ogige ịhapụ ụlọ nwa oge na ugwu ọwụwa anyanwụ Naịjirịa, ma mee ka ezinụlọ dị iche iche hara ịnwe ebe obibi.

english: In Dikwa, 500 people have been rendered homeless due to flooding and have set up home in disused registration centres .
igbo: Na Dịkwa, mmadụ 500 aburula ndị enweghị ebe obibi n'ihi ịde mmiri ma hiwe ụlọ n'ụlọ ebe ndị a na-edebe akwụkwọ maka ndị a na-akwabeghị.

english: Large numbers of families, who fled from conflict months ago, are left homeless while others are forced to share overcrowded tents with neighbours or relatives
igbo: Ọnụ ọgụgụ dị ukwuu nke ezinụlọ, bụ ndị gbabara n'ọgba aghara ọnwa gara aga, bụ ndị na-enweghị ebe obibi ebe ndị ọzọ na-amanye ka ha soro ndị agbata obi ma ọ bụ ndị ikwu ụlọikwuu karịrị akarị

english: My home is completely destroyed.
igbo: Ụlọ m bibiri kpamkpam.

english: My floor has turned to mud and water is everywhere.
igbo: Ala m aghọọla apịtị na olulu mmiri n'ebe niile.

english: The rain keeps coming and we do not have any choice butto wait for it to stop or share with others,' said displaced mother-of-four Fatima Mohammed (30)
igbo: Amaghị ebe mmiri ahụ si na-abịa, anyị enweghị nhọrọ ọzọ karịa ichere ka ọ kwụsị ma ọ bụ ịnọọrọ ndị ọzọ - Fatima Mohammed (30) nne ụmụ anọ kwuru.

english: The Adamawa State government, the organization said, had officially declared an outbreak of cholera in three local government areas duringthe rainy season.
igbo: Gọọmentị steeti Adamawa ekwupụtala ọkwa na oria ọgbụgba. n'ime mpaghara ọchịchị obodo atọ n'oge mmiri.

english: The total number of cases reported as of August 16 stands at 633.
igbo: ọnụọgụgụ nke mkpesa emere na ọnwa ọgọst 16 bụ 633.

english: Four people have so far lost their lives to the disease.
igbo: Mmadụ anọ ka agụtagoru bụ ndi tufugoro ndụ ha n'aka nrịanrịa .

english: Due to recent heavy rain and flooding, more cases could be confirmed over the coming weeks, the NRC pointed out .
igbo: Site na mmiri ozuzo na ide mmiri oge na-adịbeghị anya, enwere ike ikwenye ọnọdụ ndị ọzọ na izu ndị na-abịa, NRC mere ka ọ pụta ìhè.

english: There are no sanitation or drainage facilities in most camps.
igbo: Enweghị adịmọcha ọbụla ma ọ bụ ọwa mmiri n'ọtụtụ ogige.

english: People are going to the toilet in open spaces because there are nofacilities for them to use and now that the camps are filled withstagnant floodwater, water-borne diseases like cholera quicklyspread,' Batonon added.
igbo: Ndị mmadụ na-aga ụlọ mposi n'ime oghere maka enweghị ebe ha nwere ike iji rụọ ọrụ ma ugbu a ụlọ ọrụ jupụtara na ide mmiri, ọrịa ndị eji mmiri ebute dị ka ọgbụgbọ na-agbasa ngwa ngwa, 'Batonon kwukwara.

english: Meanwhile, the United Nations and partners have appealed for $848million to address the needs in northeast Nigeria this year.
igbo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, otu jịkọrọ mba na ndị mmekọ rịọrọ arịrịọ maka nde dọla 848 iji lebara mkpa ndị dị na ugwu ọwụwa anyanwụ Naịjirịa afọ a.

english: About eight months into the year, less than 40 per cent has been received.
igbo: Ihe dika ọnwa asatọ dị n'ime afọ ahụ aga, eritebeghị pasent 40 n'ime ya.

english: Additional financial support is urgently needed to reach the 6.2million people targeted for humanitarian aid in 2019.
igbo: A na-achọ nkwado ngwa ngwa iji gwoo nde mmadụ 6.2 ezubere maka enyemaka mmadụ na 2019.

english: People will die if they don´t receive urgent assistance now,' Batonon said.
igbo: Ndị mmadụ ga-anwụ ma ọ bụrụ na ha enwetaghị enyemaka ugbu a,' Batonon kwuru.

english: Furthermore, heavy rain periods present opportunities by armed groupsto infiltrate and target displacement camps.
igbo: Ma, oke mmiri ozuzo na - enye ohere site n'aka ndị otu ndi agha gbabigoro ma buso ogige ndị mmadu agha.

english: On Tuesday night (August 20) in Dikwa, a female suicide bomberdetonated a bomb, killing herself and injuring four civilians.
igbo: N'abalị Tuzdee (ọgọst 20) na Dika, nwanyị gbara ogbunigwe tụbara bọmbụ, gbuo onwe ya ma merụọ ndị nkịtị anọ ahụ.

english: This was the first attack of its kind in the area since December 2018.
igbo: Nke a bụ nke mbu n'mpaghara ebe a na Disemba afọ 2018.

english: RE: DSS And The 6th December Federal High Court, Abuja Incident By Lucky Ighoyota
igbo: RE: DSS na Ụlọ Ọkaịkpe nke Ụbọchị Isii N'Ọnwa Disemba, ihe mere n'Abuja site n'aka Lucky Ighoyota

english: The invasion of the Federal High Court on Friday by DSS operatives to perfect a rearrest of Omoyele Sowore and his co-defendant, Olawale Bakare, less than 24 hours after they were granted bail is the highest act of sacrilege against the judicial arm of government that the operative has constantly expressed contempt for .
igbo: Mwakpo nke ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọkaịkpe wakporo na Fraịdee ka onye ọrụ ya bụ Omoyele Sowore na onye na - agbachitere ya, Olawale Bakare erughị awa iri abụọ na anọ ka enyere ha ohere mgbapụta bụ ihe kacha njọ na-akwado megide ikike ikpe nke gọọmentị nke onye ọrụ ahụ egosipụtala nlelị maka ya.

english: On Saturday, December 7, 24 hours after the debacle at the Federal High Court, Abuja, the Department of State Services prevaricated about the real fact just to offset its damaged reputation.
igbo: Na Satọde, Disemba 7, ka awa iri abụọ garachara, ụlọ ikpe ukwu ahụ, n'Abuja, Ngalaba Na-ahụ Maka Ọrụ kwuru banyere eziokwu n'ezie iji kwụsị aha ya mebiri emebi.

english: It is no surprise to us or the general public, who are now used to the DSS' novelties of historical records of numerous lies m intended to create a false or misleading impression.
igbo: Ọ bụghị ihe ịtụnanya nye anyị ma ọ bụ ọha na eze, bụ ndị maara akụkọ ndị DSS nke nwere ọtụtụ akụkọ ụgha iji mepụta echiche ụgha ma ọ bụ nke na-eduhie eduhie.

english: The invasion of the Federal High Court on Friday by DSS operatives to perfect a rearrest of Omoyele Sowore and his co-defendant, Olawale Bakare, less than 24 hours after they were granted bail is the highest act of sacrilege against the judicial arm of government that the operative has constantly expressed contempt for.
igbo: Mwakpo nke ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọkaịkpe wakporo na Fraịdee ka onye ọrụ ya bụ Omoyele Sowore na onye na - agbachitere ya, Olawale Bakare erughị awa iri abụọ na anọ ka enyere ha ohere mgbapụta bụ ihe kacha mma na-akwado megide ikike ikpe nke gọọmentị. onye ọrụ ahụ egosipụtala nlelị maka ya.

english: After willfully violating two different court orders that granted bail to Omoyele Sowore, and until Justice Ijeoma Ojukwu's 24-hour ultimatum to the operative, it became an obvious fact that the compliance with the court order was with the ulterior motive of releasing and rearresting Sowore, just to be seen to have obeyed the pending court.
igbo: Mgbe akpachara anya mebie iwu ụlọ ikpe abụọ nyere ikike ịgbazigharị Omoyele Sowore, rue mgbe onye ọka ikpe Ijeoma Ojukwu nyere ọrụ ahụ, ọ bịara bụrụ ihe doro anya na nrube isi n'iwu ụlọịkpe ahụ bụ ebumnobi nke ịgbahapụ na iweghachite Sowore, naanị ka a hụ ka o rubere isi n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ.

english: During the court proceeding of the day under reference, defence counsel, Femi Falana (SAN), intimated the judge of the intention of the DSS to rearrest Sowore, but it was overlooked.
igbo: N'oge usoro ikpe nke ụbọchị ahụ n'okpuru ntụnye aka, onye ọka ikpe nchekwa, Femi Falana (SAN), gwara onye ọka ikpe na ebumnuche ndị DSS bụ idobe Sowore, mana elefuru anya.

english: However, as soon as Sowore was about stepping out of the courtroom, DSS operatives laid hands on him to rearrest him without a charge; hence, the pandemonium between the violent operatives of the DSS and supporters of Sowore who couldn't comprehend the justification for a rearrest barely 24 hours after his release.
igbo: Agbanyeghị, ozugbo Sowore na-achọ isi n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ pụta, ndị ọrụ DSS tụkwasara ya aka ịwakpo ya n'enweghị ebubo; N'ihi ya, ọgba aghara dị n'etiti ndị na-eme ihe ike nke DSS na ndị na-akwado Sowore bụ ndị na-enweghị ike ịghọta ihe mere eji eme ihe n'erughị awa 24 ka ahapụchara ya.

english: Eyewitness and media accounts have it that the DSS operatives stormed the courtroom violently and disrupted proceeding for which the sitting judge, Justice Ojukwu, had to scamper for safety.
igbo: Onye hụrụ ya anya na akụkọ mgbasa ozi nwere na ndị ọrụ DSS were iwe were ọsọ wee megharia usoro onye ọka ikpe nọ ebe ahụ, bụ Justice Ojukwu, gbara izu maka nchekwa.

english: In the press release of the DSS, it accused Sowore's supporters of shielding him from an 'imaginary arrest.'
igbo: Na akụkọ mgbasa ozi nke DSS, o boro ndị na-akwado Sowore ebubo na ha na-egbochi ya 'njide efu.' Mana n'eziokwu, mwakpo ahụ gosipụtara na ọ bụghị njide echere n'echiche.

english: But in reality, the rearrest already proved that it wasn't an imaginary arrest.
igbo: Ebe ọ bụ na Sowore pụtara n'ụlọ ikpe maka okwu a na DSS, ndị ọrụ agha na-arụ ọrụ n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ na Disemba 6 dị ọtụtụ karịa mgbe ọ bụla. Nke a bụ iji gosipụta na mwakpo ọzọ awakporo Sowore bụ mkpebi nke ọrụ ahụ kwudịrị tupu ọ tọhapụ ya na Disemba 5!

english: Since Sowore's appearances in court over this case with the DSS, armed operatives of the service in the court premises on December 6 were greater in number than ever.
igbo: N'okwu ndị DSS kwuru na ndị ọrụ ya anọghị n'ime ụlọ ikpe ahụ iji wee mepụta mwakpo ahụ, nyocha dị egwu na ihe nkiri ndị mgbasa ozi na ndị hụrụ ya kpughere gosiri na ụfọdụ ndị ọrụ ha na-eyighị uwe DSS nke akpọrọ aha otu na-adọkpụ Sowore na ala n'ime ogige.

english: This is to show that Sowore's rearrest was a decision reached by the service even before his release on December 5!
igbo: Otu onye n'ime ụmụ nwoke na-eje ozi n'ime ụlọ ikpe ahụ nke onye ọrụ ike Sowore nwere bụ Marshall.

english: On the claim by the DSS that its operatives were not inside the courtroom to carry out the rearrest, a critical look at the videos in circulation by the media and eyewitnesses revealed that some men of the operatives not dressed in DSS' branded uniform dragging Sowore on the ground inside the courtroom.
igbo: O yighị uwe ndị DSS mara akara.

english: One of the service men inside the courtroom to forcefully rearrest Sowore was Marshall. He was not dressed in the branded uniform of the DSS. He was in a black jacket as seen in all videos in circulation.
igbo: Ọ nọ na jaket ojii dịka a na-ahụ ya na ihe nkiri niile ana-ekesa.

english: Marshall was always the DSS operative restraining Sowore from speaking with the press during his previous appearances in court.
igbo: Marshall bụ onye ọrụ DSS na-egbochi Sowore ka ọ ghara iso ndị nta akụkọ na-ekwu okwu oge ọ gara n'ụlọ ikpe.

english: Also, it is worthy to note that Sowore while still within the premises of the court told this same Marshall that he was a disgrace.
igbo: Ọzọkwa, ọ dị mma ịmara na Sowore mgbe ọ ka nọ n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ gwara otu Marshall na ọ bụ ihe ihere.

english: With this fact alone, it is abundantly clear that after 24 hours of silence over the court debacle by the DSS, in a bid to salvage their publicly damaged reputation, they still couldn't manufacture a 'smart lie' that serves to make amends.
igbo: N'ezie eziokwu a, o doro anya nke ukwuu na mgbe awa 24 nke ịgbachi nkịtị gbasara akwụkwụ ụlọ ikpe nke ndị DSS, n'ịzọ iwepụ aha ha mebiri emebi n'ihu ọha, ha ka nwere ike ghara imepụta 'amamịghe ụgha' nke na-enyere aka ịgbanwe.

english: It is unthinkable of the DSS to accuse Sowore of addressing a group of persons at Transcorp Hilton Hotel, Abuja, on the same day of his release of a 'reassured cause' to create anarchy in the country.
igbo: Ọ bụ ihe jọgburu onwe ya na ndị DSS boro Sowore ka ọ kpọọ otu mmadụ okwu na ụlọ nkwari Transcorp Hilton, Abuja, n'otu ụbọchị a tọhapụrụ ya 'ihe masiri obi ike' iji mepụta ọgbaghara na mba ahụ.

english: This allegation is spurious, bogus, fake, and inauthentic.The DSS intends to make the public think something that is not true.
igbo: Ebubo a bụ okwu ojoo, okwu ugha, na-abụghị eziokwu. Ndị DSS bu n'obi ime ka ọha na eze chee ihe na-abụghị eziokwu.

english: In other words, the DSS is trying to establish the basis for rearresting Sowore to be that he had violated one of his bail conditions. This is laughable!
igbo: N'ikwu ya n'ụzọ ọzọ, DSS na-anwapụta ihe ndabere maka ijigide Sowore na ọ bụ na ọ dara iwu otu ịgbapụta ya. Nke a bụ ihe ọchị!

english: It is on record that when the DSS earlier insisted on validating the sureties to Sowore's bail, Justice m Ojukwu asked the counsel to the DSS if the agency was running a parallel court.
igbo: Ọ bụ na ndekọ na mgbe ndị DSS kwusiri ike na nkwado nke ịgba akwụkwọ Sowore ebubo, Justice M. Ojukwu jụrụ ndụmọdụ DSS ma ọ bụrụ na ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-arụ ọrụ ụlọ ọrụ ọzọ yiri ya.

english: Most reasonably now, if a bail condition has been violated, it is of the same court that gave the conditions to determine that. The bail conditions were not by the DSS but by the court.
igbo: Ihe kachasị dị ugbu a, ọ bụrụ na emebila mgbapụtaa, ọ bụ otu ụlọikpe ahụ nyere ọnọdụ iji kpebie nke ahụ. Ọnọdụ mgbapụta abụghị nke ndị DSS kama ọ bụ nke ndị ụlọ ikpe.

english: By DSS' inconsistent actions, the agency has assumed both the role of the court, the law, and the judge in this matter. This is a tragedy and a travesty of justice.
igbo: Site na omume DSS, ndị ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ewerela ọrụ ụlọ ikpe, iwu na onye ọka ikpe n'okwu a. Nke a bụ ọdachi na aghụghọ nke ikpe.

english: DSS' historical records of numerous lies, human right violations, court contempt, and the recent desecration of the court all speak of one truth, which is, the operative is unabashedly unruly and does not have the genetic composition to abide by the law.
igbo: Ihe ndekọ akụkọ ihe mere eme nke DSS nke ọtụtụ ụgha, mmebi iwu ndị ruuru mmadụ, nlelị ụlọ ikpe, na mmejọ ụlọ ikpe na nsonso a, na-ekwu maka otu eziokwu, ya bụ, ndị na-arụ ọrụ na-enweghị isi na enweghị usoro mkpụrụ ndụ iji rube isi n'iwu.

english: There is no plan by any one group connected to Omoyele Sowore to organise an insurrection in the country.
igbo: Onweghị atụmatụ otu ọ bụla jikọrọ Omoyele Sowore ịhazi ọgbaghara na mba a.

english: A wise saying has it that the evil that men do live after them.
igbo: Okwu amam-ihe kwuru na ihe ọjọ nke mmadụ so ya biri.

english: DSS' unequivocal reputation for false alarms is a psychological self-defense mechanism to preempt the provocative paranoia their oppressive tendencies are stirring in Nigerians.
igbo: DSS 'aha enweghị nkatọ maka mkpu ụgha bụ usoro nchedo onwe onye iji gbochie ajọ mkpamkpa nke omume mmegbu ha na-akpali na ndị Naịjirịa.

english: The agency is gradually militarising our democracy by its undemocratic actions and terrorising assaults on dissenting
igbo: Ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-eji nwayọọ nwayọọ na-ebuso ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya agha n'ọrụ site na omume ya na-esighi ike na mwakpo na-eyi ọha egwu.

english: We are requesting well meaning Nigerians to lend their voices to condemn the disobedience against the democratic rights and freedom of expression of our staff.
igbo: Anyi na-arịọ ndị Naịjirịa nke oma ka ha tinye olu nke ha megide nnupu isi megidere ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya anyị, ndị ọrụ anyị na nnwere onwe ikwu okwu dịka iwu anyị siri dị.

english: Also, we are demanding the unconditional release of Omoyele Sowore from illegal detention.
igbo: Ọzọkwa, anyị na-achọ ntọhapụ nke mwakpo Omoyele Sowore nke iwu na-akwadoghị njide ya.

english: Reactions Trail Genevieve's Lionheart Movie Oscar Disqualification
igbo: okwu ndị so ihe nkiri obi agụ nke Genevieve ewepụrụ na ntụli OSCAR .

english: 'Lionheart' is among the 10 African films that were submitted for Oscar consideration this year.
igbo: 'Lionheart' so n'ime ihe nkiri Africa iri nke edepụtara maka ntụli Oscar afọ a .

english: Since this news broke, there have been arguments for and against the decision by Oscar.
igbo: Kemgbe a nuru ozi a, na e nwere okwu arụmụka na okwu imegide gbasara mkpebi Oscar.

english: Today, Nigerians woke up to the news that their first-ever submission for best international feature Oscar consideration, 'Lionheart' has been disqualified by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
igbo: Taa, ndị Naịjirịa kpọtere ozi na ntinye akwụkwọ nke izizi ha kachasị mma nke Oscar, 'Lionheart' agụmakwụkwọ nke Arts na Mgbakọ Sayensi kewapụrụ ya.

english: The panel said the movie had 'too much English dialogue'.
igbo: Ndị otu ahụ kwuru na ihe nkiri ahụ nwere 'mkparịta ụka Bekee buru oke ibu . '

english: The movie which was directed by ace Nollywood actress, GenevieveNnaji, according to the Los Angeles Times ran afoul of the academy rule which states that an International feature film category must have 'a predominantly non-English dialogue track' .
igbo: Ihe nkiri omere nke Nollywood, Genevieve Nnaji duziri, dị ka akwụkwọ akụkọ Los Angeles si kwuo na ụlọakwụkwọ na-ekwu na ihe ngosipụta nke ihe nkiri mba ụwa kwesịrị ịhapụ 'usoro mkparịta ụka na-abụghị Bekee.

english: 'Lionheart' is among the 10 African films that were submitted for Oscar consideration this year.
igbo: 'Lionheart' so na ihe nkiri iri nke Africa nyere maka ntụli Oscar nke afọ a.

english: This isn't the first time the academy has disqualified a foreign film from consideration for having too much English dialogue
igbo: Nke a abụghị nke mbụ ụlọ a na ewepu ihe nkiri mba ọzọ maka bekee;

english: In recent years, the 2015 Afghan film, Utopia, and the 2007 Israeli movie, The Band's Visit, were disqualified for the same reason,' Los AngelesTimes reports.
igbo: Na nso nso a, ihe nkiri Afrịka nke Afghanistan, Utopia, na ihe nkiri Israel nke 2007, bụ nleta otu egwu, ka ewepụrụ aha ha maka otu ihe ahụ, 'ka akụkọ Los Angeles na-akọ.

english: Since this news broke, there have been arguments for and against the decision by Oscar.
igbo: Kemgbe akụkọ a pụtara ihe, e nwela arụmụka maka mkpebi Oscar imeghachị omume ya,

english: Giving her reaction, an American filmmaker, Ava Duvernay wondered whythe movie was disqualified when the official language of Nigeria was English.
igbo: Onye ihe nkiri America, Ava Duvernay nọ na-eche ihe kpatara na ewezighi ihe nkiri ahụ ebe asụsụ gọọmentị Naịjirịa bụ bekee.

english: In a tweet on her official Twitter handle she wrote: 'To the academy(Oscar), You disqualified Nigeria's first-ever submission for Best International Feature because its in English.
igbo: O dere n'akara twita : 'Iji na-ụlọ mmụta (Oscar), Ị wepuru ihe nkiri mbu nke Naịjirịa maka njirimara ha bụ bekee.

english: But English is the official language of Nigeria.
igbo: Mana asụsụ bekee bụ asụsụ ala Naịjirịa.

english: Are you barring this country from evercompeting for an Oscar in its official language?
igbo: Ị na-egbochi obodo a ka ọ ghara ịdị na-eme Oscar n'asụsụ mbụ ya?

english: 'In her response to Ava Duvernay's tweet, Genevieve Nnaji said: 'I am the director of Lionheart.
igbo: 'Na nzaghachị Ava Duvernay na akara twita, Genevieve Nnaji kwuru, sị:' Abụ m onye nhazigharị nke 'Lionheart'

english: This movie represents the way we speak as Nigerians.
igbo: Ihe nkiri a na-anọchi anya ụzọ anyị si ekwu okwu dịka ndị Naịjirịa.

english: This includes English which acts as a bridge between the500+ languages spoken in our country; thereby making us one Nigeria.
igbo: Nke a gụnyere asụsụ Bekee nke emere dị ka àkwà mmiri dị n'etiti asụsụ ruru 500 ana-asụ n'obodo anyị; nke mere anyị otu Naịjirịa.

english: 'It's no different to how French connects communities in former Frenchcolonies.
igbo: 'Ọ dịghị iche na otu French si ejikọ obodo na mba ha chịburu.

english: We did not choose who colonized us.
igbo: Anyị ahọrọghị ndị chịrị anyị.

english: As ever, this film andmany like it is proudly Nigerian.
igbo: Dị ka ọ dị ugbu a, ihe nkiri a na nke dị ka ya bụ ihe onye Naịjirịa na-anya isi.

english: 'For Nigerian actor, Deyemi, he chose to see the positive side, saying:'I can only imagine how many more views Lionheart will have on Netflix by the end of today!
igbo: Nye onye na-eme ihe nkiri Naịjirịa, Deyemi, ọ họọrọ ịhụ akụkụ dị mma, na-ekwu, sị:' Apụrụ m iche ọtụtụ echiche obi ga-enwe na Netflix na njedebe nke taa!

english: Anyhow you look at it this is a win! Staywinning.
igbo: N'ụzọ ọ bụla ịlere ya anya na nke a bụ mmeri! .

english: 'To think that some Nigerians actually complained that Lionheart had too much Igbo!
igbo: I ji na-eche na ụfọdụ ndị Naịjirịa n'ezie mere mkpesa na obi agụ nwere asụsụ Igbo nke ukwuu!

english: Only for the Oscars to think it has too much English?
igbo: Naanị ịnụ ndị Oscars ka ha kwuru na ọ nwere ọtụtụ Bekee?

english: Total BS!
igbo: Oke BS!

english: Honestly, I don't even care for the Oscars at this point!
igbo: N'ezie, adịghị m ele ndị Oscar anya ugbu a!

english: They might as well change the name back to 'Foreign language',' a Twitter user, Steven Chuks, stated.
igbo: Ha nwekwara ike gbanwee aha ahụ laghachị 'Asụsụ Ọzọ', otu onye twita, Steven Chuks kwuru.

english: Another Twitter user, Britain Danielle, said, 'Something about this doesn't seem fair.
igbo: Onye ọzọ na-eji Twitter eme ihe, Danielle kwuru, sị, 'Ihe ụfọdụ gbasara ihe a adịghị mma.

english: The film was disqualified because it's mostly in English.
igbo: Ewepụrụ ihe nkiri ahụ n'ihi na ọ kacha n'asụsụ Bekee .

english: Meanwhile, the official language of Nigeria is English.'
igbo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, asụsụ gọọmentị Naịjirịa bụ Bekee. '

english: Recalling Tai Solarin's Prediction By Edwin Madunagu
igbo: Icheta amụma Tai Solarin Site Edwin Madunagu

english: Does it mean that nothing has changed fundamentally in Nigeria's social order or in the Leftist challenge to it, or both?
igbo: O putara na onweghị ihe gbanwegogoro n'usoro ọrụ ndị mmadụ na Naịjirịa ma ọ bụ n'ime aka ndị akaịpa na ya, ma ọ bụ ha abụọ?

english: How has Nigeria's ruling capitalist class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule?
igbo: Kedụ ka ndị otu ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịmegharị onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, wepụta ụdị nhazi ma na-aga n'ihu?

english: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force?
igbo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka otu, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dịka ike ọchịchị kacha ike?

english: Nigeria's 2019 elections, particularly the recent governorship contests in Kogi and Bayelsa states, have forcefully brought back a prediction which the late Tai Solarin made about 40 years ago in the aftermath of the 1979 elections.
igbo: Ntụli aka nke 2019 nke Naịjirịa, karịsịa asọmpi gọvanọ n'oge na-adịbeghị anya na steeti Kogi na Bayelsa, ejirila ike weghachite amụma nke onye ikpe azụ Tai Solarin mara ihe dị ka afọ 40 gara aga na ntụli aka nke 1979.

english: Of course, recalling this prediction is also recalling my response to it at the time.
igbo: N'ezie, ịcheta amụma a na-echetakwa azịza m n'ebe m nọ n'oge ahụ.

english: I was then 33.
igbo: Adị m afọ 33 mgbe ahụ.

english: It is appropriate to begin any story I might wish to tell here by introducing Tai Solarin to young Nigerians who were not born when the prediction was made.
igbo: Ọ dị mma ịmalite akụkọ ọ bụla m nwere ike ịkọ ebe a site na iwebata Tai Solarin na ndị na-eto eto ndị Naịjirịa na-amụghị amụ mgbe amara amụma ahụ.

english: This set of Nigerians now constitutes the majority of the Nigerian population.
igbo: Ndi Naịjirịa ugbu a mejupụtara ọnụ ọgụgụ ndị mmadụ nọ n'Naịjirịa.

english: Tai Solarin was a prominent Nigerian male from South-Western Nigeria who was a secular humanist and educationist, but whose humanism was exceptional because it was all-round (that is, in thought as well as in action), consistent, courageous and well-informed.
igbo: Tai Solarin bụ nwa nwoke ama ama nke Naịjirịa si mpaghara ọdịda-ọwụwa anyanwụ nke Naịjirịa nke bụ onye ọrụ ụwa na agụmakwụkwọ, mana ọrụ mmadụ ya enweghị atụ n'ihi (ya bụ n'echiche na omume) nnagide ya, obi isi ike ya na oke mmụta ya.

english: Tai Solarin was not a Marxist, not a communist and not a worker by class placement.
igbo: Tai Solarin abụghị onye Marxist, ọ bụghị onye komunizim ọ bụghị onye ọrụ site na idobe otu.

english: But he was a proletarian in lifestyle.
igbo: Mana ọ bụ onye mkwado ndụ.

english: In politics he would be described as a progressive, but not a progressive in the mould of the present-day Nigeria's neofascist 'progressive'.
igbo: Na ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị a ga-akọwa ya dịka onye na - aga n'ihu, mana ọbụghị onye na - aga n'ihu ugbua ndị Naịjirịa 'na-aga n'ihu'.

english: Tai Solarin was a progressive in the original sense of being located in the Leftist ideological and political universe.
igbo: Tai Solarin bụ ihe na-agagharị n'echiche mbụ nke ịbụ onye nọ na mpaghara echiche ndị akaịkpa na ụwa ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị.

english: He was, in general, a 'social critic' and, in particular, a critical, popular and respected newspaper columnist.
igbo: Ọ bụ ya n'ozuzu ya, 'onye nkatọ mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya' na ọkachasị, ọ bụ onye edemede akụkọ pụrụ iche, ama ama ma na-akwanyere ùgwù.

english: Now to the beginning of this piece.
igbo: Ugbu a ruo n'isi mmalite nke mpempe a.

english: We may recall that Nigeria's Second Republic began on October 1, 1979 after a 13-year period (1966-1979) of military rule that witnessed a civil war.
igbo: Anyị nwere ike icheta na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche nke abụọ Naịjirịa malitere na Ọktọba 1, 1979 mgbe afọ 13 (1966-1979) nke ọchịchị ndị agha nke hụrụ agha obodo .

english: In the general elections that ushered in the Republic, Shehu Shagari of the National Party of Nigeria (NPN) emerged as (Executive) President and Obafemi Awolowo of the Unity Party of Nigeria (UPN) emerged as the second strongest presidential candidate.
igbo: Na ntuli aka niile emere na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya, Shehu Shagari nke otu mba Naịjirịa (NPN) pụtara dị ka (Ezekutiv) onye isi ala na Obafemi Awolowo nke otu njịkọ Naịjirịa (UPN) pụtara dịka onye ntuli aka nke abụọ.

english: The result was, to say the least, very contentious—as we can recall or research.
igbo: Nsonaazụ ya bụ, ịsị ntakịrị, oke esemokwu — dịka anyị nwere ike icheta ma ọ bụ mee nyocha.

english: But the issue here is neither the contentiousness of the result of the presidential contest nor the side which Tai Solarin supported.
igbo: Mana ihe dị ebe a abụghị esemokwu nke nsonaazụ onye isi ala ma ọ bụ akụkụ nke Tai Solarin kwadoro.

english: He was a member of the UPN .
igbo: Ọ bụ onye otu n'ime ndị UPN .

english: Rather, we are concerned with his prediction five weeks into the new Republic.
igbo: Kama, anyị na-echebara amụma ya izu ise ga-abanye na mba ọhụrụ.

english: On November 4, 1979, 34 days after the installation of President Shehu Shagari, the Sunday edition of the Tribune newspaper carried a column by Tai Solarin titled The Stolen Presidency.
igbo: Na Nọvemba 4, 1979, ụbọchị 34 ka e hibechara Onye isi ala Shehu Shagari, mbipụta Sọnde nke akwụkwọ akụkọ ikpe bụ otu nke Tai Solarin kpọrọ aha oche Onye isi ezuuru .

english: In it the columnist wrote: 'If this government lasts four years the four-year-old NPN will have been firmly planted as Government Party everywhere, and the UPN, the GNPP, the NPP and the PRP will have been drained to annihilation, both in membership—it is already starting—and in morale.
igbo: N'ime ya, onye edemede ahụ dere, sị: 'Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị a ga-adị afọ anọ… NPN ga-anọ etinyere onwe ya dịka otu Ọchịchị ebe niile, na UPN, GNPP, NPP na PRP ga-ebibikwa ma ndi otu ya - o bidola - na ihe omumu.

english: The 1983 election would therefore be between the NPN and the Revolutionary Party which, having studied how the NPN came to power knows exactly what to do to supplant the NPN for the presidency.
igbo: Ntụli aka nke afọ 1983 ga-adị n'etiti NPN na otu mgbanwe, ebe ọ mụrụ banyere NPN wee bụrụ ọchịchị maara nke ọma ihe ọ ga-eme itinye onye NPN maka onye isi ala.

english: There would then be a confusion on the national raft.
igbo: A ga-enwe ọgba aghara na ụdọ mba ahụ.

english: Then commotion among the sharks.
igbo: Mgbe ahụ ọgbaghara n'etiti ndị shark.

english: And we, the common people, will have, as victims, paid the supreme sacrifice'.
igbo: Anyị onwe anyị, ndị nkịtị, ga-akwụrịrị ụgwọ dị ka ndị a na-enye ụgwọ.

english: My comment on this prediction was immediate—as was expected in those days.
igbo: Ihe m kwuru banyere amụma a bụ ihe ozugbo - dịka a tụrụ anya n'oge ahụ.

english: It appeared in an edition of the Nigerian Chronicle, a daily newspaper owned and published by the Cross River State government.
igbo: Ọ pụtara na mbipụta nke akwụkwọ akụkọ nke Naịjirịa, akwụkwọ akụkọ kwa ụbọchị nke gọọmentị Cross River dere ma bipụta ya.

english: The comment was later revised and included in the text of a lecture I delivered at the University of Ife (now Obafemi Awolowo University) in November 1980 under the auspices of the institution's Alliance of Progressive Students (ALPS) on the occasion of the 31st anniversary of the killing of Nigerian miners at the Iva Valley Mines, Enugu, by the colonial police.
igbo: Edegharịrị nkwupụta ahụ ma tinye ya na ederede okwu nkuzi m kwuru na Mahadum Ife (Mahadum Obafemi Awolowo ugbu a) na Nọvemba 1980 n'okpuru nkwado nke ụlọ Akwụkwọ Ndị Ọzụzụ Ndị Mmụta (ALPS) n'oge emume ncheta nke 31 nke ogbugbu ndị na-egwu ala Naịjirịa na ndagwurugwu Iva Valley, Enugwu, site n'aka ndị uwe ojii .

english: And later still, in May 1981, the comment was included in a book which emanated from the lecture.
igbo: Ma mesịa, na Mee 1981, ekwupụtara nkọwa a n'akwụkwọ nke si na nkuzi ahụ .

english: The lecture as well as the book that emanated from it were titled: Human Progress and Its Enemies: The Struggle for a more humane social order in Nigeria.
igbo: Okwu nkuzi a yana akwụkwọ nke si na ya pụta bụ aha akpọrọ: oganihu mmadụ na iro Ya: Mgba maka usoro mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya karị na Naịjirịa.

english: In the book, I said, 'Tai Solarin's prediction is unusual in two ways.
igbo: N'akwụkwọ ahụ, ekwuru m, 'Amụma Tai Solarin bụ ihe pụrụ iche n'ụzọ abụọ .

english: In the first place, Tai Solarin was predicting the disintegration and demise of his party, the UPN.
igbo: Na mbu, Tai Solarin na-ebu amụma banyere mwepu na mbibi nke otu ya, UPN .

english: In the second place he was predicting that it would require a Revolutionary Party to dislodge the NPN from power: a type of prediction that normally comes from a revolutionary and not a liberal.
igbo: N'ebe nke abụọ ọ na-ebu amụma na ọ ga-achọ ndị otu mgbanwe iji chụpụ NPN n'ike: ụdị amụma na-esitekarị na ngagharị iwe abụghị nke na-emesapụ aka .

english: We may ignore Tai Solarin's scenario—for the Revolutionary Party, when it emerges, will not fight according to the rules fashioned by the enemies of progress.
igbo: Anyị nwere ike ileghara ọnọdụ Tai Solarin anya - maka otu mgbanwe, mgbe ọ na-apụta, ọ gaghị agha dịka iwu nke ndị iro nke ọganiihu siri dị .

english: But we agree completely that the NPN, as a political party, is today the best organization of the Nigerian bourgeoisie and the most accurate reflection of Nigerian bourgeois interests.
igbo: Mana anyị kwenyere kpam kpam na NPN, dịka ndị otu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, bụ taa ọgbakọ kacha mma nke ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị Naịjirịa na ngosipụta ziri ezi gbasara ọdịmma ndị Naịjirịa .

english: So long as the bourgeois social order remains so long will the NPN (or a new monster it may give birth to) continue to be the dominant political organization of the bourgeoisie.'
igbo: Ọ bụrụhaala na usoro ọdịmma ọha mmadụ ka ga-anọ ogologo oge, NPN (ma ọ bụ anụ ọhụrụ ọ nwere ike ịmụ) ga-anọgide na-abụ nzukọ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị kachasị elu nke ndị ogaranya .

english: It follows from above that 'only a revolutionary agency, representing the true aspirations of the popular masses (the workers, the peasants, students, etc.) and fighting consistently for an entirely new social order, can ever dislodge the NPN from power.
igbo: O si n'elu pụta na 'naanị ụlọ ọrụ na-agbanwe agbanwe, na-anọchite anya ezi ọchịchọ nke ọha mmadụ a ma ama (ndị ọrụ, ndị nkịtị, ụmụ akwụkwọ, wdg) na ịlụ ọgụ maka usoro mmekọrịta ọha na eze kpamkpam, nwere ike ịchụpụ NPN n'ike .

english: To that extent—and to that extent alone—we agree with Tai Solarin.
igbo: Ruo ókè ahụ — na ruo naanị ọnụ ụzọ ahụ - anyị kwenyere Tai Solarin .

english: But we do not share his pessimism.
igbo: Ma anyị adịghị enwe echiche enweghị nchekwube .

english: A revolution cannot be conceived in a pessimistic perspective.
igbo: Enweghị ike ịtụgharị mgbanwe site n'ọnọdụ ọjọọ .

english: A revolution—to use the words of Leon Trotsky—is incompatible with pessimism and other forms of spiritual collapse.
igbo: Ntughari - iji okwu Leon Trotsky na-emegide enweghị nchekwube na ụdị mbibi ime mmụọ ndị ọzọ .

english: Tai Solarin's pessimism arose from the fact that he made a separation between the people and the Revolutionary Party—a type of separation that exists between the people and the existing political parties.
igbo: Nkwuputa okwu Tai Solarin sitere na eziokwu ahụ ọ kewara ndị mmadụ na ndị otu mgbanwe - ụdị nkewa dị n'etiti ndị mmadụ na ndị otu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị dị ugbu a .

english: A genuine revolution can only be made by the people under the leadership of their revolutionary organization, and such a revolution demands the highest forms of optimism and moral courage.'
igbo: Naanị ndị ndu ha nwere ike ịme nghazigharị, mgbanwe dị otú ahụ chọrọ ụdị nchekwube kachasị elu na obi ike omume .

english: Looking now at this nearly 40-year old 'exchange' between Tai Solarin and myself, it strikes me that I could myself not have realized its full import.
igbo: N'ileghachi anya ugbu a ihe 'afọ agbanweta' n'etiti Tai Solarin na onwe m, ọ na-akụ m n'enweghị m ike ịghọta na mbubata ya zuru oke .

english: Tai Solarin said only a Revolutionary Party could dislodge the NPN from power.
igbo: Tai Solarin kwuru na ọ bụ naanị otu mgbanwe nwere ike ịchụpụ NPN n'ike .

english: I agreed with him but amended the proposition by replacing 'NPN' with the phrase 'NPN or a new monster it might give birth to'.
igbo: Ekwenyere m ya ma mezie echiche ahụ site n'iji 'NPN' dochie 'NPN' ma ọ bụ ogologo anụ mmiri ọ nwere ike ịmụ ' .

english: This suggests that I had a 'flash' that NPN could be succeeded by another party—or another entity—but nonetheless, a 'monster' (such as a military junta) organically emerging from NPN.
igbo: Nke a na-egosi na enwere m 'ọkụ' nke NPN nwere ike bụrụ onye ọzọ - ma ọ bụ onye ọzọ ga - anọchi - mana agbanyeghị, 'anụ mmiri' (dịka isi iyi ndị agha) na-esite na NPN .

english: But the 'flash' was not pursued.
igbo: Mana 'ịcha ọkụ' ahụ achughị.

english: It is clear that the class perspective was missing from Tai Solarin's analysis and prediction.
igbo: O doro anya na echiche otu ahụ nyocha na ịkọ amụma Tai Solarin .

english: This is explicable, given that he was not a Marxist.
igbo: Nke a bụ ihe kwere omume, ebe ọ bụ na ọ bụghị ndị otu Marx .

english: But my response was also not sufficiently ideological.
igbo: Ma azịza m ezughị echiche m zuru ezu .

english: Let me explain.
igbo: Ka m kọwaa .

english: In political-ideological contestation, even in our own context, the terms 'bourgeois' and 'capitalist' are not simply interchangeable.
igbo: Na ndoro-ndoro echiche nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, ọbụlagodi n'ọnọdụ nke anyị, okwu 'ndị ọgaranya' na 'onye isi ike' abụghị ndị agbanwere .

english: The absence of 'capitalist' in my 'disquisition' qualifies it as petty-bourgeois, even if revolutionary.
igbo: Enweghị 'ikeketeorie' na 'ọkwa m' mere ka ọ pụta ìhè dịka obere-ọgaranya, ọbụlagodi ma ọ bụrụ na mgbape agba .

english: If I had adopted a more appropriate ideological posture I would have stated explicitly that what I was alluding to was the removal of the capitalist class, as a class, and not just its political organisations like the NPN.
igbo: ọbụrụ na mụ tinye echiche ziri ezi karie, m ga ekwupụta n'ụzọ na ihe m na-atụgharị bụ iwepu ndị akwụkwọ ikekarị ya dịka akwụkwọ, ọbụghị ndị otu ndọrọ-ndọrọ ọchịchị ya dịka ndị NPN.

english: Having said this, the questions now are: Why is it that for almost 40 years, I have periodically—after every major election or change of government—felt the way I felt following the 1979 general elections and Tai Solarin's prediction?
igbo: Mgbe ikwuru nke a, ajụjụ dị ugbu a bụ: Gini mere na ọ fọrọ obere ka ọ bụrụ afọ iri anọ, na-enwe oge - mgbe ọ bụla ntuli aka ma ọ bụ mgbanwe ọ bụla nke gọọmentị - nwere mmetụta dị m ka m soro ntụli aka ndị isi na 1979 na amụma Tai Solarin ?

english: Why is it that despite the Nigerian Left's insistence, at least since 1979, on the inevitability and irreducibility of a Revolutionary Party, the party has not emerged?
igbo: Gini mere na agbanyeghị na mkparịta ụka nke ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa, ọ dịkarịa ala kemgbe 1979, na-aga-agharịrị na enweghị mgbagha nke otu Ree, otu ahụ apụtabeghị ?

english: Why should we find ourselves repeating the same theses and propositions after every bloody and farcical display called 'election'?
igbo: Kedu ihe kpatara anyị ga - eji hụ na anyị na - emegharị otu echiche na atụmatụ a mgbe ngosipụta ọbara niile na nke ọrụ ugbo na - akpọ 'ntụli aka'?

english: Does it mean that nothing has changed fundamentally in Nigeria's social order or in the Leftist challenge to it, or both?
igbo: O putara na onweghi ihe gbanwegogoro n'usoro ọrụ ndị mmadụ na Naịjirịa ma ọ bụ n'ime aka ndị akaịpa na ya, ma ọ bụ ha abụọ ?

english: How has Nigeria's ruling capitalist class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule?
igbo: Kedụ ka ndị otu ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịhazi onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, wee were usoro nhazi ọhụụ wee gaa n'ihu na-achị ya ?

english: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force?
igbo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka otu, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dịka ike ọchịchị kacha ike?

english: Madunagu, mathematician and journalist, writes from Calabar, Cross River State.
igbo: Madunagu, onye na-ahụ maka mgbakọ na mwepụ na odeakụkọ, dere si Calabar, Cross River Steeti.

english: Reflections On Cold War And Africa's Human Progress By Phumlani Majozi
igbo: Ntughari banyere agha Nzuzo na Ọganihu ndị Afrika Mmadụ Site na Phumlani Majozi

english: In contrast to 30 years ago, the world is a better place in consideration of almost all the metrics of human development including economic growth, healthcare, access to education, and human right.
igbo: N'adịghị ka afọ iri atọ gara aga, ụwa bụ ebe kachasị mma n'ịtụle ihe omimi niile nke mmepe mmadụ gụnyere mmepe akụ na ụba, ahụike, ịnweta agụmakwụkwọ, na ikike mmadụ .

english: This rate of progress is unprecedented in human history.
igbo: Mmụba a a na-enwe n'ihu bụ ihe a na-ahụtụbeghị mbụ n'akụkọ mmadụ .

english: My colleague at African Liberty, Alexander Hammond, has done incredible work on global human progress for the Cato Institute.
igbo: Onye ọrụ ibe m na ntọghapụ ndị Afrika, Alexander Hammond, arụwo ọrụ dị egwu na ọganihu mmadụ na ụwa maka ụlọ akwụkwọ Cato.

english: Unsurprisingly, it's only after the Cold War that we have seen extraordinary advancements in technology and declines in global poverty rates.
igbo: N'agha, ọ bụ naanị mgbe Agha Nzuzo gasịrị ka anyị hụworo ọganihu pụrụ iche na teknọlọjị wee jupụta na ọnụego ịda ogbenye zuru ụwa ọnụ .

english: But before the fall of the Berlin Wall, the world was divided.
igbo: Mana tupu ọdịda nke mgbidi Berlin, ụwa kewara .

english: While Russia led the Soviet Union on a mission to turn the world into a communist paradise, the United States (US) invested huge resources to stall the Soviet Union's communist ambitions.
igbo: Ezie na Russia duuru otu Soviet na ụwa ime ka ụwa ghọọ paradaịs, United States (US) tinyere ego buru ibu iji kwụsị ebumnuche ndị otu Soviet .

english: The two countries, Russia and the United States, had distinct philosophical worldviews; communism and capitalism.
igbo: Mba abụọ a, Russia na United States, nwere echiche nkà ihe ọmụma ụwa dị iche; komunizim na ikeketeorie .

english: Because of their differences, they both exploited many resources to advance their ideologies to every corner of the globe.
igbo: N'ihi ọdịiche ha, ha abụọ jiri ọtụtụ akụ rụọ ọrụ iji bulie echiche ha n'akụkụ niile nke ụwa.

english: The clash of these ideologies has resulted in incessant global instability, which negatively affects almost all regions of the world.
igbo: Esemokwu nke echiche ndị a akpatawo ọgba aghara zuru ụwa ọnụ, nke na-emetụta ihe fọrọ nke nta ka ọ bụrụ mpaghara niile nke ụwa .

english: Multilateral institutions like the United Nations became an ideological battlefield for the two powers.
igbo: Otutu ụlọ ọrụ dịka out jikọrọ mba ụwa United buru agha ebe ndị echiche ha nọ buru agha.

english: In that tumultuous period in human history, none of us benefited; in fact, things became worse for much of the developing world with political dysfunction fuelled, in part, by the Cold War.
igbo: N'oge ọgba aghara ahụ n'akụkọ ihe mere eme nke mmadụ, ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime anyị ritere uru; n'ezie, ihe kara njọ maka ọtụtụ mba na-emepe emepe, ebe ọnụọgụ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ka ọkụ, akụkụ ya ụfọdụ, site na Agha Nzuzo .

english: Today, sadly, people tend to underestimate the harm that was done by this global ideological standoff that lasted decades.
igbo: Taa, ọ dị mwute ikwu na ndị mmadụ na-echefukarị nsogbu nke esemokwu echiche ụwa niile nke were ọtụtụ afọ ime .

english: Could it be due to short memories?
igbo: O nwere ike ibute obere ncheta?

english: Well, the African continent was one of the Cold War battlegrounds.
igbo: N'ezie, Afrika bụ otu n'ime ala ndi agha .

english: My homeland, South Africa, was one of the victims of the Cold War.
igbo: Ala nna m, ọdịda nke Afrika, bụ otu n'ime ndị ihe metụtara Agha Nzuzo .

english: One of the reasons why it took us longer to end apartheid was because global powers saw our struggle against apartheid in the Cold War lens; Americans viewed Nelson Mandela as a communist and they believed his outlawed political movement, the African National Congress, was funded by Moscow.
igbo: Otu n'ime ihe mere o jiri were anyị ogologo oge ịkwụsị ịkpa ókè agbụrụ bụ n'ihi na ike ụwa niile hụrụ mgba anyị na-alụ megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ na agha oyi; Ndị Amerika lere Nelson Mandela dị ka onye ọchịchị Kọmunist, ha kwenyere na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ya, ndị kongres Afrika, nke Moscow kwadoro.

english: The US and Britain were conflicted about the struggle against apartheid in South Africa, hence, when we talk about the history of South Africa's black struggle against apartheid, we should not isolate it from the dynamics of the Cold War.
igbo: US na Britain gbara mgba banyere ọgụ megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ na South Africa, n'ihi ya, mgbe anyị na-ekwu banyere akụkọ banyere ọgụ ojii South Africa megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ, anyị ekwesịghị ikewapụ ya na Agha Nzuzo.

english: The Cold War raged on for years in Zaire — now the Democratic Republic of Congo — as the country endured crisis after crisis.
igbo: agha oyi ahụ bidoro ruo ọtụtụ afọ na Zaire - ugbu a ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na Congo - ka mba ahụ diri mgbe nsogbu gasịrị .

english: The political turmoil that culminated in Patrice Lumumba's brutal death in 1961, usually called the Congo Crisis, was in part, fuelled by the power struggle between Russia and the US.
igbo: Ọgba aghara ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ahụ bilitere na ọnwụ obi ọjọọ Patrice Lumumba na 1961, nke a na-akpọkarị Kọnị Kongo, bụ akụkụ nke mgbagha ike dị n'etiti Russia na US kpalitere .

english: The corrupt Mobuto Sese Seko who took power in 1965 and ran Zaire to the ground, was supported by the United States for most of his tyrannical rule because he was an ally against the Soviet Union.
igbo: Onye nrụrụ aka bụ Mobuto Sese Seko onye weghaara ọchịchị na 1965 wee gbaa Zaire n'ala, ndị United States kwadoro ya maka ọtụtụ ọchịchị aka ike ya n'ihi na ọ bụ onye jikọrọ otu Soviet.

english: The above Cold War cases on South Africa and the DRC, and on many other fronts in Africa, caused enormous political and socioeconomic damage to the continent.
igbo: Ikpe ndị a dị n'etiti South Africa na DRC, na ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ na Africa, kpatara mbibi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na mmekọrịta akụ na ụba na kọntinent ahụ.

english: The end of the Cold War put the world in a new, positive direction.
igbo: Ọgwụgwụ nke Agha Nzuzo butere ụwa ụzọ ọhụrụ, nke ziri ezi .

english: A more cooperative world led by the US.
igbo: Morewa na-arụkọ ọrụ ọnụ nke US na-eduzi .

english: The results of the formation of this new world were astonishingly a boon for human progress.
igbo: Nsonaazụ nguzobe nke ụwa ọhụrụ a bụ ihe ịtụnanya maka ọganihu mmadụ.

english: Speedy advancements in technology and globalization have cut global poverty to less than ten percent.
igbo: Ọganihu ndị dị na teknọlọjị na ijikọ ụwa ọnụ emewo ka ịda ogbenye zuru ụwa ọnụ belata pasent iri .

english: Today, most women have the opportunity to go to school, and child mortality has reduced by more than half.
igbo: Taa, ọtụtụ ụmụ nwanyị nwere ohere ịga ụlọ akwụkwọ, ọnwụ nke ụmụaka ebelataala ihe karịrị ọkara .

english: Global healthcare has generally improved.
igbo: Ahụike ụwa niile adịla mma .

english: Equally, experts seem to agree that we now live in the most peaceful times in modern human history.
igbo: N'otu aka ahụ, ndị ọkachamara na-ekwenye na anyị bi ugbu a n'oge udo kachasị mma n'akụkọ ihe mere eme nke mmadụ .

english: But it is Africa that still lags behind on fundamental measures of human development in the post-Cold War era.
igbo: Mana ọ bụ Afrika ka na-akwado ụzọ dị iche iche nke mmepe mmekọrịta mmadụ na Afọ mgbe Agha Ọgbọ nzuzo gasịrị.

english: African countries have failed abysmally to liberalise their economies; they still rank at the bottom of the Heritage's Index of Economic Freedom.
igbo: Mba Afrịka emeghị nke ọma ịhapụ akụ na ụba ha; ha ka nokwa na nkenke akara ngosiputa ihe Nketa nke Onwe ha .

english: Civil conflicts, dictatorships, and corruption have continued unabated.
igbo: Esemokwu obodo, ọchịchị aka ike, na nrụrụ aka ka na-ebelata .

english: Although global poverty rates may have declined since the early 1990s, Africa's rates remain incredibly high compared to other regions of the world.
igbo: Ọ bụ ezie na ọnụego ịda ogbenye ụwa nwere ike gbadata kemgbe mmalite 1990, ọnụego Afrika na-anọgide n'ụzọ dị elu ma e jiri ya tụnyere mpaghara ụwa ndị ọzọ.

english: Having gone through one of its rough periods in history, Africa needs a pro-market revolution.
igbo: N'ịgafe n'otu n'ime oge siri ike ya na akụkọ ntolite, Afrika chọrọ mgbanwe nghazi ahịa .

english: The revolution needs people that are willing to put their countries first, not their personal interests.
igbo: Ntughari a chọrọ ndị mmadụ ibute mba ha ụzọ, ọbụghị nke onwe ha .

english: Ethiopian Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed, recipient of the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize, is one of the people we must look up to in moving Africa forward.
igbo: Onye isi ala Etiopia, Abiy Ahmed, onye natara onyinye nke udo nke 2019, bụ otu ndị anyị ga-elerukwu anya n'ịkwaga Afrika n'ihu .

english: The Cold War is now history.
igbo: Agha Nzuzo bụ akụkọ ihe mere eme ugbu a .

english: And history is history; there's not much we can do to change it.
igbo: Ọ bụkwa akụkọ ihe mere eme; O nweghi ọtụtụ ihe anyị nwere ike ime iji gbanwee ya .

english: All we can do is to learn from it and use it as a guide to a better future.
igbo: Naanị ihe anyị ga - eme bụ ịmụta ihe na ya ma jiri ya na-eduzi ọdịnihu ka mma.

english: Phumlani M.
igbo: Phumlani M .

english: Majozi is a politics and international affairs analyst, and a senior fellow at AfricanLiberty.org.
igbo: Majozi bụ onye nyocha ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na onye na-ahụ maka ihe gbasara mba ụwa, yana onye otu okenye na ntoghapu Afrika.org .

english: You can follow him on Twitter: @PhumlaniMMajozi
igbo: ịnwere ike iso ya na akara Twita: @PhumlaniMMajozi

english: REPORTER'S DIARY: 'Who Did You Come To See?
igbo: Akwụkwọ ukwu: 'onye ka ịbịara ịhụ?'

english: ' — A Visit To The 'Racist' Shi Shi Chinese Restaurant In Lagos
igbo: - Nleta 'ndị na-akpa ókè' ebe ana ere ihe oriri ndị China Shi Shi dị na Legos

english: On arriving Shi Shi, tucked away in a residential area in Ikeja, we approached the gate.
igbo: Mgbe anyị bịarutere Shi Shi, gbachie ebe obibi na Ikeja, anyị rutere n'ọnụ ụzọ ámá ahụ .

english: 'Good afternoon,' we called out to the grumpy and irritated-looking security guard.
igbo: 'N'ehihie ọma,' anyị kpọkuru ndị nche na-ama jijiji ma na-ewe iwe .

english: 'Who did you come to see ? he queried.
igbo: 'Onye ka ị bịara ịhụ?' ọ jụrụ .

english: Taken aback by the question, the SaharaReporters correspondent asked: 'Is this not a restaurant?'
igbo: N'ajụjụ a, onye nta akụkọ SaharaReporters jụrụ, sị: 'Ihe a abụghị ụlọ oriri?'

english: The security guard looked as if he was contemplating a response, but seemed to think twice about it and stepped back.
igbo: Onye nche ahụ dị ka ọ na-eche echiche banyere nzaghachi, mana ọ dị ka ọ na-eche ugboro abụọ banyere ya wee laa.

english: What better place to have lunch than a restaurant accused of racism?
igbo: Kedu ebe ka mma iri nri ehihie karịa ụlọ oriri eboro ebubo ịkpa ókè agbụrụ?

english: SaharaReporters visited Shi Shi Chinese restaurant on Thursday due to multiple allegations of racism towards Nigerian visitors to the restaurant, located at 21B, Emina Crescent, off Toyin Street, Ikeja, Lagos.
igbo: Ndi ntaakụkọ Sahara gara ụlọ oriri ndị China Shiụ Shiụ na Tọzde n'ihi ọtụtụ ebubo nke ịkpa ókè agbụrụ megide ndị ọbịa Naịjirịa na ụlọ oriri ahụ, nke dị na 21B, Emina Crescent, kwụsịrị Toyin Street, Ikeja, Legos

english: Our Experience
igbo: Ahụmahụ anyị

english: On arriving Shi Shi, tucked away in a residential area in Ikeja, we approached the gate.
igbo: Mgbe anyị bịarutere Shi Shi, gbachie ebe obibi na Ikeja, anyị rutere n'ọnụ ụzọ ámá ahụ.

english: Good afternoon, we called out to the grumpy and irritated-looking security guard.
igbo: N'ehihie ọma, anyị na-akpọ ndị nche na -atakasị ahụ na-ewe iwe.

english: Who did you come to see? he queried.
igbo: Onye ka ị bịara ịhụ ? ọ jụrụ .

english: Taken aback by the question, the SaharaReporters correspondent asked: 'Is this not a restaurant?'
igbo: N'ajụjụ a, onye ntaakụkọ Sahara jụrụ, sị: 'Ihe ọbụghị ụlọ oriri?'

english: The security guard looked as if he was contemplating a response, but seemed to think twice about it and stepped back.
igbo: Onye nche ahụ dị ka ọ na-eche echiche banyere nzaghachị, mana ọ dị ka ọ na-eche ugboro abụọ banyere ya wee laa azụ.

english: The team proceeded (we came disguised as a company of people who had come to hang out).
igbo: Ndị otu ahụ malitere (anyị nwoghachitere dịka ndị mmadụ bịara ibubata ihe).

english: The entrance smelt of something funny, but the source of the smell was not readily visible.
igbo: Ọnụ ụzọ mere ihe na-atọ ọchị, mana a naghị ahụ ihe mmalite nke isi ahụ ngwa ngwa .

english: There was a show glass displaying what looked like bags made of real leather.
igbo: E nwere otu ihe nkiri na-egosi ihe yiri akpa ezigbo akpụkpọ anụ .

english: We made our way into the dimly-lit restaurant.
igbo: Anyị bara n'ụlọ oriri na-adịghị mma .

english: Inside, we approached the front desk, which had a stern-looking female Chinese national at the register (probably trying to reconcile the books).
igbo: N'ime, anyị bịarutere na tebụl ihu, nke nwere ụmụ nwanyị China na-ele anya n'azụ na ndebanye aha (ikekwe na-achọ idozi akwụkwọ ndị ahụ) .

english: She barely looked up, save for the Nigerian attendants, waiters who looked completely bewildered and almost shocked that we were standing there.
igbo: O weliteghị anya elu, ewezuga ndị Naịjirịa na - eje ozi, ndị na - eche ndị Naịjirịa gosiri itunanya ma tụọ ụjọ na anyị guzo ebe ahụ.

english: In the sitting area, two Asian men were seated, looking on at us.
igbo: N'ebe ndị mmadụ nọdụrụ ala, ụmụ nwoke abụọ si Eshia nọ ọdụ, na-ele anyị anya .

english: We were ushered to a seat, five of us on a round table overlooking a transparent glass and an outdoor sitting area.
igbo: A kpọgara anyị n'oche, anyị ise na tebụl okirikiri na-eleghara iko na-ahụ ụzọ na ebe a na-anọdụ ala n'èzí .

english: As the menu arrived, so did about three waiters, circling for no reason, with one making as if she wanted to serve tea, all the while peeking into our phones.
igbo: Ka nri ahụ bịarutere, ihe dịka mmadụ atọ na - echere anyị, na - agbagharị n'enweghị ihe kpatara ya, otu na - eme ka a ga - asị na ọ chọrọ inye tii, oge niile na - eleba anya na ekwentị anyị.

english: The Wait
igbo: Nche ahụ

english: As we awaited our moderately-priced fried rice and spaghetti, we made small talk, sipping the tea.
igbo: Ka anyị na-eche osikapa anyị na eghe eghe, anyi kwuru obere okwu, na-añụ tii .

english: By now, apart from the waiters who looked aloof and were now stationed at strategic points in the restaurant, the stern-looking Chinese lady behind the counter was now sitting close by in the restaurant.
igbo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, ewezuga ndị na-eche nche na-ele anya ma nọrọ n'akụkụ ebe a na-echekwa oriri n'ụlọ oriri ahụ, nwanyị China ahụ na-ele anya n'azụ ebe ọ nọ ọdụ n'akụkụ nri.

english: She beckoned to another lady (Chinese) and spoke something to her in their language, while motioning at us.
igbo: Ọ bekuru nwanyị ọzọ (onye China) wee gwa ya okwu n'asụsụ ha, mgbe anyị na-emegharị anyị .

english: The new lady in the most inconspicuous manner (even for an amateur) started taking photos of us and recording.
igbo: Nwaanyị ọhụụ na - enweghị atụ (ọbụlagodi onye na-amụ amụ) bidoro n'ese anyị foto na ndekọ .

english: I caught her glance and she tried to look away while concealing her phone.
igbo: Ahụrụ m ya ile ma ọ nwara ilepụ anya ka ọ na-ezo ekwentị ya .

english: Sigh.
igbo: Maa usu.

english: We continued to have conversations and our food began to arrive, the Chinese fried rice first.
igbo: Anyị gara n'ihu na-enwe mkparịta ụka ka ebutere nri, osikapa e ghere eghe nke China bịara na mbụ.

english: In a bid to what I perceive as remedying our awkward 'glance lock', 'Camera lady' approached our table and offered to teach us how to use chopsticks.
igbo: N'ịgbaso ihe m chọpụtara dị ka idozi 'mkpọchi nlegharị anya' anyị, 'Nwanyị igwe foto' bịakwutere tebụl anyị ma kwee nkwa ịkụziri anyị otu esi eji osisi eje eri nri.

english: Please note: while I was preoccupied with documenting our experience with a secret recorder, the team noticed that the two Asian men who were seated and had made their orders 'looked disgusted, got up and made their way into one of the many rooms' in the restaurant.
igbo: Biko detuo: mgbe m na-echekwa banyere ihe ndekọ banyere ahụmịhe anyị na onye na-edekọ ihe nzuzo, ndị otu ahụ chọpụtara na ụmụ nwoke abụọ Eshia nọ ọdụ ma mee ihu ha 'na-asọ oyi, bilitere ma banye n'otu n'ime ọtụtụ ụlọ' n'ụlọ oriri

english: The Show Must Go On
igbo: Ihe nkiri a ga-agariri n'ihu

english: And so it began, the overly choreographed friendliness, niceness, half-smiles and forced response to questions.
igbo: Ya mere, ọ malitere, oke ọrụ ọbụbụenyi a na-eme, ka ọdịmma, ịmụmụ ọnụ ọchị na ịmanye azịza ajụjụ .

english: Ya ya (camera lady) was now tutoring us on how to use the chopsticks.
igbo: eh eh (nwanyị igwe foto) na - akụzịrị anyị ugbua etu esi eji osisi nri .

english: A member of the team quickly requested a selfie and with concealed reluctance, she proceeded and everyone was obliged, including me.
igbo: Otu onye so n'òtù ahụ rịọrọ maka ise foto ngwa ngwa wee zilaga ya, ọ gara n'ihu, iwu ji onye ọ bụla, tinyere mụ onwe m.

english: I wondered if they took selfies with all their guests or if it was a curated PR move?
igbo: Anọ m na-eche ma ha na ndị ọbịa ha niile ọ na-esekọ foto ka ọ bụ ọ bụrụ na ọ bụ ihe nlegharị anya nke PR ?

english: Soon after, we had to leave and requested takeaway packs for what was left off our spaghetti and fried rice (God forbid it wastes).
igbo: N'oge na-adịghị anya ka nke ahụ gasịrị, anyị ga-apụ ma rịọ maka ngwugwu maka ihe fọdụ spaghetti anyị na osikapa e ghere eghe (Chineke ajụ ka ha laa n'iyi) .

english: As we were about to leave, a woman clad in black (Chinese) appeared from one of the many doors.
igbo: Ka anyị na-achọ ịpụ, otu nwanyị nwanyị yi akwa ojii (onye Cjina) pụtara site n'otu n'ime ọtụtụ ụzọ.

english: She walked up to us and said 'hello' and stayed there.
igbo: Ọ rutere anyị nso ma sị 'ndewo' ma nọrọ ebe ahụ .

english: A member of the team asked for her name and she said Si Si and introduced herself as the manager of the place.
igbo: Otu onye so n'òtù egwuregwu ahụ rịọrọ maka aha ya ma ọ sị Si Si ma gosipụta onwe ya dị ka onye na-elekọta ebe ahụ .

english: One member of the team queried if 'everyone is welcome here?
igbo: Otu onye otu ha jụrụ ajụjụ ma 'a na-anabata mmadu niile ebe a?' nke o kwuru, sị 'ee'.

english: ' to which she simply said 'yes'.
igbo: Ọ gara soro anyị pụọ n'ọnụ ụzọ (ọzọ, kedu ntọala onye ọrụ ya hụrụ ndị ahịa ruo n'ọnụ ụzọ ahụ?) .

english: She then proceeded to accompanying us out the front door (again, what establishment has its manager see customers to the door?
igbo: Ka anyị na-apụ n'ụlọ ahụ, ahụrụ m onye nche ọ dịka ọ bụ onye Naịjirịa n'anya ya dị ka ụjọ ọna-atụ ya .

english: As we exited the building, I noticed the security guard (seemed like a Nigerian from his looks) looked jittery.
igbo: Apụghị m ịhapụ ya, n'ihi ya, m laghachịrị wee see foto n'ihu ụlọ ahụ .

english: I couldn't let it go, so I went back to take a photo in front of the building.
igbo: Kedu otu ọzọ anyị ga-esi gosi na anyị bịara iri spaghetti ịkpa oke?

english: How else would we prove we came to eat racist spaghetti?
igbo: Ọ bụrụ na onye nlekọta ahụ si na windo nkụwa ahụ na-ele anyị m kọwara na mbụ; ọ tụghị anya na anyị ga-alaghachi na mberede maka foto.

english: It turned out the manager was watching from the glass window I described earlier; she hadn't anticipated our abrupt return for a photo.
igbo: Ihe ndị ọzọ na-enyo enyo bụ onye na-eche nche, bụ onye tụrụ alo ka m jiri mgbidi nwere ụfọdụ ifuru see foto ahụ ka m ghara iguzo n'akụkụ ọnụ ụzọ nke nwere aha ntọala ahụ akpụrụ na ya.

english: More suspicious was the security guard, who suggested I use a wall with some flower pots for the photo as opposed to standing by the entrance which had the name of the establishment carved into it.
igbo: Na njedebe

english: From our findings, interaction with staff and management, we couln't help thinking that Shi Shi resturant is indeed racist, hence the security guard's inquiry about who we were looking for in a place listed as a public restaurant even on Google.
igbo: Site na nchoputa anyi, nmekorita nlekọta na ndị ọrụ, enweghị ike iche ihe ọzọ na-abụghị na ụlọ oriri Shi Shi bụ ihe agbụrụ, ya mere ajụjụ ndị nche banyere onye anyị choro bịa na ebe edepụtara dika ụlọ nri ọnọdụ ọbụla na Google .

english: There was also the issue of the staff recording a video of us, the policing while in the restaurant and the manager accompanying us out.
igbo: Enwekwara esemokwu nke ndị ọrụ na-esekọ ihe nkiri anyị, ọrụ uwe ojii mgbe anyị na-eri nri na onye njikwa anyị na-eso anyị pụọ .

english: Would they have done all that if we were Chinese?
igbo: Ha gaara eme ihe niile ma ọ bụrụ na anyị bụ ndị China?

english: In the restaurant's bid to gloss this over, it ended us awarding us an exaggerated reception.
igbo: N'agba nke ụlọ oriri ahụ iji mee ka e kpuchie omume ha, ha nyere anyị nnukwu nnabata .

english: Reps Order Repair Of Terminal Receiving Vehicles At Apapa Port
igbo: Nde nnọchị anya nyere iwu ndozi nke ebe a na-anata ụgbọ ala na ọdụ Apapa

english: The House instructed the Nigerian Ports Authority to immediately repair the quay wall of the facility and carry out a much needed infrastructural upgrade at the Tin Can port as well.
igbo: Ụlọ ahụ gwara ndị ọrụ ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri na Naịjirịa ka ha rụzie mgbidi mbibi nke ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ngwa ngwa ma rụọ nkwalite ihe owuwu dị ukwuu na ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

english: Daily Trust
igbo: Daily Trust

english: The House of Representatives has ordered the repair of the terminal at Apapa port complex in Lagos responsible for receiving vehicles legally imported into the country.
igbo: Ndị ụlọ omebe iwu nyere iwu ka arụzie ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n'ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri Apapa dị na Legos maka ịnata ụgbọ ala ebubatara n'ụzọ iwu.

english: The House instructed the Nigerian Ports Authority to immediately repair the quay wall of the facility and carry out a much needed infrastructural upgrade at the Tin Can port as well.
igbo: ụlọ ahụ gwara ndị ọrụ ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri na Naịjirịa ka ha rụzie mgbidi mbibi nke ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ngwa ngwa ma rụọ nkwalite ihe owuwu dị ukwuu na ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

english: Sponsor of the bill, Benjamin Bem, said the poor state of the facility was costing the country loses of N600bn annually.
igbo: Onye na-akwado ụgwọ ahụ, Benjamin Bem kwuru na steeti dara ogbenye n'ihi na ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-efu mba ijeri naịra 600 kwa afọ.

english: Bem said, 'The House is worried that the collapse of the quay wall (retaining wall) and the apron area of the terminal, which has the length of 438 meters, could lead to closure of the only terminal that receives vehicle cargos from across the world into Nigeria being closed and loss of huge revenue accruable to government and loss of jobs to many Nigerians.'
igbo: Bem kwuru, 'ụlọ ahụ na-echegbu onwe ya na ndakpọ nke mgbidi mbibi (na-ejigide mgbidi) yana mpaghara nke ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri, nke nwere ogologo mita 438, nwere ike iduga mmechi nke naanị otu ọdụ ụgbọ elu nke na-ewebata nnukwu ụgbọ ala site na mpaghara mba ụwa n'ime Naịjirịa na-emechi ga ebutere gọọmentị ihe efu nakwa enweghị ọrụ ndị Naịjirịa '

english: While noting that the actual operation of the terminals have been privatised, Bem observed that it remains the duty of the ports authority to build and upgrade the infrastructure.
igbo: Ka amatara na enyefere ọrụ nke ndị ọrụ ụgbọ mmiri ahụ n'aka ndị nkiti, Bem chọpụtara na ọ ka bụ ọrụ ndị ikike ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri iji wuo ma kwalite akụrụngwa ndị ahụ.

english: REVEALED: NFF 2nd VP Masterminded Backdoor Inclusion Of DSS DG's Son Into Nigeria's U-17 Squad To Stop Corruption Case Against Him
igbo: Achọpụtala: NFF osote onye isi nke abụọ turu alo azụ ụlọ iji tinye Nwa DSS DG banye out U-17 nke Naịjirịa iji kwụsị ikpe nrụrụ aka megide ya.

english: Sources have revealed how Second Vice President of the Nigeria Football Federation, Shehu Dikko, masterminded how Bichi's son was smuggled into the final team list submitted by coach Manu Garba to FIFA despite his name not being on the 50 players provisional list.
igbo: Isi mmalite ekpughere otu onye na-esote onye isi oche nke NFF nke Naịjirịa, Shehu Dikko, lebara anya n'ụzọ nwa nwanne Bichi si tinye n'ime ndepụta otu ikpeazụ nke onye nchịkwa Manu Garba nyefere FIFA na-agbanyeghị aha ya na-anọghị na ndepụta ndị egwuregwu 50.

english: As the inclusion of Abba Bichi, son of the Director-General of the Department of State Services, in Nigeria's squad for the Golden Eaglets U-17 team in the ongoing FIFA U-17 World Cup continues to generate buzz, more details have emerged how the inclusion of Bichi's son was facilitated.
igbo: Dika ntinye Abba Bichi, nwa onye isi nke Ngalaba Na-ahụ Maka Ndị Ọrụ, na ndị otu Naịjirịa maka ndị otu egwuregwu Golden Eaglets U-17 na FIFA U-17 na-aga n'ihu na -eweta nsogbu, nkọwa ndị ọzọ apụtawo banyere ntinye nke nwa nwoke Bichi.

english: Sources have revealed how Second Vice President of the Nigeria Football Federation, Shehu Dikko, masterminded how Bichi's son was smuggled into the final team list submitted by coach Manu Garba to FIFA despite his name not being on the 50 players provisional list.
igbo: Isi mmalite ekpughere otu onye na-esote onye isi oche nke NFF nke Naịjirịa, Shehu Dikko, lebara anya n'ụzọ nwa nwanne Bichi si sonye n'ime ndepụta otu ikpeazụ nke onye nchịkwa Manu Garba nyefere FIFA na-agbanyeghị na aha ya anọghị na ndepụta ndị egwuregwu 50.

english: SaharaReporters had published how top NFF officials coerced Garba into selecting Bichi and even threatened him if he does not give-in to the request.
igbo: Ndị ntọakụkọ Sahara bipụtala etu ndị isi NFF siri rụgide Garba ịhọrọ Bichi ma yie ya egwu ma ọ bụrụ na o nyeghị ya.

english: It was revealed that Garba had expressed doubt in the ability of the young lad to break into the team.
igbo: E kpughere na Garba kwupụtara obi abụọ banyere ikike nwata nwoke nwere ịbanye n'òtù ahụ.

english: How NFF Smuggled DSS Director General's Son, Abba Bichi, Into U-17 World Cup Team
igbo: Otu NFF si dufuo Onye isi DSS, Abba Bichi, n'ime ndi egwuregwu ịkọ mba ụwa U-17

english: Also, to accommodate Bichi's son into the team, Garba had to drop one of the regulars in his team.
igbo: Ọzọkwa, iji mee ka nwa Bichi sonye n'òtù ahụ, Garba hapụrụ otu n'ime ndị otu egwuregwu ya.

english: However, fresh facts have revealed that Dikko hatched and implemented the plan with the support of some NFF officials.
igbo: Kaosi di, eziokwu ohuru ekpughere bụ na Dikko choro ma mejupụta atụmatụ ya site na nkwado nke ụfọdụ ndị NFF.

english: Multiple sources disclosed to SaharaReporters that Dikko came through with the plan to seek favour on his corruption case with the Independent Corrupt Practices and other related Offences Commission and the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission.
igbo: Egosila ndị ntọakụkọ Sahara otutu ihe na Dikko sitere na atụmatụ a iji chọọ ihu ọma gbasara omume aka azụ ya na ebe ndị n'akpọchị ndị aka azụ, ndị iwu ndị ọzọ na ndị ọrụ na-ahu maka mkpafu akụ na ụba.

english: The ICPC is investigating Dikko and some other executives of the NFF for financial malpractices and diverting funds meant for the association.
igbo: Ndị ICPC na-enyocha Dikko na ụfọdụ ndị isi NFF maka mmejọ ego na ụzọ ichekwa ego echere maka ọgbakọ a

english: The ICPC in September obtained a court order to seal a house belonging to Dikko in Rivers State.
igbo: Ndị ICPC na Septemba nwetara ikike ụlọ ikpe iji mechie ụlọ nke Dikko na Rivers Steeti.

english: 'The inclusion of DSS boss' son was to get favour and goodwill.
igbo: Nsonye nke nwa onye isi DSS bụ iji nweta ihu ọma.

english: Dikko carried out the plan so that he and other NFF executives undergoing investigation by EFCC and ICPC would be free.
igbo: Dikko mere atụmatụ ahụ ka ya na ndị isi NFF ndị ọzọ na-eme nyocha nke EFCC na ICPC ga-enwere onwe ha.

english: 'This was perfectly planned out at a time NFF is under intense watch and investigation,' sources said.
igbo: A kpara nkata a nke ọma n'oge NFF nọ na nche na nyocha siri ike.' akọrọ na .

english: NFF President, Amaju Pinnick; First Vice President, Seyi Akinwunmi; Dikko; and another executive member, Yusuf 'Fresh', are all facing corruption case in a 17-count charge on misappropriation of $8.4m belonging to the football body.
igbo: onye isi ndị NFF, Amaju Pinnick; osote onye isi nke mbu, Seyi Akinwunmi; Dikko; na onye so n'otu ndị isi ọzọ, Yusuf ' ịdị saam', ha niile nwere ikpe maka aka azụ na ikpe ọnụọgụgụ17 banyere ịkpafu dọla nde 8.4 nke otu bọlu .

english: The NFF executive members had been ordered to appear in court on November 5 2019, which is the next adjourned date for the case.
igbo: Enyere ndị isi NFF iwu ịpụta n'ụlọ ikpe na Nọvemba 5, 2019 nke bụ ụbọchị enwelara ikpe ahụ.

english: Meanwhile, the NFF had claimed that Oduko was selected by the coach because of his understanding of the game and skills, countering claims that he was dropped for a fellow teammate.
igbo: Mana ndị NFF kwuru na ọ bụ onye nhazị ha họrọ Oduko maka otu o si aghọta egwuregwu a, na-ekwughasi okwu ekwuru na a hapuru ya maka onye otu ha ọzọ .

english: 'Bichi is a striker; Oduko is a left-back.
igbo: Bichi bụ onye straika; Oduko bụ onye ukwu ịpa azụ

english: Oduko was dropped for Charles Etim.
igbo: A hapuru Oduko maka Charles Etim .

english: Oduko was the player that lost the kick in the shootout with Guinea in the semifinals of the U17 AFCON in Tanzania, which condemned Eaglets to the third-place match,' said NFF media officer, Demola Olajire.
igbo: Oduko bụ onye ahụ gbajọrọ na asọmpị anyị na Guinea gbara na U17 AFCON na Tanzania, nke mere anyị ji gbaa ndị nke atọ' onye kwuru bụ onye ntọakụkọ nke NFF, Demola Olajire.

english: The Golden Eaglets had played two matches in the ongoing tournament but Bichi is yet to feature in the competition.
igbo: Ndị Golden Eaglets emeela egwuregwu abụọ n'asọmpị a na-aga n'ihu mana Bichi apụtaghị na asọmpị ahụ.

english: Rivers Police Explain Closure Of Port Harcourt-Aba Road Since March 9 Elections
igbo: Ndị uweojii Rivers na-akọwa Mmechi ụzọ Port Harcourt-Aba Road Kemgbe ntuli aka nke Mach 9

english: The action was meant to 'protect INEC office situated between Waterlines and GRA bus stops, its personnel and electoral materials in the office'.
igbo: Emere ihe a 'iji chekwaa ụlọ ọrụ INEC dị n'etiti ebe nkwụsị Waterlines na ụgbọ ala GRA , ndị ọrụ ya na ihe ntuli aka dị na ụlọ ọrụ'

english: The Police Command in Rivers State has said the continuous closure of the Port Harcourt-Aba road leading to the office of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) is in 'public interest'.
igbo: ndị uwe ojii na Rivers steeti ekwuola na mmechi na-aga n'ihu na Port Harcourt-Aba na-eduga n'ọfịs ndị na-ahụ maka ntụlị aka (INEC) bụ 'maka ọdịmma ọhaneze'.

english: DSP Nnamdi Omoni, spokesman of the Rivers Police Command appealed to the residents of Port Harcourt, the Rivers State capital, to show understanding and cooperation.
igbo: DSP Nnamdi Omoni, ọnụ na-ekwuru ndị uwe ojii Rivers rịọrọ ndị bi na Port Harcourt, isi obodo Rivers steeti, iji gosi nghọta na imekọ ihe ọnụ.

english: According to Omoni, the closure was not intended to cause hardship for the residents.
igbo: Dị ka Omoni si kwuo, ebughị n'obi iwetere ndị bi na ya ihe isi ike.

english: The Waterlines Bus-stop to GRA stop axis of the road has remained closed since the March 9, 2019 governorship and house of assembly polls.
igbo: Mpụga Waterlines ruo nkwụsị okporo ụzọ GRA ahụ ka emechiri kemgbe ọnwa 9 nke afọ 2019, ntuli aka nke gọvanọ na nke ụlọ ọgbakọ.

english: 'It is in the interest of Rivers; it is not intended to cause hardship for the residents.
igbo: 'Ọ bụ maka ọdịmma nke ndị Rivers; ebughị n'obi ịkpatara ndị bi na ya ihe isi ike .

english: The people should bear with the Command; it is only for a while,' he said, adding that the action was meant to 'protect INEC office situated between Waterlines and GRA bus stops, its personnel and electoral materials in the office'.
igbo: Ndi mmadu doo obi maka Iwu a; ọ bụ naanị nwa oge, 'ka o kwuru, na-agbakwunye na ihe a mere iji' chekwaa ụlọ ọrụ INEC nke dị n'etiti nkwụsị bọs nke Waterlines na GRA, ndị ọrụ ya na akụrụngwa ntuli aka '.

english: Rivers Women To Turn Up At INEC Office Naked — Unless Effanga Is Removed As REC
igbo: ụmụnwanyị Rivers ga-agbaọtọ ga na ụlọ ọrụ INEC - Ọ gwụla ma ewepụrụ Effanga dịka REC

english: The women threatened that if in the next 48 hours, Professor Mahmood Yakubu, the National Chairman of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), fails to heed to their demand, they would storm INEC's Port Harcourt head office naked.
igbo: ụmụ nwaanyị ahụ yiri egwu na ọ bụrụ na n'ime awa 48 na-abịa, ọkamụta Mahmood Yakubu, Onye isi oche nke ụlọ ọrụ na-ahụ maka ntuli aka (INEC) jụrụ ịnabata arịrịọ ha, ha ga-agbaọtọ gaa n'isi ụlọ ọrụ INEC nke Port Harcourt.

english: Thousands of women have taken to the streets of Port Harcourt, the Rivers State capital, to demand the immediate redeployment of the Obo Effanga, Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC).
igbo: Ọtụtụ puku ndị nwaanyị agbaala n'okporo ụzọ Port Harcourt, isi obodo Rivers Steeti iji chọọ nchụpụ Obo Effanga, dịka REC.

english: The protesters, dressed in black and drawn from the 23 local government areas of the state, said his continued stay in the state was breeding tension and possible breakdown of law and order.
igbo: Ndị ngagharị iwe a, yi uwe ojii na ndị si mpaghara iri abụọ na atọ nke steeti ahụ wee sị na ọnụnọ ya na steeti ahụ bụ esemokwu na nsogbu ga - agbasa nke iwu na usoro ya.

english: Carrying placards with various inscriptions, the women threatened that if in the next 48 hours, Professor Mahmood Yakubu, the National Chairman of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), fails to heed to their demand, they would storm INEC's Port Harcourt head office naked.
igbo: Na-eburu kaadị e dere ihe dị iche iche, ụmụ nwanyị ahụ kwuru na ọ bụrụ na n'ime awa iri anọ na asatọ na-abịanụ, Prọfesọ Mahmood Yakubu, Onye isi oche nke ụlọ ọrụ na-ahụ maka ntuli aka (INEC) añaghị ntị na arịrịọ ha, ha ga-agbaọtọ gaa n'isi ụlọ ọrụ INEC dị na Port Harcourt .

english: Protests for and against the INEC REC have intensified in Rivers State in the last three days, with pro-government demonstrators asking that Effanga be retained in the state, whereas the anti-Effanga protesters want his removal, accusing him of compromising the outcome of the March 9 governorship and state house of assembly elections in the state to favour Nyesom Wike, incumbent Governor of Rivers State.
igbo: Ngagharị iwe nke megide INEC REC agbaliela na Rivers steeti n'ime ụbọchị atọ gara aga, ndị na-eme ngagharị iwe gọọmentị na-arịọ ka edobe Effanga na steeti ahụ, ebe ndị na-emegide Effanga na-achọ ka ewepu ya, na-ebo ya ebubo imebi ihe ga-esi na ya nhọpụta ndị isi ọchịchị n'abalị iri-iteghete nke ọnwa nke isii na steeti iji kwado Nyesom Wike, onye ọchịchị gọvanọ nke Gọọmenti Rivers steeti.

english: The women are not alone in the call for the removal of Effanga, as some governorship candidates have joined the call.
igbo: Ọ bụghị naanị ụmụ nwaanyị nọ n'ọkwa maka mkpochapu Effanga, ụfọdụ ndị na-azọ ọkwa gọvanọ esonyela oku a.

english: In a recent article he wrote and circulated, Tonye Cole, the governorship candidate of the All Progressives Congress (APC), said only the redeployment of Effanga would guarantee conducive atmosphere for free and fair elections in Rivers State.
igbo: N'edemede ya na-adịbeghị anya o dere ma kesaa, Tonye Cole, onye na-azọ ọkwa gọvanọ nke APC, kwuru na nanị nhapụ nke Effanga ga-eme ka enwee ntuli aka ziri ezi na Rivers Steeti.

english: He called for the outright cancellation of the polls, just as he re-echoed earlier calls by Dumo Lulu-Briggs, the Accord Party candidate, who had described the entire exercise as a 'charade', and Victor Fingesi of the Action Democratic Party (ADP), who said INEC planned the polls to fail.
igbo: Ọ kpọrọ oku ka akagbuo votu ahụ kpamkpam, dị ka ọ kpọghachiri oku Dumo Lulu-Briggs na ntuli aka ndị otu Accord, onye kọwapụtara mmemme ahụ niile dịka 'ọgbahara', yana Victor Fingesi nke ADP, onye kwuru na INEC mere atụmatụ ịtụ vootu ga-akụ afọ n'ala.

english: Ruiz Asks Anthony Joshua For Third Fight After Nigerian Reclaims Heavyweight Titles
igbo: Ruiz na-arịọ Anthony Joshua Maka ọgụ nke atọ mgbe ndị Naịjirịa welatara ịkọ mmeri

english: It was a masterful performance from AJ in Saudi Arabia; the Nigerian-born British boxer schooled Ruiz from range and never allowed the Mexican-American to close the gap.
igbo: Ọ bụ ọmarịcha arụmọrụ sitere na AJ na Saudi Arabia; onye Naịjirịa na-akụ ọkpọ amụrụ na Britain kụchara Ruiz, nye ya nnukwu oke ma ghara ikwe ka onye Mexican-American ahụ mechie oghere ahụ.

english: Anthony Joshua on Saturday night comprehensively defeated Andy Ruiz Jr 118-110, 118-110, 119-109 in their rematch to regain his IBF, IBO, WBO and WBA (super) heavyweight titles.
igbo: Anthony Joshua n'abali Satọde jiri nke ọma merie Andy Ruiz Jr 118-110, 118-110, 119-109 na nhazigharị ha iji nwetaghachi aha IBF, IBO, WBO na WBA (ike) ike mmeri.

english: It was a masterful performance from AJ in Saudi Arabia; the Nigerian-born British boxer schooled Ruiz from range and never allowed the Mexican-American to close the gap.
igbo: Ọ bụ ọmarịcha arụmọrụ sitere na AJ na Saudi Arabia; onye Naịjirịa na-akụ ọkpọ a mụrụ na Britain kụchara Ruiz nye ya nnukwu oke ma ghara ikwe ka onye Mexican-America ahụ mechie oghere ahụ.

english: Joshua jabbed Ruiz Jr to death and he never gave the champion a chance to get inside and land the nasty hooks that led to AJ's demise the first time around.
igbo: Joshua tiri Ruiz Jr ọnwụ ma ọ dịghị mgbe ọ nyere onye mmeri ohere ịbanye n'ime ma webata nko ahụ jọgburu onwe ya nke mere ka mbibi AJ na adaa nke mbụ.

english: After the fight, both men showed their respect for one another and embraced before they did their post-fight interviews, according to talksport.com
igbo: Mgbe ọgụ ahụ gachara, ụmụ nwoke abụọ ahụ kwanyeere ibe ha ugwu ma nabata tupu ha agbaa ajụjụ ọnụ mgbe ha na-ebuso agha, dịka talksport.com si kwuo.

english: When Joshua asked Ruiz if he wanted to retire following calls for AJ to do the same after he lost in New York, Ruiz answered that he wanted a third fight.
igbo: Mgbe Joshua jụrụ Ruiz ma ọ chọrọ ịla ezumike nká na-esochi oku maka AJ ime otu ihe ahụ mgbe ọ nwụsịrị na New York, Ruiz zara na ọ chọrọ ịlụ ọgụ nke atọ.

english: Grabbing the mic, he said, 'I want the third fight.'
igbo: ọ naara igwe okwu n'ike, si 'achọrọm ọgụ nke atọ'.

english: He then asked the crowd, 'Who wants to see the third fight?
igbo: ọ jụrụ ndị gbakọrọ, 'Kedu onye chọrọ ihu ọgụ nke atọ?'.

english: In fact, Ruiz Jr asked the Saudi Arabia crowd several times if they would like to see a third fight between the two men and he seemed to want to do it in Saudi again, too.
igbo: N'ezie, Ruiz Jr jụrụ igwe mmadụ Saudi Arabia ọtụtụ oge ma ha ga-achọ ịhụ ọgụ nke atọ n'etiti mmadụ abụọ ahụ na o yiri ka ọ chọrọ ime ya na Saudi ọzọ.

english: Joshua suggested he was well up for it too, declaring, 'If you've heard, we're gonna do a third.'
igbo: Joshua tụrụ alo ka ya nọrọ nke ọma, na-ekwupụta, 'Ọ bụrụ na ị nụrụ, anyị ga-eme nke atọ.'

english: Ruiz was outclassed on the night and he admits he went into the rematch too heavy, having tipped the scales at more than 20 stone on Friday.
igbo: N'abalị agbapụrụ Ruiz ọ ma kweta na ọ banyere ọgụ ahụ n'oke arụ ahu, na o tinyere ihe karịrị akpịrịkpa ahụ ihe karịrị okwute iri abụọ na Fraịde.

english: He said, 'It was his night.
igbo: O kwuru 'ọ bụ abalị ya .

english: I didn't prepare how I should have.
igbo: A kwadoghịm kam si kwesi'

english: 'I gained too much weight.
igbo: Eburu m ibu nke ukwuu .

english: I don't want to give excuses, he won.
igbo: Achọghị m ịnye ngọpụ, ọ meriri .

english: He boxed me around.
igbo: Ọ kụrụ m ihe tinka kuru pan.

english: 'If we do a third fight, I'm going to get in shape.
igbo: 'Ọ bụrụ na anyị na-agba ọgụ nke atọ, aga m enwe ọdịdị .

english: I'll be in the best shape of my life.
igbo: Aga m anọ n'ụdị kachasị mma nke ndụ m.

english: 'I thought I was going to feel stronger.
igbo: Echere m na m ga-enwe ahụ ike .

english: Next fight I'm going to get more prepared.
igbo: M na-esote ọgụ m ga-akwadokwu .

english: I tried to train myself for this.
igbo: Agbalịrị m ịzụ onwe m maka nke a.

english: I was chasing him too much.
igbo: Anọ m na-achụ ya nke ukwuu .

english: I was hesitating too much.
igbo: Anọ m na-egbu oge nke ukwuu .

english: Russia Gets Four Year Ban From All Global Sporting Events Over Doping
igbo: Russia na-enweta mmachi afọ anọ na mmemme egwuregwu ụwa niile maka nruruaka .

english: It means the Russia will not be allowed at events such as the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics and the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar.
igbo: Ọ pụtara na a gaghị anabata Russia na ihe omume dịka Tokyo 2020 Olympics na Paralympics na 2022 na asọmpị mba ụwa FIFA na Qatar.

english: Russia has been handed a four-year ban from all major sporting events by the World Anti-Doping Agency.
